1321111122112.content:
"I believe I enjoy your company as well," Princess Kela said still pouting a bit. "Though I do get the impression you are teasing me."

"My, should I take that as you like being teased?" Princess Fia replied with a giggle. "I assure you, I have been perfectly sincere. Though perhaps I have had a bit of fun as well. Your arrival has been the most stimulating occurrence in quite some time, after all."

"I do not," Kela insisted. "However, I cannot blame you either. Had our positions been reversed I am not certain I would not have done the same."

"Then perhaps I should visit Grovan while transformed into a man before our wedding," Princess Fia replied. "Do you believe the name Prince Fiat would suit me?"

"It sounds more fitting for a maker of carriages," Princess Kela replied. "Perhaps Prince Fiaj? It sounds rather exotic, don't you agree?"

"I suppose it does at that, though I am unsure it suits me," Princess Fia replied.

The door opened and the maid walked in carrying a tray with a tea pot and two cups, all made of fine porcelain. "I have returned with your tea," she said, carrying it over to the table.

"My, what impeccable timing," Princess Fia said as she sat down, motioning for Princess Kela to do the same. "Princess Kela and I were discussing a matter of great urgency, perhaps you could give your opinion?"

"I am not sure I would use the words great urgency to describe it," Princess Kela commented as she sat down as well.

"Oh but it is indeed," Princess Fia countered.

"I'm not sure what I could add, but I would be glad to give my opinion if you think it would help," the maid said as she poured the tea.

"Wonderful! Princess Kela and I were discussing what name I should go by in the event I were transformed into a man," Princess Fia explained "I believe Prince Fiat would be suitable, yet Princess Kela would prefer Prince Fiaj. While I'm sure Princess Kela quite skilled at this subject, I am unwilling to concede the matter so easily."

Kela blushed and looked away.

The maid finished pouring the tea and placed the pot down on the tray. "I can't imagine you as a man, princess. You're far too beautiful a woman," the maid replied. "Though between the two, I I like Prince Fiaj better. It sounds like the name of a prince from a far off land who has come to sweep the princess off her feet." The maid looked off in the distance with a starry eyed gaze.

Kela smiled slightly at her victory in this matter.

"A shame, it looks like I must concede after all," Princess Fia said with a twinge of regret. "Oh, but what of Princess Kela? I think Prince Kelas would suit her in such an event."

Kela froze at the princess' words.

"I suppose it is not bad, but would it not be confused with her brother Prince Kelos? Their names are already rather close," The maid explained.

Princess Kela sighed with relief that she wasn't exposed after all.

"Although I must confess I cannot see Princess Kela as a man either. She's also far too beautiful," the maid added. "Will there be anything else?"

"No, that will be all for now, you may go," Princess Fia said.

"Very well Princess," the maid said. She promptly left the room.

"I know the maid was simply paying me a compliment, but I don't like the thought of not being seen as a man," Princess Kela said.

"I suppose not," Princess Fia replied. "Still you can hardly expect otherwise. I can assure you, she was entirely sincere in her comment on your beauty." She took a sip of tea.

"Perhaps. I'll merely have to make her swoon for me in my male form," Princess Kela said. She picked up a brown macaron and bit into it.

"My, but you are certainly taking this in stride, Princess Kela," Princess Fia replied.

"I can deal with this for a week," Kela said. "After all, it's my own fault. Though you really seem to be fond of addressing me as 'Princess Kela.'"

"Because it is such a wonderful name," Princess Fia replied. "Try introducing yourself with it. Say, 'Good day, I am Princess Kela of Grovan. Charmed to make your acquaintance.'"

"Good day, I am Princess Kela of Grovan. Charmed to make your acquaintance," Kela repeated. "It still sounds strange."

"Well you have been Prince Kelos all of your life, so it is understandable," Princess Fia said. "Anyway, after tea I have an art lesson. I do so enjoy painting. Would you be willing to sit as a model for me, Princess Kela?"
1321111122112.title: Tell her you enjoy her company too.

choices: Go freshen up as Princess Fia suggested.
Visit that blasted scribe first.
13211111221121.content:
"I'd love too," Princess Kela said. She took a sip of tea.

"Oh, how surprising," Princess Fia said. "I must confess, I expected you to decline. After all, it would result in a painting of you in your present condition." She gracefully nibbled on a pink macaron.

"I... I hadn't considered that," Kela replied. "All I could think of was spending more time with you. It must be the spell!" A feeling of dread came over her.

"I do not believe so," Princess Fia stated. She paused to take a tip of tea. "I would venture that you are in fact afflicted with a second spell, Princess Kela."

"Another spell?! When could it have happened?" Kela asked.

Princess Fia giggled softly. "I would say it has been since you attended the wedding of a certain duke and duchess several years ago." She stood up and approached Kela, bending forward slightly. "Is your heart rate not increasing?" She placed her right hand on Kela's chest, causing both of them to blush. "I'm afraid this is one of the symptoms. I appear to have been afflicted by it as well." Her left hand guided Kela's right hand to her chest. "See my heart rate has also increased. The name of this spell is..."

"Love?" Princess Kela interrupted, blushing even harder.

"Correct." Princess Fia said softly. She leaned in and kissed Kela, who reciprocated.

"I-Is this ok?" Kela asked. "After all, I'm not a man now."

"By law in this kingdom, you are as you were born, Princess Kela" Princess Fia replied. "It is why my father had not transformed me when I was but a child. As I was born female, I cannot inherit the throne even if he did so. Thus, you are by law male even if your form has been changed. Though I do not expect my father to recognize you as such. The royal magistrate, however, will. Provided you are able to supply evidence of your transformation."

"I do not believe that will be a problem," Princess Kela said.

Princess Fia leaned in for another kiss. However, they were interrupted by a knock on the door. "It this late already? I suppose we shall need finish this later," she said standing up. "This is a good chance to introduce yourself properly, Princess Kela." Fia turned to the door and called out. "You may enter."

"Tut, tut, such delay, your grace," an older bald man wearing a paint smeared smock said as he entered the room. His remaining hair was graying, and her was slightly overweight. He followed by two maids, one carrying an easel and some canvases, the other carrying a large tarp. The two of them began to set up the equipment. "Oh!" he said with a start. "It appears you have a visitor." He walked over to Kela. "I am Raefardo, court artisan," he said.

"I am Princess Kela of Grovan," Kela said. She held out her right hand in a feminine manner as she had observed her sister do in the past.

Raefardo kissed the back of Kela's hand. "Always a pleasure to meet such a charming rose."

"Princess Kela shall be sitting as my model while she is in Traeven," Princess Fia said.

"Is it not merely tonight?" Kela asked.

"Why not at all. Tonight I shall merely sketch you," Princess Fia replied. "Then shall be the details over the next few sessions. Once the sketch is complete, I shall begin the actual painting. I regret I may be unable to complete this before your return. However, your visage shall remain with me, enabling me to complete this work even if you must depart, Princess Kela."

"I had no idea painting was so involved," Kela said in amazement.

"Indeed, your grace," Raefardo said. "Princess Fia takes it very seriously and puts in the effort of a master artisan.

"I am but an amateur," Princess Fia insisted. "Now then, Princess Kela, would you be so good as to disrobe?"

"Of cou... Wait, I certainly did not agree to that!" Kela stated emphatically, blushing intensely.

"I am joking, naturally," Princess Fia replied with a giggle. "I do have a pose in mind, however. Would you stand for a moment, Princess Kela?" She reached out her arm to Kela as Kela herself had done to many a lady as Kelos.

"Of course," Kela said, as she took Princess Fai's hand. She thought for a moment how strange it was to be on the receiving end of such a gesture as Fia helped her stand.

"Now please sit on my bed," Princess Fia instructed, which Kela obeyed. Fia then picked up a book and handed it to Kela. "Open this about half way and hold it as if you're reading." Kela once again obeyed. Fia then guided Kela into exactly the position she had in mind. "There. Will you be able to hold this pose while I sketch?"

"I think so," Kela replied. "I am curious why you decided on this though?"

"I believed reading would suit you, Princess Kela," Princess Fia explained. "Now then, I shall be sketching. I apologize, but please don't talk if you can avoid it, and above all, do not move without first notifying me."

For the next hour Kela held the pose as best she could, while Princess Fia used charcoal pencil to put her image on canvas, with Raefardo giving her tips and pointing out mistakes. With little else to do except sit there as time passed, Kela read the pages she had opened too.

"I believe I have finished for the evening," Princess Fia stated.

"Of course, your grace," Raefardo said. "An excellent beginning to your work."

Kela stretched, a bit stiff after posing for so long. "May I see it?" she asked.

"It is but an unfinished sketch. I would think you prefer to see the finished work, but if you insist, you may, Princess Kela," Princess Fia said.

Kela stood up and walked over to the canvas and the sketch of her gracefully sitting with a book in hand. The bed and walls were just quickly drawn lines, but Kela herself was well outlined, her already face highly detailed. "This is very good," She said.

"I would say it's shaping up to be her grace's best work yet," Raefardo added.

"Please, it is merely a child's scribbles compared to your own masterpieces," Princess Fia said. "I would propose this is more the beauty of the model than the talent of the artist." She looked over to Kela, who blushed in response.

"That may also play a role," Raefardo said. "Though do not sell your talent short, your grace. You're my prize pupil. Anyway, I bid you farewell until tomorrow." The maids began to clean up after the art session as he left.

"I do apologize, but I must freshen up I would advise you to do the same, Princess Kela," Princess Fia said. "Afterwards, would you care to dine with me tonight?"

"Of course, Princess," Kela replied.

"Very well, a maid will show you to your room," Princess Fia said. "But first I have something I wish to give you." She grasped Kela's hands, then waited until the maids were gone. She then leaned forward and kissed Kela deeply. After a few moments, the two of them separated. "Until dinner then, Princess Kela?"

"Until then," Kela replied. She then left the room.

132111112211212.content:
Princess Kela wandered the hall outside Princess Fia's room along for a few moments. She signed as the clicking of her heels on the marble floors provided a constant reminder of her situation. Trapped in this painfully feminine body for a week was certainly not part of the plan. Still, things could be worse. After all, though it was a failure on her part to maintain her hasty cover, she was at least recognized as royalty now. To think she could have been forced to serve as a maid or worse. At least the marry Princess Fia part seemed to be going well. Perhaps too well. Kela stopped in front of a mirror and looked at her reflection. A beautiful woman looked back at her. "She's right, I would look lovely in a bridal gown," Kela said out loud and she placed her hand on the mirror. That was perhaps the worst part. Despite all the humiliation she should be feeling, she didn't even mind. The sound of hurried footsteps coming towards her broke her thoughts. She turned and say the maid who had served the tea and macarons earlier rushing towards her.

"I'm so sorry, princess!" the maid called out as she approached. "I should have come sooner."

"That's quite alright," Kela replied. "I was taking the chance to collect my thoughts."

"Of course, Princess," the maid said.. "Shall I show you to your room so you may freshen up?"

"Yes, please. Though first I would like to visit the scribe who had accompanied me," Kela said.

"Certainly. Right this way," The maid gestured for Kela to follow her.

"What might your name be?" Kela asked as she followed.

"Elista, Princess," she replied. "But you don't have to trouble yourself to remember it."

"It is hardly any trouble to remember a single name, Elista," Kela said.

"I am honored, Princess," Elista said. The two of them continued to make small talk as they navigated the corridors of the castle. Before long they reached the scribe's room. "Here we are, Princess," she said.

"Thank you, Elista. Would you mind waiting outside? I shall not be long"

"Of course, Princess."

Kela knocked on the door. "I'm coming in," she stated, opening the door and barging through.

"Oh, perfect timing, your highness. I have just finished sending a message to your mother, updating our progress. I must say, you certainly look beautiful in that dress. I'm sure Queen Esmeralda and Princess Orianna would be delighted to see you finally dressing as a proper lady," he said with a subtly mocking tone.

Kela clenched her fist ready to strike the scribe. How dare he inform them! No doubt the court was already talking about this. However, in her haste, she had forgotten to close the door. She turned her head slightly, and saw Elista peaking her head through. She breathed deeply and relaxed her fist. This was not the time to strike. His punishment would wait. "I'm sure they would, however, I plan to return home wearing my usual attire," Kela said, glaring at the scribe.

"Oh of course. Though shall I have it tailored to better show off your figure?" The scribe asked, smirking.

1321111122112122.content:
"That won't be necessary," Kela replied. Clearly the scribe was trying to provoke her to action. There must be some reason for it. Kela once again held her wrath. "I do not believe I care for your tone either, scribe. Before the King earlier you introduced me as a servant girl as well. Your impudence will have consequences."

"You were able to meet Princess Fia that way, so it all worked out," The scribe insisted. "Besides, you're the one who made it necessary, Princess. Had you not wanted to conceal your identity, this wouldn't have happened. Though I've heard Princess Fia saw through you almost immediately."

Kela glared at the scribe. This was not a conversation she wished to have in front of others. "That is what I have come to talk to you about. Princess Fia is a far more stimulating and capable woman than I expected. She and I have taken to each other surprisingly quickly. I believe she would be open to the prospects of marriage between our kingdoms. You will relay that to mother."

"Wait, seriously?" the scribe replied in astonishment. "And here I thought this entire thing was a waste of time."

"You were incorrect," Kela said. "As expected of you. Now would you send that message home?"

"I would, but I'm afraid my messenger spell can only be used 5 times a day," the scribe said. "You'll have to wait until tomorrow. Or dispatch a courier. Or see if Traeven has someone who could send it for you."

"Right, so you used one to send your previous report, you should have four remaining uses," Kela responded. She crossed her arms and glared.

"Normally, yes, but I sent a message to my wife too. And my parents. And my brother. And..."

"Enough!" Kela interrupted, furious. "You used your messenger spell for personal letters while on a diplomatic assignment?!"

"Kind of," the scribe admitted.

"I am not sure if you're simply an idiot, or deliberately trying to undermine me," Kela replied.

"It was important," the scribe insisted. "I had to tell them I arrived safely. They worry, you know. Accidents can happen along the way."

Kela glared again. "I am tired of dealing with you. You will send my message first thing in the morning, or else. Further you will refrain from any unauthorized personal messages."

"Of course, your highness," the scribe said. "Oh!" A scroll popped into the scribe's hands. He looked down at it. "A message from your sister." The scribe handed it to Kela.

"This is just a message, correct? It will not be a repeat of earlier, will it?" Kela asked.

"Well, it was sent by spell, so it should be safe," the scribe said. "Master Xarlet could probably send a magical scroll, but I doubt he'd bother."

Kela looked at the scroll in her hand.
1321111122112122.title: You're being watched, keep your cool.

choices: Forgive her, she didn't mean any harm.
Chastize her, she is a servant and should know her place.
13211111221121221.content:
"I'm sure it's fine," Princess Kela said. "It's silly to be afraid of a scroll after all." She gulped, then closed her eyes and quickly opened the scroll. Feeling nothing amiss, she looked herself over just in case. "See, nothing." She then read the message.

                             Dearest brother Kelos;

Oh, excuse me, of course I mean dearest sister. Word of your accident is all over the palace. Mother was rather amused. I think perhaps she would have preferred another daughter over a son. Father was livid, however. Really, I had thought you would be more careful around magical artifacts. Did you forget that time you feed my prized dressage horse magical chicken feed? I certainly have not. Suddenly finding a giant chicken in your stable on the morning of the kingdom's largest equestrian competition is not an experience I wish to repeat. There are still some who impudent fools who dare call me the featherbrained princess behind my back.

But I digress. Mother and Father wished to recall you immediately, but I convinced them to give you a chance. I wanted to spare you the humiliation of returning home both a failure in your mission and a woman. Despite of what you have done in the past, I'm still looking out for you. Though it is a sight I am unwilling to miss. Which brings me to the reason for this message. I am leaving for Traeven in the morning. I expect to arrive in 4 days time. I have handled all the arrangements via message so you don't have a thing to worry about beyond looking your prettiest for my arrival. I am so looking forward to seeing my dear sister in attire fitting for a princess. It may be a selfish request, but I have always been found of lavender and would love it if you were wearing such a gown when I arrive. Perhaps with white lace?

I should not need to remind you after the events of the day, but do be careful around magic. After all, I would hate to think what would happen if your transformation were permanent. Though I am told under Traeven law it will not effect your status, our own may lead to some issues regarding succession to the throne. Still, I doubt Princess Fia will be eager to marry another woman, even if you were considered a man by law. Perhaps she would allow you to serve as her maid. I was told that almost happened. If you were unable to change back, I suppose I would have no option but to do my duty and take the throne for myself. Father would be displeased, but I think mother would be happy. I think my first act will be to change the rules of succession. I see no reason why an elder sister should be second in line behind her younger brother. Do you not agree, sister?

                                                                                         Sinc erely;
                                                                                         {ind ent}Your beloved sister Orianna


"Her dressage chicken was not my fault! How was I supposed to know that's what they meant by 'this feed shall only be consumed by chickens.' Besides, she still won. The rules didn't ban chickens after all," Kela insisted. She heard a giggle from the hallway. Turning, she saw Elista, who promptly attempted to pretend she was not listening.

"I remember that," the scribe said. "So that was your doing? It started a bit of a fad for a time."

Kela turned back to the scribe. "I thought it would just make her horse cluck or something. Besides, she started it when she turned my fox hounds into actual foxes! They chased each other off. I was never able to find three of them. I hope they lived well as foxes... Anyway, the important thing is she's coming here!"

"I suppose she misses her little sister," the scribe replied.

"She wants me to wear a lavender dress... There's still a few days left, so I'll worry about that when she gets here. For now I need to prepare for my dinner with Princess Fia." Kela turned and walked out of the room, then looked at Elista. "Please show me to my room."

"Of course, Princess," the maid replied. "This way." She led Kela to her room.

Kela sighed. "I suppose you overheard what was being said."

"I'm sorry, princess. I know I shouldn't have," Elista said.

"No, I suppose you all have your orders to keep watch on us," Kela said.

"It's not that," Elista insisted. "It's just... I thought you'd be really mean, but you've been nice to me all this time. I... I wanted to learn more about you, so I listened in. I'm sorry!"
13211111221121221.title: Open it. It could be important.

choices: Kela challenges Dioral to become a woman and dual.
Fia becomes a man to dual Dioral.
132111112211212211.content:
Kela was taken back by the maid's words. After all, nice was not a word she would have used to describe herself. Even now her plans were the same, add Traeven to Grovan's growing empire. Marriage to Princess Fia was the easiest way, but conquest would be fine too. Already the guards that had accompanied her were likely transformed and probing the castle for weaknesses to be exploited. Yet here was this maid calling her nice. "Well, if she already sees me this way, I might as well go with it. She may prove a valuable informant," Kela thought to herself. "Think nothing of it. There was no privileged information discussed. Though it may be unwise for you to continue to eavesdrop on private conversations. One day you may overhear something that will get you in trouble." Kela patted Elista on the head.

"R-Right!" the maid replied, slightly flustered. "If you don't mind, princess, can I ask one thing? Dressage chicken?"

Kela giggled then immediately stopped herself. "You know of dressage horses, do you not?" The maid nodded. "My sister is quite renowned in Grovan for her dressage skills. The royal stables also breed the finest competition horses. Naturally, she was favored to win. I may have quite accidentally given my sister's prized horse Anne magical feed which turned her into a horse sized chicken." Kela held back laughing. "Still it is a testament to my sister's skills and the quality of Anne's breeding and training that my sister was still able to claim victory. It was quite a sight to behold. An actual dressage chicken event using similarly transformed horses was organized, but it did not go well. It seems chickens do not make disciplined mounts regardless of their stature."

Elista broke out laughing. "Ahahaha I'm sorry princess, but that's too much! Ahahaha"

"My sister was not quite as amused," Kela replied. "I don't believe she has ever lived that down."

"What about your sister's horse though? Is she still a chicken?" Elista asked.

"The very next day," Kela explained. "She has since been breed. Two of her foals have become prized dressage horses as well."

The maid gave a sigh of relief. "That's good. I was afraid she'd have become a meal."

"That would never have happened, even if her horse couldn't change back," Kela said. "Grovan has long prided itself on its fine horses and calvary. To do such would be considered an insult to the kingdom's honor. In fact all nobles are expected to be accomplished riders of some sort. I was quite an avid fox hunter until my sister transformed my hounds. After that, I could not help but think the fox being hunted was one of the three I couldn't find to change back. After those incidents we were forbidden to as much as speak to Xarlet, Grovan's magician, without permission. Our parents feared escala...."

Kela stopped as she heard heavy footsteps approaching the two of them. The sound of clanging metal reverberated with each step. The sound drew closer, until a man in full plate armor, trimmed with gold accents and polished to near mirror shine. He carried a helmet under his arm. Long, flowing locks of blond hair reached down to his shoulders, framing his rugged face. "What luck, I had heard there was a lovely new flower in the castle. I am Captain Dioral, quite pleased to make your acquaintance." He bowed.

"I am Princess Kela of Grovan," Kela replied. She gave a quick curtsy, as best as she could.

"To think such a dense thicket of thorns could produce a rose of such beauty," Dioral said, while looking at Kela's chest. He took her hand, leaned down and kissed it. "Though I had thought Grovan had but Princess Orianna and Prince Kelos." His eyes darted right for a moment, then came right back to center. He then flashed a knowing grin.

"I am Prince Kelos' twin sister," Kela stated. She attempted to pull her hand back, but Dioral held firm.

"Let go of her!" Elista shouted as she intervened, quickly prying Kela's hand out of the captain's grip. The two looked at the maid in shock.

"Insolent servant, what is the meaning of this!" Dioral shouted after recovering from his shock.

"I- uhh I was... I mean" Elista stammered, more shocked by her actions than anyone.

"I will see to it that you will spend the rest of your days cleaning the stables for this!" Dioral fumed.

"Enough!" Kela yelled stepping in front of the maid. "You are the insolent one here! She saw you were clearly hurting me and moved to protect me. You will apologize to the both of us!" She glared at the towering man in front of her.

Dioral smirked and grabbed Kela's shoulder, pushing her against the wall. "A feisty one, aren't you? I like that in a woman."

"Unhand me, brute! I am a Prince of Grovan and a guest of Princess Fia!" Kela screamed.

"Let go of Princess Kela!" Elista shouted, grabbing the knight's arm. Dioral shoved her with his shoulder, sending the maid flying to the ground.

"You animal!" Kela shouted. She punched Dioral with her free hand square in the jaw, knocking his head to the side. He quickly recovered and grabbed her arm to prevent another blow.

"You pack quite a punch for a dainty bud," Dioral said, moving his jaw from side to side. "It seems you have thorns after all. But I suppose my suspicions about you have been proved correct, Prince Kelos. I must say though, I do prefer your current form." He grinned menacingly. "How does it feel, Prince? To be in that weak, frail body, unable to fight back. Unable to protect that girl. Unable to protect yourself." A chill ran through Kela as Dioral leaned in and kissed her. "Tell me, shall I show you how it really feels to be a woman?"

Kela said nothing and spit in his face.

"I suppose I shall leave it here for today," Dioral said. "Do not worry that pretty little head of yours, I'll forgive your little maid friend too." He shoved Kela aside, though she managed to stay on her feet. The armored figure turned and walked away chuckling."

Kela rushed to the fallen maid's side. "Elista! Elistia!" she called out, trying to rouse her.

"Mmmnnn... Princess Kela..." the maid said clutching her head. "Why am I... OH!" Elista immediately sat up. "Princess! Are you alright? Did he hurt you?"

"No, nothing serious," Kela said. She looked to the side. "That overgrown ape! How dare he! I'll make him pay for this outrage!" she thought to herself.

"It's my fault, princess. If I hadn't jumped in like that..." the maid said apologetically.

"No, you did nothing wrong. He's the one who decided to act like a savage," Kela said.

"I suppose, but... OH!" Elista stood up suddenly. "Your dinner with the princess! You need to get ready!" She quickly led Kela to her room and helped her prepare.

"My, I was beginning to wonder if I had been stood up as the commoners call it," Princess Fia said, as Kela arrived slightly late. She looked at the silk emerald green gown Kela was wearing. "But I suppose you had trouble picking out your gown. I must say you chose well, Princess Kela. It compliments your hair nicely. You look very beautiful."

"Thank you, but I let Elista pick it out," Kela replied. "Gown selection was not the reason I'm late." She recounted the events since their parting.

"That brute!" Princess Fia exclaimed. This was the first time Kela had actually seen her angry. "To think he wold assault my bride knowing full well who she is!" Fia breathed in and then exhaled. "I should have him in irons! However, he has my father's ear, so it is not possible to punish him unless my father permits it. I do not intend to let him get away with this transgression!"

"Nor will I!" Kela replied. "I will never forgive him for this humiliation! If I were still a man I would challenge him to a dual!"

"A dual of honor? I'm sure my father would approve," Princess Fia stated. "Perhaps you could simply wait until you return to your normal form, princess Kela?"

"If there are no other options, but I'd rather not wait," Kela said. "He may try something else."

"I dislike suggesting this, but would it not be possible to return to a man sooner? I'm positive our court magician, Marlin could make you a potion," Princess Fia said.

"I've been told mixing magic can have unpredictable effects," Kela said. "I would rather not risk it. Although you may be on to something..."
132111112211212211.title: Forgive her, she didn't mean any harm.

choices: A normal duel to first blood with rapiers.
A beauty contest!
1321111122112122111.content:
Kela stood outside the royal conference room. Inside King Arthras was meeting with his advisors, including that bastard Dioral. Surely by now he would have informed the king of your identity. She shuddered at the humiliation this would bring. But like many things, it had its benefits. While Dioral would surely scoff at a challenge from a woman, that she was still a man under law would give it weight. Even if he turned it down, it would cause him shame. Surely he could not refuse in front of the King, and if by chance he did, it would be victory in itself. She breathed deeply and clutched the vial in her hand. It had surprised Kela how easy it was to convince Marlin. Surely Xarlat would have demanded a favor, but Marlin simply made the potion. Now is the time to use it. She burst through the door and shouted "I have come to challenge Captain Dioral, knight of Traeven to a duel of honor!" The entire room turned to Kela.

Dioral smiled smugly, "What an honor it is to see you again, Princess of Grovan. Though this is hardly the time."

"Impudent woman! How dare you interrupt this meeting with your foolishness!" one of the advisors, a middle aged, thin man with a bushy mustache yelled.

"It is alright," King Arthras said. He looked over to Kela. "Captain Dioral has told me of your identity, Prince Kelos." He said in a gruff voice. "I have yet to reach a decision on your status. By our own laws you would have all the rights and privileges of a man. Still, your transformation took place outside of the castle. You presented yourself as a woman, and my advisors have told me under your own laws you would be considered one. An argument has been raised you should be held to that. Either way, I did not offer you the hospitality fitting for visiting royalty. For that I am willing to overlook this intrusion. Your reason for it, however, leads me towards the latter conclusion, if only for your own protection. Surely you understand that with your current body if this duel were to occur it would be with your defeat."

"Indeed," Dioral added. "Our encounter last night should serve as ample proof."

"I am aware I am not a match for him physically. It is why I have procured this!" Kela held up the potion, grinning. "This potion shall transform Dioral into a woman as well, denying him a physical advantage of simply having a male body. It will ensure a fair contest to be decided by our skills."

Many of the adviser chuckled at this.

"Why would I drink a potion given to me by a Grovanian?" Dioral replied, waving his hand dismissively. "It is likely just poison."

"I can assure you it is not," an old man with a long white beard and a deeply wrinkled face said. "You see it was I who made that potion. It will indeed transform you into a woman to ensure a fair contest. I can assure you it has not been tampered with either. I can tell when my potions have been opened on sight."

"May I ask why you would assist our guest in this?" King Arthras said.

"It seemed amusing," the wizard replied.

"I am under no obligation to accept a duel from a woman," Dioral said smugly. "Do go have tea and discuss dresses with Princess Fia and leave the men to their business."

"I see, to think the famed Dioral is a coward," Kela replied with a faked sigh. "I suppose I cannot blame you. You are quite right to be fearful of facing me in an even match. I am, after all quite accomplished in martial skill."

"It is not fear," Dioral replied. "You ask quite a bit from me, to become a woman for the sake of a duel? I need stakes to make it worth my while."

"You will return to a man, provided you win. Or at least survive," Kela said. "Your own court magician will surely see to that."

"That is not quite sufficient. You get honor if you win, but what do I get? Return to a man? That is only necessary if I accept," Dioral grinned smugly. "I do have a proposal though. If I win, you shall renounce your claim to manhood and become my wife!"

"Your wife?!" Kela asked in shock.

"Surely your honor is worth such a wager," Dioral said.

"I suppose it is," Kela replied. This was unexpected. While she thought it unlikely, there was a chance she could lose. To live her life as a woman, to be mounted by this brute, to bare his children? The thought made her sick. However, to back down now would be his victory. There was still one more card she could play though... "Indeed, but it was not solely my honor you tarnished last night. You struck a maid who was merely trying to defend a guest. The terms should reflect that as well. I agree to your terms, but in exchange you must agree to atone for that and live as a woman, serving as a maid!"

"Very well, I shall accept your terms, if it is ok with the king. His Majesty might object to his finest warrior being reduced to a mere servant," Dioral said with confidence. He was either sure of victory or sure Arthras would not allow this.

"It is interesting, so I will allow it," King Arthras said. Dioral looked disappointed for a moment.

"Very well then, give me the potion," the knight said. Kela walked towards him and handed it to him. Dioral popped the cork and drank it. Immediately his already long hair began to grow even more. Within moments it was down to his knees. His skin began to soften and his rugged face began to take on feminine proportions. His armor turned to cloth, as his body shrank down to a mere 5'2", His bulk decreased as his body began to reshape itself. His formerly muscular arms and legs were now thin and girlish. Two mounds appeared on his chest, forming modest B cup breasts. His waist narrowed and his hips widened. His penis contracted into his body and her new vagina formed. Finally his clothes reshaped themselves, forming a flowing pink gown. She seemed to get slightly taller as high heels formed on her feet. A matching bow appeared in her hair which arranged itself into a long braid. Dioral looked herself over. "This is different," she said in an alluring voice.

"My clothes didn't change when I was transformed," Kela commented.

"I do not wish to cause unnecessary humiliation in my vict... clients," Marlin replied.

"I have accepted your terms!" Dioral said in her new, feminine voice. "Now as is customary, I, the challenged shall decide the form of the duel! I have decided on..."
1321111122112122111.title: Kela challenges Dioral to become a woman and duel.

13211111221121221112.content:
"WHAT?!" Kela exclaimed. "Did that potion alter your mind? How is that even a duel?"

"It was you who wished to duel in these bodies, Princess," Dioral said tracing her figure with her hands. "If we are to duel as women, let us do so as women would. Plus, I would not wish to leave an unsightly scar on my soon to be wife."

"Your concern is noted, but most unnecessary. I assure you I would not be blemished by the likes of you," Kela said smugly. "Though if you insist on this farce, I can think of no better judge than Princess Fia. Who would know more about beauty than her?" Surely the princess would decide in your favor, and Dioral could not refuse her.

"I have no objections," Dioral said. "However, I believe King Arthras would also be a fine judge. We should include him as well."

"Oh but of course," Kela agreed. The king was a wildcard. He might be a fair judge, but then he might be biased towards Dioral. After all he did have the king's favor. Even if he did, that would likely result in a tie. Likely an acceptable outcome, but not a desirable one. Something must be done to tilt the situation in your favor. "Though two judges raises a possibility of a tie. I think it unlikely, as I shall surely win, but it would be troublesome. I propose a third and final judge." The problem is who to suggest. Your sister comes to mind, but she might decide against you to get you out of the way so she can inherit the throne. Still, it's likely you could work out a deal with her. Plus, you're sure Dioral intends this to be over soon. He'd be stuck as a girl for a few days until Orianna arrives at least. There's also Marlin. He'd almost certainly be fair, and it would be likely Dioral would agree. The trouble is he would almost certainly be fair. This means giving Dioral a chance of victory.
13211111221121221112.title: A beauty contest!

choices: Win the Kings vote on skill alone
Try to bribe or entice the King
132111112211212211121.content:
"The third judge should also be of great royal stature to be worthy enough to stand alongside the wise King Arthras and the great Princess Fia. For only royalty have the necessary wisdom and insight to make such a weighty decision. Therefore I nominate the Princess of Grovan, Orianna."

The King nodded his approval at this idea, "Ah yes, your scribe had sent word that the other princess of Grovan would arrive in three days. Then it is settled, at the setting of the sun three days from now there shall be contest between Princess Kela and Sir...pardon me, Lady Dioral with honor, duty, servitude, and manhood on the line. There shall be three judges and therefore there shall be three categories fitting of a duel between women. These challenges will be in Grace, Beauty, and Judgement. There will be no swords crossed for I shall not permit these halls to be spilt with the blood of a woman. That would be unforgivable. And that goes for before and after the contest as well. If I suspect any fowl play between the two of you, a judgment shall be rendered immediately by myself and you do not want to try my patience on this matter."

Kelos cursed to under his breath, and he could have sworn he heard Dioral do the same. Neither former men seemed very favorable of fair play and had both seemed to consider underhand tactics to get the advantage. The King continued on, "Now the two of you are dismissed, Lady Dioral, until this matter is settled I have no need for your council, go steed yourself for the coming trials." Dioral stopped himself from bowing and curtsied and quickly rushed off. Kelos could tell the Dioral seemed in a rush to examine his new situation. The King did not acknowledge Kela, so you simply curtsied yourself and left with a smile on your face.

You couldn't believe your luck, you'd practically already won! You have the two votes in the form of Fia and Orianna. Sure there was a slight risk of Orianna betraying you for personal gain, but if she did surely she knew mother and father would never forgive her for turning on their only son and heir to the throne. But winning 2-1 would be nice, but winning 3-0 and utterly humiliating Dioral in the process would be better. You'd hoped to maybe sever a tendon or two in her sleep but the King made it quite clear that wouldn't be tolerated. So he'd have to try to get the King's vote the old fashioned way.

The day before the contest Orianna arrives and taunts Kelos
1321111122112122111211.content:
Prince Kelos considered going back to visit King Arthras alone and see if he would be susceptible to 'Kela's' charms. But although his body was not, his pride was still very male. He did not want to reduce himself to bribery and trickery in a contest of honor. Even if it was a beauty contest. Kelos went back to Princess Fia's quarters to discuss the situation. She greeted him quite exuberantly as immediately hugged him. "I can't believe you convinced my father to let your own sister be the third judge. That guarantees that you'll turn back and that dastard Dioral will be put in his place."

Kelos was just as excited as Fia but chase to overly compose himself and said, "Yes, quite. It is indeed a boon for us, but that doesn't mean I can just slack off. I should still train to best present myself so that my victory will not seem to be rigged. The challenges are Grace, Beauty, and Judgement correct? Do you know exactly what these will consist of so that I may better prepare?"

"I have already discussed the contest with my father. Beauty is obvious, you just have to stand there and be beautiful. Physically you have the leg up on Dioral, but your physical beauty won't be enough. You have to exude feminine beauty, if you wear a the most beautiful gown in the world and you go stomping around like a solder to war you will lose. Grace will be much like beauty, but instead of just standing about being judged you will have to perform a task, display a talent of sorts. And finally the judgement portion will be a question and answer session where the 3 judges will ask you and Dioral a question each and depending on how you answer, so may go the competition."

"Very well my future bride, for you I will become the most beautiful and elegant woman in the kingdom."

"Well maybe after me." Fia approached Kelos and kissed him on the cheek, "For luck."

"My love, luck is one thing that I will not need." Kelos said as he left to begin training.

13211111221121221112112.content:
Kelos hurried to the courtyard as the castle's trumpets blared, followed by the announcement that Orianna was arriving. She seemed to glide through the halls, complements of the intense training in grace she'd undergone the past day, under Fia's personal guidance. When she had last seen Dioral, the former captain was still having trouble walking in heels without falling on her face. Kelos smiled at the thought of her impending victory as she exited the castle, then elegantly walked down the flight of stairs leading to the courtyard as her sister's carriage pulled up. King Arthras wasn't there, but Fia was, serving to officially greet Orianna. One of the maids directed Kelos to Fia's side. Kelos smiled at Fia, who returned it, and gave her hand a gentle squeeze. Orianna's carriage came to a stop, and the guard riding next to the driver dismounted and opened the door for the princess, who stepped out and immediately focused on Kelos, a wicked grin on her face.

Fia stepped forward. "Princess, Orianna, it's my honor to welcome you to castle Traeven on behalf of my father, King Arthras." She then gave a polite curtsy.

"Thank you Princess, Fia," Orianna replied curtsying. "As First Princess and heir to the throne of Grovan," She paused and looked over at Kelos with a smirk, "I humbly accept your welcome, and I look forward to an eventful stay here in Traeven."

Kelos breathed deeply and tried to not let Orianna's statement get to her. After all, it was technically true while she was in the form. Orianna then turned to Kelos, and stood there, waiting. Kelos also stood looking at her older sister for a moment, before it occurred to her, she was second princess right now. As the younger, it was her place to curtsy first. She did so. "Thank you for coming and agreeing to be a judge, Orianna," Kelos said.

"I'd do anything for my dear little sister," Orianna said bitingly, returning the curtsy. "You've become such a fine, elegant lady. It's a nice change from that boyish phase you went through." She then turned back to Fia. "Thank you, Princess Fia, for helping my dear sister Kela finally embrace her womanhood. This beauty contest was a perfect idea. She'll make a fine princess yet."

132111112211212211121122.content:

Kelos stared at the scroll intently. "This isn't a magic scroll, right?" he asked.

"I don't see how it can be," Sean replied, "All these letters have been screened prior to being delivered."

"Count it have been put in the bag after being checked?" the prince asked as he turned the scroll, examining it from all sides.

"It's possible, but it's watched by at least two guards at all times until delivered here, so it would require both of them to allow it," Sean said. "We're being very thorough with security precautions."

"I'm still hesitant to open a scroll after my last experience," Kelos said. He put it down and reached to his desk drawer, pulling out clear stone. He held it over his right eye, and again picked up the scroll, examining it through the stone.

"What's that, your highness?" the scribe asked.

"It's a stone that can be used to detect magic," Kelos replied. "I had Xarlat make it for me after I returned from Traeven."

"A wise precaution," Sean replied. "Is the scroll safe?"

"It appears to be," Kelos replied with a hint of caution in his voice. He put the stone down, and again stared at the scroll. "If I hesitate anytime I see a scroll, I can hardly consider myself ready to be king." With that he opened the scroll. He blinked, half expecting a flash of light transforming him, however, nothing happened. He looked at the now partly open scroll, only to find it blank.

"Why would someone send you a blank scroll?" Sean wondered aloud.

"Maybe it was a mistake?" Kelos replied. He opened the scroll all the way. As soon as he did, writing began to appear on the it. "This can't be good..." As the writing fully appeared, a bright flash filled the room. As it cleared, Kelos once again was transformed into a woman. "Seriously?" she said with a sigh.

"But you just examined the scroll for magic!" Sean exclaimed.

"Whoever sent this must have taken great care to hide the magic," Kelos concluded. She stood up and examined herself. Unlike the previous scroll, this one changed Kelos' clothing as well. She found she was wearing a pure white wedding dress with intricate lace embroidery that looked like some sort of flower. Her hair was once again red and curly, but done up in a bun beneath a white veil. While there was no mirror in the room, she felt her body and face, finding the proportions familiar. "One more thing," Kelos said, as she sat down at her desk. She placed the veil down, then opened a drawer and began rummaging through a stack of papers. After a few moments she found one, pulled it out and handed it to the scribe. "This is the formula for the potion Marlin used to cure me in Traeven. Have one of Xarlat's assistants make it. Do not tell Xarlat himself."

"Oh, right he'd probably refuse to make a potion Marlin created," Sean reasoned as he took the note.

"Exactly," Kelos replied. "He'd insist on making his own cure, and who knows how long that would take. Just get it made quickly."

"Of course," Sean said. With that he left Kelos alone to carry out his tasks.

Kelos got up and locked the door after Sean left. She felt her hairbun, and located the pins holding it in place. She removed them, and let her long red hair fall down. "That's better," she said to herself, as she placed the pins on her desk. Having nothing better to do without leaving the room, she reached into the mail bag and pulled out another letter.

                   Dear Prince Kelos;
It is I, Lady Dioral. I wish to apologize for my behavior when I was a man. Being transformed into a woman has taught me much about myself. I held women in contempt, seeing them only as incubators to carry a man's seed. I have come to realize I was wrong. I may have lost my manhood, but I have gained greater wisdom as a result. During my time as a maid I have come to realize men are nothing but worthless scum. It is women who are the superior creation. I must therefore thank you for this rev...


Kelos stopped reading and shook her head as she examined the letter, which apparently went on for several more pages. She skimmed Dioral's long, rambling letter, "blah blah, men hitting on her, they're worthless, blah blah would be better off as women so they could see the truth, blah blah only women can give birth, men are cattle, ran away blah blah founding a new religion, praise the goddess, oh here's something.

I implore you to join the sisterhood. The Goddess has told me you shall be central to her new order. Turn yourself back into a woman and meet us at our temple. The letter contains a map, use it to find us, Sister Kelos, bring any women interested in a new, better world, even if they were once men, especally if they were once men.
         Sincerly,
                   High Priestess Dioral of the order of the Sacred Goddess.


"Great, Dioral went crazy... crazier... and started a cult to turn men into women and I need to fire some guards for not catching this. "Kelos sighed.

13211111221121221112112211212121.content:
Kelos put the letter aside. She'd relay it to Traeven and let them deal with the Dioral. She got back to reading the mail, which fortunately were mostly normal congratulations for the upcoming wedding. She lost track of time, when she was interrupted by a knock on the door.

"Prince Kelos, it's Sean, I have completed the tasks you assigned," the scribe said, trying to be discreet.

Kelos got up, walked over to the door, and unlocked it, letting the scribe, quickly glancing in the hall to make sure she wasn't seen. "Do you have the potion?" she asked.

"I do," Sean said, handing Kelos a beaker full of liquid. "I had to promise the assistant you'd do her a favor later though."

"What sort of favor?" Kelos asked skeptically.

"She didn't say," Sean replied. "But it's probably going to be something you won't like, judging by her tone."

"Of course," Kelos said. "Well as long as it works. What about your other assignment?"

"The guards have intercepted a number of letters containing some sort of magical spell. They were sent to Xarlat to examine," Sean said. "I don't have the final results of his examination, but apparently at least one was a gender changing spell. They were pretty well disguised. Whoever is doing this isn't an amateur."

"Any idea who sent them?" Kelos asked.

"Not currently," the scribe replied. "I also did not give the scroll to Xarlat, since he would immediately know it was activated."

"Good thinking," Kelos said. "After I change back we can give him the scroll to examine." She then held up the potion. "Well, here's to manhood." With that she drank the potion. The vibration from last time returned as Kelos' body returned to its manly form. Unlike last time, the wedding dress transformed back into Kelos' normal clothing. "Huh, last time I was still in a dress," the prince said, as he examined his body to make sure he was back to normal and was fully satisfied with the results. .

"The clothing was not magically transformed before," Sean said.

"I suppose that makes sense," Kelos said. "Now that I'm back to normal..." Kelos stopped as a weird feeling overcame his body. All of a sudden a flash of light emanated from the prince. Once it passed, Kelos was once again transformed back into a woman, wearing the same bridal gown, complete with the veil and her hair done up in a bun. "This is getting old..." She removed her veil and placed it on her desk on top of the first one.

"Perhaps it would be best to consult Xarlat after all," Sean said.

"No," Kelos stated flatly. "Xarlat would have to tell my parents about this. I want to handle this on my own and discreetly." Again she began to pull out the hairpins that were holding her hair up.

"I understand, your highness," Sean replied. "However, the potion recipe from Marlin didn't work. This is clearly a more powerful spell than before. It requires an expert."

"Are you sure the assistant made the potion correctly?" Kelos asked as she pulled out the final hairpin and let her hair down.

"I helped her make it," Sean said. "We followed the steps exactly."

"So it wasn't the potion," Kelos said. "There must be some factor we're overlooking." She placed the hairpins with the ones from the earlier transformation. Just then there was a knock on the door. "Deal with whoever it is," Kelos whispered. As quietly as possible she grabbed the veils off her desk and concealed herself in the closet.

Sean checked to make sure Kelos' dress wasn't sticking out of the closet door then opened the door to the hall. Princess Orianna was standing outside, with a very impatient face. "Oh, Princess, what can I do for you?" Sean asked.

"Where's Kelos?" she asked as she pushed past Sean into the study.

"Some urgent business came up, and he left to take care of it," Sean explained. "May I ask what this is about?"

"The seating arrangements at the wedding are totally unacceptable!" Orianna exclaimed as she sat in Kelos' chair. "Why am I to be seated in the second row?! I'm Kelos' sister! I should be in the front row!"

"I'd imagine it's due to your part in attempting to keep Kelos a woman," Sean said. Plus, if I remember correctly, you are to be seated behind the King and Queen, and next to your fiance."

"It's still unacceptable!" Orianna stated. "Tell Kelos it must be changed at once."

"Very well, I'll tell the prince as soon as he returns," Sean assured her.

"Good," Orianna said. She stood up, bumping the desk in the process, causing some of the hairpins to fall. "Opps," she said. She then noticed what had fallen. "Why does Kelos have all these hairpins?"

"Oh... They were in a letter," Sean said thinking quickly. "Prince Kelos has come across quite a few strange ones while looking through the congratulations letters."

"I see," Orianna replied. "Tell Kelos to save the odd ones for me to read too." She picked up a hairpin and examined it. "These are pretty nice. I'm going to take a few to use for the wedding." she grabbed a few of them and left.

A few moments after Orianna left, Kelos stepped out of the closet. "I've been thinking," she said. "Why are there two bridal veils? The potion turned my clothing back to normal."

"You weren't wearing it at the time," Sean said. "The potion might not be able to affect things that aren't on your person."

"Reasonable, but I wonder if there's more to it," Kelos said.

132111112211212211121122112122.content:
Kelos shrugged his shoulders as he briskly opened the scroll to another message. Quite a strange message.

{center}My Dearest Kelos


Kelos scrunched his eyebrows as he once more didn't recognize the penmanship. "My Dearest"? For someone to have the audacity to call him that! As he let loose a brief growl, he continued reading the message.

I was quite saddened to hear of your upcoming marriage with that princess Fia. I know that we were still quite young back then, but you had already promised your heart in marriage to me all those days back ago under the Twin Salas in Leucina Forest. Have you really forgotten our promise? I... My family demands that I kill you for not honoring our agreement, but I love you too much, and have loved you all this time. I will come this night to take you away. Do not worry about my family. They may be powerful, but they are also quite catering. I am sure that they will listen to me once they see our reignited love for one another. Do not meet Fia before then. I beg of you.

Your Greatest Lover


Kelos finished reading the message.

"What nonsense is th-" He began, before he noticed something peculiar about it. Drops of water adorned the bottom of the parchment, moist to the touch. Kelos bit his leap. Tears?

Normally, Kelos would discard this kind of nonsense. But there was something about the scroll... something that intrigued him. The letter talked about Leucina Forest. Leucina Forest was known to be a vast forest that spanned hundreds of kilometers, where many beasts of wild resided. It was located on the edge of the Kingdom of Grovan. An uncharted territory. An unconquered territory. Normally, no one would go there, and Kelos had no memory of ever visiting that place. Yet something stirred deep within him. Something familiar.

"Hold on to these for now," Kelos briefly stated to Sean as he marched to the throne room. There was something he had to inquire from his father.

"Father!" Prince Kelos announced as he marched into the throne room. His father was a stern looking man with a military posture, short black, though graying, hair and a trimmed beard hanging from his chin. But underneath that appearance he was quite a jolly old man who loved his wife and his children, as well as the people of his kingdom.

"My boy!" King Reginald announced as he stood from the throne, his wife Queen Latissa promptly following his movements. He briskly walked up to Kelos and enveloped him in a bear hug. "How are you doing? Are you preparing for the wedding?"

"Yes, father," Kelos replied. "Though it has been quite expensive thus far."

"All the best for my son! All the best!" He exclaimed, patting Kelos on the shoulder. "So why have you come to visit this old man today? Want to gaze at the throne you'll be sitting on?"

"No, it's not that," Kelos responded. "I just wanted to ask you a question."

"Go ahead, my boy!"

"Leucina Forest," was all Kelos said, gauging their reactions. Reginald's military training had served him quite well, eliciting just a flinch, yet the gasp that came from Latissa's mouth told Kelos everything he needed to know.

"W-what about it?" His father hesitantly asked.

"What connection does it have to me?" Kelos quickly inquired, hoping for an answer.

"I don't know-" Reginald began before being cut off by his wife.

"Let's tell him, dear," Latissa said, gracefully touching his shoulder. "I... I think he has the right to know."

Reginald looked at his wife, then at Kelos, then back at his wife again. He sighed.

"I suppose now is better than ever," Reginald said, steeling himself. "Son, you may not remember this, but when you were... 7 years of age, I believe, you and Orianna went to Marquis Lodoneusque for a party. Afterwards, when you were returning to the castle, you suddenly disappeared when we were passing near Leucina Forest. Everybody frantically searched for you for three days and three nights, and it was only on the fourth day that you had suddenly appeared at the edge of the forest out of nowhere."

"At the edge? Nothing about the Twin Salas?" Kelos asked.

"Twin Salas? Hmm, I haven't heard of such a name before. But yes, you appeared at the edge of the forest. We thought that you had been traumatized, so... we erased your memory of that incident."

"Traumatized? Why would you think that?"

"Because... when you had come out of the forest, there was a powerful spell on you. I think it was a curse of some sorts. It was so powerful that even our court's head magician, Xarlat, who was in his prime back then, couldn't do a thing about it. We had to gather 10 powerful mages from across this country and countries beyond, and even they were barely able to cure you of this damned curse."

"Curse?"

"Yes. When you had out of the forest..."

Fae magic is very powerful."

13211111221121221112112211212211.content:
Xarlat smirked as he walked into the throne room and saw the familiar faces of the royalty he served.

"Ah yes, why if it isn't our little prince, all ready and waiting for his upcoming treat." Xarlat flashed his crooked teeth, knowing that it would disturb the three. "What would three such delighted souls have of me?"

King Reginald, heeding no mind to the snarkish comment, addressed the powerful wizard. "Xarlat, our court wizard! How glad am I to see you once more! Listen, we've got quite a problem. You see, someone has threatened to kidnap my boy Kelos—"

"Is this not a job for your royal guards?" Xarlat said, raising an eyebrow.

"We have reason to believe that it is a Fairy."

The last thing that Kelos could hear was the sound of the air being sucked in through Xarlat's teeth.

"A fairy, eh? This is a toughie. A normal fairy is hard enough to stop already. They contain vast reserves of magic energy within themselves. Dragons pride themselves in their magic strength, but truth be told, fairies have a larger mana density than they do. A swarm of faeries can overwhelm a dragon."

"So a single fairy doesn't present much of a problem?" Kelos asked inquisitively.

"I was talking about dragons, you ignorant buffoon! Even their small bodies can present a problem to a high wizard such as myself!"

"So when the letter stated that his family wants to get revenge, then—" Kelos began before he was interrupted by Xarlat sucking in his teeth once more.

"Young lad," Xarlat smiled bitterly. "Faeries don't have families. High faeries do. They are nothing alike. High faeries grow to the size of humans, are typically male, though rare cases of females exist, and their magic power dwarfs that of faeries by thousands of times. I'm afraid to say that we're dealing with one right here."

"And it's not good," Xarlat added after a brief pause as he noticed the trio of royalties looking at each other. "Honestly, channeling a barrier is useless at this point. He'll just shatter it like a porcelain vase. And attacking him is useless as well. May as well kill ourselves by bouncing our attacks off his reflection shield. The most we can do is try to mask Kelos' mana signature and hope that it intermingles with that of the city folk and pray that the high fairy gives up and goes back instead of exterminating all of us."

"Is there nothing we can do?" Latissa asked.

"We would have to call for a high dragon. Two preferably. Or maybe try to find a hero and channel a lesser god into him." Xarlat replied, shrugging his shoulders. "Other than that, there's nothing much that can face a high fairy. They're usually perceived as playful and unintelligible creatures, but make no mistake. According to ancient manuscripts I've searched, they've waged wars with ancient deities before the latter ascended to the heavens."

"Then we should do that!" Reginald yelled, about to lunge for the exit. Xarlat stopped him.

"I'm afraid both tasks are almost nigh impossible at this point. High dragons are quite self-centered, even if they're intelligent, and do not desire to partake in events related to man, even if they are not on the best terms with the Fae. Even if we teleport to them right now, I very much doubt that one would help, let alone two. And a hero? I have no idea where to find one. Certainly not in Grovan or Traevan, there isn't one there. Perhaps you could seek in other places, but even so... channeling a god, even a lesser one, requires a ritual that only I might know. And I do not have the resources to perform it."

Reginald raised his eyebrow. "You mean to say that you want more sources of energy apart from the ones given to you? Does your greed for power know no bounds?"

Xarlat cackled. "Well, it's the only choice you have if you want to prevent the death of your young prince right here!"

"I would not quite say death. The letter stated that he would take me away." Kelos retorted.

It was Xarlat's turn to raise an eyebrow. "Take... away...? Ah... I see, I see! So you're talking about that incident all those years ago! No wonder my magic couldn't shatter that spell by itself. It wasn't a fairy's magic, it was a young high fairy's magic. I see, I see. So it was magic that hasn't been quite matured yet back then. Still, this is quite peculiar."

"What's so peculiar about it?" Reginald scoffed.

"Hmm... how about the fact that high faeries haven't married a human in over 3000 years!" Xarlat cackled.

"How do you know?" Kelos asked.

"Listen, young lad. High faeries might be rare, but they also contain vast amounts of magic power that rival that of high dragons. How do you think those little bodies maintain such vast reserves that equal to that of gargantuan creatures such as high dragons? It's simple, they marry beings with magic signatures that are very similar to theirs to preserve the mana and pass it onto the child. Usually it's among their kin, but sometimes they venture out to marry dryads, nymphs, elfs, and other beings with considerable amounts of magic. But humans? That is simply unheard of! Your prince right here is such a lucky man... or should I say "bride" to meet such a gentleman." Xarlat said, his cackle resounding louder than ever before.

"That's enough talk from you!" Reginald exclaimed. "My boy Kelos is scheduled to marry our dear neighbor's Princess Fia, not some far flung maggot infested fairy!"

King Reginald stopped to think. What should he do? On one hand, it was much safer to ask for the high dragons to intervene than to allow Xarlat to obtain more magical artifacts that he needed for his ceremony. On the other hand, it was very unlikely that any of the very few high dragons would help him, and he was more likelier to find a hero in the end. Reginald mulled before making his decision.

"Guards!" Reginald exclaimed loudly so that they could hear him from behind the door.

132111112211212211121122112122112.content:
"Search for a hero!" Reginald orders. "As much as it loathes me to invite one of those damned murderhobos, we're still much more likely to find one than a high dragon."

"Sire, even if we do find a hero, again I do not have the materials to perform the ritual," Xarlat said.

"You can acquire them, I trust," Reginald replied sharply.

"Mostly," Xarlet said. "I may need to make a substitution or two given the time we have, and the rest will be," he paused, then smirked, "quite expensive."

"Fine, do it," Reginald said. "What ever it takes."

"Of course, sire, gladly." Xarlat said. He disappeared in a puff of smoke, cackling.

"I don't like my future riding on finding some hero," Kelos said angrily.

"Neither do I, but against a high fairy, there's not much we can do to fight on our own," Reginald replied.

"Maybe he would listen to reason?" Latissa asked.

"Fae do not respond to reason," a voice spoke from the entrance to the throne room. "At least not what humans would consider reason."

"Orianna!" Kelos exclaimed.

"Is it that shocking to see your beloved older sister?" Orianna asked. "Really now, Kelos. My temporary exile after that incident in Traeven ended a week ago, and you haven't even made an attempt to see me. I'm hurt. But I might just forgive you and help you out with your fairy problem."

"Do you know something that could help?" Reginald asked.

"Well, if we cannot beat them, and cannot reason with them, what's left is tricking them." Orianna said.

"Do you have a plan?" Reginald asked.

"Perhaps," Orianna said. "It's still a work in progress. First thing, we need to turn Kelos back into a woman."

"What?!" Kelos exclaimed.

"If we do it with human magic, we can break the spell when we need to. If a high fairy turns you into a woman, well you'd better get used to dresses." Orianna said.

"That does make sense," Reginald said.

"I still don't like it," Kelos said with a scowl. "And where does the tricking come into play?"

"Simple, you'll tell this fairy that you still love him, but your duty to the kingdom requires you to become a man and marry Fia." Orianna explained. "Then after you have had children and the future of the kingdom is secure, you'll slip away to become his bride. After all, he's a high fairy, another decade or two is nothing to him."

"Even if that works, and I see no reason to think it will," Kelos replied. "It still only puts this off."

"Perhaps, but then you'll have had time to seek out high dragons, or heroes, or whatever," Orianna said. "Or maybe by then you'll actually want to be his bride."

"Never," Kelos stated emphatically.

"Well, you don't have a lot of options here," Orianna said. "The guards might find a hero, and Xarlat might get the ingredients for his little spell, this spell might actually do what it's supposed to, and that might be enough to defeat this high fairy. But that's a lot of mights. My plan leaves much less to chance. Plus, he's acting now because of your impending marriage to Fia. If you assure him that your heart still belongs to him, he might forget about it until you're on your deathbed. Time just doesn't mean the same thing to fae as it does to humans. At least consider it as a backup. Let's say this hero plan succeeds. Then all we need to do is change you back into a man. If it fails, this will give you another chance. You said it yourself, you don't like your future riding on some hero. Plus, even if nothing works, and we can't stop this fairy from taking you, we can rescue you and turn you back into a man. Just a reminder, if this high fairy turns you into a woman, it will likely prove impossible to break."

"I hate to admit it, but you do make a convincing argument," Kelos said. "I certainly don't want to become a woman again, but better a reversible spell than an irreversible one."

"I'm glad you're seeing reason," Orianna said, practically gloating. "Now then, say 'My beloved elder sister, please make me a pretty girl so I can be your adorable little sister like I was meant to be.' "

"How about no," Kelos said flatly.

"Fine, be that way," Orianna said. She then pulled out a potion and handed it to Kelos. "Drink this."

Kelos held the potion and looked at it nervously. "This isn't a trick, right? This won't be permanent will it?"

"I trust you have the antidote," Reginald said. "I have not forgotten your actions in Traeven."

"Of course, father," Orianna said. "If you're that worried, you can hold it." She took out another potion, approached the throne, and gave it to her father.

"Why do you even have these potions?" Kelos asked, still looking at the potion in his hand.

"I had to do something during my temporary exile," Orianna explained. "So I decided to study potion making. I have plenty of others too. I've become quite good at it."

Kelos took a deep breath, closed his eyes, and chugged down the potion. He then stood there for a moment. "Nothing's happening," he said.

"Of course not, the potion needs a command to activate," Orianna replied with a smug grin. "It's a pretty impressive piece of work, You can take a potion, then activate it at your convenience. I did tell you what you needed to say."

"Yup," Orianna said. "Go on."

"The whole thing," Orianna said.

"Like I was meant to be," Kelos finished. As soon as he did, a mild burning sensation spread throughout his body. His body hair fell out, and his arms and legs slimmed down, losing muscle tone. “Hello, little sister.”

Standing in front of Kelos was another woman glaring him down with an amused look on her face. She was slightly taller (for his current state, anyway), and slightly older than he was, but with the same red curls atop her head that his form currently had. Dressed in a fair and prim green gown that accentuated her well developed curves, she had a sharp and predatory look in her eyes that would send shivers down the spines of even the toughest of men.

“Oh my goodness you look so cute!~” She said, quickly rushing over to him and enrapturing his smaller form into a tight and joyous embrace. “You are absolutely precious! This is better than I even imagined! I mean I had an idea after seeing your men change, but you're leagues above them! And that maid outfit! I don't think you could get anymore adorable!”

Kelos did his best to let out a sigh, which wasn't the easiest, considering he was practically getting the life squeezed out of him.

This definitely was his sister.

Princess Orianna, three years older and second to the throne of Grovan next to him. A quick witted and intelligent young woman who continuously showed her drive and capabilities; known for dominating courtly negotiations and politics around the kingdom. It was an often held belief that she scorned the fact that the crown was taken away from her due to the birth of the first male in the family, but that didn't stop the fact that, between themselves, Orianna had a particular soft spot for her little brother.

Or 'little sister', as she aptly put just moments ago.

Used to being around stiff nobles and other royalty, the two had taken solace in each other while growing up, with Kelos often ruminating how if he ever wanted an honest reaction to a problem or a situation, turning to her was one of his only options.

For better or worse.

A fan of the theatrics, she'd often tease and play games with him, and Kelos could just imagine how much of a field day she must have been having knowing he had been stuck as a servant girl for the neighboring kingdom. He was sure he'd never live it down.

Still though, one thing at a time.

As Kelos was released from the other woman's grip, he took a moment to compose himself in a princely manner (in as much that a current female prince dressed as a maid could look composed), and coughed once. “Yes, well, hello Ori, dear sister. I take it you're doing well.”

“Very well, Kelos, or should I said Cally, as the reports I've been getting seem to indicate?” The princess leaned forward a bit towards her sibling, a rather sly smile forming on her face. “Did you come up with that one yourself?”

Trying not to seem flustered, as he knew a million little jabs like this were probably still to come, Kelos held a poker face. “It was a rather spur of the moment thing. A prince has to work on his feet, you know.”

“Ah, but a princess is to be pampered! Come along now, you must be exhausted! You're safe at home in Grovan now. Let's get you off those feet.” Orianna was high energy as ever, as she grabbed Kelos' hand to drag him off to who knows where. “We'll get you a nice change of clothes, and afterward I want to hear every last juicy tidbit of your little adventure. Over tea, of course.”

A little overwhelmed, Kelos...
