But really I don't see why she stands out over any other duke, dutchess, countess, or anyone. Just because she's the princess of some small kingdom doesn't make her anything special."

Kelos just shook his head and actually smiled himself, "You never did have a romantic side did you Ori?"

"Hm, romantic enough to know you turn into a fool whenever it comes to that girl, I'm sure your mind in the clouds and on her whenever you screwed up and made yourself like you are now."

Kelos knew arguing with Orianna about Fia would go nowhere, they'd had the argument 1000 times over. She just believed he should marry whoever would give the family the best political position even if it meant him marrying a troll, a hag, a baby, or hell even another man. "Well Ori, even if I did have such a skeptical view of love, I would have to go back anyway. I must return and save my men."

"Your ladies you mean," Orianna corrected, "And I don't see why you should, they're just soldiers. Easily replaceable. And did you ever think they might be better off as maids? I mean it's hard work but they were doing hard work anyways. And I'm sure they would rather be scrubbing floors than getting stabbed or shot at every other day. They might even find a nice cook or hunter to settle down with and they would..." Orianna seemed very happy with the little story she was creating but Kelos didn't like it.

"Whatever you say or feel about them doesn't matter. They are my men and I swore I'd go back for them. If they want to give up the honor of their positions I shall let them if they wish but I will save them and bring them back here to make that choice. And I assure you they will want to turn back."

"If you say so." Orianna shrugged, "But enough arguing, let's get you out of that silly uniform and relax." Orianna began dragging Kelos inter her closet as Kelos said, "I would if I could. It's enchanted and I can't remove it."

Orianna's eyebrows raised, "Really?" And before Kelos could say 'yes', she was already looking up close at the uniform and feeling it and...smelling it? "Orianna what in the world are you doing?"

"I'm testing to see what enchantment is on it."

"How could you tell?"

"Well while you've been studying for wars and battles, I've been learning other important magical traits. Nothing major, but useful nevertheless. You didn't think I just sat in my room sipping tea all day did you?" Orianna said and silently went back to work. A minute later she let out a small cry of victory. "It is a nice piece of enchanting done by the Traeven wizard I'll give him credit, but it's magic is only in effect within the castle Traeven grounds so you could easily remove it now."

"I can?" Kelos said happily, and not bothering to figure out how to get it off properly, just ripped and tugged at the uniform until after a minute he successfully ripped the whole thing off. Kelos couldn't believe how happy he was that he could see the female undergarments he was wearing. He actually touched his bare stomach for the first time in a week simply because he finally could. Kelos was taken out of his post maid uniform euphoria by the laughter of his sister. Kelos, realizing he was just wearing a bra and panties in front of his sister turned redder than his hair.

After she finally stopped, Orianna wiped some tears of laughter from her eyes and said, "Come on Cally, let's find you a nice dress to wear, that'll make you feel better." After searching for a while, Orianna seemed to find what she was looking for, a blue elegant dress which showed more shoulder and chest than was the norm, "Ah ha, this one will be perfect for you. It was custom made for me by a suitor of mine, but it was a bit small for me, but it should fit you perfectly. And it will go much better with your eyes! Oh I can't wait! Put it on!" Orianna practically squealed at Kelos as she almost without Kelos' help at all put the dress on him.

Kelos still felt humiliated, but he took solace in that it made his sister happy and the dress was a bit more dignified than the maid uniform. "Yes yes, you've had your fun, now I think it's time I turn back..."

"Not until you've relaxed more. Now come here and lay on my bed." Kelos obliged his sister as she went to a counter and returned with a series of creams. "These are of my own special creation. Now Cally, I'm going to put this on your skin and you will feel so much better. All that nasty rough skin you've gotten the last week with just wash away."

"Whatever you say." Kelos said just wanting to get this over with. Orianna rubbed some lotions on his hands and feet, they were now as soft and feminine as they were when he'd first been transformed. "I'm impressed Ori."

"You haven't seen anything yet," Orianna said with her grin, "This one will really help you out," she said as she dabbed a new bottle of cream on Kelos' eyelids.

“Mmm,” Kelos hummed, as the cream was gently applied to her face. “That does feel nice...”

It really did. Even better than the stuff Orianna had put on the rest of her. She assumed this was another one of those silly moisturizers, or some other kind of beauty product that she'd paid little attention to as a man, but regardless of what it was, its scent, which was a faint flowery smell that she couldn't rightly place, was intoxicating, and made her feel at ease in a way that she hadn't felt since before getting transformed.

“Just relax...”

The words of her sister rang through Kelos' mind, as deft hands continued with the gentle facial massage. It came to no surprise that, after the ordeals of the past week, she was mentally exhausted. In fact, as much as she didn't want to admit Ori being right, this was first time in a long time that she'd had a chance to 'unwind', so all this, plus the fact that she was already lying down on the bed, caused the young prince turned princess to start to doze off a bit, and while normally she'd have the fortitude to stay awake regardless, something extra must have pushed to draw her into dreamland.

Kelos didn't particularly have time to think what.

XxXxXxXxX

They were sitting under a tree.

Orianna up against the hardened bark, while Kelos, female of course, rested her smaller form comfortably in her sister's lap.

It was an almost picturesque scene, with a beautiful meadow surrounding them; monopolized almost entirely by a vast and seemingly endless array of pristine white flowers. The affect of it was dazzling, as the high noon sun mixed with hues of the flora to create a practically blinding brightness to the area.

This didn't bother the two girls, though, as they were safely shaded beneath the single tree in the area. In fact, the younger amongst them seemed quite pleased, with an almost glazed over look in her eyes and a goofy smile upon her face.

It was the flowers. Their smell, specifically. It was the same smell as the cream, but somehow ten times as lovely. She felt like she was in a trance.

Seemingly much less affected was Orianna though, as she gently glided her fingers through her little sister's hair; a doting look on her face as she stared at the girl resting with her.

“You know, little sister, I love you dearly, right?” She said, leaning in to whisper into the other girl's ear.

She received only a faint “mm” in response.

“More than anything, in fact. Big sister Orianna just wants to protect her little sister Cally.”

Another light hum.

“Little sister Cally should really listen more to big sister Orianna, as she knows what's best for her.”

The dazed girl seemed to be mildly thrown off by that statement, as the next thing to come out of her mouth was a slurred and meek “Hmm?” It was about as coherent as she could act in her current mindset.

“That's right. Big sister Orianna knows little sister Cally suffered through the terrible trauma of having to work as a lowly maid! Big sister Orianna just wants little sister Cally to ease her mind from such troubles.”

'Little sister Cally' seemed to relax when she heard this response, resting further up against Ori.

At this, Orianna began petting her head.

“No worries of being a maid.”

"No worries of being captured."

"No worries of being executed."

She paused for a moment before continuing.

“No worries of being a prince.”

“No worries of politics.”

“Or the throne.”

Each of the last three were thrown out in quicker succession.

“Just let big sister Orianna help you.”

Suddenly the smooth and even voice of the older girl shifted up higher and became sweeter. “I promise we're gonna have a lot of fun!~”

She leaned in close to kiss the back of her sister's head.

“Wake up, princess.~”

XxXxXxXxX

Kelos blinked her eyes open. She must have been more tired than she thought. She'd have scorned herself for falling asleep while amongst company, but the pleasantness of the rest, and the dream she had, made her not really hold any regrets. She couldn't exactly remember what she dreamed about, but she knew it was one of the better ones she'd had in a long time.

Besides, it's not like she fell asleep while negotiating with some stuffy noble. If there was one person she could show weakness to, it was big sister Orianna!

Speaking of which, where was she?

1321112112221111121211111.content:
“Mother and father have returned?” Kelos inquires, blinking her eyes in confusion. This was turning out to just not be her day. Dozing off twice in front of her big sister? It was extremely unbecoming of her, and while it certainly wasn't something taboo considering it was with Orianna, it still brought a great deal of embarrassment to her.

Ori nodded. “Yes, and I even believe they're bringing some special company.”

“Then... then I must be returned to my true form at once! I can't let them see me like this!” Falling asleep was one thing, but it'd be a whole different kind of slight to have her parents and whoever else they bring find her as a girl prancing around in dresses. That could outright bring into question her ability to handle the throne.

Orianna though seemed to look quizzically at the younger girl before her. “'See you like this?' Whatever do you mean, Cally? I know mother likes to dote on you, but surely you've come to terms with that by now!”

An eyebrow arched upward on Kelos' head. “Ori, sister, how long have I been out?” She asked, forcefully sitting herself up at the side of the bed, but worryingly, feeling a woozy sensation after doing so. She almost fell back down into the cushiony surface.

The older princess just blinked, seemingly sensing that something was a tad off. “Just a few minutes, dear. You told me you wanted to take a quick nap before they arrived, and requested I come wake you when they were soon to return.” She smiled sweetly at her sibling. “I don't blame you for feeling tired. I would be exhausted too after the fiftieth conversation we've had about returning to Traeven.”

Kelos' features grew more dire. “No... no, that's not right. I remember... I remember tea, and then I felt tired, and then- then nothing!”

Her sister's brow furrowed at that statement, looking a bit unsure how to take it. “Cally, dear, that was ages ago! Are you feeling alright?” Ori's hand reached up to feel her forehead.

Kelos felt a sharp falling sensation in the pit of her stomach. Was this some kind of sick joke? “Sister, I know you love to tease, but I am far and away not in the mood at the moment. Your tea was lovely and your company exceptional, but don't sully my triumphant return with games and trickery.”

Orianna appeared dead serious. “Cally, there are no tricks here. I promise you. That 'tea incident', the day you arrived back from Traeven, that was nearly six months ago.” She was looking Kelos straight in the eye. “You had passed out from fatigue due to all the events of the day, and when you woke up, mother and father were watching over you, having returned from their banquet with the Count.”

“I... I don't remember any of that.” Kelos had an exasperation in her voice that didn't suit the standard dulcet tones of her female form.

“We're taking you to the wizard.” Orianna matter of factly stated, grabbing Kelos' hand without hesitation, and began to try and drag her off the bed.

“No, no wait!” Kelos pleaded. “I mean of course we'll go, sister. It's a fine suggestion, but I need to hear it from you. What's been going on since that day?”

There was a dramatic pause as Ori took a moment to stare her sister down, before ever so slightly nodding. “Well, if we're going back to the beginning, you should know that thankfully mother and father took your situation far better than you had probably expected. Mother thought you were absolutely adorable, just as I did, and father seemed more amused than anything, especially after hearing from your own mouth the meticulous details of your trials as a maid.”

Kelos' eyes widened. “What did I tell them?!”

Orianna laughed lightly. “You told them everything! Even I was surprised! Mother thought it was 'precious', while I never heard father laugh as hard as he did. It was quite possibly the most joyous I'd seen him since your own birth!” She paused briefly. “Though maybe for slightly different reasons.”

Kelos felt sick. She couldn't imagine telling the humiliating details of her employment as a maid to anyone other than her beloved sister!

Orianna though kept on going. “While in no way angry- he couldn't get angry past the tears of laughter, father felt there was a bit of a learning experience to be had from the incident, and forbade you from returning to your 'proper' male form for half a year.”

That explained why she was still a she, but it didn't explain the loss of memory or anything else. Kelos urged her sister to continue.

“As further 'punishment', he ordered that you be taught in the 'womanly' arts, as any princess would. He said that a few months seeing things from the opposite side of the coin would make for a more well rounded king in the future.” A rather sardonic look appeared on Orianna face. “Though sometimes I think he forgets a bit about the 'future king' stuff. He's even started to refer to you as Cally!”

This was too much to take in for Kelos. What the hell had been going on around her? “Did- did I just accept this?!”

A bit of pride showed up in Orianna's features. “You took it with royal dignity.” She said, placing her arm upon Kelos' shoulder. “You dived into your studies. From knowledge in the arts, to clothing, information in flora and botany, anything that was thrown at you you took with exuberant drive. Little sister, in such a short time, I think you may even have surpassed me in a few subjects!”

While it was true that Kelos always aimed for perfection, it was never in her plans to study flower arranging and the like, but still, she needed to be one hundred percent caught up. “...Anything else I should know?”

“Plenty!” Ori stated boldly. “While you took to your duties as any strong future ruler would, you nevertheless kept remarking about how eventually you needed to return to being a man and getting your 'men' back from Traeven. It's one of the few things you and your mother have spats about now and again, and, unfortunately, it's been getting a little more tense as your time to turn back approaches.”

That was good. That sounded like her. That sounded like Prince Kelos, but the fact that she hadn't urged to get her men back sooner, or the fact that she didn't at least try and send someone else to handle the matter, didn't make complete sense. This wasn't all fitting together.

Orianna snapped her fingers, and Kelos stiffened to attention. “That's an additional matter. If there's been one real upside to your 'trials in womanhood', it's that I don't believe you, mother, and I have ever been closer. Mother especially seems giddy about you. She loves to dress you up in just about anything she can find!” She let out a loud chortle. “I think it's a backlash from how I was always against it as a child. With you though? You're her doll.”

Kelos' mind felt like it was about to sputter out for a moment. “Her... doll?”

Orianna sighed slightly. “I'll admit it's a teensy bit of a problem. You just can't seem to say no to her on most things. Not when it's a chance to see her without her queenly demeanor for once.” She paused again briefly in her monologue. “Even I thought it was a bit much when, after wanting to hear the maid story for the fourth time, you asked if she would like you to dress up as a maid.” Orianna did her best to not stop as an aghast look formed on her sister's face. “I don't think that alone was the tipping point, but when she asked you to be her personal maid for a day, and you accepted, that to me didn't seem properly befitting of a princess, let alone a prince!”

Kelos was silently staring at her sister, her mouth wide open in an unladylike fashion.

“I don't mean to pry, but you... you don't like being a maid, do you, sister?” This question seemed to come out of the blue, but at the same time, like it had been on her mind for a good while. “I'm just asking because I hear tell that mother might end up requesting it again soon. I certainly know she enjoyed it. She found it 'delightful', and if you were to turn back, she'd want at least one more day to have of the experience.”

Kelos was just rapidly shaking her head. “This... this isn't real. Not at all!” She yelled pointing her finger at her sister. “Orianna, this is the foulest joke you've ever played upon me, and I'm not sure I can rightly forgive you for it, even if you're my dear sister.”

Orianna sighed. “We need to go to the wizard. Or a physician, maybe you bumped your head on the frame of the bed.” She attempted to grab Kelos' hand.

1321112112221111121211111111.content:
Princess Cally sipped on her tea, the lilac tinged steam tickling her nose and eliciting a small giggle from her petite lips.

Thinking back to the 'incident' from a few months ago made her feel so silly! Bumping her head like that and causing a brief spat of amnesia! Thankfully her beloved sister was there to calm her down and allow her mind to collect things. And just in time, too! Mother and father had just returned from another meeting with the count, and they'd brought his son with them for a visit!

They had been hoping that, if Orianna didn't want to come to see him, they'd bring him to her, but as fate would have it, things didn't go as smoothly as one would expect, and the young viscount ended up bumping into Cally instead! The transformed princess was left rather befuddled by his rugged looks, but it was his charming and surprisingly witty demeanor that had helped most to hit it off between the two. By the time Ori popped in looking for her, she was just as quick to leave, speaking of not wanting to 'disturb them'.

This left the king and queen rather bemused, the king more so. Cally's mother thought the fact that her and the viscount were exchanging pleasantries was just the 'sweetest thing', and outright encouraged it; giving tips towards the young princess like she was a teenage girl starting to date her first boyfriend. These events snowballed, and the viscount made several return trips in the days and weeks to follow, and all of them to just visit Cally, who seemed to hold little to no hesitation towards his growing advancements.

This caused a bit of a change in the mindset of the king. Ultimately he was getting what he wanted; one of his daughters was being ushered into another well to do and powerful family. It was just not the daughter he had expected. And while the count was a good friend of his, and in a high position, he needed the future ruler of Grovan to be wed into something even higher.

Still, deep down, he was a sentimental man, and he didn't want to tear apart two clear lovebirds like that, especially considering the special circumstances regarding his Cally.

That led to a few very serious conversations with Orianna. He knew she was a strong, capable woman, who, if given the chance, would be sure to bring about a whole new era to the kingdom.

It was just a matter of the fact that Kelos was born, and that Kelos was a man.

That though... that didn't seem to be the entire case anymore. He waited until the six month deadline had passed regarding her punishment, but she didn't say anything about turning back. It was like it had just slipped from her mind.

It was this that ultimately settled matters for the king, and two weeks past the end of Kelos' 'trial', he made the official announcement that the right to the throne was to be passed on to Orianna, and that Princess 'Cally' was to be demoted to second in line.

He had braced himself for bad blood to come about between the two, especially considering the new queen to be had been in talks with him for sometime about the arrangement, but to his surprise, Cally had simply embraced her sister, and cheered about how proud she was, and about how her rule over Grovan would be fair and just.

It all brought a smile to the old king's face.

That led to now, where Cally continued to sip on her tea in her much more feminine looking bedroom. Enjoying her sister's special blend and basking in the warm afternoon weather had practically become a daily ritual to her, and with each passing cycle, she could swear that she felt more pleasant and at ease with herself than the last.

A quick knocking at the door interrupted her musings of all this, though. “Who is it?” Her sweet voice asked, conveniently just after finishing the last drop of her drink.

Without directly answering, Orianna stepped in, a wide smile upon her face. “Sister! Sister! I have a magnificent surprise for you!”

Cally blinked, putting her tea cup down. “Oh? Has my husband to be returned for another visit?”

“Better!” Ori clapped, an excited tone in her voice as she walked out of the room for a moment.

Just as quickly, three young girls, a blonde, a brunette, and one with raven locks, all dressed in frilly maid attire, entered the room.

Cally let out a gasp. “Jess? Sandra? Hilda?” She asked in a shocked tone, incidentally using the female names she had given them.

Hilda squealed, and leapt towards Cally; enrapturing her in a big hug. “Oh my goodness, Princess! You look so pretty!”

Sandra moved forward to try and get her off her superior, but stopped when she saw Cally just as quick to return the gesture. “But, but how?” The princess asked, a look of truly surprised joy on a features.

Orianna was quick to interject. “For the past little while I've personally been working a deal with Traeven for a return of a selection of maids to the kingdom. It wasn't a particularly strenuous matter, given they were just simple servants, but they did request keeping one personally; a certain sprightly maid named 'Cally.'” A small laugh was uttered from the future queen.

“We uh, spent a fair bit of time doing our best to train that cat.” Sandra stated.

“We've spent a fair bit of time training in general, your highness.” 'Captain' Jess spoke. “The last nine months we've done our most to try and be the best maids and servants Castle Traeven has ever seen.”

“I love cleaning!” Hilda said, releasing Cally from her grip.

Orianna nodded. “Yes, I must say, from the reports, these three are better maids than they ever were guards.”

Both Jess and Sandra blushed at the matter of fact tone the princess spoke in, but the raven haired of them took that as a cue to continue. “It kept our morale up during the wait.”

Cally held her head down, ashamed of the fact that she never had an opportunity to return and rescue them. “I-”

Jess held her hand up. “You don't have to say a word, your highness. Princess Orianna has informed us of everything. You've been an extremely busy woman, especially what with your recent engagement.”

“Ooh! Ooh! Can I help pick out the wedding dress?” Hilda asked, stars practically in her eyes.

“What's scary is she'd probably be good at it.” Sandra said, twitching a tad.

“I... I appreciate the enthusiasm, girls, but- but do you girls still wish to be girls?” Cally was feeling quite overwhelmed, but that matter jumped right to the forefront of her mind.

The three soldiers turned maids looked between each other, before Hilda spoke up. “I like being a girl!” She said with a large oomph of 'pep' in her voice.

Eying the room cautiously a bit, Sandra spoke up. “I'll admit I found being a maid somewhat... relaxing.” She said, a bit of a blush forming on her face.

Jess slowly nodded. “I did enjoy sweeping floors over getting stabbed or shot at with arrows.” Her features shifted over towards Cally, though. “But no matter what, our lives are sworn to you, princess. It's our duty to serve you in whatever way we can.”

Orianna clapped her hands once. “Excellent! Then you would serve her best as her new handmaidens.” The group looked on towards the other princess. “I can assure you it would be a much more luxurious position than anything you three had in Traeven. Wouldn't you like it, Cally?”

The young princess stared deep into her sister's eyes, before openly starting to gush. “Yes! Yes! I would love to have the three of you by my side always!”

“Princess!” Hilda rushed in for another hug, and soon afterward, with only the slightest of hesitation, Sandra and Jess joined her.

Off to the side, Orianna smiled- genuinely. Truly pleased that her little sister had found happiness. Sure it might have taken a bit of magical wheel greasing to get it all together, but she knew ultimately it had all worked out for the best.

Not wanting to interrupt the scene before her, the future queen edged out of the room. She had some paperwork to file anyway for the trio of new employees. Plus plenty of other matter to deal with. It was to be expected of someone who'd inherit Grovan in just a scant few years time.

Orianna held her head high as she walked through the halls, knowing that the future of her kingdom was secure in her hands.

13211121122211111221112121.title: Kelos asks if there's a cage to put Xarlat in.

choices: The guards allow Kelos and Sean through.
The guards attempt to arrest Kelos and Sean.
132111211222111112211121211.content:
"Xarlat is cunning," Kelos said. "Plus, you do not know how long the scroll will last, correct?"

"Correct, your highness," Sean replied.

"Then we are at a disadvantage. Xarlat could escape at any moment. We must tell my parents immediately." Kelos said.

Xarlat hissed at the decision.

"It seems Xarlat disapproves," Kelos observed.

"A good sign, I hope," Sean replied.

"Let's not waste time," Kelos said. She picked up Xarlat's cage, then looked down at herself and sighed. "The quicker we are the quicker I can get this blasted ring off and the quicker I can return to normal." She turned and quickly marched out the door, heading for the throne room.

"Wait, your highness," Sean called out.

"What is it?" Kelos asked impatiently.

"Well I thought that perhaps you'd like to change first," Sean said. "After all, you're still wearing the maid outfit from Traeven."

"I'd love to, but regrettably this accused uniform won't come off," Kelos said sharply. "But thank you for reminding me of yet another problem I need to solve. Now come along. I'll probably need you to verify my identity."

"Of course your highness," Sean replied.

The scribe and the apparent foreign maid carrying a cage with a cat in it made an odd sight as they moved through the numerous halls and passages of the castle towards the throne room. As the two of them approached the doorway to it, they were stopped by the castle guards, who raised their halberds at Kelos.

"Halt!" One of the guards ordered. "State your name and your business here!"

"I am Prince Kelos, and I have returned to Grovan to see my parents and inform them of a traitor!" She glared with a menace that would would think impossible for a girl in a maid outfit, and held up the cage containing the former wizard. "This cat was once Xarlat, who betrayed our kingdom. Get out of my way or I will see you suffer a worse fate."

"How preposterous," the guard said. He began to approach Kelos. "A stay in the dungeon will get the truth out of you!"

"It might sound unbelievable," Sean said. "However, I can assure you, this maid is in fact Prince Kelos, accidentally transformed by one of my own magic scrolls."

"Or she's a witch who has you charmed!" the other guard said. "She already said she turned Xarlat into a cat!"

"All the more reason to step aside," Kelos said. "Either I am your Prince, as the scribe attests to, or I'm a witch powerful enough to overcome Xarlat in battle and charm this scribe into my servant. Either way I'm not in a good mood and it would be wise of you to step aside."

"She does raise a good point," the first guard said.
132111211222111112211121211.title: Go to the king and queen.

choices: Kelos leaves to see Orianna.
Kelos insists on discussing the information she has first.
1321112112221111122111212111.content:
"We should test her to see if she's a witch," the second guard said.

"And how should we do that?" the first replied.

"We could see if she weighs the same as a duck," the second suggested.

"We don't have a duck," the first said.

"You highness," Sean whispered. "I think these two are idiots."

"Clearly," Kelos agreed. She then just stepped past the guards who were distracted by their discussion on how to test for witches. Sean followed. They entered the throne room, which was not very busy. There were a few petitioners, but for now the king and queen were looking over some scrolls with the finance minister, likely confirming the kingdom's budget for the year.

"They won't recognize you," Sean reminded.

"My mother's necklace will," Kelos said. "Its gems will glow in the presence of her children, even if they've been transformed. It's a way to ensure an imposter can't take the place of the heir."

"Huh, I didn't know that," Sean replied.

"It's generally kept secret," Kelos replied. "You have proven your loyalty while aiding me against Xarlat, so I will trust you with this information."

"Thank you, your highness," Sean replied.

With that Kelos boldly stepped forward. "Mother, Father," she stated, "I have returned from Traevan, albeit with some changes."

Reginald waved the minister away. "And just who are you, girl?" he said angrily.

"I am Kelos," the transformed prince replied. "I have been transformed into a woman, given this enchanted maid outfit that I can't take off, and when I finally returned to Grovan, Xarlat here," she paused and held up the cage, "Attempted to control me so he could take power. He failed, though I cannot remove the magic ring he used either. All things said, I would really like some assistance in disposing of this traitor, and undoing the various spells on me. I also have information on Treavan's defenses which will allow us to claim a final victory in this war."

Reginald looked over to his wife, Latissa. She checked her necklace, and indeed, the gems on it were glowing faintly. "She's really Kelos, dear."

"We did know about your transformation. I must say, my son makes a fine daughter as well," Reginald said. "However, we must get you into something more becoming a princess while we figure out how to turn you back into a man. But first," He then looked at the cat Kelos was carrying. "You say this cat is Xarlat?"

"Yes, father," Kelos replied. "He tried to use magic to addle my mind, but together with Sean and his magic scrolls, I was able to defeat him, and turn him into this cat."

"As expected of my child," Reginald said. He stood up, walked over to Kelos, and took the cage from her. "Though I suspect Xarlat needs to be taught a lesson. I shall see to it personally." He turned and walked back towards the throne. "While I'm handling that, go see your sister. She has experience with enchanted clothing, and will be the most likely to help you remove that uniform."
1321112112221111122111212111.title: The guards allow Kelos and Sean through.

choices: The uniform is now able to be removed.
It has no effect on the uniform.
13211121122211111221112121111.content:
""Very well, Father," Kelos said. "It might not restore me to a man, but I will feel much better once I get this accursed maid outfit removed." With that Kelos began to bow, but hesitated. "I suppose with this body a curtsy would be more appropriate."

"However you see fit, dear," Latissa replied.

"Thank you, mother," Kelos said. She bowed as she had originally intended, then left to see her sister. The scribe followed. They passed the guards who were still debating how to test if Kelos was a witch.

With Kelos gone, Reginald looked down at the cat in the cage. "I suppose you can break that spell at any time," he said.

Xarlat responded by shaking his head no.

"Strange," Reginald said, as he placed the cage on the ground and opened it. Xarlat quickly hopped out. "I would expect one of the scribe's silly little scrolls would be no match for your magic, old friend."

Xarlat extended and retracted his claws a few times in practice. He then looked around the room. Next to the throne was a silver tray. He quickly bounded up to it, and jumped, knocking it onto the floor. Xarlat then dragged it over to the king, and began to etch a message into it with his claws. "It is not the scroll."

As Reginald talked to Xarlat, Kelos made her way through the halls. Rumors of what had just transpired was already making its way through the castle, so the servants and guards stood aside as Kelos passed. Before long, Kelos had reached Orianna's room, and knocked on the door.

"Do enter, dear sister," Orianna called out with a sly, knowing tone in her voice.

Kelos opened the door and entered the room. She saw her elder sister sitting at a table, with a pot of tea. "Ori, father said you might be able to help with one of my problems." Kelos said.

"In due time," Orianna said. She stood up. "Come, let me take a good look at you, sister."

Kelos sighed and entered the room, approaching her sister. Orianna met her half way.

"There, just stay still for a moment," Orianna said as she walked around Kelos. "I must say, you make a much prettier woman than I dared imagine. You shall have your pick of husbands."

"I have no desire to pick a husband," Kelos replied. "But the reason I'm here is this thrice damned uniform. It cannot be removed."

Perhaps I should wait outside?" Sean asked.

"Yes, that would be most accommodating," Orianna said. "I'll have our little princess here dressed appropriate to her title soon enough." With that she walked over to the door and closed it on the scribe, then turned. "So the uniform is enchanted, I take it?"

"Yes, it has enchantments that make it fit anyone who wears it, always stay clean and neat, make it unable to be removed, and it encourages cleaning a room." Kelos explained. "It has been hinted that there are more enchantments as well. Father said you had experience with enchanted clothing."

"Indeed I do!" Orianna said proudly. She walked over to the corner of the room and pulled out something covered by a piece of cloth. She pulled it off, revealing an elaborate bridal gown on a dressmaker's dummy. "This dress will make anyone the perfect bride. Anyone."

"So why would you make a dress like that?" Kelos asked, a skeptical look in her eyes.

"The original plan was to trick you into wearing it and marry you off in my place," Orianna said. "But mother and father never really pushed my marriage, and now that you're a woman, it's completely unnecessary."

"I think I'll turn down any offers of clothing from you," Kelos said.

"Oh, but I'd never do anything to harm my dear little sister," Orianna replied.

"That doesn't instill confidence," Kelos replied.

Orianna took a pair of scissors. "Hold still." She then attempted to cut the maid outfit, but with no success. "Also resistant to damage I see." She pulled and tugged at Kelos' outfit. "This is really well made. I can't imagine it can't be removed. What if a maid quits?"

"I wonder if it's that simple," Kelos said.

"Hmm?" Orianna asked.

"I quit as a maid!" Kelos called out.
13211121122211111221112121111.title: Kelos leaves to see Orianna.

choices: Orianna finds the right thread and removes it.
There too many magic threads, finding the right one proves impossible.
132111211222111112211121211112.content:
Kelos promptly tried to remove the uniform, but it remained firmly in place.

"They probably have some way of removing it in that case," Orianna said. "Are there any parts of it that come off?"

"Nope, headband, dress, stockings, shoes, none of them will budge," Kelos replied.

"So how do you go to the bathroom?" Orianna asked.

"OH!" Kelos replied. "The panties come off. That's the only thing."

"Let me have them," Orianna demanded. She held out her hand.

"I'd... um... rather not..." Kelos said as her cheeks flushed red. "I wouldn't have anything on under the skirt..."

"Do you want to wear that uniform for the rest of your life and be remembered as the maid princess?" Orianna asked with a sigh.

"No, of course not!" Kelos stated emphatically.

"Then give me your panties, sis." She motioned with her fingers for Kelos to give her the panties.

"Fine..." Kelos said. She lifted her skirt and pulled down her feminine undergarment, stepped out of them, then handed them to her sister.

Orianna took them over to a writing desk and sat down. She pulled out some sort of eye piece from one of the drawers, and examined them. "Interesting..."

"Did you find something out?" Kelos asked.

"Yes, you apparently wear a smaller size than I do," Orianna replied.

"Good to know," Kelos said flippantly.

"Sarcasm doesn't become a lady, sis," Orianna said as she continued to study the panties.

"I have no desire to be a lady, so I shall continue to be sarcastic," Kelos replied.

"I think I actually found something," Orianna said. "Magic threads. Rather than enchant the whole article of clothing, it uses enchanted thread. Quite an efficient method. Traevan's wizard can simply enchant a spool of thread, which can then be stitched in to clothing as needed by normal dressmakers."

"Fascinating, but how does that help?" Kelos asked.

"Simple, we find the magic thread in the clothes you're wearing that aren't in your panties," Orianna explained.

"The one that's in these but not in the panties will probably be the one that prevents them from being removed!," Kelos followed, realizing what Orianna was saying.

"Exactly, sis," Orianna replied. "Now come over here and let me examine your clothes."
132111211222111112211121211112.title: It has no effect on the uniform.

choices: Kelos takes Orianna's hand.
Kelos insists on the panties.
1321112112221111122111212111121.content:
"Fine," Kelos said, as she walked over to Orianna's desk. Orianna stood up as her former brother turned sister approached.

"Have a seat," Orianna instructed. Kelos obliged, smoothing her skirt out before gently plopping her self down and crossing her legs at the ankle and placing her hands on her lap in a very feminine manor. Orianna smiled at this. "For someone who just said she didn't desire to be a lady, you're sitting like a proper one."

"It's simply more comfortable to sit like this in this body," Kelos said. "It must be the hips."

"If you say so, sis," Orianna replied. She began to examine Kelos' headband with her eyepiece. "Though once we get you out of these servant's clothes and into proper attire for a princess, perhaps you'll be more open to exploring your feminine side."

"Unlikely," Kelos replied.

"We'll see," Orianna said. "I mean you haven't even objected to me calling you sis."

"It's better than just being called girl like I have been while in Traevan," Kelos replied. "Besides, if I did object, would you stop?"

"Probably not," Orianna admitted.

"Then I see no point in it," Kelos replied. "Until I can get all of this magic removed, I am technically your sister."

"Speaking of which," Orianna said. She took a pair of tweezers and pulled on a thread, which came out without resistance. "Try taking the headband off."

"Gladly." She lifted it up, and it came right off. "I can't believe it, it's finally off!" Kelos exclaimed. "Thank you so much, you're the best sister ever and I forgive you for all the pranks you tried to play on me growing up!" Tears of joy trickled down her cheeks and she embraced Orianna in a sudden hug.

"It's only the first part," Orianna replied. she stroked Kelos' hair. "But your welcome. Now that I know what thread to look for, the rest should be simple." After a few moments, Kelos released Orianna from the hug, and the elder princess resumed her work. One by one, Kelos was freed from the various pieces of the maid outfit. Eventually Kelos stood there naked.

"I never thought I'd ask something like this, but can I have my panties back?" Kelos asked.

"Nope," Orianna replied. "Those are for servants. Come, sis, I'll make sure everything you're wearing is fit for a princess." She held out her hand to Kelos.
1321112112221111122111212111121.title: Orianna finds the right thread and removes it.

choices: Kelos shows an interest and wants to pick out her own dress.
Kelos doesn't really care and asks Orianna to pick one.
13211121122211111221112121111211.content:
"I suppose princess is better than maid," Kelos said as she took her elder sister's hand.

"Oh, it most certainly is," Orianna replied. "Come, I'll give you a full makeover and..."

"Can it wait?" Kelos asked as her sister dragged her along towards the private bath in her chambers. "I must talk with mother and father. Just some clothing for now would be lovely."

"Pity," Orianna replied. "Promise me you'll let me do a makeover on you later. After all, a princess is to be pampered."

"Fine," Kelos said. "If I must remain a princess for a time, I'll let you make me look the part."

"It's a deal then, sis," Orianna said. She changed direction to her closet. "I'll make you the second prettiest princess in the castle in time for dinner tonight."

"Not the prettiest?" Kelos asked.

"Hardly," Orianna said. "After all, I'm here."

"Can't have your little sister being prettier, I suppose," Kelos said.

"Exactly," Orianna replied. She smiled at Kelos, noting that she referred to herself as a little sister. She was also being surprisingly cooperative. Perhaps it was to be expected. As Kelos herself said, she had spent some time as a woman already. She may have simply gotten used to it. However, it was worth testing further. She let go of Kelos' hand, and flung open the closet door. A massive walk in closet stretched before the two. Just past the door were two large dressers, one on either side. A full length mirror stood next to the one on the right. Just beyond that were clothing rods, lined with dozens of dresses, There were gowns fit for a royal gala, simpler dresses for traveling, and everything in between, in a myriad of styles and colors. Towards the back was a rack with shoes. Pumps, flats, slippers, riding boots, seemingly anything a princess could want.

Kelos looked in amazement as the sheer size of Orianna's wardrobe. "I had no idea your had so many dresses, and such a huge closet." As she walked in, her reflection caught her eye, and she turned to face the mirror. Looking back at her was a pretty young woman, with long, wavy red hair the same shade as her mother and sister. Kelos took a step forward and put her hand on the mirror. The reflection did the same. She stood there, staring into her own reflection.

"Something wrong, sis?" Orianna asked.

"No, I just never really got a good look at myself in the mirror," Kelos said. "I hate to admit it, but I'm beautiful."

"You take after your big sister," Orianna replied playfully as she pushed up next to Kelos, her reflection joining the former prince's. "Don't let it go to your head though, sis." She pointed to her own reflection. "See, I'm still prettier."

Kelos smiled, and a feminine giggle escaped. "Maybe a little."

"Well, we can't have you standing here admiring your reflection all day," Orianna said. "Let's get you dressed. Would you like to pick out your own dress, or shall I find one that suits you?"
13211121122211111221112121111211.title: Kelos takes Orianna's hand.

choices: Kelos capitulates, and allows for a makeover.
Kelos insists they go back to their parents.
Where's that spare magic ring of Xarlat's? Has she left it lying in the closet?
132111211222111112211121211112111.content:
Kelos hesitated for a moment, but Ori was waiting expectantly, and despite all the changes, she knew it wouldn't do for a princess to show hesitation. “I've an interest in picking a dress out for myself, if you don't mind, big sister. I spent so long prancing in that maid uniform, that having a little,” a pause, as she scanned the closet. “Or a lot of choice, would feel good.”

The older girl clapped in approval: both at Kelos' willingness, and the absolutely heart-fluttering way she called her 'big sister.' “What's mine is yours, little sister! At least when it comes to clothes. It's one of the perks you'll have from now on!”

“For now.” Kelos corrected. “Not 'from now on.' I'll be fixed before you know it! This is just a...”

“Fun diversion?” Orianna teased.

“Temporary solution.” The younger sibling pouted through pert lips.

The grumbling Kelos felt soon dissipated, however, as she found herself awash in choosing from a wardrobe so vast, she risked getting lost in there for a week! Colors, frills, and textures of all varying degrees of soft comfort tickled and touched at her in a way her life as a male never got to experience.

“Red is the signature color of the women in our family.” Ori commented, as she whisked her hair back. The two were debating over a fiery gown that Kelos knew had been worn out to many a gala.

“You don't think it's a bit much?” The new girl questioned: fingering at her own locks just like Ori did, but in a less confident manner. It'd make her so red...

Placing it in front herself as she examined how it'd look in the mirror, a smile of genuine giddiness sparked on her face.

It'd make her so red!

Selection after selection was fawned over, with that outfit being merely one of many. The only options which were outright off the table were anything shaded in black and white. For... reasons.

“Heels, little sister?” Ori questioned, with a modicum of surprise, as she saw her counterpart pull a pair off the shelf.

“I... got used to them as a maid.” Kelos defended with a blush. Besides, these stuck out to her for some reason, and she really wanted to try them on...

In the past, Kelos often wondered how women could so eagerly dedicate their time to primping themselves. Being of the aristocracy, it's understandable that a level of appearance needed to be kept up, but surely there was a limit to how well you invest yourself?

In the end however, thanks to the helpful, guiding hand of her sister, she completely lost track of things! Immersed in the moment, with a tingly warmth inside telling her that that was all a-okay.

There was a *click* *clack* on the ground, as well as a bit of a *swish* in the air, as the final touches were applied, but with only an echo of bashfulness, Kelos looked on to her companion.“How do I look?” She asked, seeking approval.

Orianna stayed dreadfully quiet, as she circled around the girl: face contemplative. At one point she lifted up a tuft of fabric on Kelos' sleeve, before letting just as quick. “Big sister?...” Kelos timidly hummed, worried she didn't like it. That was, until...

“My goodness! You are utterly precious!” Ori swiftly shifted into a brightly beaming grin, as she lifted up the new noblewoman into a tight hug: Kelos' face conveniently landing right in her 'big' sister's bosom. “Oooh, little sister! I knew there was a real princess hiding under those servant's clothes! Just wait until mother sees!”

Kelos struggled and flailed for a good minute, but she simply no longer carried the strength she did as a man: fully at Ori's mercy, and fully red as a tomato. From her hair, to her attire, she was practically a glowing ember!

Finally released, but no less embarrassed, Kelos tried to shrug it off as nothing. “Yes- ah, well, thank you, big sister! But I think you're right. It might be best if we go rendezvous with Mother and Father. I worry we've kept them waiting.”

“Mm, you've definitely 'kept them waiting,' little sister. You're like a babe making her first trip out shopping! I couldn't pull you away if I wanted!” She took a devious amount of pleasure in seeing the 'babe's' face burn up again. “But since you've held them so long already, what's a tad longer? We really ought to do something about that face of yours. No makeup at all! Still the look of a maid!”
132111211222111112211121211112111.title: Playing Dress Up

Switch to the events in Traeven.
1321112112221111122111212111121112.content:
"I must insist we do that later," Kelos said. "I learned quite a bit of valuable information while I was a maid, and the usefulness of it is dependent on how long a cat can act like a human."

"Oh yes, my plan. It seems to have worked astoundingly well," Orianna replied. "But just what could be so important?"

"Detained information about Traeven's military deployments, supply cashes, defensive fortifications, logistical networks, pretty much everything we need to conquer the land in a matter of days," Kelos explained.

"That does sound a tad time sensitive," Orianna said. "Though remember your promise afterwards."

"Of course," Kelos said. "It would be unseemly to break a promise between sisters."

"Indeed it would," Orianna agreed.

"Thank you again for getting me out of that maid outfit and lending me this lovely dress," Kelos said.

"Lending? You may have it," Orianna replied. "In fact, why don't you pick out some more dresses when you come back? I have plenty I no longer wear."

"I suppose I do need some more clothing," Kelos said. "I'll also need something to sleep in. I'm just looking forward to being able to sleep without shoes on. It was so uncomfortable, and I'd poke myself with the heel in the middle of the night."

"That sounds dreadful," Orianna said, "Even servants deserve better than that."

"Once Traeven is taken, I will address the issue," Kelos said. "For now, it's time to make my first official appearance as Princess Kelos." She curtsied, then turned, allowing her dress to swish up a bit. She then headed out.

"Good luck, sis," Orianna called out as Kelos left.

"Sorry that took so long," Kelos said, as she approached Sean, who was still waiting outside.

"Actually, I expected it to take longer," the scribe replied. "I'm surprised at how quickly your sister was able to figure out how to remove that maid outfit."

"Yes, she is quite skilled," Kelos said, "But we must still hurry. I fear my replacement will be discovered. Even with help from those three idiots, I doubt a cat can really pull off acting like a human."
