Let's see how things pan out here.
Something else.
13211121122211111221112121111211122.content:
The head maid Alimah palmed her face, as she watched one of her finest upcoming subordinates lick herself like a grooming cat.

“So one of Marlin's potions spilled on her?” She asked with a sigh: features pointed towards the trio of new arrivals. Pretty little things, but more air between their ears than brains. They'd only been in Traeven a few days and already they were causing trouble.

The raven-haired one, Jess, she believed, stepped up to elaborate. “Ahem, well, yes... See, Cally was having us clean your wizard's storage room, when a vial of something fell, and...”

“And now she's acting like a kitty!” Hilda cheerfully piped in, as she leaned over the transformed feline: dangling a piece of string for it to try and claw at. Standing adjacent, Sandra was beginning to wonder who was enjoying this more: Kelos' body double, or her ditzy little companion.

“Marvelous...” Their superior grumbled. “Take her to Marlin, then. He should be able to sort this out with relative ease.”

A deadpanned look then enveloped the former set of men... Well, except Hilda. She was occupied. “W- we wouldn't want to bother him, would we?” Questioned Sandra.

“Wizards can be quite busy...” Added Jess in sly agreement.

“I wanna have fun with the kitty some more!” Chirped Hil, as Cally-Cat purred from the rubbing she was receiving.

“Enough!” Alimah scolded: silencing them. “I don't know how it works in Grovan, but we don't run a charity here. The castle is now down a maid, and I intend to get that fixed! Otherwise I'll have each of you turned just like Cally here. If you don't intend to do your duty as assigned, then Traeven will be better off having you chasing mice!”

The stickler for authority in Jess instantly responded to the browbeating. “Ya Ma'am!” She said with a salute. “We won't let you down!”

Her boss simply gave a laugh. “Now that's the enthusiasm I like to hear! Talking more like a knight!” Before a response could be given, Alimah was already beginning to walk off. “See to it that Cally gets sorted out, though. I've grown quite fond of her. She's a natural maid.”

A moment of silenced reigned, as the three women, and one cat-woman, were left unsure what to do.

“We can't just take this thing to the magician, can we? Surely he'll be able to tell it's not the Kel- Cally.” Sandra pondered, as Cally-Cat rolled on its back, and stretched.

“Worse, he'll undoubtedly be able to tell we've been transformed too.” Jess scowled, as she rubbed her chin. “I hate to say it, but behind enemy lines like this, we might just have to hope our princess can save us.”

With a bubbly smile, Hilda began to absently wonder what she'd look like with a cute kitty tail.
13211121122211111221112121111211122.title: Meanwhile...

choices: Follow the maids to Marlin's lab
Back to Kelos.
132111211222111112211121211112111222.content:
"So, I heard your friend here had some trouble with a potion," A man's voice said from behind them. Startled, Jess and Sandra spun around, while Hilda didn't react, lost in her own thoughts. Standing there was none other than Marlin.

"Ah yes, Sir Wizard," Jess said with a gulp. Apparently events were quickly spiraling outside of control. The old wizard would surely see through everything and expose them. In a few minutes they'd all be in jail and their whole scheme would collapse.

"Please, no need to be so formal. Just Marlin will do," the wizard said. He looked down at Cally-cat, who was now licking her arms. "I take it she's the one who had the unfortunate accident."

"C-can you help her?" Sandra asked nervously.

"Strange, I don't remember having a potion that makes someone think they were a cat," Marlin said as he bent over and reached out his hand. Cally-cat saw and rolled over, then crawled over to the wizard. He then began to pet her head, causing Cally-cat to purr softly.

This is it, Jess thought to herself. Marlin knows something is up, he'll see that Cally is just a transformed cat, and then he'll expose them all. She thought briefly about just bashing the old man over the head, but surely such a powerful wizard would have a defense spell prepared.

"I must be getting forgetful in my old age," Marlin said. "Leaving such a dangerous potion laying around."

A wave of relief overcame both Jess and Sandra, as apparently Marlin, despite all odds, didn't realize anything was wrong here.

"Oh don't worry, it happens," Hilda chirped, having finally snapped out of her daydream.

"I believe I can," Marlin replied. "However, restoring her mind may be tricky. This potion seems to have been quite thorough. If I didn't know what happened, I would assume your friend here was a cat her whole life." He stroked his beard, as he thought how to solve the issue, not noticing two of the women there tense up, wondering if they had been seen through after all. "I have it! This girl is your friend, right? Have you known her for long?"

"Yup!" Hilda said cheerfully.

"We've known her for years," Sandra said.

"Good, good," Marlin said. "Then come along with me to my laboratory. I'll use you memories of her to make a potion to cure her."

"If you can help her," Jess said. She still wasn't sure if the old wizard knew what was going on and was leading them into a trap, but really there wasn't much else they could do here.

"Then lets go," Marlin said.
132111211222111112211121211112111222.title: Let's see how things pan out here.

choices: Reginald agrees to Kelos' plan
Reginald dismisses Kelos' plan
1321112112221111122111212111121112222.content:
"And this observation post here explains how Traeven was able to make it seem like they knew our movements in advance during the last offensive," Kelos said, pointing to the map. "They were watching us marshal our forces the whole time, and we were none the wiser."

"I suspected a traitor leaking our movements, but never this," Reginald said. "To think they had the gall to build this post in our land."

"It would naturally be well camouflaged and hard to approach, given its location," Kelos added.

"But now that we know, we can deal with them," Reginald said. "You've done well, Kelos. We'll smash their observation post and then carry on into Traeven!"

"Actually, father, I had an idea on how we can exploit this information," the transformed prince replied. "Rather than attacking it, we get them to report what we wish them to report. I propose raising a fake army in view of the post. Naturally, they will send message to Traeven, who will then dispatch troops to intercept ours when they cross the border. However, our actual force will gather here." Kelos pointed to a place on the map near the southern most part of the border of Grovan and Traeven. "The terrain is harder there, but it's still passable, and Traeven won't know of the force until after it crosses the border, and they will have positioned their forces to stop our decoy army."

"A decent plan," Reginald agreed. "However, there is a major issue with it. Where, exactly, does this decoy army come from?"

"Illusions mostly. There will be a solid core of 20 knights and 100 veteran men at arms. I propose using servants in armor to add another 100 or so actual people," Kelos said.

"One hundred servants?" Reginald asked, raising an eyebrow. "To get that many, we would have to use maids."

"Yes, I am aware of that, father," Kelos replied.

"Women have no place on the battlefield," Reginald said. "Perhaps your current body is clouding your judgement, daughter?"

"If all goes well, it shall not be a battlefield," Kelos replied. "Plus, I intend to lead this phantom army as your daughter, while you lead the real force against Traeven."
1321112112221111122111212111121112222.title: Back to Kelos.

choices: Fia sympathizes with Kelos
Fia is angry at Kelos for the deception.
1321112112222.content:
Kelos waited in the stable as the time of being stuck in this form ran out. On cue a shimmering covered her body, and once again Kelos was a he. He looked down at his hands, large and manly. He clenched and released a fist a few times, then looked down at the rest of his body. Sure enough, he had returned to his male form. However, he also noticed a problem, he was still wearing the maid uniform. The magic in it had caused it to stretch with his body, and tugging on it revealed it was every bit as stuck in place as it had been before. Now Kelos stood alone in the stable, a grown man wearing a maid uniform. At this point he heard a bucket fall behind him, and he realized he wasn't as alone as he thought. The prince spun around to see a shocked Princess Fia standing there.

"K-Kelos?!!" Fia called out in shock as she recognized the Prince.

"Fia! I know this looks strange, but I can explain!"

The princess took a moment to compose herself. "Perhaps, but I do not believe this is the proper time or place to do so. After all, I'm sure you would not wish anyone else to witness the Prince of Grovan wearing a maid uniform. Least of all my father."

"Absolutely not," Kelos said.

Fia looked around, and saw a dirty horse blanket. She picked it up, shook it out, then threw it over Kelos' head. "This should help somewhat." She then grabbed Kelos' hand and started pulling him. "Let's go up to my room and have a nice long chat about this in private."

With little other in way of options, Kelos allowed Fia to guide him. He was fairly sure people would still be able to tell he was a man wearing a maid uniform even under the blanket, but at least no one could identify him like this. Unable to see forward because of the blanket, Kelos looked down. He watched his skirt swish with each step as the two betrothed royals moved through the halls, the shiny, black, heeled shoes clicking on the tile, his hairless legs still clad in the white stockings. Wait, hairless? The hair on his arms had returned as he transformed back, so why didn't his leg hair... Before he could ponder too deeply, a door opened, and the tile of the halls gave way to a plush carpet.

"We're here," Fia announced. She pulled the blanket off of Kelos, and tossed it out into the hall before she closed and locked the door. She then directed Kelos over to a small table with a pair of chairs. "Now then, I think this is the proper time for that explanation." She sat down and invited Kelos to do the same.

"It's a bit of a tale," Kelos said as she sat down, carefully smoothing out his skirt. He then began to explain the past week of his life, the disguise scroll, his time as a maid, as Fia hung on every word.
1321112112222.title: Someone witnesses Cally turn into Kelos

choices: Return to the head maid to ask about this.
Stay and clean. At least it will keep people from seeing you.
13211122.content:
Cally approached the doorway leading to the west tower. This section of the castle was strangely empty. Her solitary foot steps echoed through the empty corridors with not a soul in sight. Fortunately the castle had plenty of markers to indicate the right direction, but she still felt a bit uneasy being alone in this weak female body. At last she reached the door leading to the west tower and attempted to open it, finding the door quite stuck. Not being one to accept defeat, she leaned against the door and pushed with all the force she could muster with her current petite form. The door creaked and shuttered, but did not budge. Cally stopped momentarily then redoubled her efforts. Slowly but surely the door began to give way until suddenly it swung open. With the sudden lose of resistance, Cally fell forward into the entrance to the west tower, kicking up a cloud of dust, which caused her to cough.

She rose to her knees and looked around, the tower was dark, the only illumination coming from the hall. There was just enough light for her to see that the tower hadn't been cleaned in quite some time. A thick coat of dust covered everything, with plenty of cobwebs for good measure. As her eyes adjusted to the darkness, she noticed what looked like windows on the wall, shut tightly. She stood up and looked herself over. As the head maid had aid, her uniform remained clean. She covered her nose and mouth with her apron and walked over to the closest window..

The thick wooden shutters were held in place by a wooden bar, which Cally removed, then threw the shutters open. Light from outside poured into the room, and for the first time she appreciated the magnitude of what she was up against. Furniture was strewn about, also coated with the same thick dust as the floor. Quite some time was an understatement, this tower clearly hadn't been cleaned for years, maybe decades. It would probably take the better part of the day just to clean this one room. "This is just hazing," she said to herself. "Surely I can't be expected to actually clean this my myself."
13211122.title: She runs into some trouble while working.

choices: It's probably the wind, keep cleaning.
This is too much, time to leave.
132111222.content:
Kelos was about to storm off to confront the head maid about this obvious harassment when a realization struck. As long as she was here cleaning, no one would see her like this, and since she was told to do it and it was a huge job, no one could blame her for taking so long. Eventually the head maid would probably send someone to look for "Cally," but for now, there was no need for her to let anyone see her like this. She just had to play an obedient little maid and clean this place. She Opened the other two windows to allow more light into the room. While it was hard to tell int he dark, now that there was light, this room obviously occupied the entire first floor. Next she set about properly arranging the furniture. Once that was accomplished, it was time to tackle those cobwebs. Then came the dusting, and finally the floors. Though she had lost track of time along the way, Kelos was sure it had to have been several hours at least, while it was a big job, the entrance to the tower was now clean.

"One down, who knows how many more to go," Kelos said to herself. She headed over to the stairs but found them to be pitch dark. "Of course, how silly of me. I need a lantern." Fortunately there was one in the supply closet just outside the tower. She quickly went to retrieve it, half expecting to find someone looking for her, but this portion of the castle remained deserted. She got the lantern, lit it and headed back to the tower, proceeding up the stairs to the second floor. Here there was a central hall circling the stairs, with three doors leading to exterior rooms.. Like the first floor, the hall was covered in dust and cobwebs. Unlike the first floor, there was a heaviness to the atmosphere. A strange noise sounding almost like whispering filled the air. Kelos hated to admit it, but she was feeling a bit creeped out.
132111222.title: Stay and clean. At least it will keep people fr...

choices: Kelos investigates the mystery room.
Kelos decides to clean the murder room.
1321112221.content:
Despite the creepy noises, Kelos got to work. She made short work of the hall, and before long it looked ready for guests. Now it was time to clean the rooms in this floor. She tried the one closest to the stairs. The door slowly creeked open, revealing a bedroom that looked like it had been completely wrecked. Furniture wasn't just strewn about, some of it looked like it had been smashed. It looked as if there had been a fight in here. Kelos examined the bed and found several slashes in it, and what looked to be an old blood stain. As she looked around the room she saw more evidence of a struggle, slashes in the walls, torn curtains, more stains that looked like blood splatter.

A scenario was forming in her head. This room was being used by someone, a guest perhaps, or a member of the royal family not in close line of succession. Probably a man, but not necessarily so. He was sleeping when an assassin struck. However, the intended victim noticed the intruder and fought back. Their struggle wrecked the room, and left one of them on the bed bleeding out. After this tragedy, the King at the time, Arthras? His father? Perhaps even his grandfather? Ordered the room sealed. The tower was locked, untouched, except to send new maids to "clean" until they give up as a form of hazing. Though that last part didn't make much sense. Why would they just leave this room untouched all this time? Kelos made a mental note to ask someone about this, then left the room and moved on to see how bad the other rooms were.

She reentered the hallway and moved on to the next room. This one she found empty, save dust and cobwebs. She got right to work on this room, opening the window, giving it a good dusting, then finishing up with a quick mopping. In a short time, this room looked good enough to house guests again. It just needed some furniture of course, but she was sent to clean, not redecorate. Satisfied with her work here, Kelos left and moved on to the final room.

As Kelos approached the third door, she noticed the eerie noises became louder. Clearly they were emanating from here. She swallowed and opened the door. To her shock the room was lit by some lanterns on the wall. The furniture looked clean and in good repair. It seemed as if this room had someone living in it. Though Kelos has seen no trace of anyone coming to this tower in a long time. Still, it was impossible for those lanterns to have been burning all this time. The noise was louder still, and Kelos thought it sounded like a woman's voice. She felt a chill down her spine. Still she had a job to do, and only this room and the murder room were left to clean.
1321112221.title: It's probably the wind, keep cleaning.

choices: The spirit introduces herself.
Kelos passes out/Something else.
13211122211.content:
Kelos steeled herself, as she stepped into the strangely lived in room; figuring it'd be better to tackle the other for last. This one barely needed more than a quick froofing, and besides, leaving those lanterns on risked a fire hazard. Of course, those even being there was a tad ominous, but something that wasn't going to scare her away. She was a man of action!

...Woman of action?

Maid of action, really. But whatever the form, turning back now offered few benefits. More alone time meant less a chance of getting caught, and it was all under the guise of 'doing her job.' Who knew? Maybe she could actually shake up the pecking order around there if it turned out she was the only person to actually sweep through the entire tower.

So she started to do just as she did for every other corner of the keep; clean, with feather duster in tow. The insides seemed fairly innocuous, honestly. Had she no prior knowledge, it could have been a simple guest bedroom found anywhere, sans the slightly peculiar sight of open books lying around, and the heavily filled shelf which lined the corner adjacent to them.

'Maybe this is used by one of Traevan's court magicians? A secret “home away from home?” Only types I could think of that'd be interested in texts like these...' Truthfully, the redhead had no clue what she was looking at, as she peered into one of the tomes. Very complicated, and in a language she wasn't familiar with.

'Though I'm not sure how long they could last, with insulation this bad...' The minute she stepped in to the abode, things, for some reason, began to get chillier. Thumbing the hem of her skirt, Kelos suddenly found a new respect for the profession she was (temporarily) adopting. 'I should have a talk with father when I get back about the current uniform situation for the castle help. If it's anything to the degree of the servants here, then those girls deserve an upgrade.'

All the more reason though to finish up sooner rather than later. That bloodied murder room was looking a teensy more appealing at the moment. Clearly there was something wrong structurally in this part of the tower. It'd certainly explain that curious, high pitched echoing.

A few more minutes passed, and the maid-princess (princess-maid?) was putting on the last few touches to her task. It had to be said, that at least that part of the 'job' wasn't so bad. There was a strange sense of pride in knowing that getting everything tidied up to a mirror sheen was something she was responsible for. With any luck, it'd garner some kudos from her fellow 'employees.' Proof that the 'new girl' wasn't some clumsy, bumbling ditz.

Right as this thought came through, a strange gust wisped past behind Kelos, and a sweet, but oddly ethereal voice, offered one token of commentary.

“Boo~!”

Kelos echoed an intelligent retort.

“Eep~!”

In an instant, the girl twisted around; eyes shut, as she waved her duster around in a wild, reactive attempt, to smack away whatever snuck up to assail her.

Her balance though was soon caught undone, as all she smacked into was seemingly thin air; leading her to unfortunately lean a tad too hard back, and stumble toward the bookshelf she'd so diligently de-cluttered.

The aftermath was her falling flatly on her fanny, and feeling the harsh sting of several thick layers of leather-bound paper bonk against her noggin.

*thud*

*thud*

*thud*

“Oh dear...” came the response of the yet unknown figure. The only thing Kelos could tell at that time was that she was a she, and that she appeared to be something that should, theoretically only exist in storybooks.

An apparition.

A specter.

A ghost!
13211122211.title: Grim(?) Grinning Ghosts

choices: Kelos leaves to report her progress and begin investigating.
Kelos stays to clean and talk to the ghost some more.
132111222111.content:
"Oh my, are you okay, sweetie?" the ghost asked as Kelos sat there dumbfounded and sporting several lumps on her head.

"GHOST!!!!" Kelos finally shrieked, pressing further up against the bookcase. She felt around beside her. Her hands touched a book, which she promptly tossed at the spirit in front of her. The book naturally passed through, landing harmlessly on the floor with a thud.

"It's okay, I'm not going to hurt you," the ghost said. "My name is..." she paused and thought for a bit. "Oh dear, I can't seem to remember. It's been such a long time since I've had anyone to talk to." She looked rather troubled at this.

"I-I'm Kelos," the transformed prince said, forgetting her current alias in her anxiousness over meeting an actual ghost. "How long have you been here?"

"I'm not sure exactly," the ghost replied. "I remember the queen had just given birth to a son..." The ghost trailed off again, trying to remember more.

"A son?" Kelos replied. Fia had no brothers, at least none born from Arthras' now deceased wife. That meant at a minimum she had been here since Arthras was born?!! Perhaps longer, it could easily be Arthras' father she was talking about. "Was the child named Arthras?"

"That name does sound familiar," the ghost replied. "Perhaps it was."

"So, how did you become a ghost?" Kelos asked.

The ghost paused in thought. "I was visiting. To celebrate the birth of the royal baby. I heard noise in the room next door. I opened the door to see what it was, then I saw myself in the floor covered in blood."

"You must have been killed as a potential witness," Kelos said.

"Witness?" the ghost asked, with a clueless look on her face.

"The room next door looked like someone was murdered in it," Kelos said. "You probably heard the victim fighting for their life. But I don't understand why it hasn't been cleaned. That happened ages ago."

"Oh that might be my fault," the ghost said. "Every time someone came up here I tried to talk to them then they got scared and ran off."

"And after a while, they just locked off this part of the castle," Kelos observed as she got up and dusted herself off. She then began to pick up the old books and put them back on the shelf. "Do you remember anything else about that night?"

"I don't think so," the ghost replied. "Nothing's very clear except that moment I'm looking down at my body."

"Well I can at least try to find out your name," Kelos said as she finished putting the books away. "There's got to be a record someplace."

"Really?" the ghost asked. "Thank you Miss Kelos."

"You don't need to thank me," Kelos replied. "Solving this little mystery will give me something to do besides cleaning rooms."
132111222111.title: The spirit introduces herself.

choices: Kelos leaves to report her progress and begin investigating
Someone's come to look for her!/Something else.
1321112221112.content:
Kelos briefly eyed the work left in the room. It was mostly done. Despite her embarrassing panic attack, she was able to sort out the damage done to the bookshelf relatively quickly. There was the murder room across the hall, but should she really tamper with it? There could be clues- evidence towards her planned 'investigation.' Maybe it'd be best to come back later to search around with better tools? On the other hand, this might be the only chance-

“So! You're a maid?”

The redhead's thought processes were thrown off, as the apparition glided on over uncomfortably close to her side; voice surprisingly cheerful.

“I- um, well...” Given her current attire, she couldn't exactly say no, could she? Black dresses and pinafores didn't exactly scream 'noble prince and military general.' “Temporarily?... It's complicated.”

The ghost giggled. “Isn't it always? I take it you're new, though?”

“New at a lot of things...” Kelos offered, as her skirt swished a tad. Why was it so damned short?!

“Well don't you worry! I'm sure you'll start to fit in just fine! I think... I think I remember the castle maids all being very pretty, and you're cute as a button!” She took the liberty of approaching the other girl, and tap her nose right with her ethereal finger!

“Cold!” Kelos mewled; hands going up instinctively to soothe the spot, in a 'button-cute' gesture.

“Oh! I'm so sorry! I'm still not used to interacting with people!” The specter cried; hovering close with concern, but not laying a finger.

The servant sniffled as she tried to shake off the strange feeling; like dipping her face into an ice box. “It's- it's fine,” She said, before pausing. “You really think I'm cute?” Kelos didn't mean to sound so girlish asking that, but how she really looked was a question she'd been pondering ever since opening that scroll. The scribe and the guards certainly wouldn't risk calling her ghoulish, lest they wanted to swiftly find themselves in the royal unemployment line.

“Adorable!” The cryptid happily chirped. “Why, I'm sure you'll find a knight soon enough who'll sweep you off your feet! I don't know if things have changed much since I was alive, but what man doesn't love a domestic? And a pretty one at that!”

Kelos began blushing as red as her mane. There were so many things wrong with that statement, but she wasn't exactly 100% confident about unveiling her true gender, as well as social status, to an unliving poltergeist. At least at this time. Surely waiting for the second rendezvous wasn't too much to ask, right?

“Er, w- well, thank you! Miss Ghost. You seem very kind.” The princess-maid's hands went to the front of her apron. “I'm not sure why someone would do something as to hurt you like that, but I want to help you out as much as I can!” She was being sincere. Maid or prince(ss), Kelos still had a good heart.

Or at least tried to have one.

The shade smiled at the young thing in front of her. “And I can see you're very sweet, Miss Kelos! It's a pleasure being given your aid!” She stopped, as she glanced over at the adjacent door. “Though I don't want to keep any of your mistresses waiting...”

The helper nodded. She'd dawdled quite a bit, and while that was fine before, people could start sending up others to search around, which'd only complicate the situation.
1321112221112.title: Gossiping Ghosts

choices: Kelos chats with Buffy and Mandy about the ghost and potential murder.
Kelos gets sidetracked with other maidly matters./Something else.
13211122211121.content:
Madame Cynthia, head maid of Castle Traeven, blinked, as she stared down towards Cally.

“You managed to clean the whole tower?”

That was... unexpected. When she first saw this girl, the older, slightly more jaded woman, instantly figured there was something fishy about her. A personal handmaiden gifted from Grovan to Princess Fia? She could be an assassin! Or a spy! Or a plain layabout the rival kingdom wanted to do away with!

That's why she took matters into her own hands. Fia already had plenty of attendants, but the castle, ever busy, was sorely in need of some extra help. And what better way to test this creature's mettle than to see how long she'd last in the west tower? 'Haunted,' as it was.

Ha!

“Um, yes Ma'am? Up to the top, at least.” For Kelos, it was strangely intimidating talking to this lady. She was so serious... Plus it didn't help how small that scroll made her! A dwarf she wasn't, but it felt like everyone she came across was taller!

“I climbed a flight or two earlier, it seems pretty thorough, Mistress.” Chimed in another maid was near her superior's side. The name 'Buffy' rang through Kelos' mind. She remembered her because they both shared a similar red hair.

“I almost went to the top, but was too scared!” A blonde one yelped; Kelos hearing the name 'Mandy' shuffled around her a lot. “Very clean, though.”

“Oh.” The supervisor mused; standing there quietly for a moment. She stared right into Kelos' aqua eyes for an uncomfortably long time, until she did something that caught Kelos completely off guard: Patting her gently, right on the head.

“Well, good work then! Maybe you'll be of help to us after all!” She turned. “Girls! I want you to treat Cally here as a fellow sister! We may not have her for long, but a good work ethic like that is hard to come by!”

Just like that, the newly minted maid had the two of them on her; poking and prodding as they saw fit. “I love your hair!” Hummed Buffy. “You're so tiny! How did you move everything?” Praised Mandy.

It was all causing Kelos to blush. Strange how friendly everyone was able to start acting. “You must be exhausted!” The redhead began. “We'll show you to the Maid's Quarters!” The blonde finished.

“Yes, that's right. Your shift is over with for tonight. I think, out of anyone, you've earned some supper and time to relax.” Cynthia remarked, before becoming more stern at her assistants. “I expect you two to ensure she knows the schedule for the rest of the upcoming week.”

“Yes Mistress!” Buffy and Mandy's exuberance wasn't toned down an ounce; both likely used to the commanding voice of their overseer. Instead, they locked arms around Cally, and started to rather quickly drag her down the hallway.

Face cherry as a tomato, and more confused than she would like to be, Kelos nevertheless still had questions on her mind about 'Miss Ghost.' As much as she was glad things were going smoothly on this end, maybe it'd be for the best to use some of her 'leisure time' to ask questions? Buffy and Mandy, for all she knew, had their ears plenty well to the ground. Plus, it'd be at least one topic to gossip about that didn't involve dresses, cosmetics, or other subject matter she unfortunately was uneducated in regards to.

Either way, this was probably going to turn out to be a very interesting week...
13211122211121.title: Maid some friends

choices: They find everything as Kelos discribed.
The tower looks very different.
132111222111211.content:
Kelos had no choice but to follow as Buffy and Mandy pulled her down the halls of the castle towards the servant's dinning room. She decided now was as good a time as any to begin her investigation into the tower's apparently sordid past. "So... has anyone seen anything... strange in that tower?"

"Only all the time!" Buffy replied. "That's why it's such a mess, none of the maids will go back after their first time cleaning it!"

"That's why new maids are sent up," Mandy added. "It's become a sort of inauguration ritual."

"It's haunted, haunted!" Buffy added.

"There must be a fascinating story behind it," Kelos replied.

"There's a bunch of 'em!" Buffy replied.

"My personal favorite is the knight and princess from rival kingdoms who met at a ball here in Traevan and committed suicide together rather than be separated," Mandy said.

"I like the one where two suitors had a duel to the death for the hand of the princess at the time, and the loser still haunts the tower waiting for his beloved to be reincarnated," Buffy added.

Neither of the tales recounted by the maids really fit the ghost Kelos had seen. "Are there any more stories about the tower?"

"You seem really interested in ghost stories," Mandy said.

"Maybe Cally saw the ghost," Buffy suggested.

"I did," Kelos admitted. "She even talked to me."

"She? So it's not a suitor for a princess?" Buffy asked with a hint of disappointment.

"There could be other ghosts," Mandy said. She then turned to Kelos. "Cally, you must tell us everything you saw."

Kelos then regaled her new friends with her tale, the eerie sounds as she was cleaning, the room that seemed to have had a murder in it, the encounter with Miss Ghost herself. The two maids hung on her every word. It seemed incredible, a room in the tower that hadn't been touched in decades with evidence of a murder, a ghost that seemed to be friendly but with no memories of how she died. There was only one thing on the two maids' minds.

"I wanna meet the ghost!" Buffy exclaimed.

"I'd like to meet her too," Mandy said. "We can be the ones to finally solve the mystery of the haunted tower"

"We're off duty for today, so we could go up now," Kelos replied. With that the three of them changed destinations and returned to the tower.
132111222111211.title: Kelos chats with Buffy and Mandy

choices: Princess Fia arrives at the stables.
Jack gets fresh.
132112.content:
The king clearly doesn't trust the new girl, and puts her in an out of the way position. The stable boy soon has her shoveling shit from one side to the other. The power of having somebody serve under him quickly went to his head. Kelos introduced herself as Cally, although the boy answered, "I'm Jack." he barely raised his view from her bust.

Although now he was enjoying watching her ass shift and shake as she forced the shovel into another pile of dung. She muttered to herself that this was all the scribe's fault, and he was probably enjoying wine with the king. Cally uses her political skills to assess the state of affairs. The stables are well-kept, and the horses look thoroughly trained. The guards are relaxed, but disciplined. Cally decides that they aren't preparing for war, so there is no need for urgency.

The scribe arrives in conversation with the king, and the two men take the finest stallions out for a leisurely stroll. Cally blows a stray hair off her face, and takes a breath of fresh air as they depart through the castle gates.
132112.title: "the stable boy as his assistant."

choices: Enough is enough.  Kelos puts a stop to this
Kelos plays along so he can get information
1321122.content:
Kelos looked on at the departing king and scribe with a red, angry, (and unintentionally cute) face. He was deep in thought coming up with the appropriate punishment for his scribes when Jack the stable boy held a shovel in front of him. "Break time is over. Back to the old dung pile."

"What?!" Kelos said unbelieving, "I just finished scraping up all of that less than an hour ago!"

"And since then a few of the horses have given you some more work to do. Horses crap multiple times a day, just because a pretty girl scrapes it up doesn't mean they stop."

"But why bother dedicating yourself to such a minor and disgusting chore?"

The stable boy looked at the attractive assistant with confused eyes and matter of factually said, "It's my life, it's what I do. And for the next week it's your life too. We take care of the stables, we make this place look pristine on a daily basis, and as disgusting as it seems, that includes taking care seemingly never ending pile the horse crap." Jack noticed that his words seemed to have depressed his assistant. Knowing that he wanted to keep the girl in a good mood decides to make his move. "But it is a good life. I get to take care of these majestic creatures and in my own little way I'm holding this kingdom together." Jack added with a cocky grin.

Kelos looked at the stable boy with pity. Is that really what this delusional boy tells himself to get through the day? "What do you mean by that?" Kelos asked genuinely interested in what Jack's crazy reasoning would be.

Jack simply gave the girl a wide grin, "Let's just say horse dung isn't the only ugly thing I keep away from the public eye." Knowing he had the girl on a hook, Jack made his way back into the stables, and as if write on cue Kelos ran up to him and curiously asked, "What do you mean?"

"Oh...it's nothing. I've said too much." Jack said coyly.

"No please, tell me what you are implying." Kelos said with bated breath. If this stable boy had any information that could give him even the slightest advantage over the kingdom of Traeven he had to take it.

"Well, you know what it's like with your Prince Kelos, Cally. All servants have a little bit of dirt on their lords, it's just that the things I know happen to be of much significance."

"And that would be?" Kelos asked anxiously.

Kelos' face was red as a tomato, as her heels clacked through the halls of Castle Grovan. Currently, she stood several steps back from Orianna, with her head turned down. To any passersby, she was no more than a simple attendant to the princess, accompanying the royal on her latest frivolity.

In truth, it was more that Kelos was so embarrassed, she needed to hide behind her big sister for protection.

The damned skirts these maids wore were obscene!

Ori was eventually allotted an outfit more befitting her social stature, but moment to moment, the younger 'princess' was becoming more intimately aware of the frills, and uncomfortable design aspects, of her current attire. There wasn't anything special about her uniform- it was the one all workers wore around the keep, but never before did she pay so much attention to the bare valley of skin between the hem of her dress, and her stockings...

A fit of giggles brought the redhead out of her musings.

“You know, sister, you're making this very difficult to not find amusing.” Orianna's voice held a playful lilt to it, even as they continued to the king's quarters.

“Orrrriiii~!”

Twice now Kelos' voice reverted to a whine like that. It honestly reminded Orianna of back when they were kids, with her little 'brother' always running to her for help. With the higher pitch even, she could almost imagine she traveled right back there...

Well, the more things change, the more they stay the same.

“Yes, yes. I understand, dear. You had an awful day.” She said, turning to her kin, and placing her hands around her shoulder. “You might want to watch your tone though, especially with what father has you wearing. Royalty can get away with saying much, but the help...” Seeing the 'maid's' face scrunch with worry almost caused Ori to turn a simple condolence into a bear-hug. An inch or two shorter, and Kelos could easily be mistaken for an oversized doll.

“...That said, if you keep making a face like you are, I'm sure he'll be a tad bit more lenient~.” Orianna gave a dramatic sigh. “Dear oh dear! my little sister, already learning the womanly arts!”

Kelos responded by doing what she was wont to do that day- complain.

“Orrrriiii~!”

It was an inspiration for a future king such as herself.

His cape smelled rather nice, too...

There was the lingering thought of why he curiously assigned a male to be their chaperone though; the more shrewd part of Fia wondered if it wasn't some strange tactic the king was brewing up to use on Kelos, but another part of her, the part that was his daughter, argued that it was likely just a case of him being overly protective. It made sense- two princesses in one room required double the attention.

She spit some of her long red hair out of her mouth and sat up in bed with a yawn. The hair in her mouth was certainly a sign she was still a woman, and a glance down at her chest confirmed it. Kelos felt like she barely got any sleep at all, between the unusual sensations of her current body and the experience from the night before. She then glanced at the bed next to her, only to find Fia missing. Apparently she had woken up before Kelos. The still sleepy princess looked out the window. "I don't mind it," Iris replied.

Fia clasped her hands together. "Good, it's settled then!" She then turned to Kelos. "So, Princess sleepyhead, breakfast is ready, and when we're finished, shall we take a bath together?"

Fia, at gatherings and events, always made sure to display herself with the utmost of royal dignity, but once one peeled back that layer of armor, she really was a cute and energetic young woman, and it was nice to see her trying her best to help with the captain. Her father raised her well.

Her father...

Kelos' eyes shifted over to the adjacent chair where his cloak was now lazily being hung off of.

She felt like she should return the lent garment. True, any of the regular servants around could handle the matter for her, but she felt it would be a solid icebreaker to see his highness again. It would do no good to leave the impression of a timid shaken up girl in his mind. She was a Grovan princess! She needed to show her pride! Plus it really was the least she could do after he helped her.

Shrugging, she supposed it wouldn't hurt to make a quick detour before going to Marlin...

---

Left?

No, no, no, right.

Hmm...

Maybe she should just keep going forward?

Kelos was really feeling quite silly right now.

Here she was, dressed in an exceedingly girlish nightgown, and looking like a doe lost in the woods, as she moved through the unfamiliar halls of the Traeven castle. Without Fia or any sort of person there to guide her, she wasn't sure where she should be going. It wouldn't have mattered if she left for Marlin first or not, it seemed, because she'd have ended up sputtering around in the maze she was in regardless.

Trying to ask some of the help that had been floating around wasn't as fruitful as it could have been; most seemed completely unaware of her status as being the heir to the neighboring kingdom. One rather authoritarian woman kept on insisting she was a servant, and pressed to doll her up in a maid outfit!

Needless to say, Kelo scurried on out of there quick enough.

“The hospitality here has been rather mixed...” After last night, and what she was experiencing right now, things weren't going as smoothly as they could. At this point, she'd settle on just finding Fia and going to breakfast, or-

As Kelos turned another corner, she found herself plodding into something tall, hard, and, as her hand felt around to figure out what it was... rugged?

“Ah, Princess Kelos my dear! What a surprise to see you!”

It was King Arthras. Kelos had bumped head-first into his chiseled frame, and he hadn't even flinched.

“Have you recovered from last night?” A tone of concern was in the ruler's voice, as he used his arms to gently pull himself apart from the princess; his royal demeanor making sure to look her right in the eye.

“Ah- um, your highness. Good morning.” Kelos found herself frazzled once again; stumbling over her words, as she stared at the calm and cool visage of the king. “I'm much better now, thank you. Ah, thanks to you, that is.”

The monarch gave a reassuring smile. “I dealt with Galan.” His tone had an absolute authority to it. “The man is now on a particularly treacherous quest. I'm sure once he returns- if he returns, he'll come back a changed person.” Though the truth of the situation was much different. Now he was off on a paid retreat for his compliance with Arthras' plan. A visit to the enchanted springs up north would do his loyal knight some good R&R.

“Thank you, your highness. Again. You honor me and my kingdom for your swift actions.” There was an awkward pause a moment after, as if Kelos knew not what to say, but a quick realization of what her purpose in looking for him in the first place sparked in her mind. “It's actually quite nice to see you, as I was hoping to return the cloak you loaned me earlier.” The princess lifted her hands a bit up to show the folded garment cradling in her arms.

Arthras' eyes shot open, and his grin somehow grew wider. “My cape! How thoughtful of you girl! I remember, before she passed, the queen would always greet me each morning with it.” He took the item, and quickly donned it. “Fine memories.”

“Ah, yes...” Kelos shuffled her feet a bit, not knowing how to rightly respond. “Well, it's nice to see you this early, but I think I'm going to be off to Marlin now. I'm hoping he can maybe help me with my situation.”

“Nonsense!” Arthras' booming voice spoke. “You can talk with that wizard anytime. Right now my dear, you're going to join me for a special breakfast with the king!”

Kelos took a slight step backwards at that. “Oh, by all means, I don't want to impose...” She really wanted to see Marlin.

“It wouldn't be imposing at all! I think it would be a grand thing to discuss the relationship of our two kingdoms. Plus, we'll dine on Traeven delicacies I doubt you've ever even heard of!”

Kelos crossed her arms and raised a brow. “What food does Traeven have that's never crossed into Grovan?”

“Care to find out?” The king just winked.

“Well...”

Noticing the dam was breaking, Arthras pressed further. “Besides, do you even know how to get to Marlin from here?”

The silence he received was all he needed.

“Then I'll be your chaperone for the day! It's the least I can do after the last night's fumbles.” He reached his hand towards her. “Take my arm, girl.”

Instead of trying to stumble through her words like a simpering schoolgirl though, she decided it'd be more wise to pause by feeding herself what looked to be a particularly delectable cinnamon bun.

She actually let out a soft moan, much to her embarrassment, as she took her first bite into the baked good; savoring the sweet sugary taste it provided, which again, caused his majesty Arthras to bellow out a jolly chuckle. “If nothing else, I can assure you a steady supply of those for the stay you're making.”

“That's- that's very kind of you,” Kelos responded; trying to regain her composure, while using a napkin to wipe her lips. “Though if you don't mind me changing the subject, I would like to learn of some other things about the kingdom...”

“And I too would like to hear of some matters regarding Grovan.” The lord spoke in return.

What followed then was an extended conversation where the two royals pitched back and forth light banter about their two kingdoms; all the while, Kelos fed herself with the electrifying treats laid out before her by the castle's chefs. Curiously, though she didn't particularly pick up on it, the king himself never really delved into eating too much; the lion's share of the offerings passing through the princess's lips.

As time moved on, and subjects changed, the matter of politics, and things relating to the various landmarks and wonders that each of their nations held, shifted to somehow be more about the various heroics and victories that King Arthras had scored in his years as both a ruler, and on the battlefield.

“...Then I pointed my sharpened blade mere inches from the cursed noble's whiskers, and stared the man in the eye. It was in that moment he surrendered, and the attempted coup to the throne was finally thwarted.”

Kelos placed her hand to her chest, as she was absolutely rapt in the story being spoken to her. It was one of deception, bloodshed, and fierce combat, but in the end, goodness and chivalry won out. To think that the man who sat before her here found himself in the center of it all, was nothing less than incredible! And “incredible” was the only word that she managed to gasp out, as she heard the tale finish up.

Arthras grinned proudly at the response he got. “Yes, well, I can show you where I keep his enchanted helm as a trophy if you like. The man himself though is now locked away deep in the prisons below.”

The evil she'd just heard the headpiece wrought sent shivers down her spine. Truthfully, Kelos wanted nothing to do with it. Though the knowledge of how the king dealt with it made her respect for him grow thrice fold.

As well as made the seemingly perpetual flush on her face shine even brighter...

“I- maybe later, your highness.” But 'later' suddenly sparked other thoughts in his head. “Oh! How long have we been chatting? I don't want to keep anyone held up!” Though considering the empty plates that had been scattered across the table, evidence was plenty that she'd been doing more than just 'chatting'.

“Worry not, girl. That's the benefit of being the king. Others have to work on my time. If you stick with me, you'll learn that.” The tiny wink he gave her might have been a smidgen too much. “...But it's true it wouldn't be a bad idea to don something more appropriate for the approaching time of day.” Arthras' eyes shifted over the clothes the princess was wearing; her sweet form still attired in the nightgown she slept in.

Kelos blinked, shocked at the realization of the frilly thing that she hadn't changed out of. What was she, a slob?! “Ha. Y- yes. I suppose you might be right.”

The ruler withheld any cute comments, and instead moved to help the girl out from her chair. “I'll escort you to Lady Cynthia so she can help get you cleaned up. The maids will deal with what's left here.”

“A- alright. Oh- oof,” the lady moaned, as she was assisted to stand up; the heaviness of the meal she just dined on finally weighing in on her. “Ah- I mean that sounds acceptable. I'll let you lead the way, your majesty.” She tried to rephrase things, as she took the arm of the man again; this time, without the hint of hesitation as before. He was helping to provide a bit of balance for the woozy fullness she was feeling.

As they walked, something else was niggling at the edges of her mind. Something about her needing to meet with someone, but she supposed she'd figure that out later. Half of her was feeling the need to start the day proper, while the other half simply wanted to relax after the delightful meal she had.

Either way, she'd let Arthras guide her for now, which, to the king, was perfectly alright to him.

The question to those at large was whether or not the food he had prepared was as innocent as it seemed...

13212111111133212113223121221112122112.content:
Arthras looked down at the young woman on his arm. It certainly seemed like the potions that had laced the food were doing their job nicely. None of them were particularly powerful, but taken together they were making the Grovan Princess much more accepting of her situation. One to make her memory a little foggy for a time, one to relax her, one to make her behave slightly more feminine. By the time Kelos realized anything was wrong, if Kelos ever realized anything was wrong, she'd already be a woman permanently, likely pregnant with the new heir to Traeven's throne, and Fia would be safely married off to a convenient ally. It was the perfect plan.

Kelos, still woozy, looked up at Arthras and saw him staring at her. "Is something wrong, majesty?" she asked.

"I was just thinking what a lovely young woman you are. You remind me a bit of my late wife when I married her," Arthras replied.

"Surely you flatter me too much," Kelos said, blushing and looking away from Arthras. "I never met the late queen, but I'm sure I can't compare to her."

"Modesty is befitting a princess," Arthras replied, "but unnecessary here. I would not say such a thing idly. You shall be the only woman at the ball tonight whose beauty might rival my daughter's."

"T-Thank you, majesty," Kelos said blushing, though smiling at the same time. While part of her was saying she shouldn't care about being beautiful, another part was very happy to hear the king's praises.

Arthras smiled at Kelos' lack of protest. Treating her as the woman she currently is, combined with the potions in the food, was clearly breaking through Kelos' male persona. The trick now was to find the right balance, push just enough to further Kelos' progression into womanhood, but too far for Kelos to start resisting and reassert her male identity. "Speaking of the ball, have you picked out your gown?" the king asked.

"My gown?" Kelos asked. "No, I haven't. I was going to see Cynthia for help with that today, but I think there was something I needed to do first." Kelos tried to remember what she had forgotten.

132121111111332121132231212211121221121.content:
"You were supposed to do something first? Nonsense. Why don't you go for your preparations right now? I'm sure you'll look lovely." Arthras replied.

But Kelos fell deep in thought. She didn't know why, but she had a feeling that she was forgetting something. There was something she needed to do. She was almost certain of it. But what would a pretty young lady like her need to?

She shook her head. What was she thinking? She was a man! ...Or supposed to be at least. Why was she thinking of herself as a princess? Why did she want to pretty herself up all of sudden? It didn't make any sense whatsoever.

She briefly looked up at the king. He couldn't have done anything to her, right? He was a noble man, who saved her from the clutches of that evil knight. He was honorable, and chivalrous. Yet, unbeknownst to her, her woman's intuition, which was enhanced by the potions, was sensing that something is wrong. She needed to go back to being a man as soon as possible. Man...

That's right! Marlin! Kelos suddenly jumped up and bowed to King Arthras.

"I apologize, but I must remove my presence for now. I have business with the court magician," Princess Kelos rapidly fired off her excuse before turning around before gracefully exiting in, unbeknownst to her, a ladylike manner.

The king clutched his head within his hands.

"I was so close!" He whispered as he clicked his tongue. His plan was straightforward. First, he would have Princess Kelos come to the ball. Then, he would compliment her, grab her fancy, and offer her a couple of drinks. And finally, he would lead the princess, whose mind would be marred by the potions and alcohol, to his bedroom chambers, where he would consummate with her. It was all so perfect! But alas, the stupid princess had to be smarter than he expected.

His thought skipped to Marlin. How would he persuade him not to turn the Princess back? Bribery wouldn't work. Marlin might be a senile man, but he was still a true and honest man. As he strutted up to the window, pondering, his eyes almost fell out of his sockets.

"What is that blumbering idiot doing here?" Arthras swore under his breath, as he saw Sir Golan walking underneath his window into the castle. "He was supposed to be on a vacation!"

King Arthras knew not why Golan was here, but he knew he needed to stop him before he encounters the princess. Otherwise, the entire ruse might be revealed to her, and he would look like a total fool! He dashed out of the dining room, praying that the princess would get lost in the halls and meet neither Marlin nor Golan.

Meanwhile, Princess Kelos is walking quickly through the hallways in her revealing attire. She knew that this problem would need to be fixed as quickly as possible, before she truly loses her mind... and potentially her future crown. Deep in thought, she didn't notice someone walking out from another hallway at a crossroad, and both of them collided, collapsing in a spectacular fashion.

"Excuse me, I..." Princess Kelos began before she noticed she crashed into...

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
Kelos, for a moment, felt slightly appalled at the fact that she caused an elderly man to stumble to the ground, but that shame quickly shifted to wonder, as, before even she could stand, the geriatric hopped himself onto his feet so sprly, that she doubted even someone half his age could accomplish the same moves.

“Ho ho ho, no need to worry, my dear! I wouldn't be where I am today if a few scratches and bumps stopped me!” In a swift flourish, he offered his hand out. “Marlin the Court Magician, at your service!”

Still a little shocked, the redhead could do little else but accept the assistance up. “...Princess Kelos of Grovan. It's a pleasure.” She said, now upward and mobile again.

The wizards eyes widened in curiosity as he heard this. “Ah, I've heard of your arrival! Here for something or another about being a suitor to unite the kingdoms? You must forgive me, I spend so much of my time with my work, I've little ability to keep up with politics. There's still boundless amounts to learn about the arcane arts, and my pursuits leave me limited room for anything else! Why just a while back, one of your contemporaries from Grovan had to come to me to fix a matter regarding finding themselves trapped as a horse! Poor dear was so flustered and happy about being human again, she forgot to tell me she had another spell cast on her! I'm in the middle of dealing with that as we speak.”

Kelos was amazed and somewhat bewildered by the man's abundance of energy, as well as his ability to usher out so many words in a matter of seconds. It was making her lose her train of thought. “Well um, yes. I'm the heir to the Grovan throne, and I'm here to offer my hand to Traeven.”

Without missing a beat, the magician carried on. “That sounds wonderful! Traeven and Grovan together at last! And I must say, King Arthras has picked a fine looking specimen to be his new queen!”

The princess's face started to flush the same color as her hair; both from the praise, and the thought of becoming his majesty’s wife. That wasn't what was happening! Was it?

It was ridiculous, she was here to marry Fia, not Arthras! Even though she'd probably spent at this point an equal amount of time conversing with both, and while the king had proven to be quite the charmer, she still had other priorities! This old coot was gravely misinformed!

Besides, she doubted someone who was so bumbling and inexperienced could do anything but make a fool of themselves at trying to be courted by a rugged man like Arthras. Having to hold up to the standards his late wife must have reached would practically be impossible...

Before she could provide a rebuttal though, the magic-user started to take his leave. “Anyhow my dear, it's quite nice to meet you, but I've much to do today! I'm sure we'll become more acquainted once you've settled in!”

That caused Kelos' jumbled train of thought to move in a different direction. “Wait! Hold on!” She couldn't forget, this was practically serendipitous! “I was hoping to actually speak with you.” She was now following him as he continued to pace off wherever he was headed.

“Ah, you have been speaking, though! You're speaking right now! But is there something in particular you wish to speak of?” The tone of the wizard always seemed to have an amused lilt to it.

Kelos meanwhile was having a bit of a struggle maintaining her walking speed while subconsciously holding a lady-like gait. “Yes, well, you see, I was hoping to maybe gain a bit of... magical assistance from you.” She said, while looking a bit flustered as they moved through the various hallways. “It's quite a long story, but I'd be willing to explain it all if you'd give me a few moments.”

Marlin in turn span on his feet, and placed his index finger barely a centimeter from the girl's nose. “No need for words, girl! Your face has been saying it all along! You feel your form isn't adequate to your suitor, and wish to use my alchemic mastery to fix matters.”

The princess paused for a moment, before a smile filled her face. “Yes! That's amazing, you're quite right!” She was a teensy bit shocked he was able to get it so quickly, but he was a wizard. Who knew what sort of powers he had up his sleeve? Looking into her mind was probably child's play!

Though it did raise worries with what she should be thinking about...

The old man just laughed. “Well my dear, once you get to my age, you tend to be able to understand these sorts of matters. Now why don't you come enter my workshop, and we'll see what we can do to aid you.”

To Kelos' surprise, it seemed the place they'd stopped was actually right outside the magician's office, and not wanting to look a gift horse (a gift Iris?) in the mouth, she gratefully followed the man in.

What the princess wasn't aware of though, was there was an immense amount of confusion going on. Marlin wasn't some telepath. In fact, at the moment, he was quite misinformed! He'd had little care about the arrival of the Grovan party up until they came, and only found himself involved when having to sort the situation out with the former guard captain (now handmaiden in training). Even through this, he took no real interest in learning much about the princess who was before him. Royals were all the same, weren't they? What mattered was if they funded his research! So he knew not of Kelos' original gender, nor even her name until she spoke it to him!

What he did know though was that she was a girl who was trying to make herself look good to a suitor, and many times in his past, he'd come across a bevy of women who'd beg him to make magical improvements to themselves; cosmetic, or even mental. It'd been how he'd earned much of his pocket change before gaining his cushy Court Magician position.

This Kelos person though seemed sweet and kind enough. Looked to treat him with respect! If he had to have her as a queen, chances were it wouldn't be too unbearable. Plus, having a wife around would do the king well. Might make him feel not so on edge. As such, Marlin figured he should at least lend her a bit of aid with 'wooing' the man.

The question was though, should he just give her a few touch ups, or attune her to more of the king's personal and unique tastes, so she can really catch his eye?

Figuring such matters out was what was so fun about his job!

"Right this way, my dear," Marlin said, as he led Kelos through a practical maze of tables filled with all sorts of jars and beakers and stacks upon stacks of books and scrolls. Kelos couldn't help but wonder about the mysterious compounds and ancient lore contained within, and if any of it was dangerous. She took great care not to bump anything. After all, she has enough trouble with magic already, and certainly didn't need to spill a potion that would turn her into an animal, little girl, or who knows what. Finally they came to a small clearing, barely large enough for two people to stand, with a desk covered with scrolls, books, and scraps of paper on the far side with a chair.

"Your lab certainly has some... character," Kelos said looking around.

"Ho ho, might that be your way of saying it's a tad messy?" Marlin asked jovially. "It might seem that way, but I can assure you, I know where each and every item in this lab is, from the smallest jar of powdered wolfbane to the shiniest magical amulet. Like the one under that pile of papers near your left foot."

Kelos looked down and there was indeed a pile of papers there. She bent down and looked through them, finding a gold amulet shaped like a crescent moon with a large green gem, perhaps an emerald, mounted so it was being held by the tips of the crescent right where Marlin said. "That's pretty impressive," she said, holding the amulet up and examining it. "This is magic though?"

"Yes, that particular one is said to have the blessing of an ancient fertility goddess," Marlin explained. "Supposedly a woman wearing it will become pregnant with absolute certainty."

Kelos immediately dropped the amulet with a horrified look on her face. "Surely not just from touching it," she asked with a sound of desperation in her voice.

"No, of course not, my dear," Marlin said, slightly puzzled why a young woman like Kelos would react that way. Surely being a mother would appeal to her, wouldn't it? "You would have to actually do the act while wearing it. Though legend says it need not be with a man."
1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.title: Marlin 'helps' Kelos

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
Yes, there was definitely something off about this girl. Marlin thought to himself. Perhaps it was the way she was raised. Those Grovan wasn't the most civilized nation. The poor thing had likely been raised as if she were a boy. She may have never had time to be a proper young girl. But that was nothing he couldn't fix. After all, apart from that, she was already quite the beauty, and had apparently already caught the King's eye. Clearly the place she needed the most help was mental. Marlin then pushed aside a stack of scrolls, revealing a chair. "Come sit, my dear," he said.

"The chair isn't magic or anything, is it?" Kelos asked as she approached cautiously.

"Not at all, it's simply a normal chair," Marlin reassured the princess.

Kelos sat down in the chair in a rather unladylike manor. After all, soon Marlin would turn her back to normal, so there was no point in trying to act like a woman. "So you can help me?" she asked.

"Of course," Marlin replied. "I'll just need to examine you a bit and ask some questions." He bent over near Kelos and examined one of her eyes with a magnifying glass. "So, tell me a bit about how you grew up. Did you receive military training?"

"Yes, of course," Kelos replied. "Why?"

"It'll help me help you if I know about your past," Marlin explained. Finished examining her eye, Marlin brushed Kelos' hair aside and looked in her ear. "Did you play with other girls when you were a child?"

"My older sister sometimes," Kelos replied. "There was Lucia, the daughter of the former minister of finance too. "

"I see," Marlin said. So she did have some female peers. He stopped looking in Kelos' ear and began to examine her hands. "How about boys?"

"There was Kendrick, the son of the captain of the palace guard, and Alex, the son of the minister of parks." Kelos replied.

"Grovan has a minister of parks?" Marlin asked.

"Traevan doesn't?" Kelos countered. "My mother always said it's important for cities to have parks and 'green spaces' as she calls them. It keeps the people happier."

"Perhaps we can talk more about Grovan's domestic policies later," Marlin said. "For now, tell me a bit about these other children. Who did you spend the most time with and what did you do while playing together?"

"Well, I guess I spent the most time with Kendrick or Lucia," Kelos explained. "Kendrick would usually go riding with me, and Lucia would usually spar with me."

"Spar?" Marlin asked. Certainly that was an unusual activity for girls.

"Yes, Lucia had a real talent for swordplay," Kelos explained. "She beat a full grown man when she was 10. Her dream was to be a royal knight. I'm pretty good with a sword too, but she'd usually win our matches."

"What about Alex or your sister?" Marlin asked.

"Alex liked to study a lot, so we mostly studied together after class. When he was 14 he left the castle to become a priest," Kelos said. "My sister, well sometimes we'd play together, but mostly we'd play pranks on each other. She'd also occasionally make me wear her old dresses and have tea parties with her."

"Okay, I believe I have heard enough," Marlin said. Of course the poor girl was like she is, she was raised with boys and a girl who might as well have been one. He stood up, then walked around the room, gathering vials of strange colored liquids. "I'll have a potion whipped up in a jiffy that will solve all your problems!"

"Thank you," Kelos said as she watched the wizard work.

Marlin added the liquids to an empty vial one at a time and mixed. Soon he had a translucent red potion and looked satisfied. He put a cap on it, then turned around and walked back over to Kelos "This should do it. You might be dizzy for a bit after drinking it, so I'd recommend waiting until you get to your room so you can lay down."

Kelos took the potion. "Of course. Thank you, Marlin." she said. "How shall I repay you for this?"

"No need to, my dear. I'm happy to help." Marlin replied. "But if you insist, you can tell me more about those parks and green spaces."

"I'd be glad to," Kelos replied. "Thank you again." She turned and left Marlin's chambers.

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
"I should tell Fia the good news," Kelos thought, as she looked at the potion in her hand and smiled. Quickly, she made her way through the castle halls, looking for Fia's room.

"There you are!" a voice called out, as Kelos rounded a corner. Kelos looked and saw Iris down the hall. She rushed up to the transformed Prince. "Princess Fia had Cynthia and I scouring the castle looking for you!"

"Oh, sorry, I went to return King Arthras' cape," Kelos explained. "The king insisted I have breakfast with him. Though the food made my head a bit foggy. After that I went to see Marlin though, and..."

"I'm sure Princess Fia will understand," Iris said. "But we need to hurry. You're late for your dress fitting for the ball tonight."

"Dress fitting?" Kelos asked. "But..."

"No buts, Princess," Iris said, interrupting again. "If we don't get you fitted now, you'll be late for the ball." She grabbed Kelos' hand and began to pull her through the halls. "Cynthia also wants to go over basic etiquette with you, so you'll make a good impression as a princess."

"I'd rather make a good impression as a prince," Kelos replied. "In fact I..."

"Not happening," Iris said. "Cynthia said she already put out the final guest list with you as Princess Kelos. The ball was carefully managed to ensure an equal number of men and women. You becoming a woman allowed her to arrange for two more male guests." She looked down at the potion in Kelos' hand. "If you turned back into a guy, Cynthia would be very upset. She already has plans to deal with that. Plans you won't like. You're going to be Princess Kelos for this, one way or another." She held out her other hand. "Give."

"I'm your Prince you know," Kelos insisted.

"At the moment, you're my Princess," Iris corrected. "And I'm your handmaiden. It's my duty to look out for you. Trust me, it'll be a lot easier on you if you cooperate. It might not seem like it, but this is in your best interest. Plus, I want to get that potion checked to make sure it will actually turn you back."

"Marlin said it would solve all my problems," Kelos insisted.

"Did he explicitly say it would turn you back into a man?" Iris asked.

"Well, no," Kelos admitted.

"Again, give." Iris said.

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
"Fine," Kelos said with a sigh, as she handed the potion over to Iris, who quickly slipped it down between her breasts as the pair continued walking. "I should be more careful around magic anyway."

"Indeed you should," Iris replied. "But then, so should I. In my haste to undo my transformation, I may have made it permanent. I don't want the same thing to happen to you."

"Thank you," Kelos said. "If there is a way to return you to normal, I'll make sure it's found. Even if it proves impossible, you shall always have a position in my service."

"I appreciate it, Princess," Iris replied. "It has always been my honor to serve you, regardless of the capacity I do so."

"You found her!" Cynthia called out, as she saw the two of them approach Fia's room. "I was about to order the castle guards to search!"

"Kelos!" Fia exclaimed, exclaimed as she burst out of her room, and embraced Kelos. "I was worried you were lost!"

"Sorry," Kelos replied. "I went to return your father's cloak, then he insisted I join him for breakfast, and I got sidetracked."

"Daddy better not be trying to steal my future wife!" Fia said, half jokingly.

"I was planning on being your husband," Kelos replied.

"Oh, but you'll make such a beautiful bride," Fia insisted.

Kelos blushed and looked away, as an image of her and Fia, wearing matching bridal gowns and kissing at the alter popped into her mind. She closed her eyes and took a deep breath.

"Are you not feeling well?" Fia asked.

"I think I'm becoming too accustom to this form," Kelos replied. "I was picturing us getting married wearing matching gowns."

"That's a great idea!" Fia exclaimed. She hugged Kelos tightly. "Though I suppose one of us will have to be a man for the marriage to be legal. But we can have a private ceremony like that before the legal one."

"I'm sorry to interrupt, but Princess Kelos needs to be fitted for her dress," Cynthia said. "Plus, I need to go over what's expected of her at the ball."

"I've been to these things before," Kelos replied.

"Yes, as a man," Cynthia said. "Plus, there are a few special rules for this one."

"Special rules?" Kelos asked.

"Boring rules," Fia said.

"Important rules," Cynthia stated. "For instance, if a man of equal or higher standing asks you to dance, unless you have already committed to a dance, you must accept their first offer. If you have committed, then you must give them your first available dance. If the man is of lower standing, you may accept if you wish, but are not required to do so. You may turn down a second offer from anyone, regardless of their rank, except the host. In this case, King Arthras. You may turn down his third request though."

"That seems complicated," Kelos replied. "Is this always the case? I've had women turn down first requests to dance, and others who accepted after committing to someone else."

"No, it usually isn't," Cynthia explained. "However, this ball tonight is Princess Fia's 18th birthday. It also serves as matchmaking. This is also why there's an equal number of male and female guests."

"But Fia and I are already engaged," Kelos replied.

"It's not just for me," Fia added. "Most of the guests are young single nobles, rich merchants, that sort of thing. There will probably be at least 10 marriages that result from tonight."

"Oh, I see," Kelos replied. "So the rules about dances are to make sure the men and women mix?"

"Yes," Cynthia said. "You're starting to understand, Princess."

"What if a woman asks another woman to dance?" Kelos asked, looking over at Fia.

"Well I suppose there's no rule against it," Cynthia replied. "It might make a bit of a scandal though."

"Princess, Fia, might I have your first dance?" Kelos asked.

"I'd love to, but it'll have to be my second," Fia replied. "My first dance has to be with my father. It's tradition."

"Well it'll be your first dance with a suitor then," Kelos said.

"Yes, I'll gladly accept," Fia said, smiling.

Kelos turned back to Cynthia. "Are there more rules to go over?"

"Yes," Cynthia replied. "But that was the most important one. Would you like to go over the others now, or should we start the fitting now?
1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.title: Kelos gives Iris the potion.
