1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
Kelos just ran a palm over her brow. All this etiquette when what she really wanted was to be with Fia... It was far too taxing. “No, no. Let's get to the fitting. If I'm to debut as a princess, then I've little desire to be a slovenly one. Rules can wait.” The fact she'd yet to change out of her night clothes while prancing around the castle did enough to damage her image.

“Ooh! This is going to be so much fun~! I'll help you pick out the perfect gown!” Fia's eyes were practically twinkling at the thought of playing dress-up with her fiancee.

Iris grimaced slightly, knowing she'd have to hamper the mood. “I'm sorry, Princess Fia, but since it took so long to find Princess Kelos, you're equally running behind schedule. You've your own fitting planned in just a few minutes.”

“And while Mandy and Buffy are far less strict than I, keeping them waiting would be unseemly.” Cynthia added, as she looked to her future queen.

“Oh foo!” Fia groaned, as her jubilant demeanor quickly soured; head tilting toward the floor. “By the time we get to see each other again, it'll be at the ball...”

Kelos was near equally displeased, but tried to keep a level head; leaning over to the other girl, with hand reaching to lift her chin. “Then I'll have the pleasure of seeing you at your most beautiful there.”

Fia, smiling lightly, inched closer to her betrothed. “I'm more interested in seeing how beautiful you can be...”

Before their lips graced, Kelo was unfortunately snatched away at the shoulder by the very attentive Madame Cynthia. “And to get there requires you to come with me.”

“I- but...” Kelos was soon being dragged off by the matron whose time for girlish antics stretched thin; her job was to craft women out of this lot, not playful schoolchildren.

As Fia's image was pushed further into the distance, Kelos eventually conceded, knowing at least Iris would keep her good company.

- - - -

It spoke volumes to Kelos how strangely comfortable she was becoming in this body, as she sat bare in a bath, and allowed Cynthia to rinse her flaming red mane. It provided an almost strange sense of deja vu, locked in the same room where she was dressed just yesterday, but all the while, lacking a level of fear and sheepishness recently becoming a woman had instilled in her.

It must have been the Grovan blood making her adapt so well.

“I have to say, Princess, I'm amazed you were ever once a man.” Cynthia eyed the figure before her. Kelos very much looked like a more petite version of the other Grovan heir, Princess Orianna. Had the maid not known of Kelos' origin, she could likely surmise just as well that she was the royal's younger sister.

“I've hopes to be one again...” Kelos commented. The weight on her chest was less unnatural now, but still something she hadn't much a desire to be a permanent fixture.

Finishing up her last touches, Cynthia began to gingerly usher her ward out of the tub. “Well tonight, you are not, which is something you should embrace. Your movements are improving quite steadily, but slipping into a mannish posture will only dissuade potential suitors.”

As she was being toweled off, a questioning look took hold over the royal. “The only suitor I hope to impress is Fia.”

The maid paused. “Oh? Are you certain? Don't underestimate animal instinct, deary. There will be plenty of good stock at the ball. If you're not careful, you could end snatched up as some noble's doting little wife.”

Kelos' blush was as fierce as her hair; hands protectively wrapping her towel tightly around herself. “I- I'd never! I mean...”

Cynthia chuckled, as she guided the princess to the adjacent wardrobe. “I may not always look it, but you and your friends aren't the only ones able to have a bit of fun. Calm down.” As she went to pick out lingerie however, her voice echoed out once more. “Though I do hope your morning with His Highness was to your satisfaction.”

The fire on Kelos' cheeks didn't cool, as her mind turned to Arthras; all the while, giving little resistance, when her assistant tugged the towel away. “The King... he's kind. I feel I owe a lot to him.” She went ahead and sashayed into a pair of pearl-white panties that were handed to her, while Cynthia stepped behind, and began the less than simple task of helping don the corset. “Especially with being so accommodating to... this... mess.” She signaled down towards her body, while the voice that spoke paused intermittently, as she felt the bindings to her middle tighten.

The mistress just held her tongue about calling that figure of hers a 'mess.' At least she was taught modesty. “Then repay him by presenting yourself well tonight. I've a collection of gowns here that fit your measurements.”

Kelos nodded, glad she was given options. If Fia was with them, then they'd likely spend hours trying on every slip, sweater, and skirt.

The older woman's last words though were niggling at her. Repaying Arthras... The more she thought about it, the more it seemed like something she ought to do. “Cynthia... would you happen to know of a dress that might be to the King's preferences, then?” She wasn't sure if that was the correct way to word it. She had no desire to catch Arthras' attention... honestly! She knew all too well how flirty he was getting with her during breakfast.

...But if he had a way he liked women to dress, why not do so?

Her maid smiled, as she took out a pink ensemble, not unlike the alternate choice presented to her yesterday when she went for that now ruined burgundy gown; this one however proved far more ornate, and suited for a high class gathering. “His Majesty prefers his women feminine. Once we get you sorted into this, I can also work toward applying makeup that'll almost certainly grab his attention.”

Kelos once again began to balk. “I- I- that's not what I mean! I am not 'his woman!'”

Before she could continue, Kelos' vision was covered in shadow; dress already being shimmied over her head.

“Not yet.”

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
Kelos suddenly lifted her arms, blocking Cynthia from placing the dress over her. She felt a fog in her mind that had been there since after breakfast begin to clear a bit. "Not yet and not ever!" Kelos stated with a fiery glare. "Why are you doing this?"

"What do you mean, Princess?" Cynthia replied.

"All this, talk about King Arthras, that I should wear a dress that suits his taste, that I should wear makeup to suit his taste, it's as if you're trying to set me up with him," Kelos fumed.

"Of course I am," Cynthia said. "You're just the King's type of woman. A lot like Fia's mother, in fact."

"I don't look anything like her," Kelos said. "And Fia has not mentioned anything about that."

"Because Fia doesn't know," Cynthia said. "The late queen had a secret. She was once a man."

"Wait, what?" Kelos replied in shock.

"Yes, she was a young knight back when Arthras' father was king," Cynthia explained. "Well I suppose she was he at the time. What was his name back then..." Cynthia paused as she tried to remember. "It's been so long... Sir Sigmund, yes that's it. It seems there was a witch terrorizing a village in the northernmost regions of the kingdom. So the kind sent a party of five knights to find the witch and either kill her or force her to leave. While they succeeded in driving the witch away, she gave each of them a curse. They returned to the castle as normal, but when they reported to the king, the curses activated. Sigmund became a woman. One of the other knights was turned into a beastman. The third was deaged into a child. The fourth transformed into a serpent. The last became a statue. Marlin worked to break the curses, naturally, However, something unexpected happened. The young Prince Arthras had never shown much interest in romance. He'd have the occasional fling, but nothing more than that. He was immediately smitten with the transformed Sigmund. He courted her, and by the time Marlin figured out how to break the curse, Sigmund had accepted her life as a woman, changed her name to Liesa, and agreed to become Arthras' bride."

"How long did that take to break the curse?" Kelos asked.

"Well each curse was different, and Liesa's was considered the lowest priority, so Marlin got to it last," Cynthia said. "It only took a few days once he did work on it, but by then three months had passed."

"Less than three months from proud knight to bride to be?" Kelos asked. "That doesn't seem like much time." She wondered if she would meet the same fate if she continued on the path she was on.

"Now then, your dress!" Cynthia said excitedly.

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
Kelos stared at the gown being presented to her, transfixed. She could have pushed it away, or yelled at at the one offering it, or even just stomped right out of the room. But instead, something far different managed to slip from the corners of her mouth: “Cynthia... what was Liesa like?”

The maid paused, curious, if for only a moment. Quickly however, a pleasant smile maneuvered onto her face, as she just as quickly maneuvered closer to her ward. “Oh? Liesa? She was a fair ruler. The people, the kingdom, her husband, they loved her. I especially did. It was a tragedy when that illness struck. Arms up now, dear.”

Kelos' brow furrowed, as she was guided into the exceptionally froofy outfit. “But... what about before? And right after? With that curse. How did he- she, cope?”

Cynthia ran her hands over the princess; arms, waist, checking for any creases that might mar the pretty silhouette she was finally getting a chance to see. “Well Sigmund was a fine knight, I recall. One of Arthras' most loyal. That's why the king at first wanted to help her so.” As Kelos proved rapt, the servant gently took her hand, and started the trot to the makeup table. “The change though, when it happened, was difficult. Sigmund was very prideful, and hated how she couldn't rightly serve her king.”

The princess gave the tiniest nod, as she was sat down. It was comforting, somewhat. Her story and the knight's didn't sound similar at all. Prince Kelos prided himself on not being too... prideful. This whole experience was proof of that! She liked to think her reason, and ability to not fall into an arrogant stupor, is why the negotiations of this trip hadn't fallen through to rock bottom. She could imagine a thousand other scenarios where ego would only make things inconceivably worse.

By all means, here she was, sitting in a (surprisingly quite comfortable) ballgown, and getting made up by a, at least polite enough, maid, who just had the fleeting fancy of playing matchmaker between her and the king. It meant something good that romance seemed more on the table than needless bloodshed, right? At least for the sake of the two kingdoms.

Though the powdering her cheeks were getting could be seen as another form of brutality. Cynthia was going out of her way to make her look pretty, it appeared. Very thoughtful.

“Now hold still sweetie, your eyeshadow is next.” The head maid was glad Kelos looked to be taking things in stride. She proved a bit fussy at first, but the maturity to accept a good spoiling is what really set her apart some of the other people she'd known. “This is just coming from me, but what I honestly believe helped turn things around for Liesa were sessions like these. I'd only been a young apprentice at the time, but even back then a royal pampering meant something. Don't you agree?”

It took a few more moments, but Kelos was eventually allowed to get a peek at the finishing touches being done to her. What sat in front of the vanity mirror was the most primly pristine princess this side of Traeven; a reminder of all those gatherings where she'd seen Fia, and had her breath taken away by just how beautiful she looked. For some reason, her chest was getting all fluttery.

“I- well... you've- you've done a commendable job, Cynthia. Making me... presentable for the event.” Kelos simply sat for a few moments; looking on in scrutiny, as the woman behind her fiddled with lengths of the red locks cascading down the back of her head. The dress, the artfully applied lipstick, the way her lashes waved every time she blinked. It was hard to describe the emotions knowing that that was. “I'm... I'm a man, you know.”

Cynthia didn't move an inch from her position, as she braided the younger girl's hair. “Dear, did I ever tell you Sigmund had a fiancee?” She paused briefly, but her hands kept moving. “It was a trying time for them as well after the curse, but both I feel through it all learned a lot. Love can mean many things. Relationships aren't as clear as the fairy tales say they are.” Cynthia comforted Kelos by gently gracing her palms on the other's shoulders. “While Liesa eventually found Arthras, the love she shared with her fiancee didn't taper. Only changed. Even today, they feel a deep bond.” Smoothly walking over to in front of the girl, and looking down into her eyes, the maid just offered one final thing. “All I'm saying is you'll be much more happy if you don't let silly expectations tell you how to live. Go to the ball tonight. Have fun. Do what your heart tells you. The only thing you are, is a person.”

A shade of red was soaking deeply on the princess's cheeks. “I... I want to dance with Fia.”

“Then dance with her!” The caretaker cheered. “Though, I still think you and Arthras would make a cute couple.”

Now adorned in a french braid, and ready for the festivities tonight, Kelos honestly didn't know where this all would take her.

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
Kelos walked through the crowded halls towards the ballroom. She thought it strange that just hours earlier these halls were nearly empty, with merely an occasional servant attending duties or a guard patrolling. Now though, they seemed full of life as guests for the ball made small talk with each other. She passed a few familiar faces, a countess from a neighboring kingdom she had a fling with a few years ago, a prince she had met during an official visit, a duke who had served as ambassador to Grovan for a time, but most of them were strangers. Though she was certain none of the people she did know would recognize her in this form. After all, she had been male at the time. Briefly she wondered if she had in fact known any of those others she had passed. Perhaps some of them were people who had met a similar accident. She giggled a bit at the thought that one of the young women she had passed may have once been a man as well. Or perhaps the opposite, one of the men being a former woman. Her thoughts were lost as she heard the sound of music floating through the air, which indicated she was in the right place. She turned a corner and the entrance to the ball room lay ahead of her. The doorway flanked by guards dressed in ceremonial uniforms holding elaborate golden lances. She wondered if they were solid gold or just gold leaf. She approached, prompting no reaction from the guards. On the other side was a maid, standing behind a podium with a long scroll. Next to her was a butler, carrying a trumpet.

"Ah Princess Kelos," the maid said. "Welcome. Both King Arthras and Princess Fia are really looking forward to seeing you tonight." She quickly looked through the list before checking off Kelos' name. She then turned to the butler, and pointed to the name. The butler nodded and raised the trumpet to his lips.

"DA-DAA-DA-DA-DUN-DA-DA! the trumpet blared.

"Now arriving, Princess Kelos of Grovan!" the butler announced at the top of his lungs. The crowd immediately turned to face the door. While Kelos couldn't make out anything specific, a murmur rose from the other guests. Clearly she was now the center of attention.

"Was that really necessary?" Kelos asked with a sigh.

"Sorry, King Arthras' personal orders," the maid said. "Good luck."

Kelos stepped through the doorway and looked around. The ballroom was elaborately, some might even say garishly decorated. There was already a decent crowd of people, though from the length of the list the maid had she guessed it wasn't even half the total number of guests. She briefly considered how she was going to get through the night.
1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.title: The time for the ball finally comes.

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
There was no sense in trying to hide, Kelos reasoned. After all, her plan to dance with Fia would make some waves too. She took a deep breath, faced the crowded ballroom, smiled, and curtsied, then walked in. Man, woman, prince, princess, either way she was Grovan royalty and would face this with her head held high. She looked around for people she knew, and spotted a few, all of whom were staring in disbelief. She was about to approach the closest to her, when someone else had beaten her to the punch.

"Cousin Kelos? Is that really you?" a young woman's voice called out. Kelos turned and looked over the girl. She looked familiar somehow. Cousin? Then Kelos realized who this was.

"Camille?" Kelos replied. She looked over her younger cousin, eldest daughter of her father's younger sister, they had played together quite often when there were little. However, it had been years since they saw each other, as her father was Duke of Albio, which while official neutral, was close to Traevan, and had been distancing itself from Grovan even prior to the war. "I didn't recognize you at first. You were only a little girl when I saw you last, and now you've grown into such a beautiful woman."

"Thanks," Camille replied. "Umm, so have you, which is kind of... strange since you were a boy."

"Yes, I had a little magical mishap on my way here and was transformed into a woman," Kelos replied.

"I-is it permanent?" Camille asked.

"I've been assured it's temporary," Kelos replied.

"Too bad," a woman said as she approached the two. "You make a better woman than you did a man."

"Countess Therese," Kelos said. "It's been a while."

"Not long enough, Princess," Therese replied. "But I must say, your new form suits you. You certainly lacked balls when you were a man."

"I see you still have your charming way with words," Kelos replied.

"Who is she?" Camille asked.

"We were engaged to be married," Therese said. "But then you left me for a chance at that bitch Fia!"

"We were not engaged," Kelos corrected. "Mother and father turned down your family's request."

"You could have said yes," Therese retorted.

"I could have, but my heart has always belonged to Fia." Kelos said.

"Well it doesn't look like that will be happening now, Princess," Therese said. "I do hope you'll find a nice husband and learn what a real man is like."

"Now, now," Camille said, trying to defuse the tension. "Why don't we put the past behind us and enjoy the ball?"

"Oh, I already am," Therese said. With that she turned and walked away.

"Well she's as pleasant as ever," Kelos said.

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
"So," Camille said. "Since you're a woman now, do you have your eye on any of the guys here?"

"Not a chance," Kelos replied curtly.

"That's no fun," Camille said. "You're a woman, so you should take this chance to experience a wonderful romance!"

"Only temporarily," Kelos stated.

"But think of it!" Camille insisted. "A handsome prince from a far off kingdom. At first your hesitant, but then you get lost in his eyes that hide so much mystery. You start dancing and get swept off your feet. The two of you kiss on the balcony just as the ball ends and promise to see each other again. But alas, it's not to be, he's called off to war, and dies on the battlefield defending his kingdom..."

"Is that a plot to a play?" Kelos asked, interrupting.

"Oh, uhh... maybe it's something I've been writing..." Camille admitted sheepishly. "But wouldn't it be incredible if it actually happened?!"

"It would be absolutely selfish of me to steal your fantasy," Kelos replied sarcastically. "If I find a handsome prince trying to sweep me off my feet, I'll refer him to you."

"Oh that reminds me," Camille replied. "You were once a guy, so do you have any inside information about anyone here? Like let's say you were stuck as a woman and absolutely had to marry someone here, who'd make the best husband?" She looked at Kelos with wide eyes, eager for whatever information she had.

"I don't know everyone here," Kelos said. "And a lot of the people I do know, it's only by reputation."

"There's gotta be something" Camille said, practically begging.

"Fine," Kelos said. She looked around. While it was true she didn't know everyone here, she had met quite a few. Most nobles had stories about their eccentricities spread. Of course many were false, but every so often one was true. She looked around at the growing crowd. In her head she recalled what she had heard about them, and rejected each in turn as a recommendation for her cousin. "Ah, that guy," she said after a few moments, gesturing to a rather handsome man who was chatting with a group of women, who were hanging on his words. "Prince Bosley of Cresselfurd. He's charming, intelligent, and as far as I know a decent person."

"Those other women seem fixated on him," Camille said as she watched the women laughing at whatever he was telling them.

"He's probably my main competition here," Kelos said. "I'll introduce you." Kelos took her cousin's hand and began to pull her over. "Once you get him to fall for you, it'll be one less suitor for Fia.

"Wait!" Camille exclaimed. "We can't just go over like that! What about those other women? Besides he won't recognize you!"

"Sure we can, and I'm sure he's seen stranger things than a man turning into a woman," Kelos said. "Trust me, he'll tell you all about them too. If there's one flaw he's got, he likes telling stories a bit too much." Kelos dragged her hesitant cousin across the ballroom to the prince.

"And so there I was, still hung over, and woke up surrounded by trolls," Bosley said as Kelos and Camille walked up. "The biggest one, he looked to be their leader., he stepped forward and was like Now human we shall take your life. So I said to him,"

"Just as long as you don't take my liquor!" Kelos interrupted, completing the Prince's story.

Bosley looked over at her. "I'd think I'd remember telling someone as lovely as you this story before."

"You didn't tell me, I was there," Kelos said. "Then the troll took your liquor and drank the whole bottle."

"Yes, he shouldn't have done that," Bosley continued. He turned back to the women he was talking to. "If you ladies remember, I said one sip got me drunker than I'd ever been in my life. Well trolls can't normally get drunk, but this bottle, it was the nectar of the gods. Wouldn't you know it, the troll got drunk and he was one of those sobbing drunks. My companions and I spend the next few hours listening to this troll tell us all his problems. Then he passed out, and the other trolls just sort of wandered off." He then looked back at Kelos. "Speaking of my companions, I don't recall a beautiful princess on that hunting trip."

"That's because I wasn't one at the time. I'm Kelos, I had an unfortunate magical accident and have become a woman," the transformed prince explained. The women listening to Bosley giggled at this news.

"Well I can't say I mind the change," Bosley replied as he looked over Kelos' figure. "Much easier on my eyes. But I'll bet the ladies are disappointed."

"No doubt," Kelos replied. "I wanted to introduce you to someone though." She pulled her Camille up front. "This is my cousin, Lady Camille, daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Albio."

"It's a pleasure to meet you, Lady Camille," Bosley said, taking her hand and kissing it.

"Oh, no the pleasure is all mine," Camille replied, her face turning a deep crimson. The women glared at Camille, who didn't seem to notice them as she gazed into the Prince's soft, brown eyes.

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
"Say, Bos, remember the party after that? You must have danced with every girl in the town," Kelos said, trying to shift the conversation to dancing. She was pretty sure Prince Bosley would dance with Camille if she asked him to, but it felt better to try to set the mood so he'd ask.

"Only half," Bosley replied. "I saved the rest for the rest of you."

"Bossie, honey," one of the women said. "I'd just love to see you dance."

"Me too," one of the others said.

Camille fidgeted nervously, not sure she could compete with the women hanging on the prince.

"Camille here is a terrific dancer too," Kelos said. The women glared at Kelos.

"Oh umm... I'm not really great," Camille said.

"She's just afraid of putting everyone else to shame," Kelos said.

"Bossie, you shouldn't waste your time on a little girl like that," one of the women said. The others giggled at this remark.

"Ladies, please," Bosley said. "It's a long night, I'll have time to dance with all of you. I'm formally asking all of you girls for your first dance."

"O-Of course!" Camille exclaimed. The other women also quickly agreed.

"Great," Kelos said. "Now if you'll excuse me..."

"That includes you, Kelos," Bosley said. "May I have your first dance, Princess?"

"Seriously?" Kelos replied. "You know I'm really a guy."

"Not at the moment," Bosley said. "Besides, would you rather it be someone you know, or some strange man who wants to make you his wife?"

"You raise a good point," Kelos admitted. "However, I have already promised my first dance to someone else."

"Huh, already embracing your feminine side?" Bosley replied. "Who's the lucky guy?"

"Fia," Kelos said.

"But you're both girls!" Camille exclaimed.

"Yes, and?" Kelos replied.

"You two are going to be the talk of the night," Bosley said with a hearty laugh. "Fine, may I have your second dance?"

"That one's taken as well," a man called out from behind Kelos. Bosley and the women hanging on him looked up as Kelos and Camille turned. Standing there was none other than King Arthas.

"Oh, King Arthras," Kelos said. "I don't believe you've met my cousin, Lady Camille, daughter of the Duke of Albio."

Camille curtsied. "It's an honor to meet you, your majesty. On behalf of Albio I greet you and give thanks for the invitation tonight." Arthras nodded in acknowledgement.

"And this is my friend, Prince Bosley of Cresselfurd," Kelos said.

"Pleasure, your majesty," Bosley said. Again Arthras nodded.

"I had hoped for your first dance, my dear," Arthras said. "However, if you and Fia insist on this silliness, I shall allow you to dance together. But in exchange your second dance shall be mine."

"You're a popular woman," Bosley said teasingly. "I'll take your third dance then."
1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.title: Kelos tries to get Bosley to ask Camille to dance

The pendant cannot be removed.
1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
"Very well then, I accept," Kelos said. "Though Prince Bosley did ask first."

"Don't worry about it, Kel," Bosley said. "I'll spend the time with your cousin and these other fine ladies."

"Good, it's settled. I'll look forward to our dance, Princess," Arthras replied. He took Kelos' hand and kissed the back of it. "Now if you'll excuse me, Fia shall be making her appearance soon." The king started to walk away. However, he then stopped and turned around. "I almost forgot, I also have a gift for you." He pulled a pendant out of his pocket, presenting it to Kelos.

"It's so pretty," Camille said, as Kelos took the pendant from Arthras.

"Thank you, I suppose," Kelos said, holding it up by the golden chain. It was shaped like a crescent moon with a green stone held between the points. It seemed familiar to Kelos, as if she had seen it recently.

"Well, put it on, my dear," Arthras said expectantly.

"Let me help," Camille said.

Bosley approached Kelos from behind. "Kel, remember what I said about men who want to make you their wife?" he whispered.

"Don't worry, accepting this won't mean any obligation to marry me," Arthras said with a chuckle. "Just don't accept any rings, for doing so would be a binding vow of marriage."

"I shall remember that," Kelos said. "Still, I am not actually a woman, so accepting this gift seems somewhat odd. What would I do with it once I am returned to normal?"

"Then give it to Fia," Arthras said. "Or pass it down to a daughter."

"Perhaps," Kelos said as she looked over the pendant. She tried to place where she had seen it. Maybe it was the late queen's and she had seen it in a portrait? Regardless, there's no harm in accepting it, right? She turned to Camille and held it out. "Would you be so kind?"

"Of course," Camille said. She took the pendant and unclasped the chain. Kelos turned around as Camille placed the pendant around her cousin's neck, the clasped the chain. She let go, allowing it to hang naturally.

"It looks ravishing on you, Princess," Arthras said. "But if you'll excuse me, I must be off." He again kissed Kelos' hand and left in a hurry.

"You sure that was a good idea, Kel?" Bosley asked. "That pendant might be enchanted to keep you a woman."

"I can't deny that he would certainly like me to remain this way," Kelos said, facing Bosley. "But surely he's aware using magic to trap me in this form would result in continuing war. I believe he's attempting to convince me to stay like this willingly. Still, it is something to consider." Kelos turned to Camille. "Could you help me remove this pendant?"

"But you just put it on," Camille replied, confused.

"It's simply a test," Kelos said. "If it can be removed, it is likely not enchanted."

"Oh, sure," Camille said. Kelos turned so Camille could access the clasp.

1321211111113321211322312122111212211211.content:
Camille ran her fingers over the necklace's chain, only to find something missing. Something that was certainly there before. "Um, I'm not sure how, but the clasp is gone."

"That honorless curr!" Bosley exclaimed.

Kelos examined the pendant hanging around her neck. "I think I know what this is. How could I not have recognized it? If I'm right, it could be a problem."

"It's a magic necklace to keep you a woman after all?" Camille asked.

"It could have such an effect, but if it's the one I'm thinking of, it has another purpose," Kelos explained. "Rather than a curse, it was blessed. By a fertility goddess."

Kelos closed her eyes and focused on her male form. Short black hair, wide shoulders, strong pecs, well toned abs, muscular arms and legs. Truly a man among men. Yet no matter how Kelos focused, she retained her current form. "You're stopping me!" Kelos accused.

"I don't have the power to, Princess," Cyhir said. "I can create objects, I can show images, but your appearance here is a product of your own subconscious mind. This, deep down, is how you view yourself."

"Preposterous!" Kelos exclaimed. "Why would I view myself as a woman?"

"May I look through your memories?" the goddess asked.

"What for?" Kelos replied skeptically.

"Because the answer may be contained there," Cyhir said.

"More importantly why do you even care?" Kelos asked.

"I've taken a bit of an interest in you," Cyhir replied. "I want to know who Princess Kelos is deep inside."

"Fine," Kelos said. With that, the goddess held out her hand, and suddenly a flood of images nearly overwhelmed Kelos. All of the memories she had seemed to play at once. Meeting Princess Fia for the first time, graduating from the military academy, the first time eating solid foods, playing dress up with Orianna... Wait...

"There!" Cyhir said. The other memories faded away and Kelos saw her older sister's room. Everything seemed so big though. She felt a push and a familiar voice behind her.

"Let's see how you look in the mirror, Cally," Orianna said. Kelos then saw herself? Himself? as a child, wearing Orianna's old dress, with a wig on.

"I look so pretty!" Kelos heard herself say in her childhood voice. "Am I a princess now?"

"As long as you're wearing this dress you're Princess Cally," Orianna said.

"I'm starting to see where you got that image from," Cyhir said. The scene faded away, only for a new one to appear.

Kelos saw the hall in the Grovan palace race by. Things still seemed big, but not quite as big. Suddenly Kelos saw the door to Orianna's room. She then saw a young hand pound on it, and heard her voice call out, "Ori! Open up, it's an emergency!" The door opened, and Kelos saw it flash by, then the room spined and the young hand slammed the door shut and locked it. Before Orianna could even speak, Kelos heard her voice. "Ori, I need your help! I was looking around in the south tower for something interesting and I found a necklace and something about it made me want to put it on and I did and I... I turned into a girl!"

"I wanted to forget about that," Kelos sighed. "Ori helped me keep that transformation secret, but it took a long time to change back."

"Just how long did it take, Princess?" Cyhir asked.

"It was a few months," Kelos admitted. With that, the scene changed yet again. This time Kelos appeared about twelve, and was with two other boys. The three of them were wearing matching uniforms of the Grovan Academy of Military Arts, which Kelos attended for several years. The three of them were sneaking along a wall leading to the opening in a fence between their school and a neighboring girls academy at night.

"I'm still not convinced this is a good idea," young Kelos said. "But this way leads to the finishing school. Are you sure you want to do this?"

"Yes, I have to see her again, no matter what!" one of the other boys insisted. "The semester ends tomorrow, so I won't get a chance to see her for over a month!"

"What if we get caught?" the third boy asked.

"You'll be fine," Kelos said. "Just stay hidden here and hold our stuff." He handed him two vials containing a blue liquid. "Remember we absolutely need these to go back to the dorms."

"Right," the third boy said taking the vials.

Kelos then pulled out two pink vials and handed one to the second boy. "You and I need to drink up though."

"Are you sure this is safe?" the second boy asked.

"Perfectly," Kelos replied. "On three. One, two, three!" With that the two of them drank the pink liquid. A puff of smoke later and two girls wearing uniforms from the Finishing academy were standing in their place.

"It seems you willingly changed into a girl that time," Cyhir said.

"Yes, I suppose," Kelos said. She then let out a girlish giggle. "We did get caught, but the matron thought we were students there, so we were sent back to the girls dorm. Luckily we met Harman's love and she covered for us. Still, since the Military academy was on break but the finishing school didn't get one, we spent that time with the other girls."

"So another month as a girl?" Cyhir asked.

"I suppose," Kelos replied as the scene faded out.

"Just how many other times have you been a girl?" Cyhir asked.

"I try not to think about it too much," Kelos said.

"Well, it's clear where your image of yourself as a woman came from," Cyhir said. "You won't do after all."

"Do for what," Kelos asked.

"For my new champion," Cyhir said. "If you had overcome your cursed form and defeated Uwain, you would have demonstrated your strength and could take his place. However, I see you have become too much a woman for that."

"Given your cult's practices, I would not accept even if you had deemed me worthy," Kelos said.

"You would have had no choice in the matter, Princess," Cyhir replied. "But it seems I now need Uwain after all, despite his failure. I will now give you a choice. Tell the townsfolk to release my champion by sunset, or I shall order all of my remaining men to loot the town, and transform all its men into new women." With those words the dreamscape faded and Kelos found herself looking at her reflection in the window.

"Well, isn't that just lovely," Kelos said frowning.

"Princess?" Jaz asked.

"I have just been contacted by Cyhir, the goddess Uwain and his followers worship," Kelos explained. "Either Uwain is released by sunset, or his followers will attack the town and spare no man."

"What will we do, Princess?" Jax asked.

"We must tell Derron at once," Kelos answered. "This is his town, and his choice. Though I will certainly recommend..."

132121111111332221111222.content:
"...defending the town," Kelos finished. "Even if Uwain is released, he'll want revenge. The best case is things go back to the way they were, with bandits preying on the townspeople. It's a risk, but this is a chance to crush these bandits and rescue their prisoners once and for all." She then started heading in the direction Derron went. "Jax, with me, Sean, wait here for the mayor's assistant. Everyone else, survey the town, find buildings that can be fortified, routes that can be blocked off, and anything that will assist a defense."

"At once, Princess," the guards replied. Everyone hurried to their assigned duties.

"Again, where are you keeping my son?!" Derron shouted as he whipped the captured bandit with a thin branch fresh, leaving a red welt on his back.

"Oh, you'll see your daughter soon enough," Uwain replied. This earned him another lash.

"Mayor Derron, I must speak with you at once!" Kelos exclaimed as she pounded on the door to the interrogation room.

"Ah our little princess is here with some important news," Uwain said with a defiant tone in his voice.

"What is it, Princess?" Derron called out. "Not to be disrespectful, but I'm a bit busy here."

"Here it comes," Uwain said.

"The goddess the bandits worship, she came to me in a vision with an ultimatum," Kelos replied. "She wants Uwain released or all the remaining bandits will attack the town."

"I trust I'm free to go," Uwain said.

"We must reject this and make preparations to defend the town!" Kelos continued.

"I see," Derron said. "We'll finish this later." He then left the room, leaving Uwain restrained.

"You'll regret not releasing me!" Uwain called out as Derron closed the door and locked it behind him.

"Are you positive this was a vision and not simply a dream?" Derron asked.

"I am," Kelos replied.

"Very well," Derron said. "We shall rally every able bodied man."

"Women as well," Kelos said. "The women in this town may not have been training since they were little like I have, but they can still be useful, even if it's just as more eyes to spot bandits trying to flank the town."

"Understood," Derron replied. "I have not fought a battle, while you are the one who brought that bastard in, so I'll defer to your judgement. Though, as detestable as it would be to release him, I must ask why you rejected it outright."

"Because he would surely lead the bandits in either a revenge attack or increased raids," Kelos replied.

"Sound reasoning," Derron replied. "We shall make this town an invincible fortress!"

132121111111332222.content:
While Kelos was successful in stalemating Uwain, her guards were fighting a losing battle. While the bandits were no match for them one on one, they were making effective use of their greater numbers, striking, then retreating while another bandit took their place. The guards fought well, but in the end were defeated one by one.

"You've fought well, Princess, but look around you," an exhausted Uwain said. "Your bodyguards are defeated. Even if you best me, you cannot hope to defeat all of my men. If you surrender, we shall treat you well. After all, we wouldn't want to risk our ransom."

Kelos, likewise exhausted, cursed her current form. Had she her normal strength, this bandit would have been defeated as casually as the first one. If the guards had been able to hold the line for even a little bit longer, Kelos was certain she would have still gained the victory, likely demoralizing the rest as their leader fell. But that was not how events played out. "I suppose there's no choice," she said, gritting her teeth. "I surrender." She dropped her sword, and was instantly seized by two of the bandits, who quickly tied her hands behind her back.

"I give up too!" the scribe called out from in the carriage. He climbed out, and was quickly seized just as Kelos had been.

"I'm sorry, Princess, I failed you," Jex said sadly.

"We all failed today," Kelos said as the bandits dragged her group along. Kelos looked back at the carriage and saw more bandits climbing over it, taking the chests filled with gifts she had brought for Princess Fia and rounding up the horses. All except one, she noted. The transformed captain was nowhere to be found. "Perhaps there's still some hope," she thought. Though what exactly the captain could do as a horse was a question, surely she didn't simply run away. Kelos allowed that thought to sustain her as she and her men were brought to the bandit camp.

Once they arrived, the bandits threw the guards and the scribe into large metal cages, still bound. Kelos, on the other hand was treated somewhat better, being kept in a small wooden shack with a rickety cot and a small table and stool, with two of the stronger looking bandits standing guard outside. "Probably their royal suite," Kelos said sarcastically. Kelos looked around for weaknesses. "Maybe I could use a table leg as a club," she thought.

Just then there was a knock on the door. A woman appearing in her early thirties, wearing a simple and dirty cotton dress entered. She was missing an eye and had a number of scars on her face. Kelos looked her over and noticed some on her arms as well. She also noticed the woman was very pregnant. She was carrying a lavender ball gown and shoes, along with what appeared to be a corset and some other feminine undergarments. Kelos recognized it as one of the gowns she was to give to Princess Fia

"Master Uwain has invited you to join him for dinner, Princess," the woman said in a monotone voice.

"I would prefer to dine alone," Kelos replied. She noted the woman's tone. She seemed to be someone whose spirit was completely broken.

"Master Uwain is not giving you a choice," the woman replied in the same flat tone.

"I suppose not," Kelos replied. "You're speaking from experience there I assume."
132121111111332222.title: Kelos and her guards are captured by the bandits.

choices: Kelos allows Erwin to lead her to Uwain.
Kelos asks if she can speak with her men.
1321211111113322221.content:
"Very well, let's get this indignity over with," Kelos said.

The woman placed the clothing she was carrying on the cot and helped Kelos remove her armor. She did not say anything.

"So, what's your name?" Kelos asked.

"Erwin, Princess," the woman replied.

"Isn't that a man's... oh," Kelos said, realizing the implications of Erwin's name.

"You are correct, Princess," Erwin replied. "If the ransom is not paid in time, your guards shall share my fate." She rested her hand on her pregnant belly. "As will you. Women who are captured and are not ransomed will be used as breeding stock. Men will be transformed into women and used as breeding stock." she spoke in the same monotone voice.

Kelos shuddered at this revelation. "How horrible," she said with a gasp. "Have you tried to escape?"

"Escape is impossible once you have been marked," Erwin said. She lifted her dress to reveal her butt. On it was a brand, a complex pattern that seemed to be shifting as one looked at it. "Even if you leave, with this, you can be returned here at a whim. She put her hand on her missing eye. "Escape attempts will then be punished."

"What monsters!" Kelos exclaimed. She heard snickering outside. The bandits guarding her were apparently amused at Kelos' reactions to this news. "Surely Treaven cannot allow this to occur on their soil! Have they not sent soldiers?"

"They have," Erwin replied. "I was the knight in charge of tracking down Master Uwain. Now, I bear his child."

Kelos did not reply to this. The two women remained silent as Erwin finished undressing Kelos and helped her put on the provided clothing. Kelos stood there naked for a moment, taking the opportunity to examine her body. While she had never seen naked breasts from this angle, she could tell they were perfectly proportioned. Her waist was slim, her stomach firm, and her hips flared out seductively. A perfect female body, save one thing, it should be male.

Erwin then helped Kelos get dressed. First came the corset, which, despite the tightness was not all together uncomfortable. Then came a pair of stockings, that were held in place by garter straps from the bottom of the corset. Next came a pair of panties which Kelos slid on over the straps. Kelos then put on the gown and slipped her arms into the sleeves, after which Erwin fastened the buttons on the back. Finally, Kelos stepped into the matching pair of heels. Erwin directed Kelos to sit on the stool and began to pull her hair back and braid it.

Finally breaking the silence Kelos asked, "When is the baby due?"

"Within the month," Erwin replied.

"How do you feel about becoming a mother?" Kelos asked.

"You misunderstand," Erwin said. "I am breeding stock, not a mother. The boy will be taken from me and I shall be milked like a cow for the next 6 months, after which I shall be impregnated again. I will never see him. Even when he is born I shall be blindfolded."

"It seems I was mistaken. I apparently owe monsters an apology for sullying them by comparing them to our captors," Kelos replied.

Erwin finished braiding Kelos' hair. "You are now ready for dinner, Princess," she said. "Do enjoy your meal."

"I do not think that likely," Kelos replied. She leaned over and whispered in Erwin's ear. "I'll come back and free you, I promise. Even if it takes the entire Grovan army."

"If you try, you shall join me," Erwin said. Not once in their conversation did her monotone voice change inflection.

choices: Kelos thanks him and allows him to kiss her hand.
Kelos slaps his hand away and insults him.
13212111111133222211.content:
"Lead on to our captor," Kelos said with disgust in her voice. She had in her time seen some rather terrible things, you don't get anywhere in Grovan without at least witnessing some "enhanced interrogation" of prisoners or an occasional raid on enemy civilians. Taking an important prisoner and ransoming them was a known tactic as well. Still, there were rules to this sort of thing. What Erwin described was certainly well beyond that. Kelos thought about the scars she saw on Erwin's body and wondered how many more were hidden under that dress. Probably quite a number, she thought, enough to break a proud knight into someone who didn't even seem to react to the thought of being treated like a farm animal, to have completely given up hope.

"This way, Princess," Erwin replied. She left the shack, with Kelos following. The two bandits standing outside followed just behind as they passed.

"Of course," Kelos thought noting this. She also noted their new swords, clearly taken from her men. However, she didn't have time to dwell on this. The short heels on her boots had not been a challenge, but she was currently wearing 5 inch heels, and keeping her balance was proving difficult and demanded her concentration. She nearly fell a few times, but quickly adapted by taking smaller steps and swinging her hips more as she walked. This also caused her dress to brush up against her stockings more, a strange sensation Kelos found herself enjoying despite her best efforts.

"We're here, Princess," Erwin said as they arrived at a large log cabin.

"Thank you," Kelos replied. She approached the door and prepared to knock, but stopped herself as she heard some voices inside.

"I'm the high priest of Cyhir," one voice said. "I've studied the texts more than anyone. The prophecy clearly warns about a scarlet haired woman."

"There are lots of red heads," the other voice, which Kelos recognized as Uwain, replied.

"True, but this Princess is trouble. She beat you," the other voice said.

"She surrendered," Uwain stated.

"Because the others defeated her guards and she didn't have a choice. Look, if you're not going to listen to my warnings as priest, then listen to me as your friend, be careful around her," the other voice said.

"I do appreciate your concern, but she's just a woman," Uwain replied. "Who will make us very rich. Now if you'll excuse me, she'll be here soon."

Kelos decided this was a good time, knocked, then immediately entered. "Oh, I hope I interrupted something important," she said.

"Ah, speak of the devil," Uwain said. "Not at all, my dear, you're just a bit early. I'm somewhat surprised you didn't need to be dragged here by force." He was wearing one of Kelos' finer royal uniforms, one she had intended to wear to impress Princess Fia as Prince Kelos. She felt sick by the sight. "I must say you look ravishing in that dress." He approached Kelos, and took her hand, preparing to kiss the back of it, as Prince Kelos had done to many a fair maiden.
13212111111133222211.title: Kelos allows Erwin to lead her to Uwain.

Kelos orders tea instead.
132121111111332222111.content:
Kelos wanted more than anything to simply kill this disgusting excuse for a man, but choked back her sense of fury and a bit of bile. After all, she was unarmed, and outnumbered 4 to 1 here. Plus, the lives of herself and her men were at stake here. An opportunity would come later, for now she resigned herself to playing the role of a captured princess, and not do anything to provoke the captors. "Thank you," Kelos forced herself to say As Uwain bent over and kissed her hand.

"I'll leave you two now," the high priest said. Kelos looked him over. He was somewhat older than Uwain, his hair and beard spotted with grey, yet he still appeared quite fit. Wearing the same style of clothing as the other bandits, there was nothing to really mark him as a priest, high or otherwise.

"Oh, won't you stay and tell me more about that prophecy you mentioned?" Kelos asked, trying to sound innocent, but not quite succeeding.

The priest gave Uwain a look as if to say, "I told you so."

"He has priestly matters to attend to," Uwain said, gesturing to the priest to be on his way. The priest complied and continued out. The two guards who had escorted Kelos took up position flanking the door.

"A pity," Kelos said. She had hoped there would be some information she could use to help escape in the prophecy, but it seemed they were reluctant to share.

"The holy writings are not for the ears of outsiders," Uwain explained. "Only men born into the Sons of Cyhir are allowed to hear of them,"

"What of women born into your little club?" Kelos asked.

"A Son of Cyhir can only mate with a female marked by Cyhir, and a female so marked will birth only sons," Uwain explained. He looked over to Erwin."This one is carrying my son, for example. But let us not discuss such things. Come, sit." He walked over to a table in the middle of the room, pulled a chair out and gestured for Kelos to sit down. Kelos walked over and sat in the chair, doing her best to mimic how she had seen women sit at dinners, keeping her legs together and brushing her hand under the dress. Urwain pushed the chair in.

"Are my men being given food?" Kelos asked.

"There will be plenty of time to discuss their fate," Uwain said. He then turned to Ewrin. "Get me rum!" He then looked at Kelos. "And you, my dear?"

Kelos pondered this for a second. Was asking for rum just his uncouthness, or was it perhaps meant as a challenge, a drinking match to regain some pride from their earlier battle? In either case, perhaps it would be wise to avoid drinking alcohol, then exploit his eventual drunkenness?
132121111111332222111.title: Kelos thanks him and allows him to kiss her hand.

choices: Kelos plays along hoping to use this game to turn things in her favor.
Kelos tries to talk Uwain out of this madness.
1321211111113322221112.content:
I'll have tea," Kelos said. "Earl Grey, hot."

"She was an Earl?" Uwain asked, not being familiar with tea. "I should have ransomed her off instead of marking her then."

"It's a type of tea," Kelos said with a sigh. "One I know you have, because you took the box I had as a gift for Princess Fia, along with everything else in my carriage." She glared at Uwain.

"I like to think of it as redistribution of wealth," Uwain said with a chuckle. He then turned to Erwin. "Go get us our drinks," he ordered.

"Wait, shouldn't someone else bring them," Kelos asked. "Erwin is due to give birth soon, she should rest."

"She's a slave, not a princess, my dear," Uwain replied turning back to Kelos. "She'll work until she's in labor. She should be grateful she's not shoveling horse shit." He then turned back to Erwin. "Get going, woman."

"Yes sir," Erwin said in her same monotone voice. She turned and left the cabin.

"You don't have to worry your pretty little head over her," Uwain said. "She's tough. Now then, while we're waiting, I've arranged some entertainment." Uwain nodded to one of the guards. The guard returned the nod, then banged on the door. It was opened from the outside, and several more guards led Kelos' men into the cabin. They were stripped to their underwear and in chains, blindfolded and gagged.

"What is the meaning of this?!" Kelos shouted in anger.

"We're going to have a little game, princess," Uwain said. "One of your men will be marked tonight, the game will determine which."

"What sort of game?" Kelos asked, looking over at her men. They were obviously uncomfortable, but their lack of reaction to 'will be marked' told Kelos they were likely unaware of the meaning of this.

"Simple, dear girl," Uwain said smugly. "You'll propose a series of challenges for your men. The first one to fail to complete a challenge will be marked."

Kelos was enraged by Uwain's attempt to humiliate her men. "What if I refuse?" she asked.

"Then they shall all be marked," Uwain said. "Also, if I find your challenges to be less than fully entertaining, or stalling for time, I will issue my own." he grinned wickedly.

"What sort of challenges?" Kelos asked.

"That's where the fun comes in," Uwain said. "My men will take turns giving you a category for your challenge. Every time a category is picked, the challenge in it must be harder than the last."

Kelos looked back over to her men thinking about what to do.

"I have an idea," Kelos said. "We can send a messenger ahead saying we were delayed when we stopped to help some travelers who were attacked by brigands. A family returning to their home village. The bandits kidnapped the young daughter, so being the dashing prince I am, I tracked them down and rescued the fair maiden."

"That is a believable story, your highness," the scribe replied. "However, will they not investigate a report of such wanton banditry in their own kingdom? Plus, given your... condition, it seems to be tempting fate. The captain is currently indisposed, and while I'm sure your skill with a blade remains, that body lacks the physical strength of your rugged male form. Plus, we would be sending a guard ahead. If we were actually attacked..."

"I may not be as strong as I was, but I am still more than a match for any brigand, and I personally selected every guard here. I have no doubts about their ability," Kelos replied confidently. "I further doubt the king will be so concerned about a resolved bandit problem, but we shall say it happened outside Traeven's territory to be sure."

"Very well, your highness," the scribe said. "Though how shall we explain things to the men? The captain did not react well and is now a chalice, well the water in the chalice to be precise, for his disbelief. They might believe you to be a witch."

"That man is a capable fighter and good commander in battle, but he always was a bit stubborn and overzealous," Kelos replied with a sigh. "Say... can he hear us like that?"

"Yes, the scroll was intended to allow one to spy on important meetings," the scribe replied. "He can see as well."

"I see," Kelos replied. She picked up the captain. "Well, I suppose both of us learned an important lesson about playing with magic today." She placed him down on the seat opposite her then turned back to the scribe. "I believe it would be best to tell the men..."

"the truth. Otherwise I would need to hide in the carriage until I return to normal. I can deal with being a woman for a time, but I will not cower away!" Kelos stated.

"But is that not what you are... Oww!"

"It most certainly is not," Kelos interrupted, fist ready for another strike. "I simply realize the importance of a first impression. It would be scandalous for the man trying to claim Princess Fia's hand to arrive as a woman!"

"She simply hasn't had the honor of a suitor as handsome and manly as me," Kelos said, brushing a curl of hair to the side.

The scribe refrained from commenting on the beautiful young woman before him referring to herself as manly while playing with her hair. "Of course, your highness."

"If they don't believe me? the scribe asked.

"We still have some scrolls left, if they don't believe you, you shall demonstrate one," Kelos said. "So I suggest you be convincing."

"Yes your highness," the scribe replied. "Though if I may be so bold as to make a suggestion, you are still wearing your uniform, it doesn't suit your current form."

Kelos sighed and looked down at her painfully feminine form, still wearing her now ill fitting male clothes. "Nor will anything else I brought with me," Kelos replied, frowning at the scribe.

"Perhaps, but we have brought many gifts for Princess Fia. I believe this includes some clothing that might be more appropriate."

"Are you saying I should wear a dress?! And one intended as a gift for Princess Fia at that?!" Kelos shouted angrily.

Kelos again looked down at herself. The scribe was correct about one thing, these clothes did not suit her at the moment. From her boots being too large for her now dainty feet, her pant legs being too long threatening to trip her as she walked. Still, wearing a dress? Surely that would not be much better, would it?

1321211111121121.content:
"It's only for a day," Kelos thought to herself. "As a member of the royal family, I do have a duty to maintain my appearance and as of now I must admit I look ridiculous." She sighed, and slid across to the door of the carriage. She moved to stand up, but her now shorter legs didn't quite reach the ground, resulting in her boot partially slipping off. Kelos landed awkwardly and stumbled to the ground. "Blast this spell!" she exclaimed.

"Your highness!" a guard called out. "Are you alright? The scribe told us what happened, but we could hardly believe it." He offered Kelos a hand.

"I'm fine, you simpleton!" Kelos snapped, swatting the hand away. "I have not become addled, I'm just not used to my new height." She pushed her over sized boot back on her foot then carefully stood up and brushed herself off and took a deep breath. "Bring me the chest with the dresses intended for Princess Fia. It's shameful, but my current clothes are inadequate for my current form."

"Your highness," the scribe called out from behind. "I have dispatched the messenger to Castle Traeven, and informed the men of the situation. They were a bit incredulous, but I was able to convince them."

"Finally something gone right," Kelos said. "Given how the day's been going, I'm surprised. But the men must be sworn to secrecy. None of this indignity can get back home"

"Of course, your highness," the scribe agreed. "I must say I'm a bit surprised myself. I was worried I'd need to demonstrate a scroll."

"Perhaps you should anyway," Kelos replied.

"Your highness, I brought the chest," the guard called out. He carried a rolled up tarp and led two other guards who each held one side of a massive chest. The first guard laid the tarp out on the ground, and the other two placed the chest on it.

"Good thinking there," Kelos said. She walked over to the chest carefully, making sure she avoided tripping again. As she approached, one of the guards opened it, revealing dresses, shoes, and feminine undergarments, made by the finest seamstresses and cordwainers in Grovan.

"I see you decided to take my advice," the scribe said.

"Be quiet!" Kelos scolded. She grabbed a green dress, matching shoes, white panties, and a white brassiere. "I wish there was a place I could clean up though."

"There's a stream nearby," the guard who opened the chest said pointing into the forest alongside the road. "I saw it when I looked around after we stopped. It's hidden behind the bushes, but if you need help, we'll be able to hear you."

"That will do," Kelos replied. "If I run into trouble, I'll call for help." She headed off into the forest. Sure enough, after clearing the bushes, not 30 feet from the carriage was a stream which seemed to run parallel to the road. Kelos took off her rapier, leaning it against a tree, stripped off her ill fitting male clothes, and cleaned her body with the cool water from the stream. She tried to avoid thinking about her thin, girlish figure and modest breasts. "It's just for a day," she told herself. She then slipped on the panties and brassiere, struggling a bit with the latter. After a few minutes, she managed to fasten it. She then turned to the dress, noticing it fastened in the back. She undid the lowest buttons near the narrow waist, then slipped the dress over her head, rather than undo them all and step into it, as she recognized was proper. She then reached behind and fastened the buttons she could reach. "Why do they put these in the back anyway," she sighed. Finally Kelos stepped into the shoes. While none of it was a perfect fit, it was at least passable. She went to gather up her discarded male clothes, when she heard a rustling in the bushes on the far side of the stream. "Who's there?!" Kelos called out, as she quickly grabbed her sword and drew it, facing the direction of the noise.

Out of the bushes stepped...

At Kelos' challenge, a knight stepped out from the bushes, and removed his helmet, revealing his long blond hair and a ruggedly handsome face. "I apologize m'lady," the knight said. "I assure you I did not intend to view you in a state of undress. I was searching for a prisoner who escaped my custody."

Kelos attempted to reply, but found she could not speak or move. In her head she heard a woman's voice say a single word, "fool." Against her will, Kelos' body lowered the sword and adopted a more feminine stance. "A knight as handsome as you would surely have no need to spy on a young women, so I must conclude you are being honest," Kelos found her body saying on its own. "Is this ruffian dangerous?" Kelos struggled to regain control but to no avail. "What the hell is this?!!" Kelos thought. The woman's voice replied, "This is your own fault, you stupid prince, now be quiet so I can find out that's going on!"

"Quite dangerous," the knight replied. "This was no mere bandit, but a dragon."

"Oh my, a dragon?!" Kelos' body replied. "You're the dragon aren't you?!" Kelos thought. "Get out of my body!" "Yes, because dragons are renowned for their possession abilities," the woman's voice replied sarcastically. "Now would you please SHUT UP!"

"Yes, she's young, but quite powerful," the knight replied. "I was able to slay her mother, but this one proved difficult. I was able to catch her using a transformation arrow provided by Marlin, the court wizard at my castle which trapped her in the form of a human girl, and a collar that sealed her magic. However, she was able to trick one of my men into removing the collar, killed him, and escaped."

"How terrible!" Kelos' body exclaimed. "What's terrible is you possessing me!" Kelos thought. This time the woman's voice ignored Kelos and continued addressing the knight. "But are you not taking a risk approaching me? Could I not be the dragon laying a trap?"

"As I said, the dragon is trapped in her current form. She cannot perform such tricks at the present," the knight explained. "But I forget my manners." The knight approached Kelos, took her right hand and kissed the back of it. Kelos was disgusted by this act, yet the one controlling his body swooned. "I am Sir Dioral of Traeven, my lovely rose."

"I am Prince Kelos," Kelos' body replied, to Kelos' shock. "What are you doing?!!" Kelos shouted in his mind. "If you had just been quiet," the woman's voice replied then continued to address Dioral. "Though at the moment Princess would be more accurate." "STOP!!!" Kelos thought, but the woman continued. "I am suffering from the effects of a curse brought about by my own foolishness. Though, unfortunately it is but temporary. Not that I shall think it unfortunate once I return to normal."

Dioral was taken back by the frank and unexpected reply. "So you're a guy?" he asked.

"At present I am a woman in mind and body," Kelos' body replied. "It's a shame that mannish brute I was will return tomorrow." Kelos was furious at this. "GIVE ME BACK MY BODY!!!"

"I see," Dioral replied.

Suddenly, in the corner of Kelos' eye, he noticed something shine in the bushes behind Dioral. The thing controlling his body was focused on the knight and didnt' seem to notice, but apparently while Kelos couldn't move or speak, he was not stuck looking at the center of the body hijacker's attention.

132121111112112111.content:
"There's something in the bushes!" Kelos called out in his mind. The thing controlling his body shifted attention away from the knight in time to see shining light from a spell about to be released. "Behind you, Sir Dioral!" Kelos' body called out.

Dioral spun around just as the magic spell was released. Instinctively, he dove to the side, landing in the water as the spell flew past him.

A young girl emerged from the bush. She appeared about 8 or 9, dirty and covered with scrapes. She was wearing a plain brown linen commoner's dress that had quite a few rips, some of them with what looked like dried blood and no shoes. Her long black hair was a tangled mess with sticks and leaves caught in it. Her ears were covered in dark green scales. Clearly, this was the dragon. "That spell would have made him my loyal servant!" she pouted. "I guess I should have dealt with you first, woman." She pointed at Kelos as a ball of light formed on her finger.

"I'll give you control back temporarily," the voice in Kelos' head said. Suddenly Kelos found his currently female body responsive again. Without a moment's hesitation, Kelos charged the young girl. She thrust with her sword, hoping to run the dragon girl through with the initial strike followed on my the momentum of the charge. However, Kelos did not consider the shorter length of her feminine arms, resulting in the attack being delivered too soon. The dragon dodged to the side. Still, Kelos' attack managed to nick the dragon's arm, causing her to wince in pain and the spell to fizzle.

Kelos passed to the side of the dragon and struck her from behind with the hilt of her sword. The dragon grabbed on to Kelos' dress as she began to fall from the blow. A crackling filled the air as the dragon cast a lightning spell. "AHHHH!!!" Kelos screamed as electricity flowed through her. "DIE, HUMAN BITCH!" The dragon shouted. Dioral, back on his feet stabbed the dragon with his sword. The dragon screamed in pain, but the lightning from Kelos jumped to the metal sword conducting the electricity right To Dioral. "Mmmg," he grunted as he pulled back. Despite the pain she was in, Kelos took note of what happened with Dioral, and stabbed the dragon. As expected, the electricity conducted right into the dragon. Again the dragon screamed, this time stopping her lightning spell and pulling back. Kelos slumped to her knees, jabbing her sword into the ground and leaning on it, stopping her from completely collapsing. "That was somewhat disappointing," the voice in Kelos' head commented. "Shut up," Kelos replied weakly.

Dioral charged the dragon, who leapt to the side and attempted to cast another lightning spell. Dioral quickly stabbed into the ground with his sword, then used it to throw some mud in the dragon's face. Blinded by the mud, the dragon missed Dioral with the lightning spell, striking a tree and starting a fire. She pulled back, wiping the mud out of her eyes. With that, Kelos' guards burst in to the scene. Seeing she was now greatly outnumbered by fresh soldiers, the dragon attempted to retreat, passing the wounded Kelos.

1321211111121121112.content:
Kelos reacted as quickly as her wounded body would let her, trying to grab the dragon. However, her legs gave out, and she toppled over. In her fall she grabbed at the dragon's dress, causing her to fall as well. In an instant, Dioral and Kelos' guards were there. the guards restrained the dragon long enough for Dioral to put the magic blocking collar back on her.

"NOOO! My magic!!!" the young dragon exclaimed as Dioral and one of the guards firmly held her by the shoulders. The young, though still formidable dragon had now been rendered as harmless as a typical human girl. "I'll get you for this!" the dragon said, turning and glaring at Kelos.

"I'll be ready," Kelos said, smiling before blacking out. After a period of time, Kelos opened her eyes, and saw nothing but blackness. Looking down, Kelos saw not her current feminine body, but his original male form. However, despite the blackness around him, his body looked as if it were daylight out. Before he could say anything, the blackness was replaced with a blue sky and a field of flowers. Looking around, Kelos saw the familiar sight of Grovan's flower garden. "I'm back home?" he wondered aloud.

"Not quite," a familiar woman's voice called out from behind.

Kelos spun around, to see a beautiful blonde haired woman wearing the green dress Kelos had put on. "Princess Fia?" he asked, recognizing her.

"Again, not quite," the woman said as she walked towards Kelos. "We're in your mind. I'm.."

"You're the one controlling my body!" Kelos exclaimed, taking a step back.

"That's right," the woman said. "I'm a spell intended to make sure your new bride was loyal to Grovan. However, you decided to wear me instead, Princess Kelos."

"I'm not a princess!" Kelos replied.

"Really? You could have fooled me," the woman said. She waved her arm and a large full length mirror, which showed Kelos, again a woman, wearing the same dress.

"How did you do that?" Kelos exclaimed, looking down at her body and seeing that she had indeed become a woman.

"Like I said, we're in your mind," the woman said. "Things here are malleable in ways the real world isn't." The scenery changed yet again. The two of them were standing on a balcony overlooking the throne room in Grovan. Kelos' parents were sitting on their thrones, and Kelos saw herself, as a 14 year old boy approach the throne then bow and kneel. "Remember this?"

"Yes, it's when my father summoned me to tel me my application to the military academy was accepted," Kelos replied.

"Are you sure?" the woman asked with a giggle. The scene began to replay, only this time, instead of Kelos as a young boy, a young girl walked towards the throne.

"Yes, of course I'm sure," Kelos replied. "I remember it clearly, my mother summoned me to tell me I was being sent to finishing school... Wait, that's not right! It was something else!"

"Like I said, things here are malleable," the woman replied. Suddenly, they were back in the flower garden.

Kelos focused and again she was back to her male self. "So I see. Though I still remember being a girl there."

"Of course, since I changed your memory, you can't change it back without knowing what the original is," the woman said. "I'll consider changing it back for you."

Kelos scowled at her. "So what do you want?" he asked.

"I want to live," she said. "I'm in a fairly bad situation here. I was intended for Princess Fia, so you and I aren't fully compatible. If we were, I'd have fully replaced you, while absorbing all your memories."

"That's terrible," Kelos said. "If Fia had worn that dress, you'd have killed her and taken her body?!"

"In a manor of speaking," the woman said. "No one would ever know though."

"Who's idea was this?!" Kelos asked angerly.

"Is that the thing you should really be most concerned about, Princess?" the woman asked.

Kelos looked down and again found herself a woman. She frowned, focused, then turned back into a man. "So what happens now?" he asked. "Am I going to share my body with you forever?"

"That's a possibility," the woman said. "Though there are several others, Princess." She frowned as Kelos remained a man.

"You can't change me if I'm actively focusing on being a male, can you?" Kelos asked.

"Apparently not," the woman said. "Anyway, there are some more possibilities. I replace you and take over your body, you replace me and I die, or we merge and become one being. Needless to say, I'm not found of the last two."

"I'm not found of any of them," Kelos replied. He thought for a minute. "Perhaps there's a way to remove you from my body. I've heard of souls being trapped in objects, something like that could be possible."

"Are you proposing we cooperate?" the woman asked.

"I am," Kelos replied. "We can ask Traeven's wizard for help."

"I suppose that would be acceptable," the woman said. "But if he can't help, I have every intention of taking your body for my own."

"I suppose it's fair enough," Kelos said. "But I won't let you succeed... err what's your name?"

"I don't have one," the woman said. "But I suppose you can call me Kelia."

"Kelia?" Kelos asked.

"I'm a spell intended to take over Princess Fia who ended up in Princess Kelos' body, so Kelia." she explained.

"That makes sense, except for one thing, I'm not a princess," Kelos replied.

"We'll see when we wake up," Kelia said. With that the world seemed to fade, as Kelos began to wake up.

Kelos moaned weakly and slowly opened her eyes. Her entire body ached, and her mind felt foggy. She looked around the room, yes she was in a room, not her carriage. It seemed lavishly decorated, but looked unfamiliar to her. She concluded she probably wasn't back home. Likely this was a guest room in Castle Traeven. Her right hand felt warm, as if someone was holding it. She slowly turned her head and saw a blonde haired woman.

You have both mine and my father's gratitude for recapturing her."

132121111112112111211.content:
"I've been possessed," Kelos explianed. "The dress I picked to wear had a curse, intended for you. A spell that would take over your body and life. If I had given this dress to you, and you had worn it, you would have been essentially killed and replaced, and no one would be the wiser."

"How terrible!" Fia exclaimed. "How could you do such a thing?!!"

"If I had known about it, I wouldn't have worn this dress," Kelos replied. "I apologize for this underhanded action by my kingdom. I swear I shall find the person responsible and deliver swift punishment."

"Tell me why I shouldn't just have my father make you a woman permanently!" Fia yelled, her eyes seemingly burning in rage.

"Because then the war between our kingdoms would never end, and the ones responsible will only gain more influence in Grovan's court," Kelos replied, remaining as calm as she could. "Again, I knew nothing of this, but I would also suggest the possibility that those responsible have placed similar spells on some of the other gifts I brought for you. All of them should be examined carefully before you accept them."

Fia huffed, still angry, but acknowledging Kelos was probably telling the truth. "So you said you were possessed." she said coldly.

"Yes, by the spell I told you about," Kelos explained. "It was crafted for you, and has so far proven able to control my body, but not replace my mind. Right now we're sharing this body."

"So you want Marlin's help to remove the spell?" Fia said.

Kelos' posture shifted and became more feminine as Kelia took control. "Close, but not quite, Princess." she said. "Princess Kelos and I wish to be separated into our own bodies." Kelia reached up and felt Fia's cheek. "It's a shame I didn't get the body I was made for, it's quite lovely. Though I suppose this form is suitable. Pity it's only temporary."

"Damn it, did you have to take over now!," Kelos thought.

"Hush, girl," Kelia replied mentally. "I simply wish to make sure there's no misunderstanding that would result in me dying."

"You're the spell Kelos was talking about," Fia said.

"My what an observant young lady you are," Kelia said. "You may address me as Princess Kelia."

"Oh? And just what makes you a princess?" Fia asked condescendingly. "Why you're little different than a demon."

"I suppose that is one way to see things," Kelia said. "But as I was born of Princess Kelos wearing that dress, I like to think of her as my mother, and as the daughter of a princess, I too am a princess."

"Mother?!!" Kelos fumed mentally.

"Whatever," Fia replied dismissively. "So, what have you done with Kelos?"

"Oh, she's still here, and quite angry at the moment. Seems she doesn't like being called a mother. Perhaps it makes her feel old?" Kelia snarked.

"Perhaps not," Kelia agreed. "But I do digress. We wish to speak to Marlin in hopes he will give me my own body. Ideally a copy of yours, secondly a copy of this one, but I would be willing to settle for any body that is both human and female."

"Then I shall attempt to keep Princess Kelos' body, and keep it as a Princess." Kelia said.

"So Kelos is essentially a hostage here?" Fia asked.

"I suppose you could say that," Kelia said. With that her body language became less feminine as Kelos again regained control.

"So there you have it," Kelos said coldly. "I need to get her out of my head. If cooperating and getting her her own body is what it takes, than so be it."

"She can take control at any time?" Fia asked.

"It seems so, and I have yet to figure out how to regain control unless she allows it," Kelos replied. "Plus she can alter my memories. She's already changed at least one so I was a girl in it. I'm worried she's changed more, but I just haven't noticed yet."

"Let's go then," Fia replied. "I'll take you to Marlin immediately."

"Thank you, Fia," Kelos said.

"Fine," Kelos conceded. "I'll agree, but I have conditions. First, I stay in control the entire time."

Kelia smiled. "You have my word. I will not take control of your body."

"Nor will you alter any of my memories," Kelos demanded.

"You won't let me have any fun at all," Kelia replied.

"My body is a no fun allowed zone for you," Kelos insisted.

"Fiiiine..." Kelia replied with a pout. "Here, I'll give you back control." With that Kelos' body language shifted becoming less feminine.
