"I'm not a demon!" Kelia insisted mentally.

"You certainly act like one," Kelos replied.

"If you're done squabbling internally, I can get to work," Marlin said. He walked up to Kelos, and tapped her forehead.

A tiny eep escaped the transformed prince's lips as a tingling wave radiated out from the spot Marlin touched, engulfing her entire body. As it passed Kelos noticed a change, her transformed body had seemed just a little off, but now it seemed far more natural. "What did you do?"

"I removed the disguise spell without removing its effects," Marlin replied. "That is now your true body. It feels more comfortable, correct?"

"It does," Kelos said. "Wait, my true body? Does that mean I'm stuck like this?!"

"Only until I finish my research and can get that spirit out of you," Marlin replied. "Then it will be a simple matter of changing you back."

"If it makes you feel any better, you're very beautiful, Kelos," Fia offered.

"You know, my foolish little princess," Kelia said. "Rather than wait for my own body, I think I'll just keep yours!" She attempted to take control, but her efforts were futile. "What? How?!"

"Oh, I should mention," Marlin said, speaking directly into Kelos and Kelia's shared mental space, "I have also magically bound you to your word. You cannot take control of Kelos' body or alter her memories."

"I should have known not to trust you, demon" Kelos thought. "Thank you, wizard."

"Think nothing of it, my dear," Marlin replied, this time speaking aloud.

"Did I miss something?" Fia asked.

"Kelia simply tried to break her word," Marlin said.

"You win this time wizard, but I will..." Kelia began to think.

"You will behave," Kelos finished for her. "This wizard is going to help you get your own body. Just behave for a little bit and you'll be your own person. Try his patience and he may decide not to help us."

"Fine," Kelia replied in a huff.

"I think you should just leave them like that," the dragon said. "It'll be funny."

"Now now, I have already agreed to help," Marlin said. "Speaking of which, if you ladies will excuse me, I must get to work." Marlin started to the door, before pausing and turning around. "Wait, this is my laboratory. You leave!"

"Of course, sir wizard," Fia said. She curtsied. "Come along, Kelos." She then started to leave. Kelos hurried behind her.

"Not you," Marlin said, casting a restraining spell on the dragon as she tried to leave too. "I will require your assistance."

As Kelos walked out, the door to Marlin's lab closed on its own. Startled, Kelos turned and saw a sign appear on it saying "Research in progress, do not disturb."

"Don't worry, I'm sure Marlin will find a solution in no time," Fia said.

"I hope so," Kelos replied. "Being a woman is bad enough, but having a voice in my head makes it even worse."

"Are you saying there's something wrong with being a woman?" Fia challenged, looking angry.

"Umm... it's... it's not that there's anything wrong with it," Kelos stuttered.

"So you're okay with being a woman then?" Fia prodded.

"Yes! Being a woman is great!" Kelos exclaimed, though not in a convincing voice.

Fia giggled. "You're really fun to tease."

"Idiot" Kelia said mentally.

Kelos simply blushed.

It seemed as Kelos' entire body turned beet red, and her heart raced. She tried to stammer out a response.
