"I shall restrain her myself if need be," Fia stated.

"Oooh! Oooh! Can I help?!" the dragon asked enthusiastically.

"Not in here," Marlin said. "A struggle might set off one trap in particular, a spell to teleport you all directly to the dungeon." He stroked his beard. "Though perhaps there is a solution to this."

"Besides, princess," Kelia said. "I have access to Kelos' memories of being trained in combat. It's not as good as being trained myself, but I would wager it's more than you have."

"Last chance, Princess Kelos, agree to the extension, or kiss your manhood bye bye forever," Kelia gloated. Her body language became less feminine as she gave Kelos back control for the final decision.

"Fine, you want my decision, I refuse. Fia, Marlin, I trust you to sto..." Kelos was cut off as Kelia retook control.

"Foolish girl, I hope you'll make a better mother than a man," Kelia replied, she then turned and headed for the door. Fia started to chase after her, but Marlin placed his hand on her shoulder, stopping her. Kelia reached out to open the door, only to find it stuck tight. "What is the meaning of this? Did you not say you could not act against me as I'm you're guest?"

"I'm not acting against you, princess," Marlin said. "I merely locked the door so our conversation would be private. After all, we were discussing some personal matters. Can't have half the castle hearing of it. Now where did I put the key?" Fia smiled at this, as she recognized Marlin's plan.

"Let me out immediately!" Kelia demanded.

"Of course, dear," Marlin replied with a sly smile. "As soon as I find the key."
13212111111211211121112.title: Kelos trusts Fia and Marlin won't allow Kel...

choices: Kelia seduces the guard, locking Kelos as a woman.
The guard is interested but acts professionally.
132121111112112111211122.content:
Kelia sat down on a stool as she watched the wizard halfheartedly search the room for the missing key. "Can't you just open the door with magic?" she asked.

"Magic should not be used for such mundane tasks," Marlin replied, stopping his search to monologue. "Would you send an army to deliver a parcel? Would you summon a storm to water a flower? No, you would of course send a messenger or use a watering can. Likewise, a door shall be opened with a key." He then resumed his search with even less effort applied.

"Well said, sir wizard," Fia said with a smile.

"I'd summon a storm to water a flower! That sounds cool!" the young dragon said.

Kelia just rolled her eyes. and continued to sit there, watching this mockery of a search. Surely there must be some way out of this room. She thought back to Marlin's words, a struggle will teleport you directly to the dungeon? That might be the answer. She looked at the others in the room. Clearly Marlin wouldn't fall for such a plan, and Fia, even if she did, as the Princess, she could order the guards to leave. That damned dragon though, she might be hot headed enough to take the bait. Kelia smiled slyly as she looked over to her mark. Right now she was talking to Fia about how cool lightning is, which the princess was clearly feigning interest in.

"You can't expect this plan to work," Kelos thought. "What, you expect the guards there to just have sex with the first woman who pops into a cell?"

"Wouldn't you?" Kelia replied.

"Not before finding out who this woman and what is she doing suddenly appearing in my dungeon, which would involve contacting Marlin, as he's the obvious source here," Kelos explained. "Then probably, depending on the answers."

"How professional," Kelia replied. "But I'm counting on the guards being a bit more lax." She got up and made her way over to the dragon.

"It won't work," Kelo thought. Kelia ignored him and approached her mark.

"So lizard girl," Kelia said mockingly. "How exactly does a mighty dragon get beaten by an idiot prince who got himself turned into a woman and possessed anyway?"

The dragon looked at Kelia with rage in her eyes.

"I was just wondering how a dragon could be so pathetic," Kelia continued, pressing the dragon.

"Stop, she's trying to trick you into teleporting her out of here," Fia said, instantly seeing through Kelia's plan.

However, the young dragon had already been hooked. While the magic bonds prevented her from transforming into her true form or using magic, she couldn't let this go. "I'll show you who's pathetic!" the young dragon screamed as she leapt at Kelia, grabbing her hair. In that instant the two of them popped out of existence for a brief moment, only to reappear in separate cells in the dungeon.

"Yes, you've certainly shown me," Kelia said. "Thank you for your assistance."

"You bitch!" the dragon shouted.

"What's going on down there?" a guard asked. His armor clanged as he headed down the stairs to investigate.

"So you were saying this wouldn't work?" Kelia thought mockingly.

"I didn't say you wouldn't be able to bait her," Kelos replied.

"No, but you underestimate my womanly charms," Kelia replied.
132121111112112111211122.title: Kelia finds another way out.

choices: Fia finds a clue to Marlin's whereabouts.
Kelia ignores Fia and picks up something else.
1321211111121121112112.content:
"Good sir Wizard," Fia called out as she knocked on the door to Marlin's lab. "We have an urgent situation!" She repeated the knock, louder this time. However, her calls and knocks went unanswered.

"Is he not in?" Kelos asked.

"He should be," Fia replied. "He usually gets started bright and early, and works in his lab all day." She tried the doorknob and found it unlocked. Carefully she opened the door. "Marlin? It's Princess Fia. I have come seeking your aid." She peered in cautiously.

"Step aside, Princess," Kelia said, retaking control. She pushed Fia out of the way and barged in. "You there, wizard!" she called out. "Give me my own body or I shall take the one belonging to your princess' future husband!"

"Yes, barge into a wizard's lab and try to extort him, that'll work out well for you," Kelos quipped in his mind.

"Shut it girl," Kelia snapped back. "I have about 5 hours before this body reverts back to a man, and I certainly do not want to deal with having a dick."

"He doesn't seem to be here," Fia said, following Kelia in and looking around. "Perhaps it would be best to talk to my father. He likely knows where Marlin is."

"Why bother?" Kelia said. "We have everything we need right here." She walked over to one of the many dusty bookcases and grabbed an ancient tome, opening it up.

"WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU DOING?!!" Kelos screamed internally at Kelia's rash moves.

"Princess Kelia," Fia said, trying to be as polite as possible. "Surely you can see that browsing through a wizard's personal library is not the most prudent action. Even if there are no magical traps on any of the books, it is highly unlikely you'll find the proper spells in any reasonable amount of time."

"Plus there's the whole wizard who will be angry about you going through his stuff," Kelos added.

"I suppose you are correct," Kelia said, "To be so close to success, yet denied because your wizard isn't here."

"Perhaps there's some clue to where he went," Fia said. "I shall check his desk. If there's nothing, we shall ask my father. Do not touch anything else."
1321211111121121112112.title: Kelos and Fia go to Marlin's lab but can...

choices: Go with that gut feeling and leave the girl.
Help the poor girl.
13212111111211212.content:
"Don't hurt me, miss," the young girl pleaded with a tear in her eyes as she stepped out of the bushes. She appeared about 8 or 9 and was dirty and covered with scrapes. She was wearing a plain brown linen commoner's dress that had quite a few rips, some of them with what looked like dried blood and no shoes. Her long black hair was a tangled mess with sticks and leaves caught in it. Over all, she appeared to have been in the woods for quite some time though she did not appear malnourished. Most striking though were her ears, which were covered in dark green scales.

"I won't hurt you," Kelos said, returning her sword to its scabbard then fastening the belt around her waste. "What's your name, girl?"

The girl shook her head from side to side.

Kelos sighed. "Okay, where are your parents and why were you in this forest?"

"Mommy was killed by scary men," the girl said crying. "Then they chased me and I ran and I hid in the forest and they couldn't find me."

"Where are you from?" Kelos asked.

The girl pointed towards the east and continued to cry.

Kelos looked her over, analyzing the situation. The girl's story was plausible enough. Bandits attacked and killed her mother, but she was able to escape. However, those ears bothered Kelos, as did her not giving her name. There could be an innocent explanation for it, of course, but still something was off here. "Where's your father? Did the men kill him too?" She asked, trying to get more information.

"Mommy told me he was a soldier who died," the girl replied.

Also plausible, given the war. Still, Kelos felt something was off about the situation, but leaving this girl alone could mean her death.
13212111111211212.title: A young girl with strange, scaly ears.

choices: Accept and give her a tribute.
Just leave, she probably won't be able to fight you and the guards.
132121111112112121.content:
"I'm sorry, but I need to go," Kelos said, as she turned to leave.

"W-Wait, miss!" the girl called out. "You can't just leave a little girl alone in the woods!"

"You're right, it would be terrible to leave a little girl like that," Kelos said, turning back around. "However, you're not a little girl at all, are you? At a guess, I'd say you're a dragon."

The girl looked shocked for a moment, then grinned evilly. "Fu fu fu" the girl laughed. "Very good, miss. Very good. It seems I underestimated you." She covered her face with her right hand in a peculiar way, index finger pressed to the center of her brow, middle finger under her left eye, and thumb to the right of her mouth, with the other two fingers curled in. She swept her right arm out, fingers spread and palm down and took a dramatic stance. "Indeed I am a dragon! Not just any dragon, the magical prodigy dragon whose name is renowned throughout the lands! Behold! I am Nalisora, the Viridian sorceress dragon of death, the Mistress of metamorphosis! But to think there was a human who could see see through my disguise. Truly, I have become lax." She returned to a normal standing position, crossed her arms, and nodded with a satisfied grin, as if she were proud of her introduction.

Kelos looked dumbfounded at the dragon in human form in front of her.

"I see you're scared speechless," Nalisora said smugly. "Fu fu fu That is wise of you, miss. I might transform back to my true form and eat you in one gulp. Or maybe I'll take you and hold you for ransom. Or maybe I won't ask for a ransom and just make you a slave girl."

"Riiight, let's just go with that," Kelos said, rolling her eyes. "Please mighty dragon, what must I do to convince you to spare me?" She asked almost mockingly. While the girl in front of her was certainly a dangerous creature, from her behavior, she was likely a child by dragon standards. It was unlikely she would press an attack against the guards if Kelos retreated to the carriage.

"Good, while you may have been able to defeat my disguise, you know your place as a lowly human," Nalisora said, the mocking tone to Kelos' words flying over her head. "I demand a tribute to allow you to pass."
132121111112112121.title: Go with that gut feeling and leave the girl.

choices: Let her have the captain, he'll be able to escape when he turns back.
You can't let her have the captain. Offer her something else.
1321211111121121211.content:
Kelos sighed, but saw no reason not to humor this dragon. She may be young now, but why antagonize something that will one day grow into a powerful beast capable of taking on many armies. "Very well, what do you want for a tribute?" Kelos asked. "It better not be a shrubbery though."

"Foolish human, why would I want some dumb plant?" Nalisora replied with a puzzled look. "Only a magical artifact shall appease me," she said in a haughty tone. She then shifted to a more childish one, "And not something lame like a cursed sword that makes your hair grow one inch a day or something!"

"I don't have anything like that," Kelos replied. "Why would anyone even put that kind of curse on a sword?" Kelos paused in thought. "I have some disguise scrolls in the carriage. How about that?"

"Maybe, if you don't have anything shiny," Nalisora said. "I guess I'll look. Take me to this carriage, human."

"Fine," Kelos replied. She gathered her male clothes, then led the young dragon back to the carriage. When they arrived, Kelos was annoyed to find the guards had set up a table and were playing cards with the scribe. "What do you think you're doing?!" She shouted.

"Welcome back, your highness," one of the guards replied. "This hand's almost finished, want us to deal you in?"

"Why are you playing cards in a situation like this? What would the captain say if he saw this? Kelos shouted.

"It's not like we had anything better to do," the scribe said. "Who's your friend?"

"I'm not a friend! I'm a dragon!" Nalisora replied. "To think I would become friends with a lowly human woman! I'm just here for my tribute!"

"She wants a tribute for some reason," Kelos replied. "A magical artifact. I said she could have a disguise scroll."

"The rest of them are in the carriage," the scribe replied. "Now if you don't mind, I'd like to finish this hand. I'm up by 30 gold, and I've got this one in the bag too."

"Whatever," Kelos said with a sigh. "I'm sure the captain will have words for all of you when he's back to normal though." She led Nalisora to the carriage and opened the door. She took a disguise scroll and handed it to the young dragon.

Nalisora took the scroll and sniffed it. "Yes, it's certainly magic," she said. Sniffed it again, then took a step towards Kelos and sniffed her. "You have the same kind of magic on you."

"You can smell magic?" Kelos asked.

"I am a dragon after all. This is merely one of many things I can do that lowly humans such as yourself cannot. But please, feel free to admire my superior talents," she gloated. "So why do you smell like the scroll?"

"I accidentally used one on myself," Kelos admitted.

Namisora looked at the clothes Kelos was carrying. "Now that I look at it, those are mens clothes," she said. "Well, if you wanted to try being a woman, it's not like it matters to me. One lowly human is the same as another. Any more magic artifacts?" she began to sniff around the carriage. "OOOH" she exclaimed as she zeroed in on the cup captain. "This one smells even stronger! A disguise cup? I want it! I want it! I want it!"
1321211111121121211.title: Accept and give her a tribute.

choices: Kelos wacks her on the head.
Kelos tries to call for help.
13212111111211212112.content:
"That's not a cup, that's the captain," Kelos explained. "He opened a scroll, became a woman, then panicked and opened one that turned him into a cup."

What an idiot," Nalisora said dismissively. "Can he hear us?" Can he?"

"I was told he could" Kalos replied. "These scrolls are supposed to be for spying, so it makes sense. He'll be back to normal tomorrow."

The young dragon poked the cup. "Can you hear me, dumb human cup thing?" She poked it again. "It's not answering."

"Cups usually don't speak, Kelos replied. "So, how about one of those scrolls?"

"Nah, I don't want them anymore, they're kind of lame. Only last a day, and you're stuck for that day, plus they only work once, right?" Nalisora asked.

"Don't know," Kelos admitted. "I wasn't eager to find out. I think there's a ring of lie detection or something here I guess you could have." Kelos started rummaging though a bag.

"Who doesn't have one of those?" Nalisora asked. "Don't you have anything good like a rod of dispel, or a ring of wishes?"

"If I did, do you think I'd still be a girl, or my captain would still be a cup?"

"How should I know what goes through your lowly brains?" Nalisora replied with a huff. "Maybe you humans like getting turned into cups?"

"Who the hell would?!" Kelos shouted in annoyance. She took a deep breath to calm down. "Anyway, I don't think I have much else magical, except some message scrolls."

"Aww... You've gotta have something good!" the young dragon girl whined.

"I was just heading to Traeven to finalize arrangements for my marriage to Princess Fia," Kelos explained. "There was no need to bring a lot of high quality magical items."

"Fine, I'll just have to take something else," Nalisora said. She turned to Kelos with a wicked grin. "You!"
13212111111211212112.title: You can't let her have the captain. Offer h...

choices: Kelos agrees to be kidnapped, but only until she changes back.
Kelos tells Nalisora there will be no kidnappings.
132121111112112121121.content:
As the young dragon in human form approached Kelos, the transformed prince struck her in the head with her sword, still in the scabbard.

"Oww!" Nalisora exclaimed as she grabbed her head after Kelos' strike. "What'd you do that for?!" she asked, tears forming in her eyes.

"You said you were going to take me," Kelos said flatly, not quite knowing how to take this scene. Was this dragon attempting to lull her into lowering her guard, or simply immature and unexperienced? Regardless, Kelos reminded herself to be careful.

"I was only gonna kidnap you a little!" Nalisora protested. "Besides, you're a princess, dragons are supposed to kidnap princesses!" She rubbed her head where Kelos' blow landed. "There's a bump!"

"I'm not a princess, I'm a prince," Kelos said. "And how does 'kidnapping a little' even work?"

"It works cause I say it works!" Nalisora exclaimed, stomping her foot. "And you're a princess cause you're a girl!"

"Only temporarily," Kelos said. She reminded herself that the young girl throwing a bit of a tantrum in front of her was in fact a dangerous magical beast.

"It still counts! You're a girl so you're a princess so you should let me kidnap you cause I'm a dragon!" Nalisora insisted.

Kelos sighed. She took a deep breath and began to speak calmly and clearly to the young dragon. "I'm only a girl because of a magic scroll. Inside I'm still a boy, and I'm going to change back soon. So even if I look like a princess right now, I'm still a prince."

"So I can kidnap you until you turn back right?" Nalisora asked.

"That's not what I meant," Kelos said.

"Please!" Nalisora said with pleading eyes. "While you're still a princess!"

"Why do you even want to kidnap me?" Kelos asked.

"Cause I'm supposed to and I'm all alone now that mommy died," the young dragon said. She looked down at the floor sadly.

Even though she's a dragon, Kelos felt a little sorry for her. After all, she was still obviously a child. Though she wouldn't stay that way. Perhaps this could be a chance to win a powerful future ally. However, it could all be a trick too. Kelos thought the situation over.
132121111112112121121.title: Kelos wacks her on the head.

choices: She's a whelp
She's actually a lot bigger than Kelos expected
1321211111121121211211.content:
Kelos turned her head away from the girl, not particularly wanting to see a small child in such a sorry state, even if that said child was actually a dragon. In doing so though, her eyes peered off, zeroing in towards her supposed 'companions' and 'guards'; currently laughing it up, and having the time of their lives with their silly game of cards. It looked like the scribe had just won another hand, and if she knew the man well enough, then she knew that there was likely a bit of sorcerous trickery going on up his sleeve.

Still, to be having their little game while she was juggling between getting used to the feeling of a silken dress rubbing up against her legs, and consorting with a mythical entity, made her perturbed. Perturbed in a way that left her feeling like her men needed to be taught a bit of a lesson. Oh she was certainly chummy and down to earth with her guards, and would not really hesitate to call them her 'friends', especially after she'd taken a good few sips of wine, but a bit of mischief on her end might help snap them into shape for the future. It wouldn't exactly look good if the prince of a kingdom was taken while they were off goofing around.

Besides, she would likely be sitting on her thumbs for the next twenty plus odd hours anyway; no reason to not make them interesting.

“So what exactly would this 'kidnapping' entail?”

Nalisora blinked as the words rang through her pointed ears. Quick to the draw, she got back into character.

“Fu fu fu. So her majesty finally came to her senses, and realized she needed to capitulate before me, lest she suffer the wrath of the great Dragon of Death!” A sharp look was in her eye as she haughtily posed with her hand on her hip.

“Don't push it.” Kelos slightly raised the scabbard of her sword up.

“Nooo!~” The vicious dragon squealed, flinching back, and defensively placing her hands on her head.

The two stayed frozen like that for an extended moment, with Nalisora's eyes tightly shut, just waiting to be smacked.

When she realized nothing was happening though, her movements shifted so quickly that it appeared as if someone had skipped frames in a set of animations, as her fear once again switched to a look of boastful arrogance.

“Idle threats won't get you anywhere, princess.” She said, wagging her finger condescendingly towards the Grovan royal. “I'm going to take you back to my lair, and you're going to be my prisoner! And prisoners have to do everything I say! Like talk to me, and look at all the cool stuff, and play with me!”

Kelos just stared at her supposed kidnapper with a mild look of bewilderment on her face, though she did have to admit, this was already more amusing than the possibility of spending all night swatting down her men into trying to sucker her into a game of strip poker.

“ Right. Of course. I'll make sure to be a model captive, oh mighty dragon. Though we risk burning daylight. Should we not start our trek to your abode?”

“Ha!” Nalisora said, jumping back, and shifting into another dynamic pose. “Foolish human! We won't be trekking anywhere! We'll take to the skies!” At these words, a dark purple energy started to form around the girl, as she began to cast an incantation. “Feast your eyes on my true form! And let its terror sink deep into your heart!”
1321211111121121211211.title: A Very Amicable Kidnapping

choices: Nalisora brings Kelos stright to her lair.
Kelos convinces Nalisora to fly around more.
13212111111211212112111.content:
The purple energy built up and became brighter. Kelos shielded her eyes from the light. However, it quickly passed, revealing Nalisora's true form, a lizard like four legged creature covered in the same dark green scales as her ears in human form and roughly the size of a pony with large, bat like wings on her back and a long, thin tail. She had a long neck with a streamlined head with two horns. Kelos noticed the creature had a patch of lighter, emerald green scales on her left shoulder that looked kind of like a heart. Kelos thought that was kind of cute, in a way, but decided against saying so, as the young dragon clearly thought she was intimidating. After a few moments, the creature spoke with a smug tone. "So you're speechless at the sight of my true form. It's only natural for a mere human to be paralyzed with fear in the presence of a dragon."

"Yes, let's go with that," Kelos replied rolling her eyes. "So, fearless and powerful dragon, shall we depart for your lair?"

"Oh right, yes," Nalisora said. She turned to look behind her, then used her tail to open the door to the carriage and backed out. Kelos followed her outside.

"So how is this going to work?" Kelos asked. "Should I climb on your back?"

"No way!" Nalisora exclaimed. "I'm not going to let a human ride me like a horse!"

"I don't see much of an alternative," Kelos said. "I think I'm too big for you to carry with your claws."

"... Fine," Nalisora replied. "Consider yourself fortunate. Very few humans have ever flown on the back of a dragon and lived!"

"Thank you for the honor, mighty dragon," Kelos said, as she climbed on Nalisora's back, wrapping her arms tightly around the young dragon's chest. "Okay, I should be good."

"Then let's go!" Nalisora said, as she spread her wings to their full extent. She began to trot along to build up speed and flapped her wings. Before long she was airborne.

"Oh wow!" Kelos exclaimed as she watched the trees and fields below shrink as Nalisora gained altitude. She looked off into the distance and saw the outline of Castle Traeven on the horizon. "This is great! I can see for miles!" A grin spread across her face.

"Fu fu fu. This is but a glimpse of what a powerful dragon such as myself can do," Nalisora said smugly.
13212111111211212112111.title: She's a whelp

choices: Kelos gets shown around
Nali wants to show Kelos something specific
132121111112112121121111.content:
Kelos marveled at the experience of having the wind blow through her newly lengthened red locks. For every stumble this day had had, the current situation almost made up as a giant highlight. The time she took to the skies and rode upon the back of a ferocious dragon would certainly be making it into her eventual memoirs.

Though a few embellishments likely would have to be made. No point in mentioning that she was a buxom girl at the time. Or that the dragon was a child no bigger than the ponies kept in the castle stables. Yes, the beast in her notes will be a good few stories taller.

Soon enough though, the actual, much smaller whelp, appeared to set its sights on something; an adjacent and barren mountainside that no one except the most adventurous of climbers and explorers would really even dare attempt to scale, but it seemed the fearless creature Kelos was clinging onto had in its mind the idea to zoom straight ahead into the upcoming wall.

“Nalisora?” Kelos called, her words coming out more as whispers, as the wind cut the sound from her voice. “Nali- there's a wall! You're going to crash!”

It was at that moment that the prince, turned now 'captive' princess, started to question her choice in actions. This was a dragon, after all, and they were known for making their own unique ways to entertain themselves. Who's to say she didn't let her ride on her back just to turn her into the most royal piece of splatter that Traeven had seen since the wars of old?

Her concerns only became greater, as the beast of legend ignored her warnings, and actually started to speed up! A light tittering of laughter could even be heard in her voice as they approached quicker and quicker to their inevitable doom.

It was in that moment that Kelos couldn't help but let out a very high pitched, very undignified, and most embarrassing of all, very girly scream.

The crash though, didn't come.

In fact, the two passed through the mountainside with little difficulty at all, and when Kelos had the nerve to open her eyes once more, she was greeted with another peculiar sight; the real cliff of the mountain had revealed itself, only this one was much more ornate, with a rather large, if a tad weathered, keep, set overlooking the forests and lands below them. They had just passed through an illusory wall, and the innards had finally revealed themselves.

Quickly enough then, Nalisora landed, with both of them now being a couple dozen feet away from the main entrance; obviously the dragon wanted to give Kelos a bit of a tour.

“Impressive, isn't it, human?” She said, as the young prince stepped off her back; once again allowing her to magically reverted back to her (mostly) human form. “Though even I must admit, this isn't just my work. My mommy took this keep a long long time ago, before I was born, and she even set up the magic to keep it hidden! But now that she's gone, it's all mine! And I use it as my base to strike fear into the hearts of you lowly mortals!”

Interrupting the dragon's attempt at a supposed diabolical tirade, Kelos gently poked Nalisora on the forehead.

“Rude.”

There was a brief pause between them at that.

“Huh?” The dragon eventually managed to stumble out, a tone of childlike confusion clearly being able to be discerned in her voice. She had been stopped dead in her tracks by the simple action, and was now staring up at Kelos, doe-eyed.

“Rude.” Kelos said, pointing her finger upward, as if trying to teach a lesson. “You didn't tell me we were going to fly through any walls or the like. You could have scared a person to death with a trick of that sort!”

Nalisora though just pouted, and crossed her arms. “It was just a little joke! A joke!”

Kelos couldn't help but smile at that just a tiny bit. “Well, lets have our jokes be a little less dangerous next time, shall we?” She said, patting the dragon on the head. “Now, do you want to show me your castle, Nali?”
132121111112112121121111.title: A Hidden Lair

choices: Kelos lets Nalisora show off her room.
Kelos says she really wants to see the library.
1321211111121121211211111.content:
"Ah yes," the young dragon replied. "Come, witness the grandeur of my hidden lair!" She grasped Kelos' hand and, practically running, pulled the transformed prince along towards the entrance. Unaccustomed to heels, Kelos stumbled a bit trying to match Nalisora's pace, but somehow managed to keep up without falling. The young dragon stopped just before the large main gate. "Fu fu fu Behold the gateway to my invincible fortress!" She said, her voice a mixture of pride and excitement.

Kelos looked up at the gate, which appeared to be made of solid oak, sturdy, if a bit weathered. Above it was a crest, though Kelos didn't recognize it, a detail Kelos thought was a bit odd, given her study of military history and royal lines. "Say, do you know who originally built this castle?" she asked.

"Nope, but I know it's really, really old," Nalisora replied. "Let's go inside!" She let go of Kelos' hand and struck a dramatic pose, her right arm extending out towards the massive door. "Fu fu fu, your mistress has returned! I command you! Open!" Her hand began to glow slightly with magic power, and slowly, the door began to creek open. As it opened she turned to Kelos, with a smug smile on her face. Clearly she expected Kelos to be impressed by her magical ability.

"Yes, yes, good job," Kelos said, patting the young dragon on the head. Nalisora beamed at even this half hearted praise, which Kelos found kind of cute.

"Let's go in!" Nalisora said, again grabbing Kelos' hand and dragging her inside. As they entered, the door magically closed behind them. "This is the lobby," the young dragon said, waving her free hand. "Pretty impressive, right?"

Kelos turned her head and looked around. The floors were made of marble tiles, though chipped and uneven from age. Kelo's heels clicked as she walked, a sound the former man found somewhat disconcerting. She tried her best to ignore it, diverting her attention to the walls, which were decorated with an elaborate mosaic, with some tiles missing, depicting a battle between ancient armies both using a traditional phalanx formation. One of them had banners depicting the same crest as on the outside of the castle. The other army was marching under a more familiar crest, the ancient Divinus Imperium. Specifically, the 19th Legion, which had been wiped out on an exploration mission in barbarian lands. It seemed apparent that their opponents on that fateful day where the same as the ones who constructed this keep. Though that was likely centuries before they built this stronghold, given the architecture seemed more recent.

"Pretty great, right?" Nalisora asked.

"Yes, it's most impressive," Kelos replied, still examining the mosaic.

"This is only the beginning, there's a lot more to see," the young dragon said boastfully.

"Is there a library?" Kelos asked, hoping there would be some information about the builders of this place.

"Yeah, but it's boring," Nalisora replied. "And all the books are in some weird human language. I don't think any of them are even magic. Let's look at something better like my room!" She pointed towards a staircase leading up.
1321211111121121211211111.title: Kelos gets shown around

choices: She reaches over to her shelf
She starts heading towards the treasure chest/Something else
13212111111211212112111111.content:
The idea of taking a look at the library definitely piqued Kelos' interests. A lot of this place piqued her interest, to be truthful. The lairs of dragons were known to hold many secrets- many treasures, and while the prince was no thief, she was still quite inquisitive, and had a desire to seek out knowledge, especially knowledge that had been hidden away behind a a wall of illusion for who knew how long. If she could cap off this adventure by returning to Grovan with not only the tale of taming a dragon, but of bringing back with her some long forgotten piece of history, she'd be hailed as a hero, and this would all be on top of obtaining the hand of Princess Fia.

“I wouldn't mind visiting that library...” Kelos' voice was a bit far off, as her eyes still peered over the large foyer around her; imagination contemplating the possibilities that awaited further inside.

Nalisora though just pouted. “But that's boooring! Boring boring boring boring boring! My room has lots of better stuff!” She huffed and puffed, and then quickly jutted out her finger out, pointing at Kelos. “Besides! I captured you! That means you have to do everything I want to do! It's the rules!”

The royal tried her best to not let out a sigh, or say some sort of quip about 'just who wrote those rules'. She didn't want to forget herself. Right now, she was a guest, or rather, a 'prisoner', and as such, it would be a tad rude to demand to poke her nose around her 'kidnapper's' home just a few minutes after stepping past the door. She was a prince (well, technically princess at the moment, but that was just a minor stumble, no need to fuss about it), and as such, manners and decorum were ingrained into her practically from birth.

There was also the small matter that she was dealing with a child, or what was for all intents and purposes, a child, and the fact that she seemed to not properly have anyone taking care of her caused Kelos' brow to furrow in perturbed annoyance. The young prince herself grew up in an environment that often felt somewhat isolated. Her parents were always too busy with royal duties to spend a considerable amount of quality time with their next of kin, but even then she still had her sister Orianna, who provided company despite her teasing personality.

The whelpling here though looked to be all in her lonesome; living in an old decaying keep that was hidden away from the world. At face value, the whole situation made Kelos' soft features frown. If her mother really was dead, then she was an outright orphan.

...These were all very silly things to think about, though, and she had to keep reminding herself that she really was in the lair of a dragon of all things here. She didn't even know what the age of the beast actually was! By all means she could have been older than the Grovan royal herself, given the extended lifespans of these mythical creatures, and as such, quite possibly all together capable of handling her own affairs.

But still, from the short time Kelos had known her, she certainly hadn't been acting the adult, and that vexed her in a multitude of disconcerting ways. Before her mind could move into more serious thoughts about what to do with an orphaned dragon though, she figured she could at least do one thing to make the girl's day a bit brighter.

Shaking herself out of her introspection, Kelos held hands up, and spoke in a mock tone of defeat. “Alright, alright. On second thought, I think I'd love to see your room, oh terrifying dragon.”

The beast's face quickly changed from an annoyed grimace, into a pleased, toothy grin, which managed to show off a pair of cute little fangs that the prince hadn't particularly noticed before. Kelos might have commented, but before she could, she was grabbed by the hand and had to face possibly one of her greatest challenges yet: going up stairs while wearing heels, and all the while as a giddy dragon pulled her towards a far off location deep in the castle's interior.

As they went, they passed by many rooms, and turned through several halls. Kelos, even in the hurry, still managed to notice what looked to be entrances to several distinct locales, including a dining area, and a room closed up with two massive and ornate doors, that she had to surmise must have led to a throne, or in the least, some other area of importance.

Reaching towards the more residential portion of the keep, Kelos assumed that Nali would have taken up board in the master bedroom, but instead, the young prince (who just so happened to be currently donned in a dress) was led to a somewhat smaller abode a little off to the side of it.

“Prepare yourself, human! Because your eyes about to feast on the greatest! Room! Ever!” The dragon boastfully remarked, as she jutted open the door with force to reveal what was inside.

And Kelos had to admit, what awaited her as she stepped in certainly looked... unique. It held the appearance of what looked like, at one time, was a little girl's room- quite possibly of some royalty or clout, as it seemed to be fairly lavish. Pink paper donned with a red, heart-based pattern covered the walls, though now a not so unnoticeable amount showed their age through weathering and peeling. In the dead center of the room too, pushed up against a wall next to a window, sat a four poster bed that held the same color motif and pattern as the walls, while also holding the same level of decay, as a tear in the mattress could be noted in its bottom right corner, and the posts, once tall and jutting up in a pure display of vanity, now were starting to chip, with places where the splintering of wood could easily be seen.

There were other such similar items around them, dressers, drawers, closets and the like, but what ultimately made this room standout were the oddities and incongruities of where the dragon had clearly added her own touch.

Off in the corner, much to Kelos' shock, and a bit of wonderment, was an outright decently sized pile of gold, gems, and other such riches, simply lying there as if it was the most natural thing in the world. Plopped as the centerpiece of the heap was a large unopened chest that simply seemed to be begging to be examined to see what treasures it held within.

Shelves also lined the walls, and while Kelos could only assume a few of the items came from the original inhabitant of the abode, many were clearly gathered up by Nali herself; bottles of potions, scrolls, little doodads and whats-its, that all must have come from various “tributes” from passing travelers who crossed ways with the dragon, much like she and her men had. Though some were clearly magical in nature, others looked more benign; toys, more than anything. A bag of marbles, a spinning top, a cup and ball game, and several other items of the sort that, if she didn't know better, she could have guessed were parlayed simply because they looked fun to the still developing youth. Though Kelos knew not to doubt their potential for sorcerous potency, given that they were obtained by a creature inherently drawn to the arcane.

By all means, Kelos definitely was a bit amazed by what she was seeing, though maybe not for the exact reasons Nalisora would have expected. It was all a mix of decrepit decay, classical dragon hoarding, and a display of eclectic scrounged up goods that were likely obtained from passersby who either were tricked by her initial innocent little girl facade, and managed to give away a quick reward to her due to pity, or figured it all out, and just plain couldn't be asked to put up a bother with dealing with the annoying demands of the dragon, and just handed her a piece of spare tat, while letting her go on her way.

“My, this really is all very... impressive.” Kelos spoke, a slight sense of bewilderment in her tone, as she soaked everything in.

“Yes, yes. I could tell a princess like you would have a discerning eye for good taste.” The dragon bragged, taking her guest's words fully at face value. “I don't know whose room this was before, but they had a good start. It just needed a few more improvements.” She then quickly pointed toward the gold in the corner. “The treasure over there was given to me by my momma. She always told me that 'a good dragon always has a hoard.'” Her tone became a tad raspier as she imitated her parent's voice. “But all the other cool stuff here I got myself!”

As she said this though, her features focused towards an item in particular. “Here, I wanna show you something!”
13212111111211212112111111.title: A Room with a View and a View of the Room

choices: Kelos successfully transforms her clothing.
Something unexpected happens.
132121111112112121121111111.content:
The young dragon reached over to the shelf and picked up a wand, gold, with a pink heart shaped gem embedded in it. "Check this out!" She said as she held up the wand above her head. She then twirled and shouted "Transform!" Her clothing began to glow and shift. The plain brown dress she was wearing started to sprout ribbons and lace as its color changed to a dark purple. It retreated up her legs to above her knees as the frills puffed it out. The glow traveled down her legs leaving black stockings behind. It reached her feet then reversed, this time forming a pair of purple laced high heeled boots that came up to just under her knees. Finally the glow appeared on her head as a tiny witches hat with a ribbon appeared. "Fu fu fu! Behold! The dark dragon witch Nalisora!" the young dragon said striking a dramatic pose. "Pretty cool right?"

"Yes, very," Kelos agreed. Certainly it was a much faster way to change clothes, though the young dragon's taste in clothes were... odd to say the least. "That certainly is a unique outfit there."

"Yup, it really suits me right?" Nalisora asked. She posed a few times.

"It's certainly you," Kelos said.

"Oh!" Nalisora exclaimed. She thrust the wand into Kelos' hands. "You've gotta try it!"

Kelos held the wand cautiously and looked at it. "Are you sure that's okay?" she asked.

"Yup!" Nalisora said with a smile. "You just hold it above your head, then spin and say 'transform' and it changes your clothes. But you gotta like picture the clothes you want."

Kelos kept looking at the wand. "And it'll just change my clothes?" she asked, understandably hesitant given her experiences with magic that day.

"Yup," Nalisora replied. "It'll be fun! But you gotta keep wearing whatever it is until I say you can change."

"Fine," Kelos said, as she held the wand up like she saw the dragon girl before. "Like this?"

"Yup," Nalisora said. "Now twirl and say 'transform.'"

"Okay, but this feels kind of silly," Kelos said. She began to twirl. "Transform!"
132121111112112121121111111.title: She reaches over to her shelf

choices: Before they can continue, a loud rumbling is heard elsewhere in the keep.
Nalisora pulls out another item, but Kelos is more cautious now/Something else.
1321211111121121211211111112.content:
Kelos wanted to play it a bit safe, as right now she was still feeling cautious of the dangers that magic could bring about, especially after today! Still though, a nice change of clothes didn't sound too bad. She had originally donned her current green attire so as to make herself presentable to Princess Fia, and show that even when faced with troubled waters, the Grovan line did their best to make themselves stand tall.

Right now though, things were a bit different. Kelos was currently on an adventure after being whisked away by a dragon of all things, and cumbersome heels and swishy dresses weren't the most ideal clothing for when delving into ancient and hidden keeps.

So as she spoke the wand's magic words, images of simple explorer's gear formed in her mind. Sturdy boots, warm leggings, a breathable vest, and a belt with enough nooks and crannies in it to store whatever little nicknacks she may come across; all very standard, really. It might not impress Nalisora, but if she had to wear something at the girl's whim, she'd prefer it to be practical.

Glowing twinkles began to surround her, and a faint ticklish feeling started to overcome her body, as the magic went to work. Moments quickly passed, a big splendorous flash came about, and soon enough, Kelos' apparel, just like Nalisora's, was transformed!

Into a big poofy princess dress.

Now, Kelos was already wearing a gown. It was quite feminine to begin with, but regardless, it held a bit of tact, and arguably practicality to it. Kelos' new wear billowed in front of her, as frills and layers of cloth filled once empty space in the room.

It was pink. Bright pink. A gaudy pink. The type of which her sister Orianna would just scoff at. Though she might have appreciated just how on the nose girly it was.

Kelos' whole body was ensconced in ruffles of soft fabric, with long, elegant opera gloves now covering her arms, of which led towards a set of big, impractical shoulders that needlessly puffed up at her sides. The most absurd thing though about the get up was the long, pointy, conical hennin that now laid atop her head, with a veil of silken cloth that poured down the back of it, and did nothing other than to simply paint the picture of pristine fairy tail princess.

Kelos simply stood in silence for a good moment as she took it all in. The realization of what happened dawned on her soon enough though, and a rhythmic twitching started to pound away above the brow of her left eye, and a flush of red frustration began to overtake her face; breaking the wholly false illusion of royal perfection.

This had to have been the girliest, most feminine thing she had ever seen, let alone worn, and while it certainly was soft, the thought of trying to trek around in it made her head spin. She didn't know what happened, but this certainly wasn't what she asked for!

During all this, Nalisora was having a distinctly different reaction, as the young dragon couldn't help but let out a loud, surprised, but more than anything else, giddy, gasp, as she saw the princess transform.

“Ohmygosh you look so pretty!” Nali placed her hands on her cheeks as she rushed to circle around Kelos to get a better look.

In a practical blitz of movement, she touched, poked, and prodded the dress; feeling its various textures, smoothness, and curves of the frills, which helped in no way with Kelos' temper.

Moments passed passed by with Kelos simply simmering like a pot of tea about to boil. A pot of tea that was being swarmed by a pesky little reptile dressed up as some sort of kooky witch.

She felt her analogy might have lost a bit of bite somewhere there, but that didn't matter.

“Would you stop that?!” She snapped, as the dragon looked over the hem of her gown. Kelos' hands were clasped hard, and a look of unfettered annoyance was on her face, as she huffed out a few deep, unladylike breaths.

There was a pause as the room went dead silent, and Kelos realized quickly she needed to calm down. She was in the lair of a dragon, and she didn't want to create too much of a hostile atmosphere. Besides, this wasn't the proper way a princess should act.

Even if she really was a prince!

Nalisora had finally stopped in her machinations, with a doe-eyed look on her face as a result of the other girl's outburst. This gave Kelos a chance to inquire about things.

“Did you do this?”

Nali blinked. “Do what?”

“This!” Kelos gestured down. “This dress!”

The dragon's brow furrowed. “No, you did.”

“No! I wanted something practical!”

Nali paused, as a few gears began to clunk forward in her mind. “Are you suuuure?” She said, with a teasing spark of smugness in her voice.

Kelos flushed. “Of course!”

“Or maybe- maybe that's what you really wanted to wear!” The witchy little girl raised her index finger up, in an all-knowing fashion. “The wand's always worked for me. How do I know you're not just playing one of your weird human tricks? Why would you want something practical anyway? That's boooring.”

The princess just stared for a moment, and then shook her head. “Don't be absurd. Besides, you're a dragon! Maybe the magic works different for humans.” Thinking further, another realization hit her. “Or maybe it's that blasted scroll. The magic of that might be interfering.”

“Maaaybe~.” Nali spoke in a sing-song tone, as she quickly leaned over, and plucked the wand that was still in Kelos' hand. “But either way, that's your dress! You promised you'd wear it for as long as I want!”

Kelos simply rolled her eyes. “Can you not want it now?”

“Nope~!”

The princess expected as much. She didn't want to use the wand again anyway. It backfired once already, and she was sure, once Nalisora saw how awkward getting around in the dress was, and how it would harm their 'playtime', she'd want her out of it just as quickly as Kelos herself did. At the moment she'd just have to grin and bear it.

“So what do you have in mind for us now, oh great dragon?”
1321211111121121211211111112.title: Mixing Magic Makes a Magical Mix Up

choices: Approach them.
Try to hide from them.
13212111111211212112111111121.content:
"Let's see..." Nalisora said, pondering what to do next with Kelos. However, a loud rumbling sound from a lower floor interrupted her thoughts.

"What's that?!" Kelos blurted out with an embarrassingly girly tone to her voice.

"Fu fu fu," the young dragon laughed. "It seems some fools have wandered in and triggered one of my brilliant traps." She stood there with a look of pride. "Let's go see!" She quickly ran out the door.

"Wait!" Kelos called out. She attempted to pursue her young hostess, however, the dress she was wearing heavily restricted her movement. Worse, Kelos found she was now wearing even higher heels than the ones she had on previously. These combined to her barely being able to manage a walking pace. "I can't move very fast in this!" she called out as she exited Nalisora's room only to see the young dragon already turning a corner in the halls. She struggled along trying to at least keep sight of the exuberant child, but after a few more turns, it proved impossible. Worse still, Kelos realized she was now lost in the unfamiliar keep. Eventually Narisora would probably realize her guest couldn't keep up and look for her, but until then she was on her own. Though there was the question of these intruders. Surely it couldn't be her men having tracked her down. It would take far longer to get here on the ground, assuming they could even find it. No, Kelos corrected herself, assuming they even noticed she was missing yet. They could be simple adventurer types, or even knights sent to hunt down Nalisora. The latter was safer for Kelos, since knights would surely rescue a princess being held by a dragon. The former though could be unpredictable. Hopefully the young dragon could handle herself in either case. Kelos turned around, to try to find her way back to Nalisora's room. However, she stopped, as she heard faint voices from a hallway.

"You're sure there are no traps here?" a man asked.

"Positive," another man replied. "This floor's clean."

"That's what you said about the last floor," the first man replied.

"I wasn't expecting a giant boulder trap," the second man said defensively. "I mean who even does those anymore?"

"Now now, boys," a woman said. "Stop arguing. I've got a good feeling about finding something on this floor."

"So much for your brilliant trap," Kelos whispered. Not only had it failed to stop these people, apparently Nalisora had also managed to miss them in her own castle. These people seemed to be treasure hunters of some kind, given the talk about finding something. Of course that told little about their character.
13212111111211212112111111121.title: Before they can continue, a loud rumbling is he...

choices: Kelos rejects her offer flatly and Nalisora returns.
Kelos is tempted by the woman's offer.
132121111112112121121111111211.content:
Kelos dismissed the idea of hiding. It would be unseemly cowardice, despite her current form. She walked in the direction of the voices, her heels clicking on the floor tiles, announcing her presence to the intruders.

"You hear that?," the unknown woman whispered.

"Yeah," second man replied quietly. "Footsteps, a woman it sounds like, heels. From the gait I'd say she's had some military training and isn't accustomed to her shoes."

"You can tell that from how she's walking?" the first man asked. "Impressive."

"She's also coming towards us," the second man stated.

"Well boys, she knows we're here, let's go say hello," the woman said. She pushed past her male companions and began walking towards the sound of Kelos' footsteps. The two men looked at each other, shrugged, then followed their teammate.

Kelos picked up her pace a bit as she heard the woman's words. She wanted to meet them at a point she could easily retreat to Nalisora's room. It had a fairly sturdy door that could buy some time if things when bad, and hopefully some magic items in there would be of use. She turned the corner to the hall Nalisora's room was on, and headed down, just as the group of intruders also turned down. Nalisora's room was halfway down, so to get in position, Kelos approached the group quickly. "Who are you and what are you doing here?" she asked with a challenging tone in her voice as she looked over the trio. The woman in front was wearing a tight black dress with a slit in the side, probably silk, Kelos thought, that showed ample cleavage and clung to her every curve. Her skin was quite pale, and her eyes looked as though she was from the far east. She had long, black hair that reached her butt. She had a pair of soft looking, flat black shoes that matched her dress, and a gold pendant shaped like a crescent moon. Strangely, there wasn't even a wrinkle on her clothes or a stray hair. She looked more like someone who just got dressed to attend a party than had been wandering through an old castle littered with traps. Her companions though looked more the part. Both were wearing light leather armor, though one had a chainmail vest and was carrying a sword, while the other had a pair of daggers tucking in his belt and a bow and quiver on his back. Kelos found herself tracing the woman's figure with her eyes. The woman noticed this and shifted her stance to appear more seductive.

"My friends and I, we're dealers in antiquities you might say," the woman said as she approached Kelos, swaying her hips back and forth. "We're here because our current inventory is a bit... depleted."

"Well this castle isn't abandoned, so you can't just help yourself," Kelos replied, her eyes fixated on the woman's hips. Her face was becoming flushed, and she felt a strange wetness below.

"Perhaps not, but I think I can guess why your here," the woman said. "Caught in bed with another girl so your father sent you to this place as punishment perhaps?" She approached Kelos and seductively embraced her. "I prefer men myself, but women are nice from time to time." She leaned over and whispered in Kelos' ear. "I'm certainly willing to keep you company for the night in exchange for a few trinkets that might be laying around."
132121111112112121121111111211.title: Approach them.

choices: Kelos advises Nalisora to let them go peacefully.
Kelos advises Nalisora to fight.
1321211111121121211211111112111.content:
Kelos took a deep breath to steel her will, then pushed the woman back. "Tempting though it may be, this is not my castle and the items here are not mine to give away. I'm visiting a friend who lives here."

"Pity we couldn't do this the easy way, Princess," the woman replied. She took a few steps back. "Okay boys, your turn. Make her tell you where her friend is keeping all their valuables."

"Right boss," the man with the daggers and bow said. He drew his daggers and stepped towards Kelos. The other man didn't say anything, but also approached, though did not draw his sword.

Kelos took a step back as they advanced to assess the situation. If she were still a man, she felt she'd have a good shot at taking the two on. However, at the moment she was in a distressingly female body. Worse, her current attire was greatly restricting her movement. It was unlikely she'd be able to outrun them. Fighting was out of the question, and so was fleeing, this left her with few options. She considered just giving up and leading them to Nalisora's room, however, she couldn't just betray the young dragon without even trying to resist. There was still one option left though. "Did I mention my friend is a dragon? If you really want me to lead you to her horde, I do know where it is, but I really don't think you want to steal from a dragon. They tend not to be very forgiving of people who rob them. Nor people who hurt their friends"

"Sure, princess, and I'm the bishop of Canetralia," the man with the daggers said as he continued to approach. The man with the sword stopped and looked back to the woman with them.

"Fine don't believe me. But who else would live in this out of the way ruin? Plus, how would I get here without a horse or carriage? Simple, I flew here carried by a dragon," Kelos said. She stopped backing up and took a step forward, trying to project confidence. "A very powerful dragon at that."

With that, Kelos heard a familiar voice call out from down the hall. "Good job, you found the intruders!" Nalisora called out as she ran towards them, still in human form. "I won't forgive them for breaking in and damaging my traps!"

"BWAHAHAHAHAHA," the man with the swords burst into laughter as his hesitation and concern left. "That's your powerful dragon?! She's a little girl! HAHAHAHA"

"Don't underestimate her," the woman warned as she looked over the new arrival.

"She certainly doesn't look like a dragon," the man with the daggers said. "But she's not human either."

"She's a dragon for sure," the woman confirmed. "Shapeshifted to resemble a person."

"That's right," Nalisora said proudly. "My magic is top notch! If you apologize and leave a tribute, I might consider letting you go."

"So she's a threat?" the man with the sword asked.

"Maybe," the woman said. "You weren't wrong that she's a little girl, but even a young dragon can be tough."

Kelos once again considered her options. With Nalisora here, it was 3 on 2, but she didn't really know how strong the young dragon was, nor the dungeon raiders. If this came to a fight, Kelos couldn't predict what the outcome would be. However, they didn't appear confident in their own victory. Perhaps they could be still reasoned with and convinced to leave. On the other hand, if they decided to make a fight of it, that could allow them to lower Nalisora's guard and gain an advantage.
1321211111121121211211111112111.title: Kelos rejects her offer flatly and Nalisora ret...

choices: Kelos shakes off the feeling and punches the woman.
Kelos obeys and stops.
13212111111211212112111111121112.content:
Kelos' mind came to one conclusion, this was not a favorable battle. It was three on two, and she was not exactly equipped for a battle. Nalisora was a dragon and probably had an edge on the woman, but she seemed to be some sort of magic user. She'd probably try to stall Nalisora, making it two on one. They'd almost certainly win that, by virture of actually having weapons and not wearing a puffy dress, and then turn on Nalisora. Still, letting them go could be worse. They had some idea of what they were facing so they could come back better prepared with reinforcements. It was risky, but fighting was the only option. "We can take them," she said. "Don't let these thieves go, they'll just come back later."

"Fufufu, I was just thinking the same thing," Nalisora said. "They broke into my home and they need to be punished."

"You said that woman had military training?" the man with the sword asked.

"Yeah, pretty sure," the man with the daggers replied.

"You two can take one princess," the woman said. "I'll deal with the dragon."

"Nali," Kelos called out. "Transform and take care of the men!" She then charged the woman as best as she could with her encumbrance. Her fighting the two men was almost certain defeat. Her fighting the woman was also likely defeat. However, Nalisora could very well beat the men. If she could distract the woman long enough, they had a chance. The two men attempted to stop Kelos

"Fine!" Nalisora relied as she changed back into her true self. She took a breath and then exhaled a plume of acidic mist in the direction of the men, taking care not to hit Kelos. The man with the daggers dropped to the ground to avoid the acid, while the man with the sword covered his eyes and held his breath to protect himself as best he could. This allowed Kelos to rush past them and approach the woman.

Taken off guard by this action, the woman hurriedly cast a spell. "Stop!" the woman commanded, her voice magically enhanced. Kelos heard the woman's voice echo in her head and felt an overwhelming need to obey the order.
13212111111211212112111111121112.title: Kelos advises Nalisora to fight.

choices: Nali gets angry.
The thieves use this time to strike/Something else.
132121111112112121121111111211121.content:
It took a great deal of fortitude to overcome the force of the magic, but if there was one thing Kelos had, it was a strong sense of will. It would require more than a hastily thrown spell to leave her stumbling over her heels.

She could do that freely in her own time.

And that was why, despite the froofy poofing of her dress, and despite the clacking of her shoes against the slightly gravelly ground, she was able to close the distance against the assaulting intruder, and, gripping the silken edges of her pristine opera gloves, delivered a set of knuckles across the jaw of the would-be robber.

The thief in turn stumbled back; more due to the brazen manner at which a supposed royal was able to depart upon her a hardened right to her face. “I can see maybe a few more reasons why your daddy decided to put you on time out here.” Her tone was perturbed as she used her hand to ease the impact point against her chin.

“There are probably a fair number of surprises about me you wouldn't expect.” Kelos bantered, as she raised her arms up into a fighting stance. It looked ridiculous; this girl appeared more as if she was ready for her wedding day then to fight bandits, yet here she was eager to do so all the same.

In a bout of worse luck for the intruder, a sharp “AAAHH!” came from one of her henchmen, as they were jolted back with a toss; sliding next to his female comrade.

“Fufufu, and that's the power of The Great Nalisora's 'Chaotic Dragon Claws!'”

For anyone who happened to be watching, they would have seen that Nalisora's 'Chaotic Dragon Claws' more or less amounted to tearing a bit of the crook's armor, and then tossing him across the room, but the results either way still proved practical, and so had her acidic breath, which kept the last fighter on their toes to the point of having to back himself up against his two allies as well.

“Oh for the love of- This was not supposed to be some kind of ordeal.” The magic-user grumbled, as she helped her associates to their feet.

“That's what you get for daring to cross paths with a mighty dragon such as myself! Attacking my captive was just the most egregious of your errors!” As she approached the princess, she turned to the girl with an expectant look on her face. “Did I do good? Huh? Huh?”

“You did great Nali.” Kelos beamed, patting the younger girl's head, and absently feeling the scaled features of the whelp. She may have been smaller than most, but she still packed as big a bite as any drake. “So are you people willing to give up, and get yourselves out of here now?”

“Are you kidding me?! After all the trouble it took to get here?!” The mook whose blade had been dissolved rhetorically asked.

“Yeah, we're not leaving here without at least filling our pockets with something!” The one who was nursing his back responded.

“Enough!” In an instant, the voice of the mage between them swelled to a flurry, as a whirl of mana shot forth and caused both Kelos and Nali to brace themselves; the former feeling her dress flutter wildly in the wind.

“I usually tend to be more subtle, but this is just getting ridiculous.” In the moments that the princess and her 'captor' had allowed their guests to recoup, the spellcaster before them had begun to charge up a powerful enchantment; intent on sorting this matter without anymore lost equipment, or lost ego.

Her sights were set on Nalisora. The girl who smacked her was quite cheeky, but nothing that wouldn't take just a few minutes to sort out. No, the dragon was the real challenge.

...And maybe prize? The idea had snuck into her brain when she first saw the beast reveal its true form, and was becoming more and more appealing a thought. If they could tranquilize the creature, the amount of gold they might be able to acquire would likely make anything this shabby keep held look like a pittance! Not to mention the regard and infamy they'd earn for their daring efforts.

A grin molded itself on her face, as she put more and more energy into the charge. All of these musing had buzzed through in a matter of moments, but it was just enough to know what she needed to do, with, soon enough, a pulsating, electrifying, bolt of unknown wizardy shooting forth from her fingertips, and aimed right down towards the rambunctious reptilian.

“Nali!” Kelos yelled.

It was at this time that the transformed princess did something. It might have been viewed as a stupid something. Or maybe more just a silly something. A something possibly born from her annoying new state, that forced upon her the occasional nurturing thought. Of protecting the little girl she was with, and keeping her out of danger- no matter how many scales she held, or sharp teeth were in her mouth.

So it ended up, dress or any other hindrance be damned, she, without much thinking, pushed herself in front of the dragon to shield her from the blast.

What followed was probably a far more shrill scream than Kelos would have liked to hear come out of her voice, though it was slightly muted by the yell of “Human!” that came from Nalisora, as she saw what her 'prisoner' had done.

Within seconds, the royal fell to the floor, incapacitated from the energized shock; a few wisps of magical electricity coursing over her frame, and leaving one to question her well being.

The whelp, seeing all this, stared with her mouth agape.
132121111112112121121111111211121.title: Duking It Out

choices: Kelos is just fatigued from the fight and needs rest
Kelos is badly injured and Nalisora comes up with a creative solution
1321211111121121211211111112111211.content:
The young dragon roared in anger at seeing Kelos struck down in front of her, taking a magic blast meant for her. She retaliated with a magic blast of her own. It struck the man in front, instantly transforming him into a small garter snake, his clothes and possessions falling on the floor along side of him. "I won't forgive you!" she hissed as she leapt over Kelos' twitching body, shielding her.

The other man reached down and picked up the confused snake. "Let's get out of here!" he shouted.

"No, we've got this, get to a better position!" the woman shouted as she readied another spell, then fired another blast at Nalisora. The dragon held her ground and took the hit from the magic blast. She then fired back at the woman with another blast from her acid breath. However, the attack proved ineffective against her. "Silly lizard, I cast a spell protecting me from your acid breath after your first attack." she said mockingly. The man began to stealthily circle around behind Nalisora as her attention was fixed on his companion.

Kelos let out a feminine moan from pain as she began to regain consciousness. Despite the intense agony, she opened her eyes. Though her vision was blurry, she was able to make sense of the scene. Nali had taken position in between her and the woman. One of the men was circling around, but the other one, Kelos didn't see. Was he circling around from the other side, or had Nali taken him down already? She tried to look around, but found herself unable to move her head. If he was still in the fight, things were probably lost. Nali looked like she was focused on the woman, and didn't see the man. Kelos tried to get up, but her body wasn't moving properly. She then tried to speak, but found that impossible as well as only a tiny squeak escaped her lips. An intense wave of pain shot through her body, but all Kelos could do was let out another feminine moan. She turned her eyes and watched Nalisora fire off a spell at the woman, only for it to seem to have no affect. The woman then returned fire, and this one certainly did have an affect, as Nalisora roared in pain.

"Damn it," Kelos thought. It was bad enough she was stuck in this feminine body in this impractical dress, but right now she couldn't even move to help. That had to change. Kelos closed her eyes and tried to relax and focused on her right pinky, and tried to move it. It wouldn't budge, but she kept at it. Before long she was able to wiggle it. As she did she felt the pain subside a bit and movement came back to her. She looked up at the man, who was focused on Nali. Clearly he thought the young dragon was the only threat at the moment. Kelos used this to her advantage. As the man crept closer, she popped up and grabbed his arm. Though he was bigger, Kelos remembered her hand at hand training and drove her heel into the back of his knee. She then twisted so the man's own weight forced his leg out from under him, sending him crashing to the ground with her on top of him. Kelos used all the strength her small frame had to pull his arm back behind his back.

"Human! You're okay!" Nalisora called out as she turned to see what the commotion was behind her.

"Can't you handle one injured girl on your own?!" the woman exclaimed as she saw her remaining companion get taken down. Nalisora took advantage of this distraction and pounced at the woman. Before she knew it she was on the floor, staring at the snarling jaws of a dragon. "Fine I give up, I give up!" she shouted.

"I do too," the man said.

"I'll tie him up," Kelos said. "I just need some..." Before Kelos could finish speaking, Nalisora blasted the man with a bolt of magic, transforming him into statue. "That won't be necessary, human," she said. The snake which had been their other companion slithered out of the man's now petrified pocket. "This is why I'm called the mistress of transformation! Fufufu."

"What are you going to do to me?" the woman asked nervously.

"I've always wanted a pet kitty," Nalisora said. "Or maybe you can be my servant. What do you think, human?"

Kelos struggled to stand up. "She's to dangerous to be a serv..." Kelos stopped mid sentence as a wave of dizziness washed over her. She stumbled and fell to the ground, again blacking out.

"Human!' Nalisora exclaimed. She then glared at the woman underneath her claws. If she dies, I'll do much worse to you!"
1321211111121121211211111112111211.title: Nali gets angry.

choices: It turns out Nali had to use a bit of magic to ensure Kelos' safety.
Nali just blinks, unsure what Kelos is inferring./Something else.
13212111111211212112111111121112111.content:
Kelos felt good.

Despite the fact that she was painfully aware about being blasted by a magic spell, she still felt good. Well rested. Relaxed. Calm.

And that all meant something not good simply had to be going on.

“Good morning, Mistress.”

“Mmr?” The princess mumbled; voice dry, as she cracked open her eyes ever so slightly. Getting out of bed wasn't something she particularly would have liked at the moment, but what she saw at first was enough to rouse her in full, and more so, caused her to jitter back to the headboard that lined behind her.

Just a mere foot away was the very same woman who had struck her down with that painful bolt of wizardry.

...Except, instead of the sultry ensemble of a high class vixen, she was dressed head to toe in the frilliest, most quintessentially domestic, maid's outfit, she'd ever seen; trim and lace marking the whole of her, while dutifully applied makeup kept the burglar's face doll-like and serene. It was almost a little uncanny, given the blank, dull look in her eyes.

Kelos let out a sigh of relief as she took it all in. It appeared she and her dragon companion both got through their little scrape, with the latter kind enough to allow her to sleep it off in one of the Keep's many visitor chambers. “I guess Nali really put you through the works, huh?”

“Mistress Nalisora's spellcrafting helped show me the error of my ways, and in gratitude, I now follow the will of both her, and you, Mistress Human, as a humble servant. I've done my best to ensure that the past several days of your recovery have been a comfortable one.”

The redheaded rolled her eyes, as she took on a more casual disposition. “Listen, my name isn't 'Human,' it's 'Kelos,' and-” Her voice silenced itself though, when a look of shock filled her. “Did you say 'several days?!'”

“Three days, to be precise, Mistress Human-Kelos. Your healing required an extended rest. Mistress Nalisora has been by near constantly to check in on your condition.” The new domestic spoke all this in a monotone, as a face of growing disbelief gained hold over Kelos. “Would you like a glass of water?”

“No!” She yelled as she attempted to stand. A thousand questions, scenarios, and horrors were blowing through her mind at that very moment. The scroll was only supposed to last a day! What in the world happened?! Why was she not a he?!

Worse, by now she must have completely missed the rendezvous time to meet Fia. Days late! And days away from her guards, too! If they'd not been scouring the land themselves, then surely they'd have returned to Grovan and alerted her father by now! There could be an entire kingdom-wide search going on!

“I've got to- I've got to go and- AH!” In a frenzy, Kelos tried to untangle herself from her web of bedsheets and start moving, but instead, a wave of dizziness overwhelmed her, and the nearby maid made quick to guide her to sit.

“Mistress Human-Kelos, you are still not fully healed. Moving is not advisable, and continued action may result in restraint.” Every word was coated in a cold, robotic lilt, despite the former wizard caringly pulling up a warm set of covers over her superior. “I am under orders by Mistress Nalisora to keep you safe.”

“Safe?! The fate of two kingdoms, and my own head are on the line! Hell it might already be too late!”

“Huuuummaaaannn~!”

Abruptly, Kelos then found herself being clung to by the form of a very excited young dragon, who had just padded into the room. “You'reokayyou'reokayyou'reokay!”

Near instantly, the anger boiling over in the princess started to simmer down to a doable cool. For some reason this silly little dragon kept on finding a way to hold her mood in check. “Yes. Hello Nali.”

The pointy-eared being pulled back from the embrace, with stars in her eyes. “I thought you weren't gonna get better but now you're better and we can both play more!”

“Mistress Human-Kelos still needs to rest before she can play, Mistress Nalisora.” Chimed the maid.

“Quiet slave!” Nali shot back, a bite of frustration in her. “Didn't I tell you to come to me when the Human did anything? You failed! Demerit! Demerit!”

“I apologize Mistress Nalisora. I will do better in the future.” If the servant had any sense of free will left in her, it'd wonder just what exactly a 'demerit' entailed, as she already was set to be the dragon's thrall for however long she deemed fit.

“Fufufu. You will, or face the wrath of the Mistress of Transformation!” Said mistress' hands stuck out proudly on her hips.

“Nali, there's something very wrong going on right now.” Kelos interrupted; watching the display from the coziness of her covers.

In a mood-swing that was as quick as a flash, the haughtiness left the young hostess, and was replaced by concerned uncertainty. “Human?”

“The spell that transformed me into a woman isn't turning me back. Now I'm going to be in a great deal of trouble if I don't return to a prince very soon.” The 'human' tired to explain things in as simple a way as she could. She figured mentioning how just being late to Traeven might result in getting her head on a pike anyway, would sully the mood a tad too much.

“You wouldn't happen to know why I'm still a girl, right, Nali?”
13212111111211212112111111121112111.title: Overslept

choices: Kelos promises not to use the magic words if Nali tells her.
Kelos accepts Nali's reason and changes the subject.
132121111112112121121111111211121111.content:
"Oh that," the young dragon responded hesitantly. "I know you might be mad, but I had to! The spell you were hit with was meant for me so I couldn't transform. If the target underwent a transformation, it would hurt, a lot. I had to use magic to keep you like that. It might have even killed you! I didn't want you to die!" She once again hugged Kelos, tears in her eyes.

Kelos wanted to get angry, knew she should be angry, but found it impossible while the young dragon was crying in her bosom. She sighed and stroked Nakisora's hair. "It's okay, I know you were trying to help. I just might be in a lot of trouble because of this."

"I apologize for the inconvenience my misguided attempt at theft has caused you, Mistress Human-Kelos," the maid said.

"It's more than just an inconvenience," Kelos said. "Prince Kelos was supposed to have arrived at Castle Traeven days ago. Not showing up means the war between Traeven and Grovan may resume. This would have rather severe personal consequences for me."

"You don't have to worry about that, Human," Nali assured as she looked up. "I sent a message to your servants, and told them how there was a fight and you helped protect my home and everything. They then sent a message to that castle, and everything was taken care of!" Her mood shifted, and she beamed with pride at her accomplishment. "Oh! and I said I'd send them another message when you woke up too!" She turned to the maid. "You there, send the message right now!"

"Yes, Mistress," the maid replied. She then turned and left the room.

"Nali," Kelos started to speak, hesitated for a moment, then continued. "You said you used magic to keep me like this."

"Yup," the young dragon answered. "

"This... This isn't permanent is it?" the princess asked.

"Well I guess you could say it is, but it isn't," Nali replied cryptically.

"So what does that mean?" Kelos asked, her concern growing.

"I think you'll like this, human," Nali stated proudly. "I made it so you can change between a boy and a girl whenever you say the magic words!"

"To turn into a girl you just need to say 'Make me a pretty princess!' " Nali explained.

"And to turn back into a man it's 'make me a handsome prince?' " Kelos asked, finding no change in her form after speaking, proving her guess was wrong.

"Nope," the young dragon explained. "I can't tell you yet, the maid said her spell can last up to five days, so it's not safe yet."
