Kelos tries to let Nali down gently, and says she has to leave.
1321211111121121211211111112111211112.content:
Kelos swirled these facts around in her head. It seemed her one off sojourn into another gender might turn into a more common occurrence from now on, thanks to the mystical involvement of her draconic companion. Surprisingly, just as Nalisora had predicated, this wasn't something she found herself particularly angry about. To those more blustery and insecure, having a spell upon them that wiped clean the slate of their masculinity, could prove enraging, but Kelos liked to think she was at least a tad more levelheaded.

Besides, assuming she could change back with just a few words, keeping her new 'quirk' under wraps should be simple, right? Something just to pull out as an interesting parlor trick to friends and family. Her sister, Orianna, would most certainly get a kick out of it.

Though getting the trigger would alleviate a slew of lingering worries...

“I must say, while I do appreciate the... gift, Nali, it's a shame I can't yet test it.” She paused, as an imploring tone filled her voice. “Are you sure you're not willing to spare those magic words early?”

A spark of mischievousness filled the dragon's eye, as she held her chin up haughtily. “Fufufu, impatient, aren't, Human? Can't stand the thought of going a few days without more wondrous feats from the Mistress of Transformation~?”

The bedded girl rolled her eyes. “Yes Nali, something like that.” It was more a desire to change back into a man, should her guards, or someone else approach the Keep. They already had a bandit scuffle that proved troublesome to deal with while in a skirt. It'd be nice to have an opportunity to be fighting ready, even if the chance of more people scaling the mountain proved thin.

Nalisora puffed exaggeratedly, as she moved in circles around the edge of Kelos' bed. “I told you, you can't change yet! You might get hurt!” She stopped. “But!” Dramatic pause. “As penance for allowing my princess-captive to be injured under my watch, I will do my best to keep you occupied and entertained until your full recovery!”

“...That's nice Nali, but if you could tell me the spell maybe-”

“I only got to show you one room, too! There's lots more cool stuff that'll be real fun to mess around with!” Kelos tried to get a word in edge-wise, but was halted by a set of excited outbursts from the other girl. It seemed she was dealing with a battle that was already over.

“Mistress Nalisora, I must warn you, it is not advisable to play with any extraordinary items that might cause Mistress Human-Kelos to experience a physical alteration. In her current state, the ramifications are dangerous, and potentially unknown.” As chance would have it, at that very moment, the spellbound maid returned to the room.

“Of course I know that, slave! Who asked you?! Always coming in when you're not wanted! Five demerits! Five!” Nali stomped her foot, as she angrily pointed at the housekeeper.

“My apologies, Mistress Nalisora. I just wished to inform you that I have finished casting messages to Castle Grovan, Castle Traeven, and Mistress Human-Kelos' escorts, all indicating to them that she is in recovering health.” While the woman's days of thieving may have come and gone, her ability to manipulate magic still proved useful in serving her mistresses; teleporting correspondences near instantly was a skill any person dabbling in the art was quick to learn.

Kelos, from where she sat, couldn't help but lightly giggle, as the tiny dragon still seemed to find some reason to bark at her new servant. From the looks of things, matters were finally starting to calm down, if just a little bit.

The thought though of more transformations did worry her. Maybe should she speak up? There was a chance here she was letting Nalisora run too rampant, which might not be the best idea, if it involved something even the whelp herself talked about being dangerous.

By all means, shouldn't she try and get going, too? Already she was days late to meet Fia! There was a chance the drake was proving too distracting to her overall goals, and the goals of her future kingdom.

Still... there was a part in her who was fascinated by the goings on that'd happened through the past few days. It was almost like a fevered dream. She'd been turned into a girl, befriended a dragon, flown with it to a mysterious, isolated Keep, and battled crooks and rogue spellcasters all the while! This was stuff ripped straight from storybooks!

...Plus she was still a princess. If memory served, leaving now would be breaking a promise to Nali.

13212111111211212112111111121112111121.content:
"Very well, Nali," Kelos relented. "I did promise to stay as long as I remained a princess. Plus, I do still feel somewhat weak." Kelos laid back down and pulled the covers over her. This bed was surprisingly comfortable for such an old castle to have. Just then something occurred to her. "Oh, what happened to those two men with her?" Kelos asked. "Did you do anything else to them?"

"Oh the snake guy slithered off somewhere," the young dragon said. "The statue guy, he's still a statue."

"This castle seems awfully big for just one maid, don't you think, Nali," Kelos suggested, winking at young dragon.

"Huh... Oh OH! That's right, Human. Fufufu," Nalisora replied happily as she struck a strange pose. "It seems being around the Mistress of Transformation has given you some good ideas!" She turned to the maid. "Slave, make sure she's comfortable and has everything she needs, I'll be right back." With that the young dragon ran out of the room excitedly.

"Do you require anything, Mistress Human-Kelos?" the maid asked.

"I am thirsty," Kelos said.

"Very well," the maid replied. She walked over to a small table on the far side of the room, where a pitcher and chalice sat. She filled the chalice, then brought it over to Kelos, who sat up in bed, took the chalice, then looked at the drink. The liquid was pink in color. Kelos eyed it suspiciously. "What is this?"

"It is juice from a fruit known as a blood orange," the maid explained. "It is grown in my native land."

Kelos shrugged and drank the juice, it was sweet, though tasted acidic as well, there were some other flavors as well. "Is that some raspberry in it?" she asked.

"No, but the blood orange does have a hint of a raspberry like flavor," the maid explained. "That made it preferred to the standard ora..." Their conversation was interrupted by the sound of a stone being dragged across the floor of the hallway.

Nalisora walked into the room in her dragon form, a rope in her mouth, tied to the statue of one of the male thieves. She dropped the rope, then transformed back to a human shape. "I was thinking, Human," she said to Kelos. "Since it was your idea, why don't you transform this one?"

"How? I don't know magic," Kelos replied, looking confused.

"Fufufu, I am a great and powerful dragon, I have just the thing!" she rushed around to the other side of the statue, and retrieved a small pouch that was dragging behind it. She then pulled a small ring with a black gemstone out of the pouch. "Behold, human! The statue changing ring thingy!"

"That's a... creative name," Kelos said, giggling slightly.

"You take the ring and put it on like this," Nali said, putting the ring on her left middle finger. "Then you touch the statue you want to change, and think about what you want it to look like." She touched the statue of the man and made a small change to his ears, reshaping them to a point. "See, it's easy." she took the ring off, skipped over to Kelos, and handed it to her.

"Is it safe for me to do?" Kelos asked.

"Yup, you're not being changed at all so it's fine," the young dragon said reassuringly. Kelos looked over to the maid, who remained silent, which Kelos took to mean she did not see any harm either.

132121111112112121121111111211121111211.content:
Kelos tentatively slipped the ring around her finger. She normally wasn't one for jewelry, but she normally wasn't one for dresses either, or for that matter, female pronouns. Life was proving to be filled with unique happenstances lately, and this was one she felt she ought not miss out on.

Within moments, she could feel the tiniest tingle radiated from her hand. If what Nali said was true, she now (temporarily) held the power to reshape and manipulate most anything she came in contact with.

She could just imagine what would happen if this artifact got in the wrong hands. Any regrets about the fates of the thieves further drifted from her thoughts. A smart assassin could topple kingdoms with this ring!

As these weighty matters dwelled on Kelos' mind, a certain dragon was showing far less patience. “Come oooonnn~! Test it test it test it!” Nali chirped, hopping up and down, as she pointed at the statue.

“R- right!” Kelos nodded, escaping from her daydream, as she stepped forward; the stone figure of the burly man looming over her.

For some reason, that notion in particular kind of annoyed her. As a man, Kelos was decently tall, but with her gender swapped out, most anything other than Nali seemed to tower over her. Almost subconsciously, her hand went to the brute's shoulder, and just sort of... pushed it down.

It was strange. With little resistance, the figure started shrinking. First just a little bit, but then soon enough, it was inches below Kelos' line of sight!

“Hah! He's so tiny now! Do more! Do more do more do more!” Nali seemed to be a frenzy; taking joy in the sight of someone experiencing their first taste of transformative power.

Not wanting to disappoint, Kelos continued. This time, focusing on the 'he' aspect of the dragon's statement. As someone who had their orientation altered herself, the princess felt just a tad drawn toward sharing the wealth with others. Plus, it just didn't seem right that a crook would be allowed to be the only man around three 'beautiful' women. He didn't deserve it.

This endeavor was far more intricate than the last, with Kelos taking reference from their newest maid. As she was from the east, Kelos wanted to diversify, and make this companion appear more from the frigid north; difficult as it was, working with stone, she ensured the shade of the locks were lighter, to reflect the future blonde's appearance.

Likewise, as the maid's features were sharp, and still spoke of the dangerous assassin-wizard she once was, Kelos wanted to remove any of that sense of original gruff this man had; making her cheeks cherubic, and eyes full of wonder.

This translated naturally to her curves. An expansive chest, and wide hips, spoke, at least visually, of someone who'd spent little time on the battlefield, or really, away from any homeward comfort. All the same however, she had a litheness to her that noted she wasn't an unkempt sloth.

It went without saying as well that she was to be donned in a maid outfit; the same as the other girl's. Their silhouettes uniform, but unique.

Kelos spent a near half an hour working on her 'piece' here, with the maid at her side watching in fascination as her fellow former thief was transformed. Nali could barely hold back her giddiness; keeping silent long enough, until Kelos stayed her hand to assess the work.

“Fun, right?!” The dragon bellowed.

“Ack~!” The Grovan royal yelped, so lost in thought from her actions. “I- I- I mean... yes. It's quite... interesting.” Truthfully she was enthralled. Never in her life had she experienced such a taste of magic. Slowly seeing her wants and thoughts take shape with just the touch of her finger... It was amazing! “Nali... I was wondering, is there a way to change aspects of this girl's mind?” Certainly the dragon had the power. The maid was proof of that.

“Mm-hmm!” Her draconic friend nodded. “Just put your hand to her forehead, and you'll be able to dive into her brains! Then you can make her think all kinds of funny stuff!”

While Kelos thought the idea of 'diving into a brain' was somewhat unclean, she still felt compelled to investigate- after all, she'd gone this far already.

Finger aligning to the brow, what happened next wasn't rightly describable. She saw into the former man's life, memories, personality, and everything that made him- now rather her, really, her.

And she could change things about it...

Like at first with the physical modifications, she started small. This person honestly wasn't happy. She was a former bandit in her old life, after all, and most who get into that profession aren't exactly excelling at life. If she was going to become her new maid, then she needed to be a tad more upbeat.

Not just upbeat, though... Perky. Blonde, curvy, and perky. That all sounded like it fit perfectly.

There was a slight charge, as something deep within the girl was changed fundamentally. She had no proof, but somehow, Kelos knew her magic went into effect.

As she dug deeper into the now 'perky' maid's mind, she found new things. Interesting things. Like, apparently she had a crush on the former sorceress-turned-servant. Maybe it was the romantic in her, but Kelos fancied the idea of making that pining a tad more overt; see how exactly the other, seemingly more stoic maid, might react.

Ultimately, the princess decided to not fiddle with any of the combat skills she parsed over. Just like with the wizard, who knew when something of that sort would prove useful? She did of course though instill an absolute loyalty toward her and Nalisora. That was simple common sense.

Kelos gasped slightly, as she let go, and finished her changes. All this was... quite a rush. “I think I'm done.” She said, turning to Nali.

“Cool~!” Without even asking, the dragon, using just a flick of her wrist, cast a spell intended to bring the statue to a human state. “Let's see how she turns out!”

A blinding flash burst through the room; Kelos and the maid having to cover their eyes, as they waited to see the results, which proved...

1321211111121121211211111112111211112111.content:
The new maid blinked a few times as she looked around the room. "Wow everyone's super tall!" she exclaimed. She then recognized the other maid. "Oh my, you're like totally cute in that maid uniform!" She skipped over and embraced the other maid. "How come you're taller than me now, Chie?"

"Mistress Human-Kelos used a magical artifact to alter your body," the maid whose name had been revealed replied in her now usual monotone. She then turned with her formerly male companion so she could see into a mirror.

"I'm so tiny and cute!" the maid replied as she gazed at the reflection of the two of them embracing. She let go of Chie, and walked over to the mirror, then looked down at her body, then back up at the mirror. She then traced her hands along her body, feeling her new figure. They made their way to her breasts, squeezing and bouncing them. "Oh wow they're so soft and bouncy!" She then made several cute poses.

"Nice work, human," Nalisora said, admiring the results.

"Thanks," Kelos replied. She then approached the new maid. "Do you like your new body?"

"I love it!" she exclaimed. "I probably shouldn't since I was a guy and all but I'm so super cute! And I get to be with Chie!" She latched on the other maid's arm and snuggled up against her.

"You need a name," Kelos said. She paused and thought for a bit. "Emma. Yes, that's it."

"Ohhh! I love it! Thank you, mistress!" the new maid said cheerfully. "Chie, call me Emma from now on, 'kay?"

"Very well," Chie replied.

"I make a cute girl, don't I, Chie?" Emma asked.

"Yes," Chie replied.

Kelos turned back to the young dragon as the two maids engaged in a rather one sided conversation. "What about the man you turned into a snake? Shouldn't we find him? It could be a problem if he escapes and manages to find something that can change him back."

"I'm sure he's in the castle somewhere," Nalisora said. "Probably slithered into a crack in a wall or something. Nothing to worry about."

"Maybe it's unlikely, but there's still a chance he could escape," Kelos said. "Besides, wouldn't another maid be nice to have?"

"I like the way you think, human," the young dragon said with a grin. "Let's find a snake!"

"Oh! Oh! Can I go look for him, mistress?!" Emma asked enthusiastically.

"We'll all go!" Nali said. "It'll be a game! The one who finds the snake gets a prize from the losers! One, two, three... Start!" With that the young dragon burst from the room.
1321211111121121211211111112111211112111.title: Everything's a success, and their new maid ...

choices: To Traeven to consult Marlin.
Home to Grovan to consult Xarlat.
132121111112112121121111111211121112.content:
"No, why would I?" Nali replied looking back at Kelos with a puzzled look. "I just figured you got the time wrong on the scroll." she shrugged.

"I guess that's possible," Kelos admitted. "I'd like to think my scribe isn't that incompetent though."

"Mistress Human-Kelos, am I to understand you were not originally a woman?" the maid asked.

"That's correct, I was transformed by a disguise scroll," Kelos said.

"I must apologize then, it is likely my magic preventing you from returning to normal," the maid explained.

"What?! How?!" Kelos exclaimed.

"Disguise scrolls are not a simple spell," the maid explained in a monotone voice. "They typically contain three parts. The first part transforms the subject into a new form. The second part is a timer. When it runs out, it activates the third part which transforms the subject back to normal. The spell you were hit with cancels active magic on the target, such as a spell that increases strength or the second part of the disguise scroll magic."

Kelos' jaw dropped. "A-Are you saying I'm... I'm stuck like this forever?!!!"

"Not necessarily," the maid replied. "However, it will require a new spell to transform you back to your original body."

"Can you make that spell?" Kelos asked.

"I can! I can!" Nalisora exclaimed, raising her hand in the air. She then stopped and lowered it as she thought a bit more. "But I don't know what you looked like as a boy." She then looked at the maid. "One hundred demerits for causing trouble!"

"Again, I apologize, Mistress Nalisora and Mistress Human-Kelos," the maid said.

"Is there anything that can be done?!" Kelos asked, desperate for a way to return to normal.

"A more accomplished wizard may have other options," the maid suggested.

"Or you can stay here with me!" Nali suggested. "We can play every day and you can punish our slave until you're satisfied!"

"If I can't find a way back to normal I might take you up on that," Kelos replied. "But I love Princess Fia and if we aren't married soon war might reignite between our kingdoms." She then turned to the maid. "Do you know of any such wizards?"

"There are only two options," the maid replied. "Marlin of Traeven, and Xarlat of Grovan."

"Oooh Oooh!" Nalisora exclaimed. "Didn't you say you when we met you were going to Traeven?!"

"Yes, and I'm from Grovan," Kelos said. "Those two crazy old men are really that good?"

"Yes, at least here in the west, they are the most accomplished human magic users," the maid said.

"Okay that settles it," Kelos replied. "I shall go..."
132121111112112121121111111211121112.title: Nali just blinks, unsure what Kelos is inferrin...

choices: The trio quickly arrives in Grovan
A bad storm forces them off course.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122.content:
"...Home to Grovan to consult Xarlat," Kelos finished. "I am loath to meet Fia in this form, and Xarlat has the benefit of knowing me, and what I looked like as a man. Marlin, I think we met once before the war, maybe, but it was brief."

"I'll bring you there," Nalisora offered.

Kelos' eyes lit up at the prospect of another flight on the young dragon's back. "I'd love that!" she blurted out before taking a moment to regain her composure. "I mean, if you insist, I'll accept your kind offer."

"Let's go!" the young dragon exclaimed. "I wanna see your home!"

"Mistress, may I come along?" the maid asked. "I believe my knowledge of the spell may be useful in restoring Mistress Human-Kelos to normal."

Nalisora looked over the maid and Kelos. "Sure, I should be able to carry both of you," she replied. "Follow me!" She led Kelos and the maid to the roof, then transformed back into her dragon form. "Okay human, climb on, and hold on tight."

"Right," Kelos said, as she followed instructions, securely wrapping her arms around the base of the dragon's long, muscular neck.

"Now then slave, climb on and hold on tight to the human," Nalisora said.

"Yes, Mistress Nalisora," the maid replied. She climbed on, and put her arms around Kelos' waist, and held tightly. This had the effect of pressing her large bosom into Kelos' back.

"Well this feels nice," Kelos said. If she had still been a man, the maid's breasts pressing into her would surely be giving her an erection. In her current body this was producing an odd warmth down below. She made a note to experiment further when back in her room.

"Okay here we go!" Nalisora said. She took a galloping start towards the edge then leaped off, spreading her wings and soaring through the air.

"This is still great!" Kelos exclaimed as the three of them soared through the skies. Though she couldn't help but notice the maid was holding her even tighter. Perhaps she was afraid of heights? She filed that away in her mind. "Nali! If you fly lower, I can find the road to follow back home!"

"It's fine, I know the way," the young dragon insisted. She picked her heading, and flapped her wings hard, giving a nice burst of speed. "We'll be there soon!"
1321211111121121211211111112111211122.title: Home to Grovan to consult Xarlat.

choices: The guard verifies Kelos' identity and lets them in.
The guard dismisses them and denies them entry.
13212111111211212112111111121112111221.content:
While it had taken days for Kelos' carriage to cross from Grovan into Traeven, Nalisora zoomed though the sky at speeds Kelos could have barely imagined. She watched the ground zip by. It seemed like mere moments when the familiar towers of her home appeared in the horizon. But this point the young dragon was flying low enough that Kelos could make out people on the ground. Farmers working the field, merchants with their carts bringing their wares to market, guards on patrol, children playing, never before had Kelos seen her kingdom like this. Most of these people were too engrossed in their lives to look up, but occasionally Kelos noticed one pointing in her direction. "If only everyone could see the world from above," she mused.

"I don't see what the big deal is," Nalisora replied.

"Because to you this is just an average day," Kelos replied. "For a human who has never gotten further off the ground than the top of a tall tree, I can assure you, this a complete new way to see the world."

"I guess," the dragon said. "I'm gonna land soon so get ready."

Kelos tightened her grip. The maid did not, but Kelos wasn't sure she could tighten her grip any further without crushing her. Nalisora flapped her wings hard, breaking her forward momentum, and bringing her in for a landing right outside the castle gate. The maid quickly hopped off, seemingly glad to be back on solid ground. Kelos was a bit slower to get off, but dismounted and looked up at the sky. "We must do that again."

"Sure!" Nalisora replied as she changed herself back to her human form.

At this point, Kelos looked around. They were just outside the gate. Behind them lay the town of Grovan, and the royal square, a park where the royal family would occasionally host events for the townspeople. A crowd began to gather around them, awed at the three girls who came from the sky. "Nali, why did you land outside the walls?"

"Oh, I found out that humans get mad when you land inside their castles, and they try to poke you," the young dragon replied.

"I can't deny that as a possibility," Kelos replied. "I suppose I had better tell the guard I'm home and need to see Xarlat right away." She walked away from the crowd toward the gate. A guard stood along the right side. He was carrying a glaive with an ornate blade that appeared to be made of gold, clearly more ceremonial than practical. Though Kelos knew the blade was merely gilded, and underneath was an entirely functional blade of fine steel. While it would never be used in combat, it was more than capable of dealing with an intruder. She approached the guard. "Please inform my mother and father that I have returned home, and wish to consult with Xarlat. My little problem is more serious than originally expected. This is my guest, Nalisora, and her servant. They will be accompanying me."

The guard looked at Kelos quizzically. "And who might you be, girl?" he replied.

"Oh, that's right, you won't recognize me like this," Kelos replied as she looked down at her body. "I am Prince Kelos. I was transformed into a woman, which is why I must consult Xarlat. I'm sure you can verify my identity with my parents."
13212111111211212112111111121112111221.title: The trio quickly arrives in Grovan

choices: They reach the throne room.
They meet someone in the hall.
132121111112112121121111111211121112211.content:
"Well you did just fly in on a dragon, which was pretty impressive," the guard replied. "I guess that's enough to at least send a message." The guard took out a scroll and scribbled down a message. He tied it up, then broke a seal, which caused the scroll to disappear. Within moments another scroll appeared in his hand. The guard opened it and read it. "You may enter," he said, stepping aside to let the three pass.

"Your dedication to your duty is commendable," Kelos said, as she walked by.

"You are to head to the throne room," the guard said. He then looked down at Nalisora, who was staring at him. "What?"

"That thing's cool," the young dragon said, pointing to his glaive.

"Umm, thanks," the guard replied, a bit confused.

Nali then rushed to Kelos' side. "Say human, can I have one of those things? Can I? Can I?"

"I'll see what I can do once I'm restored to normal," Kelos replied. "Let's hurry, I want to get back to myself as soon as possible."

" 'Kay," Nalisora said, as she turned from the guard to follow Kelos.

The trio made their way through the courtyard towards the central keep. Kelos looked around at the familiar sights of home. Guards not currently on watch were doing some sparring and exercising. servants were walking about, carrying out their duties. It seemed a typical day, except for the fact that she was a woman, and being escorted by a dragon.

"Wow there are so many humans here!" Nalisora exclaimed as she looked around excitedly.

"Yes, this castle is the center of my country's government after all," Kelos replied. They then entered the keep, where a butler was waiting. He was an older man, with grey hair, though he still had most of it. He was clean shaven and had strong, blue eyes. Kelos recognized him, as he had been in her family's service since before she was even born.

"Ladies, please follow me," he said, giving a polite bow, while gesturing for them to follow.

"I know my way to the throne room, Raymond," Kelos replied. "But come along, you do have your orders to escort us, do you not?" She continued walking in the lead.

"You know my name? Have we met before, miss?" the butler asked as he followed.

"Yes, did they not tell you who I am when they told you to meet us?" Kelos asked.

"They did not," Raymond replied, trying to place this woman in front of him, but coming up blank. "Though I must say you bear a striking to the queen when she was a young woman. Are you perhaps a relative?"

"Yes, I am," Kelos replied. "But don't worry, you aren't becoming forgetful, you wouldn't recognize me like this. I've changed quite a bit since you saw me last. I am Kelos, I was transformed into a woman."

"I'm terribly sorry, your highness!" Raymond exclaimed. "If I had known it was you..."

Kelos raised her hand to cut him off. "There's no need to apologize, you were simply not informed," she said.
132121111112112121121111111211121112211.title: The guard verifies Kelos' identity and lets...

choices: Kelos agrees with Orianna.
Kelos decides she's had enough time as a woman.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
While delayed by Nalisora asking about nearly every painting or artifact they passed, eventually the four of them reached the throne room. Raymond walked to the door, and prepared to open it, before pausing and turning to Kelos. "How should I announce your presence, your highness?" he asked.

"However you see fit," Kelos replied. "You will not offend me regardless of how you refer to me."

Nalisora interrupted. "You shall announce me as the mistress of transformation, the dragon goddess of the cool old fort in the mountains, the great and powerful Nalisora the Amazing, defeater of crazy wizard lady who turned her into an obedient maid who is here.."

"No." Kelos said flatly.

"That's a bit long, how about I come up with something?" Raymond said.

"Fiiine," the young dragon said, puffing her cheeks a bit, clearly annoyed at being denied her grandiose entrance.

Raymond opened the door to the throne room. "Announcing the return of her highness, Princess Kelos, accompanied by the Great Dragon Nalisora, and her servant."

Kelos walked in, followed by her guests. The fist thing she noticed was the various courtiers whispering. Even if she regained her manhood, Kelos knew she's probably never live this down. The second thing she noticed was rather than her mother and father, her sister Orianna was sitting on the throne.

"Welcome home, dear sister," Orianna said. "Mother and father were so worried hearing you were kidnapped by a dragon, they personally led the expedition to find you."

"Then we must send them notice of my safe return," Kelos said. "Though I was not kidnapped, I went willingly. After all, I could hardly present myself before my bride to be like this, so I decided to play with Nalisora for a bit."

"Nalisora being this girl?" Orianna asked.

"Yup, that's me, human's-sister," the young dragon replied.

"Well you've caused a great deal of trouble for Grovan, but I thank you for returning my precious little sister home," Orianna said. "Speaking of which, Kelos, just how long will you be my sister for anyway? We had been told the disguise scroll should have expired by now."

"There was a complication," Kelos replied. "While I was at Nali's fortress, we were attacked by a group of treasure hunters. One of them cast a spell on me which removed the disguise scroll's spell, trapping me like this. Thus, I have come home to seek Xarlat's aid in restoring me to normal."

Orianna's eyes lit up at this news. She immediately controlled herself, to not appear too happy with this news that she was now first in line for the throne, possibly permanently. "Of course," she said. "Though it seems a shame to let this opportunity go to waste."

"Opportunity?" Kelos asked.

"Yes, it's the perfect chance for some sisterly bonding," Orianna said. "Plus, a chance for you to learn more about a woman's heart, which could help immensely with Fia."
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: They reach the throne room.

choices: Kelos reaches Xarlat's lab first.
The aide reaches Xarlat's lab first.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
"As tempting as that may be," Kelos replied. "I'm going to have to say no. I've spent enough time as a woman. I wish to speak to Xarlat now."

"Fine, be that way, sis," Orianna said dismissively. "He's in his lab. Probably. He was working on some sort of experiment last I heard."

"Ohh can I come?!" Nalisora asked excitedly. "I wanna see a wizard's lab!"

"I don't see why not," Kelos said. "Plus I might need your minion there to tell Xarlat about her spell."

"I shall do whatever it takes to make amends, Mistress Human-Kelos," the maid replied.

"Let's go see this old wizard guy!" Nalisora exclaimed. She skipped out of the room.

"Is that girl really a dragon?" Orianna asked as she watched the mystical creature in human form.

"Yes," Kelos replied. "But she's been on her own for a long time, and she's still just a kid."

Nali peeked through the doorway back in the room. "Come on slowpokes!" she called out.

"Yes, mistress," the maid replied, as she hurried after the young dragon.

"Coming Nali," Kelos replied. She turned back to Orianna. "I was wondering if Mother and Father would let her stay here, at least for a little while."

"Aww, my little sister's maternal side is coming out," Orianna said.

"Funny," Kelos replied. "I just don't think a young child, human or dragon, should be living alone in a castle in the middle of nowhere."

"What about that maid?" Orianna asked.

"She was the leader of those treasure hunters," Kelos replied. "After she hurt me, Nali got mad and rewrote her mind with magic. She hasn't been with Nali long."

"Well you're not wrong about children not being alone," Orianna replied. "But little dragons eventually grow into big dragons and start kidnapping princesses. Which she's already done once I'll add. She's dangerous. Are you sure she hasn't done anything to your mind?"

"I'm fairly sure she hasn't," Kelos replied. "You see the maid's flat affect. I can assure you she wasn't like that before. Plus, a dragon allied with the kingdom would be a nice asset."

"Hurry up human!" Nalisora called out again. "The wizard guy's waiting!"

"Well I'd better get going," Kelos said. She turned to the doorway. "I'm coming!" She then hurried to catch up.

Orianna watched Kelos leave, then turned to her aide when her new sister was out of earshot. "Where is Xarlat really?"

"As far as I know, he is in his laboratory, as you thought," the aide replied.

"I believe Kelos is being controlled by that dragon," Orianna said. "It is vital to Grovan's future she be kept a woman until that control is broken. You must tell Xarlat to do whatever it takes to stall changing her back until then without letting them know the reason, and you must do so before those three arrive."

"I understand, your highness," The aide said. "I shall deliver the message personally. Now if you'll excuse my rudeness as I make haste." With that he turned and sprinted out a different door, taking an alternate path to Xarlat's lab.

Orianna grinned wickedly. That controlled by the dragon story was plausible enough. If she played her hand well, her inheriting the throne was within her grasp.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Kelos decides she's had enough time as a wo...

choices: Xarlat finds this problem interesting and vows to do what he can to help.
Breaking the spell is barely worth his time, Kelos can wait for a bit.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
Thanks to Nalisora's childish curiosity about the castle delaying Kelos, the aide managed to slip by the three and reached Xarlat's laboratory first. He knocked on the door. "Master Xarlat, I have come with orders from her highness, Princess Orianna." He waited for a few moments with no response. He prepared to knock again when the door slowly creeped open. Seeing no one there, the aide cautiously entered. The door then closed behind him with no viable cause, leaving him in pitch darkness. Then a blue orb of flame appeared before the aide, then slowly moved deeper inside faintly illuminating the corridor. Realizing this was to be his guide, the aide followed it through the winding corridors of the laboratory. Soon the aide noticed a light ahead. Clearly this was where Xarlat was currently working. As he reached this area, the orb disappeared with a puff of smoke. The aide stepped forward and saw a man in a dark grey robe and a black cape sitting at a table. On one side was an old scroll the man was currently reading, while various beakers and jars bubbling with unidentifiable contents. The aide opened his mouth to speak, but man spoke first.

"What pointless idiocy does that featherbrained princess feel is worth interrupting my work this time?" Xarlat asked without even looking up.

"It's Prince Kelos," the aide replied, igoring the wizard's remark about his princess. "Rather Princess at the moment. She was transformed into a woman, and is coming to seek your aide to transform back. However, Princess Orianna feels Princess Kelos is being controlled by a dragon, and therefore should not be changed back until this control is broken."

"No she doesn't," Xarlat replied. "She believes that as long as Kelos is a woman, she is next in line for the throne. Whatever, she's ordering me to not help Kelos then?" He looked up from the book, took a beaker with a green liquid, then poured it into a jar containing a red liquid. A puff of pink smoke emerged from the jar, and the contents slowly lost their color, becoming a clear liquid. Xarlat began to write notes about the effect of mixing.

"Yes, but not to let Princess Kelos or the dragon realize this," the aide replied.

"I'll consider it," Xarlat replied. "First I must examine Kelos. If the problem is more interesting than my current research, I will work on it. If it is not, I'm certainly not opposed to making Kelos wait until the King and Queen come back and override the Princess' order." With that the lights in the chamber pulsed. "Speak of the devil."

"Princess Kelos must not find me here!" the aide exclaimed.

"Fine, drink the purple one," Xarlat replied.

The aide cautiously picked up a baker with a purple liquid in it. "What does it do?"

"Ensures Kelos won't find you here," Xarlat replied. "I'd hurry if I were you, I've already opened the door for Kelos."

The aide swallowed the mysterious liquid in one gulp. It surprisingly had a sweet, pleasant taste to it, with a hint of fruit. "This tastes pretty nice," the aide said, and in doing so realized something was very wrong. Looking down, the first thing the aide noticed were her new breasts. The second thing was she was now wearing a maid outfit.

"Don't talk, just curtsy when Kelos arrives, give no indication of recognition, then leave when I dismiss you," Xarlat said. With that, voices could be heard down the hall.

"This place is so cool," Nalisora exclaimed. "I'll bet this wizard has a lab filled with stuff!"

"It's always seemed a bit sparcely equipped to me," Kelos said. "But somehow it always has exactly what is needed."

"Cause it's magic, obviously," Nalisora said. "Oooh I see a light ahead!" The trio approached Xarlat and the new maid. Following Xarlat's instructions, the new maid curtsied.

"You may go now, girl," Xarlat said.

With that the new maid turned to leave, the blue orb reappearing to light her way.

"So is your problem any less mundane than that stupid maid's?" Xarlat asked.

"I'm sure you don't recognize me like this, but I am Prince Kelos, I have been turned into a woman by a disguise scroll, then I was hit by a spell that disrupted that magic, preventing me from turning back."

"This might be mildly interesting," Xarlat replied. He waved his arm and a blue light traced Kelos from feet to head, then back to her feet before dissipating. "This could be a problem. There's a spell lingering on you. I'm afraid it will make an attempt to transform in any way fail."

"Is there anything you can do to break the spell?" Kelos asked.

"If I may, I'm the one who cast the spell in question, if you require any information about it, I will tell you all that you need," Nali's maid said.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: The aide reaches Xarlat's lab first.

choices: Kelos wants to report back to Orianna
Kelos wants to show Nali around the castle.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
As Xarlat examined Kelos, he came to a conclusion, this wasn't worth his time. The spell was somewhat tricky, and lesser wizards would surely find it impossible to remove, but it was child's play to him. He had already formulated a counter spell in his head. Then all that would be needed was a simple transformation and Kelos would be a prince once more. Five minutes work top, but those five minutes could be better spent on pretty much anything else. He glanced over to the maid. While he first considered Orianna's concerns a foolish attempt at keeping Kelos female so she would be higher in line for succession, the dragon had done a number on this other woman's mind. He still doubted Orianna was sincere, but this made the idea somewhat plausible. What had this dragon done to that woman, he wondered. Right now this seemed a more interesting avenue of research to the old wizard. "Yes, I believe I could use your assistance," Xarlat finally said. "This magic affecting Kelos is tricky, and I could use all the help I can to solve it." He turned back to Kelos. "With her assistance, I believe I can have your highness out of that dress and into your armor in three days, tops. Likely sooner."

Kelos sighed. "Three days? Is there anything that can speed this up?" she asked.

"You and your little dragon friend staying out of my lab so I can get to work," Xarlat replied. "I'll call for you when I'm finished."

"Aww... I wanted to watch!" Nalisora said, while looking closely at the beakers and test tubes.

"Stay away from those!" Xarlat yelled.

"Fiiiine," the young dragon said with a pout.

"Let's leave Xarlat to his work," Kelos said. "I'll see what I can do about getting you one of those glaives."

"Yay!" Nalisora exclaimed. "Okay slave, I order you to stay here and assist Xarlat with his research."

"Yes, mistress," the maid replied.

"Okay human, let's go," Nali said. She grabbed Kelos' hand and started pulling her towards the door.

"Wait, the light to guide us out," Kelos protested.

"Don't need it, I can see fine," the young dragon said. "Dragons can see in almost total darkness. If it's close enough we don't even need to see to see."

"You're not in your dragon form right now though," Kelos said.

"Yeah, but it still works," Nali said confidently, as she bumped into a wall. "When I'm paying attention," she finished sheepishly.

Kelos laughed slightly, though it came out as a rather feminine giggle. "I'll believe you, but remember I can't see in the dark very well."

"Don't worry, you're safe with me!" Nali replied as she carefully led Kelos throught the darkness back towards the door.

"A prince turned into the princess and then getting saved by the dragon is certainly an unusual tale," Kelos commented.

"Better than the same old story with different names all the time," Nali replied. "So what should we do next?"
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Breaking the spell is barely worth his time, Ke...

choices: It is a big deal, speak to Orianna at once.
Nalisora is right, it isn't that important.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
"How about I show you around the castle?" Kelos suggested.

"That sounds fun," the young dragon replied. "I wanna see your room! I'll bet it has all sorts of cool stuff in it."

"Very well, let's start there," the prince turned princess agreed. "I can show you my collection of ancient weapons. I have a dagger that was said to have been owned by the first king of Traeven. Which I'm sure King Arthras would love to get his hands on if he knew it existed."

"You have something that belonged to the founder of the country you're fighting?" Nalisora asked.

"I suppose it does sound a bit odd now," Kelos agreed as she led her guest through the halls to her room. "However, our kingdoms were once allies. It was a gift long ago, given to my great, great grandfather. Since then it's been passed down to the first son of the king and queen on their 16th birthday. Or first daughter if there are no sons."

"Shouldn't it be given to your sister then?"

"I may temporarily be a woman, but I was the first born son," Kelos said as the pair continued on.

"Oh right," Nalisora said. "I've only ever known you as a Princess, so I forgot."

"I suppose that is true," Kelos replied. "Anyway, my room is right around the corner here." The two of them turned, and Kelos was shocked by what she saw. Servants were removing furniture and boxes from her room, while others were carrying in others. Kelos rushed up to them. "What are you doing?!"

"Orders from Princess Orianna," a maid overseeing the operation said. "Your room is unsuited for a lady, Princess Kelos. We are redecorating it. Don't worry, it shall be done within the hour. May I suggest having some tea in the meantime?"

"No, I demand you put everything back the way it was!" Kelos insisted.

"Princess Orianna said you might object, but I can assure you, this is for your own good." the maid said. As things were brought out she checked them off a list. "We're keeping careful track of your belongings. If you are somehow transformed into a man again, they can be returned."

"I shall be restored within three days. I can assure you this is quite unnecessary," Kelos stated.

"It is unseemly for a Princess to sleep in a man's room," the maid insisted.

"It's my room!" Kelos exclaimed.

"Indeed, so it must be made into a proper lady's room for you, Princess," the maid insisted. "Princess Orianna's orders. If you have an issue with it, I suggest you discuss the matter with her."

"Is this really a big deal?" Nalisora asked. "You can just get your stuff back when you turn back into a man."

"I suppose," Kelos said. She thought the matter over as she watched some servants carry a lady's vanity with a large mirror attached into her room.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Kelos wants to show Nali around the castle.

choices: Kelos sees Ori placing a certain Traeven dagger on her mantle.
Before anything, Ori invites them to tea. It's strangely lilac colored.
Nali, thinking of Human's best interest, decides to prank Ori.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
Kelos would be lying if she didn't find herself curious with what Orianna had in mind for a 'proper young lady's' room, but lost her taste for the spectacle upon seeing books on military tactics and worldly history being replaced by embroidery sets, and- Gods, more makeup than she ever rightly should have to own!

“Would you- hey don't touch that! I need...” The maids too were of no help: sweeping and swooping around their new princess to get the job done. At this point they either were invested in their duty, or convinced of Ori's words that Kelos shouldn't be listened to. Even her dragon companion seemed nonchalant about the clearly horrendous goings on! “Nali, don't play with that!” She scolded: watching the youth fiddle with a tube of lipstick.

“Aww...” The whelp cried: placing the toy back on its vanity. She just wanted to see what it tasted like!

“I think I've had just about enough of this!” The technically demoted {i]second in line to Grovan huffed: crossing her arms under her chest. “Clearly these servants won't budge, so I guess we will have to pay my sister a visit.”

Without missing a beat, the duo swiftly began trudging through the halls: Kelos' stomps far from the graceful movements she'd gradually been adjusting into.

Nali, noticing this discontent, couldn't help but purse her lips. “Does Human not like her sister?” She innocuously asked: holding genuine interest. Very few dragons were given the luxury of close ties to their siblings: broods often spreading out and not reconnecting for years, if ever Heck! Were she not the strong, infinitely powerful Mistress of Metamorphosis that she was, she might... begrudge the fact that she didn't really have a family.

...A small frown did eek its way onto her face, though.

The reverberations of clacking heels came to a halt, as the redhead wearing them sighed: turning to younger girl. “I certainly do not hate Ori.” She answered: hand going to absently brush through the dragon's hair. “We've gone through a lot together growing up, and I care deeply for her.” A pause, as a sly grin formed on her face. “But don't let her go and hear that!” Before the clacking noted they were walking again. “This just feels like another one of her sorry pranks. She's probably tittering over having a 'little sister' to play with, and I did somewhat blow her off when trying to find Xarlat earlier. This is probably payback.”

“A prank?” Nali repeated: eyes widening. “Oh! Oh! Then Human, we should prank her back! You don't want to look like you have bad prank etiquette!”

“Prank etiquette?” Kelos questioned: eyebrow raising.

A vibrant cocksuredness occupied her companion's face. “Fufufu~. It seems the poor Human still has a lot to learn! It's okay. Not {i]everyone can have a big dragon brain!” She emphasized this with a knock to the noggin. “If Human's sister has initiated a prank off, then it's only fair that Human pranks next! Otherwise Human will just keep getting pranked and pranked until she's pranked into oblivion!” Arms rose up in an exaggerated, explosive motion.

It was a gesture Kelos wanted to shake her head at, as she pushed the door in to enter Orianna's room. She was sure her sister would quit this silly game if asked politely. What was the worst that could happen?
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: A Limit to Things

choices: Nali's right, Kelos decides to put her foot down.
Kelos decides to trust Orianna.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
"Ah, I've been expecting you, sister," Orianna said as Kelos entered, her new dragon friend close behind. "Come, won't you join me for some tea?" Orianna gestured to a table which had three cups with a tea pot in the center.

"We do have a lot of things to discuss," Kelos said with an angry glare.

"Human, the thing we talked about," Nali hinted.

"Let's see how this goes first," Kelos replied. She approached the table and sat down, in an unladylike fashion. The young dragon followed suit, sitting next to Kelos.

"I'm glad you're being reasonable about this," Orianna said. She picked up the tea pot. "Really, you'll thank me tonight. That cot you called a bed was ill suited for a princess. Why, you would surely be unable to sleep a wink in it."

"My bed was perfectly comfortable," Kelos said.

"For a boorish prince, perhaps," Orianna said, pouring some tea into Kelos' cup. "But not for an elegant and refined princess. I simply couldn't bear to see my poor little sister suffer in a hard bed with scratchy sheets." She poured another cup for Nalisora,

"I am not an elegant and refined princess," Kelos said.

"Not yet, but don't worry, I'll help you after we've had tea," Orianna replied.

"I don't intend to stay a princess long enough to need yout help, and I want all of my things put back in my room immediately," Kelos said. She picked up the cup and prepared to drink, but paused as she noted the unusual color. The liquid in the cup smelled like tea, but it was lilac, certainly odd. She stared at it. "Nali..."

"Yes, human?" the young dragon replied.

"Is there something wrong with this tea?" Kelos asked.

"Don't worry, I'd never put anything in the tea to harm you," Orianna assured.

Nalisora picked up her cup and sniffed it. "It's a potion!" She sniffed it again. "It's disguised so I can't tell what kind. Don't drink it, human."

Kelos put the cup down. "So, just what were you trying to get me to drink, dear sister?"

"It's nothing harmful," Orianna insisted. "It's just a little something to help you relax. I'm sure you need it after what you've been through. I'm only looking out for your best interests."

Kelos glanced over to her companion, who shrugged, unable to determine the type of potion.

"I'd never do anything to harm my sweet little sister," Orianna insisted.

"I believe that, but I find myself questioning your definition of harm, Ori," Kelos said.

"See, human," Nalisora exclaimed. "Human-sister's just gonna keep pranking you and pranking you!"
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Before anything, Ori invites them to tea.

choices: Going to bed/The next morning
Ori schemes over the current situation. Does she use Kelos' story as dirt?
The king and queen return/Something else
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
Staring at the cup for a good moment, silence deafening the room, Kelos reached her hand over to it. If one were to play attention, they'd see Orianna's eyes briefly light up.

...Only for them to twitch, as Kelos pushed the tea away: declining. “I'm sorry, dear sister, but I'm going to have to hold off for now. I know you work quite hard on your potions, and I'm sure whatever effects it'd have would be...” A pause, as she tried to find the best phrasing. “Enjoyable, but I don't think any sort of inebriation would be a good influence for Nali here.” She emphasized that by placing a hand on the girl's shoulder.

The older heiress seemed strained for only the tiniest of a moment... until a sly smile began to adorn her face. “My goodness. I teased you earlier about your maternal side, but you really are protective of your little dragon friend here, aren't you~?”

The new princess's face lit up in a fiery blush, but before she could rightly rebuke that remark, Nalisora was quick to jump in: features sharp in victory. “Fufufu~. Human's silly sister has it backwards! As my officially kidnapped princess, Human is to be kept under my protection forever and ever! So that means no potion pranking!”

“Forever and ever, huh~?” Ori chimed in the most patronizing tone imaginable: trying hard not to giggle.

“Nali...” Kelos hissed in embarrassment.

“Oh, it's quite alright, sister.” Orianna interjected. “As an 'officially kidnapped princess,' you ought to play your role! Forever and ever, even!”

The younger royal simply just huffed, as she crossed her arms under her ample chest: feeling like this wasn't a hill she'd be able to claim victory over.

“But of course, tell me though! Now that we've got time, how did you two meet, and what exactly went on while you were away?” Orianna urged.

It appeared, from the more troubled subject matters that began this conversation, things were transitioning to a lighter affair, as Nali was eager to give details on her grand adventure with Human, while 'Human' did her best to quiet down what embellishments she could: hard to do, when the young whelp was casting them every other word!

This went on for a long enough while, with laughter, red cheeks, and anything and everything in-between. Kelos did have to admit, that after the stress of everything, it was... nice to vent, and not have to deal with rampant craziness. Even if the tea that was supposed to help her even more grew cold.

“Well I can see how you got yourself wrapped around our little 'Mistress of Transformation's' finger, dear sister!” Ori tittered, as the trio stood. It was growing increasingly late, and at some point, both princesses took note that Nali was getting a tad worn.

“I'm not tired!” The dragon insisted, even through a yawn that escaped her lips. Absently, she allowed Kelos to take her hand, as they began meandering themselves to the exit.

“Yes, well...” Kelos paused, as she leaned in to whisper to her sister. “We can discuss more... permanent arrangements for her tomorrow, perhaps? Alone?”

A wide grin adorned itself on Ori just then. “Only if it's over tea~.” She said, as she leaned in to offer two quick pecks on each of Kelos' cheeks. “Now enjoy your new room!”

...And suddenly. Terribly so, Kelos found the door closed on her face.

“My room!” Kelos gasped with a rising fervor. She got so distracted, she couldn't negotiate demands to change it back!

“...Human?” Nali questioned: sounding very groggy.

The 'kidnappee' paused and just sighed. “It's nothing, Nali. I think my sister just got away with another 'prank.'”

“Mm, Human's sister should get pranked, too.” The dragon hummed, as she sleepily leaned into the older girl's side.

“Maybe...” 'Human' answered, with an exasperated smile. “But for now, let's crawl into bed, shall we? Apparently my new one is especially comfortable.” As they trotted off, she finished the statement with a vaguely peeved grumble.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Nali's right, Kelos decides to put her foot...

choices: Kelos changes earrings.
The magic is strong, they won't come off!
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
Kelos awoke on the plush carpet of her newly redecorated room under a leather blanket. Still half asleep she wondered why she was sleeping on the floor and why she had a leather blanket. As she shook off the lingering drowsiness she quickly realized the situation. Nali had wanted to sleep with her, and Kelos obliged. However, at some point during the night, the young dragon had apparently reverted to her true form, pushing Kelos out of her own bed before covering her with an stretched out wing.

The new princess slipped out from underneath the dragon's wing and stood up. Nalisora was curled up into a ball, sleeping peacefully, covering herself with one wing, while the other had been covering Kelos. For an instant Kelos wondered if it was deliberate on the dragon's part, before remembering she had also pushed her out of bed. Kelos simply sighed, then went to open the wooden shutters on her window. The fresh morning scent wafted in, along with a bit of an early morning chill. Kelos looked around her room and spotted a lavender robe hanging on a rack near a vanity. She walked over and put it on, instantly feeling much warmer. She thought it strange that the cold hadn't affected her as much when she was still a man. Perhaps it was her now smaller body? It was something she'd have to get used to as long as she had this body.

She sat down at the vanity. It had lots of makeup and a jewelry box in front of a mirror. Curious, she opened the box's lid. Inside were dozens of pairs of ear rings, necklaces, bracelets, rings, all fit for a princess. She picked up a pair of gold stud earrings with rubies set in them. Examining them closely, she noted the posts seemed sharp. like they could effortlessly poke through her unpierced ears. They seemed to glow slightly, then Kelos found her hands moving on their own. As if she had done it a thousand times, Kelos pushed one earring through her right earlobe, then the other through the left, before applying the clasps. She admired how they looked on her in the mirror, and then realized what had happened. Ori had put enchanted earrings in the jewelry box.

As Kelos put on the earrings, Nali began to sniff the air and wake up. "I... smell... a magic item," she said sleepily.

"Yes," Kelos replied. "It seems my sister has pulled yet another prank on me." She turned her head to show Nali the earrings. "I suppose it's harmless enough. They enchanted me to put them on. But then it is odd a girl my age doesn't have her ears pierced so I'm sure Ori was only trying to help."

Nalisora transformed back into her human form and bounded up to Kelos. She examined the earrings closely, sniffing them and visually inspecting them. "I don't think their magic is done yet," the dragon said. "You should take them off!" She then rummaged around in Kelos' new jewelry box. "Here, these are safe." She held up another pair of earrings.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Going to bed/The next morning

choices: Tea time with Ori.
Nali hunts for magic objects./Nali secretly follows Kelos.
An hour later./Something else.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
Not wanting to disappoint her dragon companion, Kelos attempted to unlatch the earrings... But the adjective here was 'attempt.' The new princess's equally new hands were certainly more delicate than they used to be, but not so much so as to be unable to handle jewelry.

“It appears they've grown rather attached to me.” She hummed through pursed lips, while leaning in closer to the mirror. Her aim was to get a closer look, and see if there was anything wrong, but this also afforded a better opportunity to admire the expertly cut rubies. Despite the enchantment, Ori certainly had good taste... The red accented her hair well, while the gold helped them pop and not fade into the background.

“I knew it!” Nali huffed with a growl. So soon from her transformation, you could easily see a tiny plume of smoke escaping from the tip of her nose. “Human's prankster sister is on a mission to just keep pranking and pranking! She's like a prank monster!”

“For what it's worth,” Kelos noted, still eyeing the mirror. “This doesn't seem like the worst prank.”

The dragon was swift to raise a pointed finger at that. “Human should know by now that magic stuff can have lots of extra magic stuff stuffed right in it! Who knows what spell got cast on you?!”

Now that did raise some concerns in the royal, as she backed off from the vanity. “I suppose you're right.” She said with a sigh. “I really shouldn't be so lax with Ori. I know she likes to tease, but she's taking matters far further than they ought to be.” There was also the uncomfortable worry stirring about the recent status change she'd technically received. From prince to princess wasn't so bad, but at the moment she'd been demoted to second-in-line princess.

“That's right!” Her whelp friend barked in return. “Which is why we should set up a super duper mega prank to get back at her! Equivalent exchange!”

Kelos couldn't help but offer a small smile, as she ran a hand across the top of the young girl's head. “I'll settle for a way to get these off first.” She indicated towards the locked gems. Though internally she pondered if there was a way to make them completely unenchanted... They were quite lovely. Wearing them out certainly wasn't going to be a chore.

Taking the touch of her kidnapee almost like a receptive pet, Nali subtlety tilted in closer. “So is that what we're doing today? More Human-Sister stuff?”

The noble's eyes squinted as she thought. There were a myriad of matters to deal with. Xarlat said a reversal potion wouldn't be sorted for at least three days, so for the time being, she'd remain of the fairer sex. Kelos' greatest concern however was ensuring Nali's ability to stay in Grovan. Which involved talking with Ori over tea... Alone. “For a little while, perhaps. Though would you be willing to do something for me, Nali?”

“Human?” The drake questioned with curious features.

Kelos was somewhat hesitant towards how to phrase this, until an idea wormed itself between her ears. “You see, I think you're quite right that my sister needs a good pranking! But to ensure total and utter prank dominance,” she assertively put a fist in her palm. “I need to go in and prank my sister by myself. On my terms!” There was an exaggerated bravado in her voice at that.

“ What I need from you though,” a finger gently touched Nali's forehead. “Is to inspect this room. Thoroughly! Make sure there aren't any possible pranks around, like my earrings, while I'm gone for say, roughly... an hour or so?”

Nali gasped as such an important task was dole out to her... Plus it'd give a chance to mess around in Human's room! “Fufufu~. Leave it to the Mistress of Transformation to sniff out any transformative trinkets the Prank Monster's laid out!” She struck a truly ominous pose at that. Or at least... What she thought of as ominous.

“Right. Of course.” Kelos stiffly said, as a sweatdrop formed. So long as it kept her from running a muck around the castle though... She wanted the dragon to live here, and that might not go so well if she winds up bothering Xarlat, and messing with the maids' routine. “So an hour. And after that, I'll give you a grand tour of everything!”

“Aye aye, Human!” Nali seemed to be only paying half-attention, as she was already snooping under the bed, and preparing to combat any recently developed dust bunnies.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: The magic is strong, they won't come off!

choices: Orianna's demands are reasonable.
Orianna wants something outrageous.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
Kelos stood outside of Orianna's room, hesitant to knock. She was still going over in her head what to say. This situation needed to be handled delicately. While she was certain she could get Ori to agree to let her new dragon friend stay and help convince their parents to make it permanent, Kelos was a bit concerned about the price of cooperation. At the very least she'd demand some sort of fashion show, Ori might even try to get her to agree to stay like this! As Kelos was lost in thought, Ori's door swung open.

"My, if it isn't my dear little sister!" Ori said. "What brings you to my room so early?"

"I just wanted to thank you for these lovely earrings," Kelos said cheerfully, as she twisted her head from side to side to show them off. A voice in her head told her that wasn't quite right.

"Oh. good, I wasn't sure you'd find them so soon," Ori replied. "I included a special enchantment just for you."

"Yes, I've noticed I can't quite remove them," Kelos commented. "Though I suppose that isn't really much of an issue. They certainly do suit me."

"They absolutely do!" Orianna said. "By the way, have you noticed the other effects?"

"Other effects?" Kelos asked.

"No? Well, they'll just be a surprise then," the elder princess said. "But may I ask, where is your little dragon friend?"

"She's looking for other magical items in my room," Kelos said. "OH! That's right, I wanted to talk to you about Nali. I can't believe I forgot something so important!"

"Of course," Ori replied. "Would you care to discuss it over some tea?" She stepped back and motioned for Kelos to come inside.

"I want Nali to live here," Kelos said as she walked in.

"You want to invite a dangerous creature to live in the castle?" Orianna replied.

"She's not really dangerous," Kelos protested. "From what I can gather, her mother was killed, and Nali's been living alone in an abandoned castle ever since. I don't want to leave her alone like that."

"Well far be it for me to go against my little sister's maternal side," Orianna said as she prepared tea. She poured two cups and brought them over to the table.

Kelos inspected the tea, which appeared normal. "This is just regular tea?"

"Of course," Ori assured. "I would never try the same trick twice."

Kelos hesitantly took a sip. "It's good!"

"Naturally. I'll have you know your big sister is an accomplished tea maker."

"I'll remember that," Kelos replied. "But about Nali."

"Yes, yes, I'll add my support to allowing her to stay," Orianna said. "However, I do want something in exchange."
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Tea time with Ori.

choices: Kelos accepts Ori's first offer.
Kelos accepts Ori's second offer.
Kelos declines wholesale/Something else.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
“Well, Little Sister,” Ori began, calmly sipping on her tea. She had to phrase this in a properly delicate way. “While I am all for you adopting young Nalisora-”

“Mmph?!” Kelos interrupted: choking back on her drink. “A- Adopting?” She stuttered after a weak cough.

“Would it not be?” Her sibling prodded. “While a dragon, that girl is clearly not a pet. She can think, speak, and apparently scrounge for magical artifacts! If what you've told me she's doing right now is true.” She giggled somewhat in the pause. “She's also very notably taken a preference to you. You're her 'Human.' I doubt she'd particularly like being watched over by the maids. Didn't you say she turned a bandit into one?”

The younger royal cringed at that, but as the words lingered, she slowly turned more contemplative. “I suppose you're right...” Just the thought though of 'adopting' Nali was making strange butterflies tingle in her stomach, in a way she couldn't properly understand. Even if this was more or less what she came in to ask, the manner with which Ori was wording it...

“Of course I am~.” Orianna happily chimed. “Now as I was saying, adopting Young Nalisora is going to come with its own set of challenges! Especially if she grows up to be a proper dragon! But I'm more thinking of matters in the immediate moment.”

This was more what Kelos was expecting to talk about in this conversation. She gladly latched onto it. “Well I figure she'll need her own room...” She mused. “Though if she prefers mine, I don't mind her staying there. But she'll need a bed. We'll have to renovate it again. Maybe make it-”

“A tad more feminine?” Ori quipped: tongue in cheek.

Kelos just stared at her in a deadpan. Honestly, would that even be possible?

“But yes, yes, Little Sister. You're being quite the utilitarian! However, you're missing the forest for the trees.” With a dramatic flourish, she pointed a finger towards Kelos.

It took a moment for her to understand, but eventually it clicked, as she glanced down. “My gender?” She asked. “Xarlat said he'd have a reversal potion sorted out in the next few days.”

“Ah, Yes. Well...” Ori was in the process of eyeing her nails as she spoke this. “I believe that the change back should be delayed for a while longer.”

“Ori?” Kelos implored.

“Hear me out, Little Sister!” The older royal happily defended. “Young Nalisora only knows you for the you you currently are now! And the you you currently are now is?...”

“A... princess?” The 'princess' cautiously answered.

“That's right! Good girl! Which is why, for the benefit of Young Nalisora the most, of course, we should try and instill as much of a sense of stability into things as we can, at the moment. You're her Human, and her Human has only shown her feminine side! Changing yourself to be so much more masculine could come as quite a shock!”

“It's not 'changing myself,' Ori! I'm just going back to normal...” Kelos crossed her arms under her chest at this, and began glancing off to the side.

“That's not how she'll see it! To her, her Human is a gentle, oh so maternal redhead, so anything else could be quite jarring!”

Kelos' lips pursed as this was all being said. “So what are you proposing then, Ori?”

“I'm proposing, that until we know your dragon friend can comfortably acclimate to Grovan, you stay as your gentle, oh so maternal, redheaded self.” At that, Ori took a final sip of her tea.

Ugh. Kelos was mentally mulling it all over. This was tricky. In the very least she didn't request that she stay a princess forever, but the 'comfortably acclimate' part left it rather open. “And if I say no?”

“Then you don't get my backing on the situation when mother and father return.” Ori said this rather flippantly... Before a glint of mischievousness filled her eye. “Unless you want follow through another, much more fun demand~.”

Even just goading her to say it was like taking one step into the lion's den. “And what would that be?”

“Wellll~.” Ori hummed in an exaggerated sweetness. “Since you love your new earrings so much, I was thinking it might be for the best if you went and enjoyed some of the other gifts I arranged for you! So if you really want my approval for Nali, without any other strings, how about you try whatever items your dragon friend scrounges up while sniffing around in your room~?”
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Orianna's demands are reasonable.

choices: Kelos returns to find Nali did exactly as instructed.
Kelos returns to find a huge mess.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
Obviously the second proposal was not a thing that would be happening. Who knows what sort of enchantments Ori placed on those items. Plus, Nali probably already claimed them all for her collection. The first proposal though, Kelos hadn't considered it before, but it did make a lot of sense. Despite being a powerful dragon, she was still a child, and children needed stability. "I hate to admit it, but you're right. Nali's only ever known me as a woman, and children can react badly to unexpected changes."

"Exactly!" Ori replied. Kelos was buying this, and probably only needed a little more convincing. "I know you're eager to change back to normal, but you should think of that poor girl. Why, losing her human might be like losing her mother all over again! It could be traumatizing!"

"I can certainly deal with remaining a woman for a bit longer," Kelos replied. "I don't think mother and father will be happy, but they should understand."

"Of course they will," Orianna said reassuringly. "In fact, I believe they'll be proud of you. A lesser person would selfishly demand to be changed back no matter how much it hurt that poor girl. Even if Mother and Father aren't, I'm proud of you, little sister."

Kelos blushed and smiled slightly. "Thanks, Ori. I know we've had our disagreements over the years, but I'm really lucky to be have you as my sister."

"I do believe we are overlooking one important detail though. Does your dragon friend want to stay here?"

"I haven't asked her yet, but I think she will." Kelos stood up and smoothed her dress out. "I just need to find the right way to ask her."

"Excellent!" Orianna took another sip of tea. "Though I never expected you to become a mother before me."

Kelos blushed. "I'm not... If anything I'm like her big sister!"

A sly half smile escaped before Orianna contained it. Kelos had referred to herself as the dragon's sister spontaneously. The longer this could be drawn out, the more Kelos would think of herself as a woman. Why Kelos might even decide to stay like this without further influence! "Pity," Orianna said. "I must say, I quite liked the idea of being called auntie."

Kelos blushed even harder. "I'll see what I can do, but Nali will probably insist on calling you 'Human-sister.' Speaking of which, I should get back and check on her."

Orianna put her tea down and stood up as well. "Yes, get back to my niece and keep her out of trouble." She then held out her arms, inviting Kelos for a hug.

Kelos looked confused for a moment, then stepped towards Ori and hugged her. "You haven't really hugged me before."

"It just seems more apropos. Now then, good luck."

"Thank you." Kelos tried to pull away, but Ori held her tight, then leaned in closer.

"Make me even prouder, little sister." With that she let Kelos go.

"I will, and thanks," Kelos smiled brightly at her sister, before leaving the room.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.title: Kelos accepts Ori's first offer.

choices: Nali accepts.
Nali can't for some reason.
They're interrupted/Something else.
1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
“Human! Human! Look at all the stuff I found!”

The walk back from Ori's abode to hers was a long one, even if it wasn't so physically: full of blushing, and contemplating thoughts over... motherhood! Goodness! The idea of even being a father hadn't so much as crossed Kelos' mind when she was a man, so to think of a change so drastic...

Regardless, those worries had a pin put in them upon seeing her little dragon companion beaming, as she held a hoard of trinkets and doodads abreast in her arms.

“Oh my!” The redhead gasped in semi-exaggerated shock. But only semi.

“Human's sister hid a whole bunch of pranks here!” The 'semi' being the truth of that statement.

“And I suppose they're all as lovely as my new earrings?” Kelos intended for that question to have more bite and sarcasm, but it came out with a light giggle, and a flicking of her hair to show off the jewelry. They really were lovely... What was she complaining about, again?

“Uh huh!” Nali affirmed: marching over, and placing the pile atop the desk of the new princess's vanity. Kelos might need to be careful: there were necklaces, and bracelets, and other items that could easily blend in and be mistaken for 'real' finery. “None could hide from the Mistress of Transformation!”

“We'll have to find a place for you to stash it all away.” The royal chimed: simultaneously staring at what, if Nali were to believed, was an enchanted tiara. A tiara! Did Ori seriously think she'd wear such a thing?!

Admittedly, the sapphire gem in the center was quite attractive...

“Really?!” The whelp gasped: already imagining adding them all from the collection she had back at her tower.

Kelos paused at this: wondering if it might be a good opportunity to segue into the actual conversation she wanted to have. “I was thinking a room in the castle?” She was slowly kneeling down to get on her ward's eye level.

“Human?” Nali asked: voice questioning, as she tilted her head to the side.

“Nali... I've been wondering lately, but... Would you like to live here? With me?” She asked, placing a sincere hand on the others' shoulder. “That keep of yours looked like it could get awfully lonely... And this way, I could be with you.” A pause, as the next phrase hung itself on her lips... Until she took the plunge. “Take care of you.”
