1321211111121121211211111112111211122111.content:
There were many rumors that stirred around the former Prince Kelos, now, and forever, Princess Kelos. Some grounded, some fantastic. Maybe the potential weight of the crown just proved too much, and abdicating was her own, true choice? Or there were the implications that her sister, now Queen, manipulated her mind, and made her desire to stay a woman. Anyone who'd met her would tell you she certainly was quite feminine for a person born a boy.

But the most baffling explanation, and the explanation Princess Kelos would tell you, smile wide on her face, was that an adorable little dragon simply happened to enchant her heart~.

“'Little' dragon? Are you serious, Sister?” Queen Orianna palmed her face, as she contemplated how empty the kingdom's coffers would be once construction on the castle's new dragon's roost was finished.

Kelos, current mother of one, merely just raised a finger in the air. “Now now, Ori, we were fully aware of the responsibility we took on when we invited her to live here. I've made plenty of sacrifices myself for it, you know.” Despite the heaviness of some of her words, a caring, jubilant smile never seemed to leave her face. Motherhood truly had done wonders for the redhead's disposition.

“Is it too late for you to take the throne?...” Ori grumbled half-seriously. She always had dreams of inheriting her father's title, but who knew it involved so much paperwork?!

“Oh goodness, no! I couldn't! Nali's almost a teenager, now! Or at least, a dragon teenager. Believe me, my hands are going to be full.”

That statement was promptly followed by a reverberating *boom* echoing its way through the halls. An increasingly familiar sound, as of recent years, with a certain, now much fuller formed drake, making her landing in an outside courtyard.

“Moooooooom!” That was another increasingly familiar sound as well, as a slightly older looking Nalisora, in human form, marched her way into the throne room, as if it was as natural as walking into her very own living quarters. “I was flying around, and saw a caravan of what looked to be troops from Teutonis! I scared them off, though.”

Kelos just shook her head, and gave an exacerbated sigh. “They likely wanted to enter our borders to cross into Traeven. Good work, Dear~.” Her words sweetened up, at that last statement. With the arrival of an actual, unironic dragon in Grovan's inner circle, suddenly, many of the surrounding nations began to shy away from conflict. Who would have thought~?

Queen Orianna however, held some hesitance. “Um, Nali dear, Auntie has a bit of a question.” A pause. “How exactly did you 'scare them off?'”

The growing whelp smiled with a twinkle in her eye. “Well using my fire breath would have been waaaaay too borrrrringgg, and I'm not the 'Mistress of Transformation' for nothing, fufufu~.” She gave a small wink at that. “Let's just say what Teutonis might be lacking in soldiers now, they've instead earned themselves a surplus of maids!”

Ori couldn't help but duck her head down, as Kelos giggled: gliding over to her daughter to give an approving head-pat. “Knowing your magic, I'm sure they'll take to their new professions quite well!” The young mother's thoughts turned to the former raider-turned-servant, who'd found a very suitable spot as Xarlat's personal assistant. Her previous experience as a spellcaster actually proved useful.

“Ugghhh, I'm going to have to write a personal apology letter to King Aison now...” Ori grumbled from her throne.

Turning from her daughter to her Queen, Kelos just gave a coy grin. “Well, if he raises too much of a fuss, I'm sure Nali here wouldn't mind giving him a new perspective or two. 'Fufufu~.'”

And that, more or less, was the story of a prince turned princess, that met a dragon who enjoyed turning others into lots of different things, and proceeded to completely upended her life. For the better, she'd always note. After all, if her daughter was the 'Mistress' of Transformation, that had to make her the 'Mother,' didn't it?

Maybe not as regal as 'Queen,' but 'Princess Kelos, Mother of Transformation' didn't have the worst ring to it~.

"Please don't leave me alone, miss," the young girl pleaded, looking up at Kelos with eyes like an abandoned puppy. Strangely, they seemed to glow softly for a moment.

Despite her suspicions about the girl, Kelos couldn't turn down a request like that. "Fine, I guess I can take you to a nearby village or something," she replied. "Come here."

A look of confusion flashed for an instant, but quickly left. "O-okay," she said, as she approached Kelos cautiously.

"Don't worry, I won't bite," Kelos said, holding out her hand.

The girl tentatively reached out to take Kelos' hand. The instant they touched, a look of realization overtook the girl. Here eyes drifted down to Kelos' discarded male clothes. "So that's why," she murmured to herself.

"What was that?" Kelos asked.

"Your hands are soft and dry," the girl said. "Like mommy's..." She looked down with sad eyes.

Kelos reached over and hugged the young girl. In turn the girl wrapped her arms around Kelos. "Don't worry, I'll take you someplace safe," Kelos said. "But for now," she picked some leaves out of the girl's tangled hair, "let's get you cleaned up a bit, okay?" Kelos led the girl to the edge of the stream.

"Wait, miss. Your dress," the girl said. "It'll get all wet."

Kelos looked down at herself. "Oh right," she replied.

"Your dress is so pretty," the girl said. "It's important to take care of pretty things." Again her eyes seemed to glow slightly.

"What was I thinking?" Kelos exclaimed, suddenly shocked that she would risk such a fine dress. She took a step back, holding up the hem of the dress so it wouldn't get dirty. Then she took off her sword, then reached behind to undo the buttons.

"I can do that," the girl offered. She walked around behind Kelos, and began unfastening the buttons for her.

"Thank you," Kelos said. As the girl finished, Kelos took off her shoes and carefully stepped out of the dress, then hung it on a tree branch. "There." She turned back to the girl. "Now it's your turn." She helped the girl take off her dress. While there were more scrapes and bruises on the girl, strangely, they didn't match the tears in the dress. It seemed odd, but Kelos just shrugged it off and helped the girl get clean, doing her best to pick out the debris in the girl's hair as the girl washed herself off in the cool, clear water. "There all done," Kelos said after a few minutes. The girl's hair was still a mess, but Kelos had been able to remove the debris and most of the knots and tangles. The rest would be handled by a brush when they got back to the carriage.

The girl stepped out of the stream and went to put on her dress.

"Wait," Kelos said. "Now that you're all clean, you shouldn't put on that filthy old thing." She walked over to her discarded male clothes, and picked up her shirt, bringing it over to the girl. "Wear this. It will be big, but at least it's clean."

"Okay," the girl replied. She put the shirt over her head. It fell past her knees, and the sleeves extended quite a distance past her hands.

Kelos rolled up the sleeved for the girl, then buttoned the shirt. She then walked over to her dress, and carefully stepped into it. She then turned her head. "Would you mind?" she asked the girl.

The girl walked over to Kelos and buttoned the dress. She then circled in front of her. "You're really pretty, miss," she said.

"I don't know about that," Kelos replied a bit uncomfortably.

"You are," the girl insisted. "It's nice to be pretty." Again her eyes glowed slightly.

"Why thank you," Kelos replied. "Though I'm sure when you grow up, you'll be even prettier. But we should really get back to my carriage. My guards are probably getting worried."

"Okay," the girl said with a smile.

Kelos took the girl's hand. She then turned to her old clothes and sword.

13213.content:
It was a cold and damp morning as the carriage rolled through the hillside just outside the Kingdom of Traeven. Prince Kelos, the 22-year-old heir to the throne, was taking part in a goodwill mission to the neighboring kingdom of Traeven. The mission was to finalize a peace accord that would end the decade-long war between the two kingdoms.

In order to end the war, Prince Kelos would take part in a marriage with the daughter of Traeven’s rulers, Princess Fia. Coming along for the journey was Captain Jex of the Royal Guard, and lowly scribe named Mathias. With only a few hours left before their arrival, Kelos was beginning to feel somewhat nervous. “I wish this wretched journey would come to an end; so I can be married to the Princess.”

“We’re almost there, sire.” Looking at the Prince, Captain Jex said, “It can’t be more than a few hours left.”

“Well we need to stop; I have to relieve myself.”

It was only a matter of minutes before the carriage came to a stop next to a small stream. After assuring Captain Jex that he’d be fine, Prince Kelos strode towards the stream where he found a large rock to hide behind.

A moment later, he’d just finished when he was startled by the sudden appearance of Mathias. Looking at the scribe, in anger, Kelos said, “How dare you approach me unannounced, scribe!”

“Apologies, my Prince.” Reaching into his satchel, Mathias said, “But as we’re close to our destination, I felt it prudent to give you this.”
Taken a rolled up scroll from Mathias, Kelos said, “What is this?”
“It’s a letter to you from your father; no doubt expressing his thanks for your part in ending this war.”

Going to open the scroll, Kelos vaguely noticed Mathias starting to back away but thought nothing of it. When he opened the scroll, he didn’t see a letter from his father; instead, he saw what looked to be gibberish. Looking at Mathias, Kelos said, “What is the meaning of...”

Kelos was interrupted by a bright light; raising his hand to cover his face as the light engulfed him. Mathias watched in amusement; fully aware of what was happening. Captain Jex, seeing the bright light, rushed to the river. He arrived just as the light subsided; leaving a beautiful young woman in body armor where Prince Kelos had previously stood.

Captain Jex, not aware of what had transpired, immediately drew his sword. Pointing it towards the now female Prince Kelos, he said, “What have you done with the Prince, fair maiden!”

“Fair maiden?” Prince Kelos began to protest when he suddenly heard his new voice. A quick glance downward revealed the feminine body of a young woman. “Captain, I’m Prince Kelos. The wretched scribe Mathias has done something to me.”
Turning his sword towards Mathias, Jex said, “Explain yourself, scribe.”

“This young woman is telling the truth; she is Prince Kelos.” Pausing, Mathias said, “Alas, I’m sorry to say that the point of this journey isn’t what either of you thought it was.”

“You better tell us what the real point is; or so help me, I’ll find a way to make you a woman as well.”

“My Prince, you weren’t sent here to marry Princess Fia.” Sighing, Mathias said, “You were sent here _______."

"True," Kelos replied. He eyed the scroll in his hand. "How long do these scrolls last?"

"Most only a day or two," the scribe replied. "That particular one though, it's a bit longer. Two weeks I believe."

The prince tossed the scroll to the scribe. "I'll let you hold on to that then," he said. "Is there a way to turn someone back sooner?"

"Only by using another scroll," the scribe said. "However, these are simple spells. If someone uses another scroll, it overwrites the magic from the first one."

"Meaning?" Kelos asked.

"Let's say you opened this one," the scribe said while holding up the yellow scroll, "and it transformed you into a woman. Then you opened a second scroll for some reason. The second scroll would transform you again, but you could no longer return to your true form. When the second scroll wore off, you would remain a woman."

"Given that I'm soon to be married, I'll make sure to avoid that," Kelos replied. "Though couldn't someone use a scroll, then another scroll, then a third scroll to turn back to normal, then a fourth to lock that as their form again?"

"So, let's see these scrolls in action," Kelos said. "Use one on yourself."

The scribe looked at Kelos, not believing what he heard. "Your highness?" he asked.

"You heard me, I want to see how good these scrolls of yours are. Use one." Kelos repeated. "I don't care which."

The scribe sighed. "Very well your highness." He began to look through the scrolls, carefully evaluating which to use. "No, that one will last too long, that one would turn me into a cup of water, that one would turn me into the Prince."

"Well?" Kelos asked impatiently. "Just pick one already."

"Apologies, your highness, but it would hardly do for me to pick the one that would turn the user into you, Princess Fia, or some other important figure for a length of time," the scribe replied, as he continued to go through the scrolls.

"You have a point there," Kelos replied, though he tapped his foot impatiently.

"This one will do," the scribe said. He held up a black scroll with white and brown trim. "It will turn the user into a maid with Castle Traevan's uniform for half an hour."

"Why so short?" Kelos asked.

"This one is just for sneaking past guards," the scribe explained. "It might be short lived, but I believe it will be the most illustrative. This one changes the user's clothes. Most of the longer lasting ones just change the user's body." The scribe opened the scroll, and a flash of light filled the carriage. When it cleared, a young, though somewhat stocky and plain looking girl with brown hair in a maid outfit was sitting across from Kelos. "There," the scribe said in her now feminine voice. "For the next half hour, I'll be stuck like this. Satisfied with their effects, your highness?"

"Yes, it's quite impressive, though why such a plain girl?" Kelos asked.

"As I said, this is to slip past guards. So a plain girl who doesn't stand out and will be harder for the guards to describe in detail was ideal for it," the scribe explained.

"Yes, that certainly makes sense," Kelos replied. "Too attractive and the guards might hold you up with flirting too."

"Exactly," the scribe replied.

Kelos looked amusingly at his uncomfortable scribe. Kelos watched very closely as the scribe subconsciously played with the hem of the maid outfit's skirt giving Kelos a very nice up skirt shot. You'll still have your mind, you'll just have a much improved body. But if you're too scared to do it yourself, allow me." Kelos picked up a purple and black scroll and opened it pointing it at the scribe.

Unfortunately for Kelos, you couldn't aim a scroll. The magic affected who opened it and in a flash Kelos sat in the carriage magically transformed...or not. When Kelos opened his eyes he saw that the scribe was still the plain maid. Fearing the worst he looked down, but breathed a sigh of relief when he saw that the scroll had only changed his clothes from his traveling wear to his formal military uniform.

"Well, this seems a bit flashy and a waste of magic but it does get the job done. Scribe, when we get back to Grovan have 3 of these made a day with the appropriate clothing." But when the prince looked to his scribe, he saw that he wasn't dutifully writing down notes or nodding, he was wide eyed and seemed terrified.

"What's you're problem scribe, you looked like you've seen a ghost."

"That that that wasn't a simple clothes change spell. It was another disguise scroll, a Prince Kelos disguise scroll."

Kelos scoffed, "Well then it seems it was a bit of a waste on me. How foolish, now, I believe we were in the middle of giving you a new permanent form."

"Oh no no no you don't understand the magical implication of what you've done. You've killed yourself!" The scribe said with tears now flowing down his cheeks.

"What are you talking about. SPEAK!" Kelos was not amused by what the scribe said and slapped the maid bodied scribe. With the tears flowing more freely the scribe spoke again, "Wh-when the magic scroll runs out, it will erase all signs of the disguise spell, so when the Kelos disguise scroll runs out it will erase all signs of Kelos from you. You will cease to be. You will no longer exist. You will di...!" Kelos cut of the scribe with another slap. "I get it. You and your damned magic has doomed me. Now fix it or I will cut our your tongue here and leave you on the side of the road. Fix it now!"

"My lord, the only thing I can do now if give you another body until I can get access to a magical laboratory. That will stop you from being erased."

"Then do it!" Kelos screamed as the scribe stumbled around trying to find the best scroll to keep Kelos from dying. Sean knew that a scroll without a time limit was the best thing. He dug around his bag until he found one he was hoping he wouldn't have to use. It was a scroll of an obedient maid. It was a much more drastic version of the spell the scribe was under but with no time limit and a mild obedience spell to go with it. It was to be used only if a very long term surveillance mission was to be taken, or perhaps used on a bandit, but now seemed as good a time as any. Sean reached into the bag to grab the scroll to give it to his lord.

Kelos watched impatiently as Sean rifled through his bag looking for a specific scroll. Getting increasingly annoyed, he picked up one of the scrolls next to him. "It doesn't have to be a specific one," the prince stated as he opened a golden scroll. The scribe looked up, seeing the scroll Kelos had chosen.

"No, not that one!" Sean exclaimed, but too late. A bright light filled the cabin, and when it passed where Kelos had been now sat a young woman with long golden blonde hair. She wore a scarlet dress cut low, revealing the top of her modest bosom. "That one turns the person into Princess Fia."

"Well, better than disappearing," Kelos said as she looked down at her new body. "I'm sure normally I'd think these too small," Kelos placed her hand on her new breasts, "But from this angle they look a lot bigger."

Sean looked at Kelos aghast. "This is terrible and all you can think of is Fia's breast size?!"

"It's my breast size too," Kelos replied nonchalantly. "Besides, what's the issue? I'm no longer at risk of disappearing, right? I might as well use this time to become more familiar with Fia."

"Well not as long as the scroll lasts," Sean admitted. "But we can't very well continue to Traeven, where the closest magical laboratory is, I might add, with you looking exactly like Princess Fia."

"Then let's turn around and head back home," Kelos suggested. "I wonder if Fia has a nice singing voice."

"The trip will take too long," the scribe said. "That scroll only lasts 12 hours."

"Wait, if I used this scroll, doesn't that mean it locked the last one as my true form? Since the last one was me, when this wears off, I'll turn back to myself, right? Problem solved." Kelos observed.

"Normally yes, but since the last scroll was you, it works a bit differently," Sean explained. "The initial problem still remains, when this scroll of Princess Fia wears off, you will still cease to exist."

"I see, though that doesn't make any sense," Kelos said.

"The rules of magic are complex and often defy logic and common sense," Sean replied.

"So what if I use another scroll? Will that still make my current form permanent?" Kelos asked.

"It's risky, your highness," Sean said. "We'd have three magic scrolls combined. The results can be very unpredictable."

"But if we do nothing, I will cease to exist when the Fia scroll expires in 12 hours?" Kelos replied.

"Well then..." Kelos started.

"Is it likely you'll find a solution in the 12 hours?" Kelos asked.

"Unfortunately not, your highness," Sean replied. "It's quite a difficult problem. Even once we get to a suitable laboratory, it may take several days to come up with a solution."

"Then I fail to see another option. No matter what happens, it will be better than not existing," the transformed prince reasoned. "Give me the scroll with the shortest duration."

Sean hesitated before handing Kelos a black scroll. "This one will only last ten minutes, but..."

"But?" Kelos repeated as she took the scroll.

"It won't turn you into another person. This one will turn you into a cat."

"A cat you say?" Kelos replied. "I sure do hope that form's instincts don't override my self control. I'd so hate to accidentally scratch that new body of yours,"

"Um... Maybe we should pick another scroll, your highness," Sean said, but too late. Kelos had already opened the scroll. A bright light filled the carriage as once prince transformed again, into a small black cat. "Your highness?"

Kelos took great care figuring out how to move in this new feline form, carefully standing up, slowly moving, learning how this body functioned. It took the formerly human prince about 30 seconds to get confident in walking. Another minute and Kelos figured out how to jump and get the claws to extend. The next few minutes of Sean's life seemed far longer as Kelos leapt, claws out, into the scribe's lap, then practiced climbing up her arm.

"Your highness please stop!" Sean pleaded as the kitty Kelos made it to the top of Sean's head and began to claw at her maid bonnet. "You're doing this deliberately aren't you?" The scribe grabbed for Kelos, but the former prince's new form was too agile and jumped away. Sean, unfamiliar with her current body's proportions promptly fell. Kelos took this opportunity to claw at the hem of her skirt. Kelos picked up another scroll and examined it. "I don't see a label on these, are they color coded?" he asked.

"Yes, only I know which are which,: the scribe replied, shifting uncomfortably in her new body.

"Isn't that..."Kelos started to say, until he was jolted out of his seat by the carriage making a sudden stop, the scroll he was holding flew out of his hand, and out the window.. "The hell was that?" the prince exclaimed, finding himself thrown into the bosom of the transformed scribe.

"Your highness, do you mind?" the scribe said.

"These are quite comfortable, you should consider keeping them," Kelos responded. He then got up. "I better see what those idiots are up to. You stay here, since there's no way they'll recognize you." With that he opened the door and climbed down from the carriage. "Why have we stopped!" Kelos yelled.

"Sorry sir, but there's an overturned cart in the road ahead," the driver replied. "The horses stopped and I had to apply the brake."

"So go around it!" Kelos ordered.

"We can't sir, it's blocking the entire road," the driver said.

"Then push it to the side and let's get moving!" Kelos said angrily

"At once sir!" the driver said. With that he gestured to the guards on horseback, who dismounted.

"Help me!" a voice cried out from the bushes alongside the road.

"Who's there?" Kelos asked as he walked over to the bushes.

"I'm just a simple merchant," the voice replied. "My horse was spooked, bucked, broke the harness, flipped my cart, threw me into the bushes, then ran off! Help me please!"

Kelos parted some branches of the thick bushes to reveal an old woman, with a wrinkled, leathery face, wearing an old robe and currently stuck in the branches. The Prince drew his sword, and with a few slashes, the woman was free.

"Thank you sir, thank you!" the woman said, as she fell to the ground.

Kelos looked at his sword. "Now it's covered in sap," he commented, paying little attention to the woman's gratitude.

"Yes, we're you're free now," Kelos said disinterestedly, as he looked around for something to wipe the sap off with.

The woman tried to stand up, but plopped back to the ground. "Would you be so kind as to help an old woman back on her feet?" she asked.

13232121.content:
Kelos sighed in annoyance as he helped the old woman to her feet.

"Thank you sonny," the old woman said as she brushed herself off.

"Sonny?" Kelos thought to himself, but decided not to say anything and waste more time with the old crone. For all he knew she probably thought his great grandfather was still king.

"Yes, well we need to get moving," the annoyed prince said. He nodded to his men to push the cart off the road.

"If you can push my cart back on its wheels, I'll give you a reward for your help," the old woman said.

"A reward?" Kelos scoffed. "I am a prince, I doubt you have anything that would be of interest to me."

"Pishposh," the old woman replied as she walked over to her cart, shooing the soldiers away, then rummaged through it the back of it. Kelos noted that despite being flipped, the times in the back were strangely organized. "I have many rare and valuable antiquities, relics from ages past, when gods and demons walked the Earth openly." She struggled to pull out a long pole wrapped in a cloth. The tip seemed to have a some sort of bladed bit, clearly it was a pole arm of some sort. "Yes, this may interest you," the old woman said. "This spear was carried into battle by a valkyrie of myth. It is said to have many strange and mystical powers."

"Said by whom?" Kelos asked skeptically.

"By me, were you not listening?" The old woman replied. "But perhaps some other items would interest you more?" She again rummaged though her cart before pulling out another long object wrapped in cloth. "This sword was forged from a link of the chains that bound Prometheus for his crime of giving fire to man. It is capable of binding the soul of those it slays to the will of its wielder."

"I have artifacts from across the world, from over the seven seas," the old woman boosted. "If you don't want something for yourself, a gift for a lover perhaps?" she continued. She pulled a small jewelry case out of the cart, opening it to revel two solid gold rings, with engravings in a language Kelos didn't recognize, those he noted they did appear to be real gold at least. "These magic rings will slowly change the wearer into their partner's ideal lover."

"I'll take that spear," Kelos said.

Kelos unwrapped the spear completely, and held it in his hand. as he did, he heard a woman's voice.

"Mistress! I've finally found you!" the voice called out

You've regained your former Valkyrie form, mistress! Though your powers have somewhat waned due to not using them in a while, you should still be stronger than most right now!"

132321211111.content:
The stone slabs of the city walls went past as their entourage had entered the city. It was their fortunate luck that enabled them to come further to the city without incident, and the guards passed them without any trouble, assuming that the Prince had arrived. After all, who else would ride such a lavish carriage?

"I can see that the city hasn't changed much," Kelos noted, peeking from the carriage curtains. The cityfolk truly did remain the same, cheerfully talking, arguing, and bargaining over prices in the marketplace. The busy life of the city went on the way it did before, unchanging.

"Have you been here before?" The scribe asked, surprised. He hadn't heard of any excursions to Traeven by the prince. It was mostly Fia coming to Grovan to visit them in their youth.

"Yes, once," Kelos nodded. "When I had first met her at the ball, I was so smitten by her beauty that I had to visit her. However, once I had gotten past the city walls..."

"You became so afraid that you left in a hurry?" Reginleif finished much to Kelos' surprise.

"Blasted spear!" She yelled out with a confused scribe watching her. "How did you know?!"

"I can read your heart, mistress," the spear said, in an almost ecstatic voice. "After all, the two of us are now linked, bound to be together for all eternity!"

Kelos blushed, realizing that she now had a companion that could read her like an open book. No matter how she would try to hide her emotions from people, there would be one person... or rather, one spear, that would always be able to know how she feels and understand her.

The carriage abruptly stopped at the front of the palace, signalling that they were finally here. Kelos motioned the scribe to exit first, before following suit with Reginleif (the spear would just not let go of her). The sweet, soothing beam of sun hit her face, blinding her for a moment, as the dozens of spears of the king's guard suddenly pointed at her.

"Halt!" One of them, the tallest of the king's squad, roared at her. "Who are you, and what have you done to Prince Kelos?"

"I am Prince Kelos." Kelos' menacing voice sounded out, intimidating the soldiers. "I have just encountered a couple problems on the way. And besides, don't you think that pointing a spear at me is a tad bit rude?"

"Yo...you're right!" The soldier suddenly flinched, backing off. "Oh forgive this pitiful, lowly soldier, Your Highness!"

'Weird.' Kelos thought. 'Why are they suddenly so subservient?'

"It's because they cannot help but submit under the presence of a god's emissary." Reginleif commented, responding to her question. "Your aura is affecting those of lower rank than you are. Only nobility may stand before your might."

After the marriage Xarlat would give Fia her body back, put a spell of enslavement on her so she does what Kelos tells and without Marlin no one would be able to break the spell. Then Xarlat being the most powerful magician in the land could have some evil fun in peace.

Kelos wasn't sure how he felt about the plan his father was right the kingdom did need to be tied together but this seemed like a very underhanded way of doing this. Kelos looked through the rain at nights destination. What is it?

Today he was going to visit to a nearby village, and greet his future subjects.

13532.content:
Prince Kelos of Grovan blinked open his eyes, as the morning sun drifted across his face.

He was just having the strangest of dreams, but for the life of him, he couldn't pin down the specifics...

Regardless, a dream it appeared to be, as around him were the comforts of his royal bedroom; lodged safely in the halls of Castle Grovan. One day, the entire fortress, as well as all its surrounding lands, were to be his to rule over!

Though not likely this day, barring something dramatic.

Nevertheless, this day had plenty in store for itself, and laying around like an oaf wouldn't accomplish any of what was planned out.

He was still a faint bit groggy, however... What exactly was he supposed to be doing?
13532.title: Kelos (Re)starts His Day

choices: Kelos says Orianna's help won't be needed.
Kelos follows his parents order to work with Orianna.
135321.content:
As the grogginess faded, Kelos remembered his parents wanted to see him in the throne room before breakfast today. Though they had not told him the reason. A mystery that can only be solved by attending. He hurriedly got dressed and headed down stairs. He passed several servants in the halls who greeted him, but he simply ignored them in his rush. He arrived to find his sister Orianna waiting, with his parents yet to arrive.

"I was beginning to think were going to be late, little brother," Orianna quipped as Kelos entered.

"The sun is barely up," Kelos replied. "I suspect we still have time."

"Apparently so," Orianna replied.

After that, the two of them stood in an awkward silence. While they had been close as children, over the years they drifted apart. Years of magical pranks had led to hurt feelings between the two, such as the time Orianna turned Kelos' prized hounds into foxes, or Kelos turned Orianna's horse into a giant chicken. Worse, Orianna made it no secret that she wished to inherit the throne. After all, she was older than Kelos, but the rules about sons being given priority over daughters for succession denied her what was in her mind her birthright.

"So," Kelos said, at last breaking the silence. "Have you been told anything about why Mother and Father called us here today?"

"Not a thing," Orianna replied. "I imagine it's the same for you."

"It is," Kelos replied. With that the silence resumed. This would be mercifully brief as before long Queen Latissa and King Reginald walked in. They sat down in their thrones. Kelos knelt and Orianna curtsied in response.

"My children," Latissa said. "We have called you today, for a very important mission. As you know, our war with Traeven is nearing its end, and we have been in negotiations for peace. As it stands now, it will be one favorable to Grovan, and Kelos, you shall take Princess Fia of Traeven as your bride." She then turned to her husband for him to continue.

"Our armies have met with great success over the past several months, and have even managed to raid farmland that directly feeds Castle Traeven," Reginald continued. "This has left King Arthras with little recourse but to yield to our might. However, little recourse does not mean no recourse. Our spies have reported that he has sent an emissary to the Empire of Teutonis to convince them to come to Traeven's aid. Teutonis has a large army, and if they were to enter the war, Grovan would be hard pressed to stand before it. Perhaps if we were not also at war with Traeven, but as it stands, we would be fighting on two fronts, and our defeat all but inevitable."

"Surely, they have nothing to offer Teutonis," Orianna said.

"As of the last war council, Traeven's treasury was depleted," Kelos added. "With no money to pay them and little food, what would Teutonis gain?"

"Traeven as a vassal and Grovan as new territory," Reginald said. He then turned to his wife.

"As such, I have the following mission," Latissa said. "You are to travel to Teutonis, together, and negotiate to stop them from allying with Traeven against us."

"Together?" Orianna asked.

"Together," Latissa repeated.
135321.title: Kelos reports to his family. They have some roy...

choices: Kelos and Orianna use this time to understand each other better.
Kelos and Orianna decide to ruin each other's reputations.
1353211.content:
"I do not require my dear sister's assistance on this matter," Kelos said glancing right towards Orianna. "I am more than capable of accomplishing this on my own."

"I am also surely capable on my own," Orianna said, glancing left. "My esteemed brother will only serve as an impediment." The two of them cast a side eyed glare at each other.

Reginald sighed. "Your mother and I believed you could put aside your differences for the sake of the kingdom and work together on this matter. It seems we were mistaken."

"Sire, if I may." An older man spoke up from the side, and Xarlet, the court wizard stepped forward. "Animosity between siblings can happen, especially when there's a prize as valuable as the throne at play. Perhaps, just perhaps there is a way to get the royal children to better understand each other."

"What do you propose, old friend?"

"Oh I have quite the idea," Xarlet approached the king and queen, and whispered just loud enough for them both to hear.

"That seems extreme, but I suppose there is no other way," Latissa said.

"Very well, wizard, make it so!" Reginald ordered.

"With pleasure," the old wizard replied with a twisted smile. He turned, and pointed at Kelos and Orianna. A pair of white orbs flew out of the wizard's finger and hit the prince and princess, entering each of their bodies, only to immediately exit. They then crossed paths as the orbs, now each glowing golden, flew towards the other royal.

"What the hell was that?" The Grovan princess exclaimed. She looked to her right and seeing no one standing there asked. "Ori?"

"I see," the Grovan prince said, looking down at himself. He looked at his hand as he opened and closed his fist.

"Oh their different reactions are certainly fascinating," Xarlet chuckled.

The princess spun to her left, and saw the prince examining his body. At this point she realized what had happened. "You swapped our bodies!"

"Indeed I did," Xarlet said with a wicked smile.

"I will handle the situation with Teutonis personally," Reginald proclaimed. "Until I return, you two will remain in each other's bodies. Hopefully literally spending time in each others shoes will help the two of you get along. Now go."

"Yes, father," the two said in unison before scurrying out of the throne room.
1353211.title: Kelos says Orianna's help won't be needed.

choices: The trip is uneventful and they quickly arrive.
They encounter complications with the trip.
1353212.content:
"Very well," Kelos said. "While my relationship with my sister has been strained, I'm certain we can put our differences to the side and work together for the good of the kingdom."

Orianna glared at her brother for a moment, but then followed his lead. "Of course we shall do our best."

"Good," Reginald said. "The future of our kingdom is in your hands."

"I do have a question," Orianna said. "What do we have to offer Teutonis? Surely a treaty of friendship or alliance will not be enough."

"Even if it is, by signing such a treaty we would be offering the lives of our soldiers to any wars Teutonis might become involved in," Kelos added.

"I shall leave it to your discretion," Latissa said. "If you wish to rule, you must prove able in negotiations and show awareness of what Grovan can and cannot give up."

"Is there anything we should be aware of involving customs in Teutonis?" Orianna asked. "I would hate to see this ruined because my dear brother unintentionally commits a social faux pas."

Kelos rolled his eyes, "I do not think I would do so, but it would be good to know if there's anything significantly different we should be careful of."

"Of course. An advisor who has spent time in Teutonis will accompany you," Latissa replied.

"There is one thing to be wary of," Reginald added. "Teutonis has a new king, and I have seen reports describing him as eccentric. He may expect behavior that differs from normal customs. I have ordered one of our spies there to contact you when you arrive for more information."

"Won't that be risky?" Orianna asked. "If our spy contacts us, they could be discovered."

"Risks are sometimes necessary," Reginald replied.

"May I be excused to prepare for the trip?" Kelos asked.

"Certainly," Latissa replied. "Do keep in mind you are being sent as an emissary of peace."

"I understand, I wasn't planning to wear full combat armor after all," Kelos replied with a joking tone.

Latissa raised an eyebrow skeptically.

"I must also prepare," Orianna said. "May I also be excused?"

"I take it neither of you have any further questions?" Reginald asked.

"Nothing immediately comes to mind," Orianna said.

"I do have more, but I believe the advisor will be able to answer them on the trip there," Kelos said. "Unless we have more information on Traeven's offers."

"We do not," Latissa said. "All we know shall be prepared for you to read on your journey."

"Then we shouldn't delay," kelos said. He bowed before leaving.

Orianna gave a curtsy before she left as well. She hurried after Kelos and tried to catch up to him in the hall. "I need to have a word with you, brother," she called out from behind.

"Fine," Kelos replied. he slowed to allow his sister to walk alongside.

"You may be heir to the throne, but I'm still the older sister," Orianna said. "As such I shall be taking the lead in negotiations."

"Fine, whatever," Kelos replied, not being in the mood for an argument. "But I would like to hear from the advisor and our spy in Teutonis first."

"W-well, as long as you understand your position," Orianna relied, taken back by Kelos not responding to her goading.

With that the royal siblings went to their rooms to prepare for the journey.
1353212.title: Kelos follows his parents order to work with Or...

choices: Something peculiar happens with the scroll that impacts one or all of them.
Ori adds a bit 'special something' to Kelos' drink. Alchemy comes in handy.
The tea is fine. Sean proceeds with his story/Something else.
13532122.content:
A prince, a princess, and a scribe step into carriage...

If that sounded like the set up to a joke, unfortunately, there was very little humor to be had here. Kelos, Orianna, and 'Sean,' their new trusty 'adviser' on any and all Teutonis-related affairs, were just now seating themselves for the long, long trip ahead. It was awkward, and it was tense, and it was every emotion the pair of siblings felt ever since those old Grovan traditions started to rear their head, and it'd been decided that Kelos, not Ori, would inherit the reigns to the kingdom.

Such a shame, too. In their earlier years they were quite close. Ori still had fond memories of the times she'd convinced her brother to play 'dress up.' What were the names they came up with for 'him,' again? Kelas? Kelia? Cally? Surely all of them got tossed around at one point or another, as she helped the dear swish into another pretty outfit. The tea parties they shared were divine!

But alas, those days were over. Only drudged up for the occasional emotional drubbing, or light blackmailing. The future 'ruler' faced increasing responsibilities to occupy his time, while Orianna was left to her own devices.

Her own devices, however, were not knitting and basket weaving. She'd spent many an hour in the castle library, or with private tutors, studying various forms of magical alchemy, as well as in-depth knowledge of politics and diplomacy. Other than ego, it's why she'd insisted on usurping Kelos on this escapade. She wasn't there to be a simple pretty face, and she'd prove that to Mother and Father.

“I wondered where you shuffled off to, Scribe.” Kelos wryly said, as he appraised his old friend. To the royal's mind, this trip just got a lot more palatable: A chance to catch up to someone who'd gone ghost for months now.

“My apologies, your highness! King Reginald's orders though weren't to be ignored! But it is nice to see you, again.” Sean smiled, with his tone full of warmth.

Ori merely rolled her eyes. “That's all well and good, you two, but we can proceed with frivolities after we're briefed on the mission.”

“Oh, yes! Teutonis. Quite the interesting place. Going through a bit of a political and cultural upheaval right now as it is, actually.

That seemed to perk the ears of both royals. “Upheaval?” Kelos echoed: turning more towards his companion.

“Mm! Appointed their first male king in nearly a millennia! It's traditionally a matriarchy, you know! The first in line was relieved of their duties due to, ehem... complications.”

“Scribe.” Orianna glowered. “Now is not the time to be obtuse.” She informed, crossing her arms under her ample chest.

“It's an obtuse situation, my princess!” The servant defended: waving his arms forward. “A situation that might be better explained over some tea.”

“I... wouldn't be against a cup...” Kelos remarked rather hesitantly.

Ori slowly nodded, if only because she believed it would help take off some of the edge she was feeling.

“Excellent! I've just the scroll that should brew us up a batch faster than you can blink!” Sean cheered, peering into his adjacent satchel of various spell-laden parchments.

Parchments that had a long history of, ehem... complications.
13532122.title: Brother and Sister. And Scribe.

choices: Kelos takes it in stride.
Kelos immediately lashes out at the scribe.
135321222.content:
As Sean used his scroll to magic up some tea, Orianna couldn't help but think back on those times. If only Kelos really were her little sister. It would be a simple act, merely a drop of her latest creation would do. She watched the scribe. Why Kelos wouldn't even know it was her, he, no, she would assume it was the scribe's doing. What better time could there be? If she were somehow discovered, another drop would reverse the transformation. Orianna smiled slyly as she convinced herself. Neither Kelos nor the scribe noticed as they were focused on the scrolls.

"Here we are," Sean said as he pulled out his scroll and held it up. On the outside was written "Instant tea set - creation magic - makes a pot of fresh brewed tea and several cups appear."

"You have them labeled, I see," Kelos commented approvingly.

"Yes, some past incidents have taught me just color coding isn't enough," the scribe replied. "It's best to have a written description of what the scroll does on the outside."

"I assume you've tested this," Orianna said, laying the groundwork for her plan.

"Of course, Princess," Sean replied. He pulled open the scroll and indeed a pot of tea and 4 empty teacups appeared in a flash of light. Orianna used this brief distraction to pull a small vial containing her latest potion from its hiding spot sewn into the sleeve of her dress.

"You've got an extra cup," Kelos said.

"Four seemed like a good number," Sean replied. "But maybe I could make the spell vary based on the number of people in attendance?"

"At least it seemed to work," Orianna said. She reached for the teapot and poured a cup for herself. She then turned towards Kelos' cup and filled it, while carefully adding a single drop of potion. She then reached over and did the same to Sean's cup. It was riskier adding a drop to both, but it would make it seem more likely the tea was the cause. She put the pot down.

"Thank you princess," Sean said.

"So, you were about to explain why the first in line was removed," Orianna said, taking a sip of tea.

"Ah yes," Sean replied.

"Also what this cultural upheaval is," Kelos added. He took a sip of tea. With attention on the scribe, Orianna slipped her vial back into his hiding spot.

"Well, let's start with the crown princess," Sean said as he also took a sip of tea.

"Why is it so hot in here all of a sudden?" Kelos asked. He felt flush all of a sudden and was sweating heavily.

"You don't look well, brother," Orianna said. She placed her tea down and reached over to feel his forehead. "Why you're burning up!"

"I'm suddenly feeling hot too," Sean said weakly.

"My whole body feels like it's on fire," Kelos said.

"Oh my," Orianna said as she looked at Kelos. "Your chest is swelling." She then glanced over at the Sean. "Yours is too! What was in that tea, you blundering scribe?!"

"It was just tea," Sean insisted. The changes accelerated. Both Kelos and Sean's chests ballooned into ample breasts. Next, their arms and legs thinned out and lost all hair. Their feet and hands shrank, their waists narrowed, and their hips expanded. The final change was their genitals rearranging to form perfect female anatomy.

"It's passing," Kelos said in her new feminine voice. "My body feels weird though."

"Same here," Sean said.

"I'm not sure you want to look, but I don't think you're my brother anymore," Orianna said. "You look more like my sister."

Kelos looked down at herself. She was still dressed in the same clothes, but they did little to conceal her new curves. She felt her new breasts and confirmed they were real. She then looked over at Sean, who was discovering her own changes.
135321222.title: Ori adds a bit 'special something' to K...

choices: We jump to when they arrive in Teutonis. Kelos has had a bit of a... makeover.
Later that night at camp, we see the makeover, with some 'sisterly' bonding.
Sean continues to debrief them about Teutonis/Something else.
1353212222.content:
“By Merlin's beard...” hummed a rather perplexed scribe, as she prodded at her new expansive bust. Brown tresses now dangled over her bangs, and while hidden by the fabric of her robes, an attractive set of curves were not too difficult to outline. 'Bookwormish,' would be the word to use, and not in a derogatory way.

“Sean.” On the other hand, there was a little firecracker sitting right beside, who was none too pleased. “I should never, ever, ever trust you with those damned scrolls!” Each word was punctuated with a shake of the new girl next to her, with the prince(?) throttling her companion by the shoulders. “Every time you do, something idiotic goes wrong!”

Kelos was a sight. But not an unfamiliar one. If Ori wanted a younger sibling, she would be happy to know she got that, and maybe a fraternal twin, as well. Pale skin illuminated radiant, azure eyes, that drew contrast to the fiery red mane that flowed down around them. It was like looking in a mirror. The only peculiarity was how short the royal had become. Both Sean and Orianna towered over her by several inches, making her petite, if not incredibly cute. This was only aided by how much more... modest the chest she'd obtained was compared to the two beside.

“Y- your Highness! I'm sorry! I don't know how-” Their adviser was having quite the difficulty articulating her words, as soprano-pitched beratements filled the air mere inches from her ear.

Sufficed to say, this all made Orianna very pleased.

“Now now, is this any way you should be acting, little sister?” The most senior of their ranks freed the scribe from the 'vicious' onslaught, and plopped the metamorphosized woman down on the seat next to her.

As it were, there'd be no mistaking between either who was Grovan's rightful representative. Kelos, currently, looked like a tag-along. Someone to sit idly at hearings, acting as a 'pretty face,' while the real work was done by the important people. A role Orianna begrudgingly played all too often in her 'official' life.

“Don't drink the tea, Ori.” Kelos huffed, as she crossed her arms under her bosom: mimicking her sister from moments ago. Humorously though, there was a fair bit less 'cushioning' up top as protection.

“I wasn't planning to.” She replied in a sort of maternal, if condescending tone, before turning. “Scribe,” she began, harshening up. “Explain yourself here. What happened? How long with this magic persist?” Ori, of course, sly minx that she was, needed to put up a front to pretend she didn't know exactly what was going on. The concoction she utilized didn't have an expiry date. At least, not a date spanning a human lifetime. She held complete control over Kelos' gender here, with the 'antidote' lying within her hands (or rather, up her sleeve). And let it be known she had no plans of even thinking of utilizing it until after they'd returned to Grovan. Her 'sister' was going to be in for a rather... unique experience.

“Like I said, I don't know! I even labeled the scrolls this time! Labeled them!” Sean bemoaned, as she adjusted her glasses (did she always have those?!). “I'll have to look into it... But it may take some time.”

“Time I doubt we have.” Ori conjectured. “You've yet to debrief us on Teutonis.”

“I would think correcting our genders should take precedence!” Kelos offered in a perturbed cry. “What will people at the castle think once we arrive?!”

“Well, sire, it might be to our benefit...” The adviser offered: gently scratching a Cherubic cheek. “Like I said, it is a matriarchy...”

“And thankfully, out of all of us, I am still in a presentable state.” Orianna affirmed: downplaying the problems, while reasserting her pivotal role in headlining negotiations.

“I'm not sure how I could ever be presentable like... this.” The transformed princess grumbled, as she assessed herself in the terribly awkward, terribly ill fitting attire she was adorned in at the moment.

Hearing that, stars began beaming in Ori's eyes. “Oh I'm not so sure~.” With a heavy tinge of playful menace, she loomed over her sister. “Tell me, dear, do you prefer Kelas, Kelia, or Cally?”
1353212222.title: Sisterly Scheming

choices: Kelos thinks it's a good idea.
Kelos would prefer another look.
13532122222.content:
Kelos sat on a log next to a roaring campfire as the carriage had stopped for the night. She was still wearing her male clothing as she held a cup of tea in her hands. This one had been brewed in a conventional pot the old fashion way, with no magic used. Next to her sat Sean, still wearing her scribe robes, just with the sleeve rolled up. They looked a bit large on her, but not nearly to the extent of Kelos' own clothing. Orianna was currently in the process of searching her luggage for clothing Kelos could wear. Kelos simply sighed.

"I still don't understand it," Sean said. "I checked and rechecked my scroll, and the tea should have been fine."

"You probably just mixed them up while you were labeling them or something equally careless," Kelos huffed.

"Yes, that will do, that will do nicely!" Orianna exclaimed. She pulled out a dress, brought it over to the carriage and placed it inside. She then practically skipped towards her new little sister. "Kelia! I've found the perfect dress for you to wear tomorrow. It will be so lovely with the style I have in mind for you." She reached out her hand to help Kelos stand.

"Well at least someone is happy about this," Kelos quipped. She handed her cup of tea to Sean and reached out to take Orianna's hand.

"I know this isn't what you're used to, but makeovers are fun!" Orianna said cheerfully as she led Kelos to the carriage. "If you had been born a girl, we could have been doing this every night!"

"Somehow that isn't making me feel any better about this, Ori," Kelos replied. "Just make me look presentable, okay?"

"Trust your big sister," Orianna said. She helped Kelos into the carriage, then got in herself, closing the door behind them. The carriage was lit only by a pair of torches on each side, so it was dim, but still workable. "Now then, strip and I'll help you with your new undergarments."

Kelos hesitated for a moment, but then shook her head and complied. She quickly removed her male clothing, and sat in the carriage completely naked. "I don't know why, but I feel really cold. It's not even chilly out"

"You're quite a bit smaller, so that will happen," Orianna replied. "Now then, let's get you dressed!" In what seemed like an instant, Orianna had her new sister in panties and a bra, which somehow fit perfectly, despite the obvious difference in size. "There."

"I had expected your clothing to be loose on me," Kelos commented.

"I have all my clothing magically enchanted to ensure a perfect fit," Orianna explained as she sat next to Kelos. She noticed her shivering a bit. "Come here, I'll warm you up." She held out her arms inviting Kelos for a hug. The former prince turned Princess again hesitated, but eventually accepted. "Don't worry, Kelia, your older sister will take care of you." She began to stroke Kelos' hair.

"This feels nice," Kelos reluctantly admitted.

"It does," Orianna replied. "I can't help but think we'd have been a lot closer as two sisters."

"We'll never know for sure," Kelos replied. "Maybe you would have hated me for being too pretty."

"There's still a chance for that," Orianna replied with a giggle. Kelos smiled in response. "Though I'd say you're more cute than pretty. Which brings up what I want to do with your makeover."

"I'm well out of my element here, so I'll trust you with it," Kelos replied.

"I'm glad you trust me," Orianna replied. A part of her suddenly felt guilty for what she had done, yet it seemed to be a huge success. "But you should still have the final word on this, since it's your appearance."

"Okay, just make sure it's phrased in a way I can understand. I'm new at this being a princess," Kelos said.

"Well, you're short, even for a woman," Orianna said. "So I was thinking a bookish look would be best."

"Bookish?" Kelos asked.

"Yes, to put it another way, I'm going to try to make you look really smart and well read. This way if you offer a suggestion at the negotiations, it won't be dismissed as prattling of a child."

"Oh, I see," Kelos replied.
13532122222.title: Later that night at camp, we see the makeover, ...

choices: During the trip, Ori encourages 'Kelia' to take up more 'bookish' habits.
It's time for Princess Kelia to make her debut in Teutonis!
How is 'Sean' handling her changes?/Something else.
135321222221.content:
Intentional or not, 'Kelia' felt a sting from Orianna's words. 'More cute than pretty,' 'short, even for a woman,' 'dismissed as a prattling child.' These were concerns that'd not once passed through the new princess's mind since getting transformed. Her current goal was to look acceptable to the Teutonian royalty, yes, but what that really entailed wasn't a matter she'd ruminated too hard on: rather busy reeling from the change in the first place!

As a man, he'd studied a variety of military tactics, as well as some considerable training with a blade. While never overtly violent, he always thought it lent an air of respect to him in diplomatic meetings- however much of a placebo that might've been. Seeing herself now though... Could she actually hold a sword? Glancing at her delicate, waifish arms, the answer was an obvious, bashful, 'no.' It'd be comical, if not dangerous. Kelos was beyond her reach here, and all those years of formal education were urging that she defer to someone with more expertise.

“...Whatever you think best, Ori. Like I said, I trust your judgment. Plus, you are in charge.” The half-naked girl said with a gently wry smile.

There was not a single word in those three sentences that Orianna didn't like. Oh! If she knew this was the response to a little, minor thing, like a gender change, then she would've done this ages ago! Kelia was acting so well behaved!

She practically pounced from there: taking the statement as a means to go carte blanche with her idea. Maybe it was because of the surprisingly pleasant way the scribe turned out, or perhaps there was simply something to taking a proud warrior, and making them a tad more demure, but Ori was giddy with the possibilities!

A pair of eggshell colored, knee-high socks, were first to claim the redhead, with their cotton sure to aid in abating the cold. An elongated dress then followed: blue, with gentle, white highlights, and a hem that draped down to her calves. Feminine frills adorned it, but not to a terribly absurd degree: a careful line needed to be ridden, lest 'Kelia' come off years younger than she actually was, thanks to her limited 'assets.' Unfortunately, the mary-janes she was further adorned in, likely did nothing to defer a sense of regression.

The most notable change in character though came to the royal's facial features: hair pulled back into a bangless, braided ponytail, while a set of glasses, similar to Sean's, were rested upon her brow.

“But I don't need these, Ori!” Kelos interjected, mid-makeover. She had worries that they'd make her vision blurry, but strangely, she saw fine in them.

“Fashion before function, dear sister.” The older sibling tutted, as she finished tying the last loop in her target's tresses. “They're fake. I've worn them occasionally during meetings to 'smarten myself up,' especially while going through documents. But now they're yours, and I must say, they make you an absolute dish!”

Kelos blushed heavily at that. She'd like to think she didn't have have experience with gowns and skirts before, but childhood memories were swiftly cropping up. Those times Ori ushered him off into one of the castle's many closets, and made the oh so manly prince (who didn't know any better) swish and giggle, until they were inevitably caught by a dutiful maid. There was even that time he got wrangled into playing with Mother's makeu-

“Now then, we just have a few finishing touches up here!” Orianna beamed, as she pulled out her personal cosmetics kit. “Afterward, we can show you off to the guards, and ask what they think! Won't that be fun~?”

The spectacle-laden royal was coming to the conclusion that tonight was going to be a very long night.
135321222221.title: Bookish Beauty

choices: Kelia answers.
Kelia lets Orianna answer.
1353212222212.content:
"I don't think I'm ready for this," Kelos said. She was sitting straight up with her legs together, crossed at the ankle as Orianna had instructed. "I remember what you taught me, but what if I slip up? What if my acting isn't good enough?"

"Don't worry, dear," Orianna said, trying to reassure her former brother, and current sister. "If anything it would work in your favor. A young princess on her first diplomatic trip, surely she's bound to make a mistake with proper etiquette. If you notice someone staring at you, just sit up straight like you are now and continue with what you're doing."

"If you say so, Ori," Kelos replied uncertainly.

"I am," Orianna said. "You are my sister and I have faith in you."

"Thank you, Ori," Kelos replied. She reached out and clasped her sister's hand and smiled. "If I get through this, it will be because of you."

Orianna was ecstatic at this, though she tried not to show it. Kelos never gave her the respect she deserved, but "Kelia" was much more aware of her older sister's greatness. "I may have helped, but it will ultimately be you who succeeds," the older princess said, feigning modesty.

Sitting across from them, Sean, who had taken to calling herself Sionna, rolled her eyes at this display. Kelos, no Kelia, she corrected herself, had adjusted well to being transformed. Probably due to Orianna's coaching. She had had no such assistance and found this body deeply uncomfortable. Worse, she had spent the majority of the trip attempting to inform the princesses on the state of affairs in Teutonis and had little opportunity to find a way to undo this. Still, as long as the mission was successful, she would have plenty of time to figure out what went wrong back home.

One of the guards knocked gently on the window of the carriage. "We're arriving now," he said.

"Thank you," Orianna replied. She then turned back to Kelos. "It's time for your big debut, Kelia." Kelos smiled weakly in response. "Remember, call yourself Kelia, think of yourself as Kelia, be Kelia."

"I'll try," Kelia replied.

"That goes for you too, Sionna," Orianna said.

"I'll do my best, Princess," Sionna replied half heartedly.

With that the carriage came to a halt. Orianna was the first one out, followed by Kelos, and then finally Sean. The three of them stood in the courtyard before the gate to the main keep. A soldier from Tuetonis was having a conversation with the captain of the guard detachment. This was certainly not the welcome any of them had expected.

"Shouldn't there be someone here to meet us?" Orianna asked. "Or does Teutonis do things differently?"

"There should be, Princess," Sionna said.

"I'll find out what's going on," Kelia said. She then approached the soldier talking with the captain. "Excuse me," she said. "I am Princess Kelia of Grovan. Might I ask if there's a problem?"

"There is no problem, Princess," the soldier replied. "The King has simply decided he should meet you personally, but is currently in a meeting. He shall be here momentarily."

"Very well," Kelia said skeptically. She returned to Orianna's side.

"What's the problem?" Orianna asked.

"The King will greet us personally but is running late," Kelia said.

"Oh, so it's that old keep them waiting to throw them off trick," Orianna replied.

"So it seems," Kelia replied.

After waiting for nearly half an hour, the gate began to rise. As it did, twenty women, wearing rather impractical armor that left quite a bit of skin exposed filed out in two columns. They took positions on either side of the gate. Finally a tall man walked out. He was thin, but still had some muscle definition, especially in his abs, which were entirely visible due to his lack of a shirt. "Welcome to Teutonis, ladies," he said. "I trust your trip here was pleasant."
1353212222212.title: It's time for Princess Kelia to make her de...

choices: The group is shown around the castle, and learn more of Teutonis
They settle in and talk.
Straight to negotiations!/Something else.
13532122222122.content:
Years of training in diplomacy and decorum had Kelos almost instinctively feeling the urge to answer: words forming right on the tip of her tongue. But she held them. Held them, since, as it had been rightly established in the beginning, that Orianna was to be dictating the proceedings.

“It is a pleasure to finally get a chance to meet you, King Aison.” And dictate, she did: gracefully curtsying to the Lord. “I am Princess Orianna of Grovan. To my side here is our Scribe, Sionna.” 'Sionna' stumbled into something between a bow and a curtsy herself: it came off oddly fitting, for the scatterbrained assumptions of her title. Though the jiggle her chest brought probably offered some additional attention.

“And this,” Ori continued: an air of pride growing on her voice. “Is my little sister, Princess Kelia. Here to accompany me during our negotiations.” 'Little Sister Princess Kelia's' face tinged red at that, but with only the smallest hesitation, she curtsied as well. It looked like a young sibling nervously meeting someone for the first time, but not at all unbecoming for the royal that she was.

“Ah! the pleasure is all mine, Princess Orianna.” King Aison seemed quick and energetic in anything he did, and soon he was upon the eldest Grovan: lending a gentlemanly kiss to her hand. “In fact, I am hoping this stay of yours will be equal amounts of play as it will be work. You'll find things here in Teutonis are far less... How should we say... stuffy? Compared to where you're from.”

Through this, as the King offered various pleasantries, Kelia was ignored. Sidelined. Treated secondary to her sister. There wasn't a singular moment between Aison and her sister where she could get a word in edge-wise. This, in its own right, was an... interesting experience. Not something she at all was used to, since, as 'Prince Kelos,' attention was constantly splayed his way. Aison certainly wasn't being intentionally rude, but it did make her wonder... Was this something Ori had had to deal with over the years, and she'd just never noticed?

“But even still!” Aison had just gotten done speaking of all the luxuries and accouterments they would be afforded at the castle. “We'll make sure this visit will be plenty educational for your young sister here.”

“She'll be sitting in during our meetings." Orianna confirmed. 'Sitting in,' though... Not 'participating.' Not 'being involved...'

“Of course!” Aison beamed. “Learning the art of diplomacy is important! Even at her age!”

...And that caused her teeth to grit. 'Even at her age?!' She was 22! Wasn't she?... That confounding Scribe's magic didn't have some regression spell baked in it, right? Glancing over at Sionna though, seeing the softness of her skin, her features, she was easily believable to be in her late teens, if anyone were to judge. And that's despite her 'attributes.'

“They say they have a spa here~.” The brunette dreamily whispered, which only led Kelia to rolling her eyes. She was beginning to believe that this was going to be the strangest 'diplomatic endeavor' she'd ever been on.
13532122222122.title: Kelia lets Orianna answer.

choices: In the morning Kelia looks even younger.
Kelia tries to use her charms for the first time.
135321222221222.content:
"Ori, I need to ask you something very important," Kelia said almost as soon as the servant closed the door to their room for their stay here. "How old would you say I look? Be honest!"

The elder princess giggled at this question. "I must say I'm quite surprised the most important question you have is how old you look. You're so cute!"

"Oooriii! I'm serious!" Kelia pouted.

"When you pout like that you look at most 14," Orianna giggled. Kelia merely narrowed her eyes in response. "I'd say you do look young, I'd say about 16."

"Right! Exactly!" Kelia said. "And that scribe, even though she's more... developed... she doesn't look much older!"

"Oh? Is my sweet little sister jealous?" Orianna teased.

"That's not it," Kelia insisted, stamping her foot. "I was thinking, what if there was some sort of age regression magic in that scroll too?"

"I suppose anything is possible," Orianna said. "But I believe it's more you just look young for your age." There hadn't been any age regression magic in the pills she slipped in the tea, and she seemed the same age as before so the scribe's scroll likely didn't have any either. Still. it really couldn't be completely ruled out.

"Which means no one is taking me seriously!"

Perhaps not," Orianna agreed. "But is that such a bad thing?"

"Yes!" Kelos insisted. "If no one takes me seriously, I can't be of any use here."

"That's not true," Orianna said. "I think you can use it to your benefit."

"How?" Kelia asked.

"If no one takes you seriously, they won't be as guarded around you. It may allow you to discover things that would normally be kept secret," Orianna explained. "You're a girl now, and a girl needs to use every weapon she has in order to succeed."

"You're saying my youthful looks and natural cuteness are weapons?" Kelia asked.

"Yes, and when used properly they can be as potent as a sword. You look about 16, so introduce yourself as 16. That's the perfect age to be learning the art of diplomacy from your accomplished older sister."

"I think I understand," Kelia replied. "I'll try my best at using my girlish charms."

"Excellent," Orianna replied. "Now then, let's turn in for the night. We have a busy day of negotiations ahead tomorrow."
135321222221222.title: They settle in and talk.

choices: Orianna eschews any clothing that brings out Kelia's 'maturity.'
Orianna gives Kelia her 'bookish' look again.
What's Sionna doing/Something else.
1353212222212221.content:
'Turning in for the night' proved to be an... interesting affair, when it wound up the room the two princesses were afforded only had one bed!

“Is this really a 'Teutonian tradition,' Ori?” Kelia asked in flushed hesitation, as her older sibling thoughtfully guided her into a modest, but feminine nightgown.

“Hm? Don't you remember what Sionna told us on the way up~?” Orianna was being a tad obtuse, while simultaneously untying the braid in her sister's hair. “Family is very important in Teutonian culture! So sharing something as simple as our body heat is perfectly natural!” Of course, she left out the part where it becomes somewhat unnatural when those family members 'come of age,' but Kelia hadn't 'come of age.' She was a delightful, impressionable, and oh-so-still-learning-the-ways-of-the-world 16 year old, who greatly needed her older and wiser sister's guardianship!

At least, that's what she told King Aison, when she requested they share a room.

Either way, Kelos failed to earn a word in edge-wise. Maybe it was having to deal with so many new sensation and situations, but the former prince was much less assured of himself as a girl than he ever was as a man, which meant hanging on Ori's words was becoming much more common.

...But was that so bad? As she was guided by the arm to a very ornate and frilly queen-sized mattress, a strangely comforting notion looped through her head: Ori was in charge. She wasn't. She didn't have to bear any of the weight of leadership. She just had to be good, do as she was told.

“Now let's be proper guests, and share our body heat! Shall we~?”

Tonight, at least, 'being good,' and 'doing as she was told,' involved Kelia playing the role of Ori's human-sized stuffed animal.

-_-_-_-_-_-

“Mm, a spa~.” Sionna, meanwhile, was currently having her own little adventure: the bespectacled brunette leaning back in a heated pool, with the 'obscene' parts of her chest just rightly obscured by the ebb and flow of the water. It was evident that, even given the late hour, the young Scribe entirely had her priorities set.

In the very least, she was having much less philosophical quandaries about her role and gender.

-_-_-_-_-_-

Kelia had to admit, despite a myriad of worries and thoughts whirling around her head, this was oddly one of the best rests she could remember in recent memory. Cuddled up against her elder sibling's bosom, she felt warm, and safe. Protected. It eased her burdens in a way she couldn't rightly articulate.

Which was why she was saddened to find herself awakening to an empty bed, early the next morning.

“Orriii?...” the young redhead mewled: wiping the sleep from her groggy eyes.

“I was letting you sleep in a bit, Dear.” The older girl gave a calm reassurance, as she sat at an adjacent table: brushing her hair, and going through some papers likely given to her early this morning. Staring out at a nearby window, Kelia couldn't help but give a short gasp, as she noticed it had to be well past dawn!

“I- I'm sorry for being so sluggish, Ori...” She stuttered through heated cheeks, as she crawled herself out of the sheets.

“Nonsense! A young girl like yourself needs her rest so she can grow into a fine lady!”

There was only a slightly teasing tone to her words, as Ori turned back to her work, which caused Kelia's face to burn all the hotter. Truth be told, given her station, she probably wasn't needed to be up early. She had no need to plan for negotiations or treatises if she was just 'sitting in.' “Are those papers for a meeting today?...” She lightly asked.

“Mm, something like that. Don't you worry about it.” Ori spoke this in the most droll, unfun, flippant tone imaginable: a stark contrast to her mood on just about everything else lately. Like a parent dealing with work, and not wanting their child to get in the way.

Kelia was going to interject a bit: maybe ask some questions, until she absently caught a look of herself in a full-sized wardrobe mirror, and it vanquished all other ideas from her head.

Gosh... She looked so... petite. Those were her thoughts, as she inched herself forward, and put a hand on the glass. “Ori... are you sure there wasn't any regression magic in that spell?” The... 'modest' size of her chest... The Cherubicness of her face... Her height. Goodness, her height! She was told she came off as 16 yesterday, but this was a 14 year old by any measure.

Orianna couldn't help but giggle, as she sashayed over to her sibling. “Oh, I don't think so, Dear~.” Even if she did think so, she might not say anything... “It's just that without your hair done up, and without your glasses, you look a tad less... mature.” Not that there was much maturity to scrape by with.

“I... Maybe?...” Kelia's features scrunched up, as she still couldn't naturally believe that this was what she looked like as a 22 year old woman.

“Now now, it's best not to dwell on needless worries!” A glint couldn't help but shine in Ori's eyes as she uttered the following suggestion: “Why don't I help you get dressed~? We've got a long day today!”
1353212222212221.title: In the morning Kelia looks even younger.

choices: Kelia stays and asks Teutonis for help.
Kelia wants to return home.
13532122222122212.content:
In no time at all, Orianna dressed Kelia in the perfect dress for a studious young princess eager to learn. A dash of make up, the right style, and it would surely allay Kelia's silly fears of getting younger. At least, that was the plan. However, as Orianna put the finishing touches on her little sister's ensemble for the day, one little fact was clear, she really did look younger. "Oh my," was the only thing the elder princess could say.

"Ori?" Kelia asked. "Is something wrong?"

"Perhaps I have been a bit too dismissive of your worries. I tried to make you look a bit older, but I dare say you barely seem 14."

"See! I told you!" Kelia exclaimed. She rushed over to the mirror to look at herself. "At this rate I'll be an infant in a week!"

"Now, now, we don't know if this will continue," Orianna replied with as calm a voice as she could muster.

"We don't know it won't!" Kelia replied. "I could keep getting younger until I cease to exist!"

"I suppose that is a possibility," Orianna conceded. "We shall have the scribe..."

"NO!" Kelia replied emphatically. "This is all her fault in the first place! I'll make sure that if she keeps getting younger too she won't get the cure until she's 6!"

"We could ask it King Aison has someone who can look at you. Otherwise the only option is to send you back to Grovan for Xarlet to examine. That will take a few days, and if you continue to get younger, you'll only be 7 or 8 by then."

"I don't want to be an 8 year old again!" Kelia exclaimed. "Being 14 is bad enough. But we can't let Teutonis find out! They might figure out who I really am."

"So that leaves Sionna as the only option."

"I already said no," Kelia replied, crossing her arms. "There's no hope if we leave it up to her. It's either I go home, or we ask for help from the king."

Orianna walked behind Kelia and hugged her tightly. "I don't know if I can focus if I'm worrying about you. I'd rather you stay here so I can know how you're doing."

"Ori..." Kelia replied. She put her hands on top of Orianna's. and closed her eyes, smiling. It had been years since the last time she felt Orianna had genuinely been concerned for her. Mother and father had given them this assignment together to help them get closer, and while they certainly didn't expect their son would be transformed into a girl in the process, it did seem to be bringing the two of them closer. Leaving now would risk leaving Ori too worried to succeed, yet would Teutonis even be able to help? Xarlet would easily be able to fix this, so returning home would be a certain cure. "I've decided."
13532122222122212.title: Orianna gives Kelia her 'bookish' look ...

choices: Teutonis' magician is as much of an oddball as Xarlat and Marlin.
Ori insists on coming with Kelia. Does this anger Aison?
Where is Sionna?/Something else.
135321222221222121.content:
“I'll stay here with you, Ori.” Kelia hummed: taking a moment to savor her sister's gentle embrace, before reluctantly pulling herself out from the grasp, and turning around. With the attire she was adorned in, the thoughtful look on her features was all too appropriate. “But we'll need to come up with an explanation that doesn't let anyone know that I'm not...”

“Usually quite as fair as you currently are~?” The older girl teased.

“S- something like that.” Kelia blushed, turning her cheeks away.

“Well, it's rather simple, Dear!” Ori beamed. “We tastefully exclude to King Aison that whole tiny, 'I used to be a terribly boring, terribly uncute prince' bit, and merely notify him of our concerns about your age.” She said, raising a finger up astutely. “After all, that part is very real, and something we need to address.”

“No teasing!” Kelia huffed. If anyone didn't know better, they might feel there was a hint of immaturity to her tone. “But still... That... That seems like it might just make sense, Ori!” As the words rolled along, a bright lilt began to enter her tone.

“Always trust your Big Sister, Little Sister! She clearly has the best ideas!” Ori puffed up a little, as she put her hands on her hips.

“If we're not careful, I'm gonna end up becoming a littler, and littler sister...” Kelia's joke was sprinkled with a hint of worry. “They have to have a wizard, right?...”

“Of course they do, Dear. Any kingdom worth its salt does~.” There was a sweetness in the elder sibling's tone, as she approached, and placed an assuring hand on the bookish girl's cheek- before a sly grin overtook her. “Although I wouldn't mind still trimming a few more years off you. You're simply adorable!”

“Oriiiii!” Kelia childishly whined.

-_-_-_-_-_-_-

“How awful! How awful, awful awful!” King Aison sat in his throne: overtaken in pure dramatics. His arm was lifted to his forehead in heightened woe, while the rest of him kicked back with nonchalant casualness. “To have your young sister besmirched with a curse, right when arriving to my abode! This is a black mark on Teutonis!”

Kelia stood at the sideline awkwardly, as she watched her sibling do all the negotiating and heavy-lifting. Despite the current problem, Ori nudged a reminder that she was 'in charge,' and that it'd be best if she kept mum so the 'story could be straight.'
