“It's unfortunate, but I am worried. I'd say Kelia here has lost...” A pause for Ori to look in the bespectacled teen's direction. “About two years?”

“Gone from 15 to 13! Dreadful!” No one immediately jumped in to correct Aison. “Well, we can't have that! Guards! Be absolute peaches, and escort Young Kelia here to our Lead Alchemist! She'll do her best to sort it out!”

In the span of a blink, a duo of buxom, scantily-clad spear-wielding women were at Kelia's side, with hands on her shoulder.

“Thank you tremendous, Your Highness!” Ori beamed. “Once we tackle this, we can move forward with our meeting.” Internally the older Grovan was breathing a sigh of relief that this 'small problem' that she... maybe-kinda-sorta was totally responsible for was smoothing over- seeing as how she transformed Kelos in the first place.

Aison however waved his hand off. “Oh, nonsense! We can start right now! Your sister is in the best of hands, and we have much to do!”

Already Kelia was being dragged off: her petite form no match for resisting the Amazonian types put in her charge. “O- Ori?”

“King Aison, I-”

Orianna was interrupted. “Oh, I know you're concerned, but if you want Kelia to grow up, playing mother hen so much certainly won't help!” The Teutonian heir hopped out of his chair. “Seeing a spellcaster live is equally as educational as any meeting she could peer in on!”

Glancing between each other for a moment, both sisters ruminated that it couldn't be too bad, right?
135321222221222121.title: Kelia stays and asks Teutonis for help.

choices: Kelia insists she's a 16 year old princess.
Kelia admits her real identity.
1353212222212221211.content:
The guards whisked Kelia through the countless twists and turns of the castle's corridors on the way to their alchemist's lair. Kelia wondered if it was really necessary to take such a convoluted path, or if it was attempting to confuse her so she couldn't find her way back on her own. Either way, it made the trip seem to take forever. Eventually though, they arrived at a corridor leading to a large door.

"The head alchemist's lab is down there," one of the guards said, pointing, but making no moves towards the door herself.

"We shall remain here to escort you back to your room," the other added.

Kelia looked up at the guards, then towards the door, then back up to the guards. "You're not even coming to the door?"

The guards looked nervously at each other, then down to their small guest. "No, well... You see... Privacy!" one of the guards stuttered.

"Yes, that's it, you should have privacy!" The second guard gave the first a look as if to say good job.

"Privacy, you say?" Kelia replied skeptically, looking the two guards in their face. Despite their nervousness they did appear sincere. She then turned towards the door. "I thank you for escorting me here." She then approached and knocked. The door opened, and a spectral hand beckoned Kelia in to a black void beyond. Part of her wanted to turn around and leave at this sight, yet the seriousness of the issue simply wouldn't allow her to wait. Kelia took a deep breath, then stepped through the doorway. As she did, the door slammed shut behind her, and she was left in complete darkness. Taking another breath, Kelia steeled her nerves and called out. "Hello? I'm here to see the castle wizard."

With those words, Kelia felt a sudden rush, as if she were moving faster than even a horse at full gallop could manage. An instant later the darkness cleared, and she found herself face to face with a woman who appeared to be in her late 20s wearing a bright pink outfit with a skirt that came barely halfway down her thighs, and a blouse that left her belly completely exposed while also showing off her ample breasts. This was clearly not an outfit a servant would wear. Kelia concluded this must be the magician. "Look, if this is about my late cookie bill, I told you girls, you'll get your money!"

"Cookie bill?" Kelia replied with an extremely confused look. "No, I'm in need of your help. You're the castle magician, right?"

"Oh, oh good. Just forget you heard me say that," the woman replied. She then took a bit of a sterner tone. "I am the head alchemist, not some pull a rabbit out of the hat magician."

"I should hope not, I have a problem that only someone well versed in real magic can help with!"

The alchemist's face lit up at this. "Excellent, excellent. Tell me all about your problem!"

"I'm getting younger," Kelia said. "I'm not really a young girl, I'm supposed to be 16!"

"I see, I see," the woman replied. "Yes, aging backwards is a well known symptom with many possible causes. Tell me, how long has this been happening?"

"Since the day before yesterday."

"That's quite a rapid onset," the woman replied. "Very well, we shall need some readings!" She snapped her fingers and the room changed. In the center was a small round platform about a foot high and two feet in diameter. The top was flat with a magic circle drawn on it. Next to the platform was a rack with a pink robe. "Take off all your clothes, and I mean everything, undergarments included, then put that robe on and stand on that platform.

"My dress buttons in the back," Kelia said, blushing slightly.

"Fine," the woman said. The same spectral hand that opened the door appeared, unbuttoning Kelia's dress before again vanishing.

A few minutes later, Kelia had finished undressing and put on the robe. "I'm ready," she said, as she stepped onto the platform. "Oh and forgive my rudeness, I haven't introduced myself, I am Princess Kelia of Grovan.

"Then let's begin the diagnosis, Princess! No matter what, don't move." the woman said without giving her name. The room suddenly filled with lights of all the colors of the rainbow. Kelia shielded her eyes, yet it seemed to do nothing, almost as though the lights were going right though her body. This lasted for several minutes before finally ceasing. "Okay, you may step down now."

Kelia complied, as a scroll appeared in the alchemist's hands. "Might those be the results?"

"Yes, they are," the woman replied as she unrolled the scroll. "You said you are Princess Kelia and you're 16, correct?"

"Yes."

"I'm just going to ask, are you being truthful with me? These results are..." She paused to pick the right words before continuing. "They're strange for a 16 year old girl with your reported symptoms. If you're not being honest with me, any treatment could have unexpected side effects."
1353212222212221211.title: Teutonis' magician is as much of an oddball...

choices: Kelia demands Allenia do something! Does she regret it?
Kelia accepts being regressed... For now.
Allenia tries to cheer Kelia up some other way/Something else.
13532122222122212112.content:
A gulp couldn't help but slither down Kelia's throat, as the alchemist before her pressed that question. Here she was, practically in her birthday suit, regressed to almost half her real age, and without her 'big sis' to offer any guidance. All that insistence of allowing someone else to be in charge might have started to drum up a submissiveness in the young teen, that previously would have readily held a poker face.

“Um, can you keep a secret, Miss Alchemist?” She asked sheepishly. Experience had shown to her as well that lying to a wizard was not a good idea. Xarlat could get very... thorny.

“Allenia!” The peculiar spellcaster noted. “You can call me Allenia, dear. Allenia the Alchemist. It's why I prefer the title so much to 'wizard,' or something so much less alliterative!”

That caused a slight smile to tilt onto the teen's features, before she somewhat wilted again. “Well, the truth is, Miss Allenia... I am not exactly 'Princess Kelia...' I'm actually more Prince Kelos!” Her voice noted in a more heightened, revealing tone, before a lump swiftly occupied her throat.

“Prince Kelos?” The alchemist parroted: turning her eyes towards the others' chest. “Dear, you're not exactly developed, yet, but I wouldn't call you a boy!”

“T- that's not what I meannnt!” Kelia rapped back in a stuttery, mildly whiny voice. “It's... embarrassing, but on the way here, I accidentally did something- I think it was a magic scroll from my scribe, and it made me a princess! It made me a girl!” She said, shifting her head down to hide away. “But it did even more, I think... Now I'm getting younger, and I'm not sure what to do!”

“Ooooh, I see, I see!” The wizard said, growing much more enthusiastic as the situation elaborated, and the 'problem' grew. One thing she was certainly becoming appreciative of was just how adorable this girl was! So shy! “And you want me to fix all that? Turn you back into a boy?”

“N- no!” Kelia was actually quick to correct. “I- I can't go back to being a boy yet. I made a big debut here in Teutonis as a girl! The whole regression issue is humiliating enough...”

“Hm.” Allenia's lips pursed, as she put her hand on her chin. “Well this does complicate matters somewhat. And you said it was a scroll that did this?”

“I... think so? My scribe is a bit of a dolt.” Kelia huffed: crossing her arms. She didn't know where Sionna was right now, but she sure hoped she wasn't enjoying herself!

“Interesting! Well, I asked all this because there were some strange oddities in the results of your test. I was detecting multiple enchantments on you from multiple sources. The gender change helps explain things!” The magician nodded.

Kelia was not in a nodding mood. “So I got cursed twice?”

“Well I wouldn't call being as cute as you are a 'curse,' but changed, definitely!” Allenia teased. “And I'm sad to say, it's more than twice! But I think I have the answers- Did you know the clothes you came in here with were enchanted? Did you know the glasses you're wearing are enchanted?”

The youth's eyes widened. “What?”

“Minor enchantments, really, but they add up! It feels like something someone dabbling in alchemy themselves might try. Clothes that always adjust to fit the wearer, and glasses that have some minor translation properties to them! You can probably read different languages you don't know right now!” Allenia revealed.

A light bulb went off in the youth's head. Ori dabbled in alchemy all the time... This was probably something she did to her own clothes, and didn't think anything of it!

“But yes! I think that might be the concern! Overexposure! Those minor little additions added onto the cocktail of your gender spell, and now you're getting younger!”

Kelia's brow furrowed. “S- so what do we do?”

The alchemist took a step forward, and in one lightning fast motion, pulled the glasses off the girl's eyes. “There! Part one of the problem solved.” She chirped: placing them onto a nearby desk. “You need to go cold turkey on the magic for a tiny while! You should stop getting younger if you're not exposed to it. But for now, you'll just have to be a bit smaller and cuter!”

The royal's mouth moved, but words failed to articulate. It was... good she supposed that she wasn't getting younger now? But she was hoping for more! “W- when can you age me up?”

“Hm, perhaps by the end of your trip? Though, truthfully, if you want to go back to being a man, you might just want to wait until your Grovan wizard can see you! I hear Xarlat is a real charmer!”
13532122222122212112.title: Kelia admits her real identity.

choices: Kelos hurries and heads to the stables.
Kelos has an unexpected diversion in the castle.
135322.content:
Kelos lay in bed for a few moments as he waited for the grogginess to pass. Then he remembered, he was going to travel to the northern villages today! He sprang out of bed and opened the window. The sun was still low in the sky, so he hadn't overslept at least, but he did need to get moving. He hurriedly dressed and strapped on his sword. He stood in front of the mirror and drew it and re-sheathed it a few times. "Perfect form" he thought to himself, as he opened the door and stepped into the hallway. He heard a clacking of heels, and turned to see a young maid walking towards him.

"Good morning, your highness," the maid said, giving a polite curtsy. "May I ask what you would like for breakfast this morning?"

The prince thought for a moment. "I don't have time for breakfast," he replied. "I'm in a hurry today, I'll just have hard tack on the road."

The maid made a pouty face. "That's not a suitable meal for the heir to the throne," she insisted. "But if that's what you want, I'll make sure your saddlebag is packed." She then curtsied again, before turning and heading down to the kitchen. She then stopped, and turned around. "Oh what time to you plan on returning, your highness? So dinner can be ready for you."

"It depends on how the tour goes, but I'd say 6 at the earliest," Kelos replied.

"You'll need time for a bath, so I'll arrange for dinner at 8, if that's okay," the maid said.

"Sure that should be fine," Kelos said. The maid curtsied again, then left for real this time. Kelos watched her leave, when he heard a voice behind him.

"Kel, you're up, and checking out the help's ass I see," a woman's voice called out. Kelos spun around, angry at the impudence to address the crown prince like that. He was greeted with the sight of a familiar looking woman, wearing the armor of a royal knight. It took him a few seconds, but he finally recognized her.

"Lucia?" the prince asked cautiously.

"That's Lady Lucia, Knight of Grovan," she replied with a confident smirk. "First woman to ever hold the title."

"Why wasn't I told about this? When were you knighted?" Kelos asked.

"Yesterday," Lucia said. "I asked your father not to tell you, because I wanted it to be a surprise. I'll be coming with you on your trip today."

"Well, I'm in good hands," Kelos said. "Though I'd like to think I've gotten better than you by now."

"Keep dreaming, Kel," Lucia replied. "But we'll spar once we get back. I won't go easy one you though." She winked at the Prince.

"I wouldn't forgive you if you did," Kelos said. "I'm going to beat you fair and square."

"The loser buys the winner a drink," Lucia said. "Since you're up, I'm going to make sure the rest of the guards are ready. Don't take too long, Kel. Oh sorry I should probably call you Your Highness."

"At least on duty, Lady Lucia," Kelos replied.

"Ha ha yeah," Lucia replied. "See ya in a bit then." She walked away. Kelos watched her leave as well, but regrettably for him, her armor concealed her curves. "Don't think I don't know you're trying to check me out too," she called back as she continued on.
135322.title: Today he was going to visit to a nearby village...

choices: Go with the talking dog, it seems legit.
Don't take orders from some mutt just because it talks.
1353221.content:
Kelos quickly readied himself for the trip and headed to the stables as fast as he could. Once there he was met by Lady Lucia and several guards, all ready to depart. The maid was also there handing a large saddlebag to the stable who hurriedly strapped it to Kelos' horse. "Is everything ready?" the prince asked.

"Yes, your highness," Lucia replied. "We're ready to depart at your command."

"Well then," Kelos said, as he walked over to his horse and swiftly mounted it. "Let's get moving."

"Yes sir!" the guards replied in unison. They also mounted their mighty steeds and the group left the castle. They traveled north along a main road out of town. People lined the streets to see the heir to the throne on his way. Kelos rode proudly past the cheering crowds.

They thinned as the group approached the edge of the city, and before long they were on a pleasant cobblestone road, well maintained by the Grovan military, with trees lining the sides, carefully pruned to give travelers shade, but not give a place for bandits to hide. The sky was clear, with barely a cloud in sight, and the early morning sun cast long shadows as it rose to their right. It promised to be good weather for the trip. The prince and his entourage passed several travelers and merchants coming the other way, some were from Grovan, and recognized him immediately, while others were from other lands, near and far, who did not. Kelos wished to talk with some of the traders from far off lands, but Lucia kept him on task, as they had quite some distance to cover.

The sun was beginning to rise in the sky as the group reached the first stop, the village of Maesurford. Vast fields of wheat spread out in both directions from the road leading to the hamlet. The group continued onward down the road to the town center the streets were eerily quiet, with no one seeming to be about.

"Kel, I've got a bad feeling about this," Lucia said.

"This does seem strange," Kelos said. "It's unlikely the entire town decided to sleep in today."

"There's a dog over there," a guard said, pointed to their left. A grey mongrel rushed out of the door to the town tailor and quickly approached the group.

"Come with me!" the dog shouted. "We need to get off the streets fast!" It turned around and started back to the tailor shop. It then stopped and looked over its shoulder. "Hurry, you fools!"

"Did that dog just talk?!" Lucia asked in shock.
1353221.title: Kelos hurries and heads to the stables.

choices: Kelos decides to confront the witch.
Kelos decides they should try to escape and get help.
13532211.content:
"Well, what are you waiting for?" Kelos shouted. "Follow the talking dog!" He turned his horse to follow the dog.

"But sir, it might be a trap!" one of the soldiers protested.

"Who'd send a talking dog to lure someone into a trap?" Kelos retorted.

"You heard the Prince, hurry up," Lucia said. Kelos was right, if you were going to bait a trap, you don't want the victims to think it might be a trap. She followed Kelos, as did the other soldiers.

"Around back, you can tie your horses up there," the dog said as it led the travelers between the tailor shop and the general store. Kelos, Lucia, and the soldiers followed, and tied the horses up. "Good, they're out of sight from the street, but all of you inside quickly! I'll explain then." The dog opened the back door to the shop with its nose, then entered.

"I want one of you to keep an eye on the horses, but from inside," Kelos said. He led everyone inside the shop. Looking around he saw a large woman with a hump and a deformed face mending a dress which seemed to have extra sleeves. She noticed the strangers and quickly turned to conceal herself.

"That's my daughter," the dog said. "She was once the fairest in the village. And I was once a man, I own this shop, I was quite an accomplished tailor, I even did some work for some minor lords and ladies. Then the witch came. She was jealous of my daughter's beauty, and turned her into what you see today. I called her a bitch, and she turned me into one. There's almost no one in town who hasn't been cursed by her in some way."

"A witch?!" Kelos exclaimed. "Why didn't you send word to the castle?"

"We tried," the dog said sadly. "She captured the messengers we sent out. I don't know what she does with them after that."

"Kelos, we have to help them," Lucia said.

"Agreed," the prince replied. "However, we aren't equipped to fight a powerful witch.

"Kelos?" the dog asked. "You're the Prince? I'm sorry I could not have warned you sooner. Please, your highness, remain hidden. The witch won't bother you if you remain indoors. It's when she catches you outside you need to worry."

"Sir, surely the castle will send a search party when we fail to return," a soldier said.

"Yes, and they shall fall victim to the witch," Lucia said.

"We need to act before that can happen," Kelos stated.
13532211.title: Go with the talking dog, it seems legit.

choices: Kelos is teleported to the witch.
A spell transforms Kelos on the spot.
135322111.content:
"If we can't escape, then the only option is to confront the witch," Kelos said.

"But Kel, you said yourself we're not prepared to fight a witch," Lucia stated.

"Yes, but I don't intend to fight her," the prince said with a sly smile. Lucia had seen that look all too often growing up. It meant Kelos had a plan he was sure would work, and more often than not, he was wrong.

"You're not going to try to seduce her. are you?" Lucia asked, giving the prince a skeptical look.

"Do you think that's all I do when meeting women?" Kelos replied with annoyance.

"Based on past experience, yes," Lucia replied instantly.

Kelos opened his mouth to retort, but then paused for a moment. "Okay, fair point," he said after a bit. "But that was not my plan."

"So what is your plan, my prince?" Lucia replied with a somewhat sarcastic tone.

Kelos turned to the dog. "So this witch, she takes notice of people on the street?"

"Yes, your highness," the dog replied.

"Then what does she do?" Kelos asked.

"It depends. Sometimes, the victim will disappear, and something that used to be them will appear moments later. Other times, the victim will be transformed as they walk. Rarely she'll appear before the victim in person, taunt them, then transform them."

"So I can't rely on her coming to me for a chat," Kelos said.

"Kel, you can't go out there!" Lucia exclaimed. "Who knows what the witch will do to you?!"

"I can't just do nothing, and I won't send someone out to talk to the witch in my place," Kelos stated as he turned back to Lucia. He then turned back to the dog. "What is your name anyway?"

"Apologies, your highness, I'm William," the dog replied.

"Do you know where this witch lives, William?" Kelos asked.

"I've heard talk that she lives in the forest, but that is simply rumor," William stated.

"What of the people who disappear and return changed, do they remember anything of where they were?" Kelos asked.

"I really don't like where this is going, Kel," Lucia interrupted. "As a knight, I am sworn to protect you."

"Don't worry, I'll be fine," Kelos said confidently. He nodded to William to answer.

"The ones that came back still able to speak were unable to say anything that could identify the location of the witch's home," William said.

"Well I'll have to hope the witch is in the mood to talk," Kelos said. He headed towards the front door. "Lucia, you and the men stay here. If I fail, try to find a way to warn the castle. I'm sure Xarlat would love to have free reign to fight a witch.

"But Kel!" Lucia protested.

"Those are my orders," Kelos said as he put his hand on the door knob.

"Fine," Lucia said. "But don't come crying to me when she turns you into a newt or worse."

"You don't need to worry about that," Kelos said as he opened the door and stepped out. He took a deep breath then shouted, "I am Prince Kelos of Gorvan! I seek an audience with the witch!"
135322111.title: Kelos decides to confront the witch.

choices: Kelia is somewhat convinced by Lucia that she used to be a boy.
Kelia remains unconvinced. She thinks everyone else's memories were changed.
William proposes the idea that Kelia may have actually been a farmgirl.
1353221111.content:
Kelos felt his surroundings instantly warp, twist, change immediately. No longer was he in the desolate roadway of the village, where the stonemasons had just begun to lay stones -- no, he was in the middle of what seemed to be a castle, with walls made of stone and not a single window in sight. Chandeliers were illuminating the area, and a red rug extended beneath his feet up a small staircase, with a throne perched on top of it. Someone was sitting in that throne.

"Good day to you," the figure's voice revealed itself. As Kelos' eyes got used to the dim lit, he noticed that the throne-sitter -- the witch, perhaps -- was not an elderly woman with a crooked nose and a humped back like he imagined her to be. No, she was young -- or at least appeared to be young, with a black as night dress adorning her slim, yet curvaceous figure.

Her face... he didn't know how to describe her face. The only two words that came to his mind were charming and mysterious. Her shining black hair cascaded down her neck and back in a strange way -- enchanting almost, and her eyes seemed to pierce into the depths of his soul. But her breasts were perhaps the most distinguished part about her. Kelos had never seen such large breasts before in the country. It almost seemed as if she was made for child-rearing, not practicing dark magicks, and Kelos couldn't imagine how much milk could be contained within her bosom.

"And to you as well," Kelos replied, bowing. He wouldn't normally do that, but he had to admit that she was currently in a higher and more advantageous position than him. "I thank you for at least greeting me."

"I couldn't just leave a prince without hospitality, could I?" She made a wry mouth. "That would be quite rude of me, especially after you took your time to come seek me. Pray tell, what is it that you want?"

"I think you know what I've come here for," Kelos rebuked, clenching his fist. "After all, you yourself whisked me away from the place of the incident. Why did you turn transform my dear and loyal citizens and pervert their true forms? Was it all for your own entertainment, witch?"

The witch stared blankly at the young prince for a few seconds, and then erupted into a burst of laughter. Kelos felt offended. It appeared as if she was laughing at him, mocking him for asking such an innocent question. He frowned.

"You really do not know anything, do you?" The witch said after finally settling down. Her laughter had lasted for almost a minute. "About that dear village of yours?"

"What is it that you mean?" Kelos' eyebrows furrows. He did not like being made a fool of.

"When I had wandered the world, training and building my reserves of magic, I had met many of people. You see, I have an innate gift to see the purity of people's hearts from birth. These people would have an outer layer of justice, compassion, and virtue covering them, but all it was was a shell, meant to hide their malice, greed, anger, and treachery. Their evil. I had been convinced that a good person does not exist in this world."

Kelos remained silent. He didn't know what the witch was talking about, but he knew it wasn't anything good.

"Take your village for instance," She continued, nodding at his silence. "William, was it? He used to hit dogs out of the frustration of a long and hard day of work, leaving the poor creature bruised and battered in order to vent his anger. Why not let him spend the rest of his life as a dog to atone for it? Or how about the blacksmith who would cheat on his beloved wife with that of his neighbor? Is it not appropriate for him to live through the hardships of a woman from now on? Or how about the barber's son who would steal his sister's undergarments to... satisfy his sexual needs? Would it not be better if he served his sister as undergarments himself?"

Kelos was shocked. He didn't think that humans could be so depraved. He had, of course, heard about individuals performing vile deeds, but he had never thought that his own citizens -- his own people would be the ones to do it.

"Even so," Kelos slowly pronounced, thinking of what he should say, What should he say here? "They are my people, and by extension, my responsibility. All their actions reflect on me, their ruler. If what you say is true, then they are truly deserving of some punishment in life. But not like this. Let them go, I ask of you."

"Ha!" The witch clapped her dainty hands, seemingly amused by something. "And your true nature finally starts to surface. I am willing to bet you are doing this for your own purposes. Do you want the praise of your father? Or the admiration of your citizens? I have met royals before, and they are one and the same! Shall I look at you for who you truly are?"

Kelos noticed that her eyes began to shine a golden color, prodding and examining him as they searched for something. They must have finally found what they had been looking for, as Kelos began to feel a kindred spirit fill him. It was warm and soothing, calming all his worries and easing all his problems. It was a good feeling, and Kelos wanted to remain this way for the rest of his life. But alas, all good things must come to an end, as the feeling was harshly cut by a gasp elicited by the witch.

"I-impossible," she uttered, extending her hand towards Kelos. She suddenly appeared in front of him, most likely through teleportation, and began to stroke his rosy cheek. "You truly do love your people. I have never seen a soul this pure before, filled with goodness to the brim of the heart. There were dark spots, of course, no doubt due to you being a man. But the rest of it is..."

"Does that mean you will take the spell off the villagers?" Kelos inquired, not sure how to feel. It felt like he was getting pampered by his mother.

"Oh, excuse my manners!" The witch suddenly retracted her arm as if though she's been shocked. "I am Ariadna, the High Witch of the Northern Lands. You ask to take the spell of the villagers? I do not particularly wish to, but if you are willing to take responsibility..."

"I will do it," Kelos said without hesitation.

"Very well," Ariadna replied. "Then I bid you farewell, and I hope we meet again."

-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-


Kelia suddenly found herself in the village's roadway once more, the exact spot where she was teleported from. She glanced around. The villagers seemed to still be cooped up in their own houses, so she decided to examine herself. Her long, red, curly hair was still there, her fine breasts were still propped up by the corsage that she was wearing, and her favorite white dress had still extended to her ankles. It seemed that everything was in its place.

"It seems that I have convinced the witch," she declared when she walked back into the house and saw a new tall figure standing there, with the dog nowhere in sight. "The village is now free of the curse."

"K-Kelos," Lucia stuttered. "Is that you?"

Kelia frowned. Who was this Kelos? She didn't know anything about him.

"If you are referring to Kelia, the Second Princess of Grovan, then yes, it is me."

Kelia saw Lucia frown. It was a frown that chastised her many times when she was young and in the wrong.

"Kelos, don't tell me the witch actually cast a curse on you!" Lucia shouted at him, waving her finger. "That's why I didn't want you to go alone. You are really selfish, you know, always trying to solve all the problems by yourself. Now you up and turned yourself into a girl! What will I tell your father?"

"Lucia, please," Kelia begged with a hushed tone, "As you can see, nothing has happened to me. My clothes and my figure have remained the same. I have always been a girl."

"K-Kelos..." Lucia uttered in an already frightened tone. "You mean you don't remember being a Prince? All those times we sparred with swords together?"

"Sparring?" Kelia asked. "I would never do such a barbaric thing! And you probably should not either. You're a girl too, after all, but you hardly ever wanted to play dolls with me!"

"Dolls? I... I would never...!" Lucia blushed, obviously taken off-guard. Kelia smiled. Oh how wrong she was. Maybe Orianna could not force her to partake in the activity, but two small streams of tears and she was running to Kelia to satisfy her whims. Still, Kelia thought that it was quite strange that Lucia thought that she was a boy. After all, she was a princess of Grovan!

"I actually do not recall of any Kelia or Kelos," William suddenly piped up, entering the conversation. "As far as I'm aware, Orianna is the sole heir to the throne."

The two ladies looked at William and then back.

"See?" Lucia pointed. "His mind was probably affected by the spell because of the residual influence of the transformation. His memory of Prince Kelos was wiped, but he didn't gain any false memories like you did!"

"Or maybe," Kelia countered. "His mind built a resistance against the witch's spells. Maybe you had your mind wiped and memories gained, and he resisted that aspect!"

They both looked at William once more.
1353221111.title: Kelos is teleported to the witch.

choices: Kelia decides this is a challenge to overcome.
Kelia decides this is a price she must bear.
13532211111.content:
"How do we know she's not simply a village girl made to think she's a princess?" William asked

"I was able to convince Ariadna to restore everyone in the village," Kelia said. "If she'd listen to a villager, I'd imagine this would have been resolved before I arrived."

"Ariadna?" Lucia asked.

"The witch," Kelia said. "She said I really cared about my people, and because of that she changed them back."

"She could simply be taking her games in a new direction," William countered. "There are three people who have three different memories. There's no way to tell which is true."

"Technically none of them could be true," Kelia added.

"I think I know a way to prove I'm right," Lucia said. "Come with me!" She grabbed Kelia's hand and pulled her along around behind William's shop to the horses that were still tied up. William shrugged and followed them.

"What are you doing?" Kelia asked.

"The horses," Lucia said. "One for me, each of the soldiers, and you."

"Well that's consistent with your memories, but also mine," Kelia said.

"I think I can show my memories are right," Lucia said. "Kel, do you remember how we got here?"

"Of course I do, we rode," Kelia said.

"Now what are you wearing?" Lucia continued.

"My favorite dress," Kelia said. "I'm not sure where you're going with this."

"If you were riding a long distance, would you wear that dress?" Lucia asked.

"No, I suppose I would not," Kelia admitted. "It's not really suitable for riding long distances."

"So why are you wearing that dress now?" Lucia asked.

"I... I don't know," Kelia replied with a confused look. "I remember waking up, putting this on and riding, but I wouldn't ride in this, I'd wear one of my riding outfits."

"See, that's proof the witch transformed you and altered your memories!" Lucia exclaimed.

"Okay, I admit it's possible, and some details about this day don't add up," Kelia replied. "But, if I really was a guy originally, why would the witch transform me into a woman and alter my memories?"

"I don't know, maybe as some sort of price for changing everyone back?" Lucia said.

"Well, she did say something about me taking responsibility," Kelia said. "But if I don't remember being Kelos, it doesn't seem like I'm paying a price at all. There was something else she said at the end, but for some reason I can't clearly remember what it was... Something about something again?"

"Maybe the two of you are looking at this wrong," William said. "What if it's not a price, but a challenge?"

"Yes!" Lucia exclaimed. "That witch is challenging you to overcome her spell and regain your true form!"

"I suppose that could be the case," Kelia said. "But so could it being a price for changing everyone back to normal." She considered the situation. Which of these seemed more likely.
13532211111.title: Kelia is somewhat convinced by Lucia that she u...

choices: "...my widowed brother, Duke Lysandre, came here looking for a bride."
"...Princess Fia has come to visit you today."
"...your grandfather Archibald has suddenly come and want to see you."
135322111111.content:
"I was already wrong once today," Kelia sighed, lifting her skirt a little. She knew that this dress wasn't real, that it was simply a result of a spell, but... she just couldn't rid her attachment of it. "I suppose I could be wrong once more. And the way she had treated me in those last few moments..." Kelia thought back to the witch's caressing. It felt strangely warm, like a mother's touch. "I would like to believe that she would not burden me. Yes, this may be a challenge I must overcome."

"Words cannot describe how thankful we are," William said, giving a semi-bow. "Even if we may not remember you, we truly express our gratitude for saving us."

"I suppose the pleasure is mine," Kelia firmly nodded with a princess' demeanor. "We must be off on our way. And William, please do not take your anger out on dogs anymore." The shocked look on William's face told the princess everything she needed to know as she left the house.

-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-


Princess Kelia was riding back to her castle on her steed, along with Lucia and her other guards. She was sitting sideways so as to not damage her beautiful dress. She had fond memories associated with it. It was the dress that her sister Orianna had given her, promising to find her the most handsome and suitable prince when she became queen. The thought itself made her blush.

Though it was quite strange. She knew that she should actually be Kelos, Prince of Grovan, the heir to the throne. But in her mind, she was the kind and meek Second Princess, who spent her days at Fia's castle, engaging in tea parties and gossiping about the latest events. Speaking of Fia, the princess felt her heartbeat rapidly speeding up every time she thought about her. It was quite a peculiar sensation, one that she had never felt around her before.

"Lucia?" Kelia called out to the young knight's strong figure. Her eyes unconsciously wandered down her backside, briefly examining it before landing upon her arse. They lingered on the swollen and slightly jiggling buttocks before she shook her head. How shameful of me! Kelia thought, chastising herself. Why was I interested in a woman's body?

"Yes?" Lucia replied without turning back around. Her voice was so soothing to the princess, yet filled with power at the same time. She always loved hearing that voice.

"Can you tell me more about Fia? It's just that... she's my dear friend, so I wish to know how I should I conduct myself around her. I wouldn't want to inadvertently cause her pain."

"She's more than that to you, Kelos." Lucia hesitantly responded, slowing her horse so Kelia may catch up to her, before continuing with a firm voice. "She's your fiance and you two are supposed to unite the kingdom. I remember how smitten you were when we were both children, always saying "Fia this" and "Fia that". I was quite tired hearing you rambling about her day in and day out. Though recently you had stopped talking about altogether, talking about your plans for expanding both kingdoms once they were in your grasp."

"But why?" Kelia was surprised to hear this about her. "Fia is such a sweet girl! If I was a man, I would do anything I can to devote my love to her!"

"Who knows?" Lucia shrugged her shoulders. "I didn't really inquire about what was going on inside your mind at the time. Speaking of love, do you still love Princess Fia?"

Kelos hesitated for a second. "I don't know," she finally shook her head. "I can remember being quite fond of men, yet for some reason, every time I think of Fia, my heart skips a beat. And..." Kelia realized that her eyes had wandered down to Lucia's arse once more. She reddened. Lucia noticed her gaze as well.

"Checking me out, I see?" She giggled. "It seems that there is some Kelos left inside you after all."

Kelia's eyes shied away as she wondered if this was the challenge that was imparted on her...

-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-


Princess Kelia was walking down the hallway of the castle, with Lucia at her side, as she wondered how she should break in the news to her family that she was not the same as before, that she was a completely changed person. She sighed.

"What's the matter, Kelos?" Lucia asked. Kelia has already gotten used to that name, though it still felt somewhat alien to her, like it didn't belong there.

"Nothing. It's just that I don't know how I will face my father. He's always a bit tempered and a worrywart at times like these. Sometimes I think he cares too much about me and Orianna."

"You're not sure?!" Lucia snorted. "What about me? How will I explain that I neglected my duty as your protector and allowed you to go outside to face a witch and get yourself cursed to boot! And right after I got my promotion too!"

Kelia wanted to console her and rebuff her statement -- that it was her decision to challenge the witch's authority -- but she didn't have time as the heavy steps of a military figure resounded through the hallway, turning their attention away from the conversation. Someone was approaching.

"Lucia!" Reginald's heavy gait approached her. Kelia performed her customary curtsy. "I have heard from the messenger that something had happened to my son! What is it? And who is this woman beside you?" He narrowed his eyes. "Wait. That hair. Those eyes. They're similar to those of my wife and my daughter Orianna. Are you... Kelos?"

"Yes, father." Kelia affirmed her father's guess with a nod.

Reginald turned back towards Lucia. "You mean to tell me that Kelos was cursed? Where were you when this happened?" Lucia bit her lip. She didn't have an answer.

"Father, it's all right," Kelia stepped in for her childhood friend. "It was my fault. I ordered her to stay back. She was simply fulfilling her duty."

"Hmph," Reginald snorted. "I guess that excuses her of high treason. But she will still receive punishment. Oh dear, oh dear, how will we resolve this mess?"

"There's also the issue of the lost memories," Lucia added in.

Reginald froze. "You mean to tell me that my son does not remember his old father anymore?"

"Not quite," Kelia intervened. "I do remember you quite well, father, but as far as I am aware, I have lived my entire life as a girl. It was only thanks to Lucia that I was somewhat convinced that I am not in fact the Second Princess of Grovan."

Reginald groaned. "If that is the case, then I have decided on Lucia's punishment. Lady Lucia, you are hereby stripped of knighthood."

"What?!" Lucia exclaimed, eyes bulging. Her childhood dreamed had always been to be a knight in dazzling armor, shielding His Highness from hordes of enemies with her body as she cleaved a path to victory for him. And now that it has come to this, she had not only set the record for being the first woman to become a knight, but also the record for being the first to lose it as well.

"Yes," Reginald continued. "And you are hereby forbidden to wear suits of armor. You may only wear dresses from now on, as someone befit to be Kelos' new lady-in-waiting. This decree shall last until Kelos returns to manhood. I suppose that is enough motivation for you to find a cure?"

Lucia wanted to object, but bit her tongue. She knew that Reginald gave her a just punishment. Kelia spent her time giggling as her father chastised her friend. She did not like seeing her friend inflicted with such misery, but had to admit that spending some time as a woman would do some good for her friend.

"Now that we have gotten that out of the way," Reginald straightened himself out. "It really is a problem that you had gotten yourself turned into a girl at this time, Kelos. After all..."
135322111111.title: Kelia decides this is a challenge to overcome.

choices: Archibald reveals his visit now was not a coincidence.
Archibald is getting a bit senile and wanted to see Kelos while he still could
1353221111113.content:
"...your grandfather has suddenly come and wants to see you," Reginald finished.

"Grandfather has come to the castle?" Kelia asked. "I haven't seen him since I was a little girl. At least that's how I remember things. Did Kelos enjoy a closer relationship with him?"

"No, your memory is fairly accurate in this regard as far as I know," Reginald said. "He has been reclusive inside his manor for quite some time. Only his personal servants have seen him in years, until today. He rarely even replies to my letters."

"No," Kelia said. "It would take too long. I doubt you have any dresses prepared, nor would there be any that fit me. Despite the resemblance, neither mother's nor Orianna's clothes fit me." The two women walked through the halls until they arrived at Reginald's personal study. Kelia paused outside the door. She remembered being a little girl, playing with her dolls while her father worked on plans to defend the kingdom. Fond memories of childhood. Yet none of that was actually real. Nor was anything she remembered about the grandfather she was about to meet. Nor anyone else for that matter.

"Are you okay, Kel?" Lucia asked.

"I saw the door to father's study and it dawned on me, nothing I remember is real," Kelia said.

"Events might not have happened as you remember them," Lucia said. "But that doesn't mean nothing you remember is real. You remember me as your friend, right? That's real. Even if we don't remember things the same way, whether you're Kelos or Kelia, I have always and will always be your friend." She held Kelia's hand gently and smiled at her.

Kelia closed her eyes and smiled gentle. "Thank you. I don't know if I could deal with this alone." She opened her eyes and looked into Lucia's. "You're not just my friend though. Father can strip you of your title and make you wear a dress, but he can't change the fact that you're my knight." She paused for a moment to compose herself. "Now then, let's meet grandfather." 13532211111131.content:
Kelia steeled herself, wondering what events are waiting for her behind this door. She shook her one more time, and gently, yet firmly, pushed it open. The interior of the study room opened itself up to her.

A room full of books. Unbeknownst to all but his close family, King Reginald had somewhat of a guilty pleasure when it came to reading. Whether it be a bright and sunny day, or a dark and rainy one, he would continuously sneak away to his study, abandoning his kingly duties, in order to crack open the newest story that had come out. His wife Latissa would often find him holding his breath as he read a story about a knight in shining overcoming trials and hardships to save a princess, before promptly proceeding to drag him out of the study to tend to the kingdom.

And now, in that study, there was another man -- hunched over with graying hair, peering over a book, before licking his finger to turn the page. Kelia's arrival had caused his eyes to turn upwards.

"Come in, my dear daughter!" His jolly, croaking voice resounded, as he waved her closer with his bony fingers. "It is so nice that you've come here together with your friend."

"Archibald, do you...?" Lucia began, but she was cut off by him.

"Call me Archee, like I told you once before," Archibald flashed his crooked teeth at her. "After all, you are my daughter's friend. Aaah, I remember you two playing with dolls like it was yesterday."

The two girls exchanged glances, both of them with bewildered looks on their faces, with Kelia's containing a slight tinge of hope. Could it be that grandfather Archilbald remembered Kelia as a girl? Kelia couldn't help but be filled with hope -- that maybe, just maybe, she was a girl this entire time. Maybe it was the others that were cursed?

But that hope came crashing down as the cackling voice of her grandfather resounded through the room.

"You should... have seen... the looks on your faces!" Archibald said in between breaths. "I am sorry for playing such a trick on you. Yes, Kelos, I remember you being a boy."

Kelia puffed out her cheeks. Memories of her childhood came flowing back to her, as her grandfather loved playing pranks on people. It seems that she was yet another victim of his.

"That was horrible, grandfather!" Kelia protested, biting her lip. "How could you play with a girl's feelings like that? Uh, a boy's feelings, I mean?"

Archibald simply flashed a smile in return, before suddenly changing. His face became stern, and serious, and the air around them changed. Reginald always likened him to a coin, because Archibald's personality was just as two-sided. He would be a jokester one moment, and then switch to being a stern figure the next one.

"Now that we got that out of the way, I would like to discuss something with you," He noticed that the ladies were still standing. "Sit down, sit down, don't make an old man feel guilty." Kelia and Lucia promptly took a seat, smoothing out their clothes as they did so.

"Why did you come here all of a sudden, grandfather?" Kelia decided to not hesitate and asked him. She was particularly curious as to his arrival.

"Because of this," he suddenly reached into his tunic and took out a crimson-red pendant.

"What is it?" Lucia butted in, observing the marvelous opaque stone. She was not as fond of trinkets as other ladies were, but even she had to admit that it was quite dazzling.

"An indicator," Archibald briefly replied. "An old hag gave it to me many years ago when I was still a young lad, but it is quite a useful device -- it tells me whenever a curse has been cast on my family. Its original state is a dark, simmering violet, but whenever someone in my family has been afflicted with a curse, it turns into a fierce, crimson red. As soon as I saw it, I knew that I must immediately head to the castle."

"And when you saw that neither my father, nor my mother or sister were affected, you naturally assumed that it was me, right?" Kelia inquired, pointing a finger at herself.

"Quite so," Archibald nodded, affirming her guess. "But now that I have taken a look at you, I think I know what the issue is. You met with Ariadna, right?"

He had to restrain himself from smirking when he saw Kelia's jaw drop. Lucia slammed her fist against the table. "How did you know?!"

"You see, my dear Lucia," Archibald made a wry smile. "It seems that the fate of Grovan's royal family is intertwined with that of the line of Northern Witches. Fifty years ago, I was inflicted with the same curse that Kelos is struggling with now... by Lucretia, Ariadna's mother."

"Then you know how to break the curse?" Lucia jumped from her seat. Despite her naturally calm demeanor, she was quite emotional when it came to issues that concerned the prince.

"I do," Archibald nodded once more. "Though it took me seven years to break the curse, during which time I sired my little boy Reginald. Ah... don't tell him that story, he doesn't know about it. Anyways, before I go on... Kelos, tell me what you think of swords fighting?"

"I think that..." Kelia wrinkled her nose. How should she answer this? Should she go with an answer that Prince Kelos would have went with? Or should she remain true to herself? In the end, she decided that it was best to stay honest. "...swords fighting is a brutish activity that should stay outside the hands of girls." She flashed a side-glance at Lucia, who simply shrugged her shoulders in reply.

"I see, I see!" Archibald reached over and clapped her shoulder. "I was the same. Back when I had to spend my days as a princess, I was quite... erm, feminine, so to speak. I loved to sneak into the royal kitchen to make pastries. My sister Liliana used to tease me for that. But I am sorry to say that it will be your biggest hardship. You yourself do not want to return to being male."

"Are you meaning to say that feminine activities will keep me... a woman?" Kelia quizzically asked, catching the flow of the conversation. Archibald silently nodded.

"In order to break the curse, you must embrace your male self. Swords fighting, hunting, archery... and yes, this includes love towards females as well. This is why it took me so long to break the curse."

Kelia hesitated. She realized what her grandfather was speaking of for a while already, but she just couldn't accept it. Her embracing a female and making love towards her? Preposterous! Unholy! How sinful! A proper lady should never entertain such thoughts. But then again, she wasn't really female, was she?

"I... I'll do it." Kelia slowly said.

"Really? Prove it." Archibald smiled, though that smile carried hints of pride.

"What?"

"Prove that you will be able to overcome your female self. Prove to me that you will be able to embrace your fiance. Kiss your companion here right now."

"WHAT?!" This time it was Lucia shouting.

Kelia hesitated. On one hand, this was her friend with whom she played since childhood, with whom she entertained no such thoughts before. But on the other, she must overcome this trial, if she wants to right her memory and her self.

What does she do?

...And slow down enough to realize that she was a she now.

There were those years back of playing dressup with her sister Orianna. 'Cally-time,' as they called it. There were also those few months as tween when she was stuck enchanted by a necklace, and got to experience a full gender change. Then there was that incident where she spent a month stuck in a girl's finishing school after drinking that transformation potion. Or-

But the maid outfit was new. “My subconscious is clearly wanting to spice things up.” This was uttered as she rolled a white stocking up her leg. First the left, then the right: enjoying the smooth softness it brought. “I definitely made the right choice.” Her voice echoed, with just that electric tinge of... something in it that seemed a tad off...

“Probably just still riding the wave of the spell that that blasted witch cast on me.” This woman certainly seemed powerful, and she was going to need al lher wits about her if she wanted to face the fiend properly! To think she warped Lucia's mind the way that she did! What an awful thing... Imagine someone influencing your thoughts, the aspects of who you were- your very essence as a person!

That anger was left to fall to the wayside however, as she donned the rest of the ensemble. No point in fuming here in her lonesome. There were more productive things she could be accomplishing! Like putting on a dress!

And that dress came post-haste. Ebony, with a skirt that 'sensibly' went down all the way to her ankles, which were then proceeded to be covered in 'sensible' flats: easy to work in. Said 'sensible' dress also came flourished in a fluffy, frilly, white white apron, to protect it from any dust bunnies which might assail it. And of course. There was the... headdress.

Kelos' gentle fingers crowned herself in it, as she examined her features in the room's sole mirror. Examined her features, and noticed the small blush tinging her cheeks. It made her look quite... 'proper.'

Servile, even!

“I just hope Ori doesn't see me like this. I'll never hear the end of it!” The last object to think about was, apparently, for whatever reason, the maid uniform came with a feather duster! “A tad silly.” She mused. “It's not like I'm going over to clean house. There's a village at stake!”

She was just about to leave it behind, and go down stairs to greet the boys, when a sideways glance at an adjacent table drew her attention. It was covered in dust. This whole room looked to be in so much more of a state of disarray than when she first entered it. How awful!

“Well... I do have the tools to assist...” The raven-haired royal raised up the duster, with a slight smile slowly growing more and more on her features.

It only took a scant few extra minutes, but by the time Kelos was done cleaning, she found herself with an extra skip in her step, as she made her way to go greet everyone.

Kelos wanted very much to save his people, but more important than that was solidifying his rule over the kingdom for the future against the likes of other nations and even his own sister. Ariadna could be the ally he needs for that. Yes, Ariadna could be a very powerful piece for him, and while she wasn't exactly trustworthy he still trusted her much more than the scheming Xarlat. So she whipped her long black hair from her eyes and said, "I accept your offer."

Ariadna's face for the briefest of moments betrayed a look of surprise but it was replaced by a smile, "Very well, I shall leave this village in peace. And I do very much look forward to working with you much more in the time to come my future queen."

"What was that?" Kelos asked as Ariadna rolled her eyes, "Fine, future King." Then at these words a wind storm seemingly came from nowhere with dirt and branches flying everywhere and the sound of howling wind along with a faintest tint of laughter were the only things Kelos heard. When Kelos opened his eyes he saw that once again he was male again, although he was still wearing the same black dress as before.

"Very amusing," Kelos said dryly making his way back to the taylor where Lucia and his knights were waiting in the doorway. Lucia ran up to Kelos as though to hug him but seemed to change her mind at the last second as she came inches away from Kelos but quickly backed off and bowed, "Kelos, my Prince. You managed to outwit the witch! You saved this village!"

"Yes, I suppose I ow!" Kelos grabbed his now freshly hit head, Lucia seemed to have decided to forget formalities for a moment, "Kelos I swear if you ever do something that brash again I will castrate you myself. You could have been killed or worse! And you just charged in! I'm the one who has to take the fatal blow for you, I am your knight not some little girl to be cast aside as you play the hero."

At this point the other knights decided enough was enough and pulled Lucia back and forced her into a bow possition, one knight said "Forgive her my prince, she will be disciplined when we return to the castle." While the other added, "Thank you my prince for saving us, you are truly a great man who would make your father proud."

"No need for thanks, I only did what was best for the kingdom, now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to get out of this dress." Kelos walked into the tailor's and told the dog who had watched the whole thing, "Please fetch me a new outfit if you would."

The dog began to growl before saying, "I will not fetch you anything. You sold out this village for a little power! What about my daughter! What's to become of her now?!" Kelos looked at the magically deformed hunchbacked woman and said, "The witch gave her word leave you all untouched by her magic. I believe that means she will let you find outside help. You can feel free to come to the castle and have Xarlat and see what he can do. But after what I just did to help this village, if you do not trust Grovan I believe Traeven has a decent wizard in Marlin who could also help you." William's daughter stumbled up to Kelos with a decent looking outfit adorn with purple and silver trimming. "Thank you, I wish you and this village the best of luck. If you'll excuse me I must go back to the castle and make preparations."

1353221112211.content:
As the group returned to the castle, most of the knights were praising Kelos for his heroism.

"Even when a woman the Prince's resolve didn't waver for an instant!" one said.

"That witch is lucky the prince wanted to talk!" another bragged.

One knight though rode back a bit, fuming to herself. Kelos noticed this and slowed his horse until he was riding alongside her. She turned her head away still angry.

"I wasn't doubting your ability," Kelos said. Lucia just ignored him. "I don't think of you as just a little girl, but we were fighting a witch. No matter how skilled you are with a sword, it won't help if you're turned into a newt."

Lucia was still looking away.

"I understand I put you in a hard position, but you understand what would have happened if we attempted to fight the witch right?" Kelos asked.

Lucia hated to admit it, but Kelos was right. Despite her skill with a sword, that witch could have given her a form incapable of even holding it well before she could have brought it down on her neck. But really that was the problem, despite all her hard work, when the time came to defend her prince, none of her skills mattered. "I need to learn magic," the knight said at last. "At least enough to get close enough to strike against a witch."

"If you wish," Kelos replied. "But I think it unlikely that we'll run into many more witches. Though some magical wards built into our armor should become standard after this."

"Riders coming up on us fast, your highness!" one of the knights in the front called out. Kelos and Lucia both looked up to see three men in palace guard uniforms on horseback approaching at a full gallop.

"Something must have happened," Lucia noted.

"Indeed,"Kelos agreed. He flicked the reins and headed up to the front. "Coming?"

"Yes," Lucia replied, following."

The riders saw Kelos' group and slowed as they approached. The saluted Kelos before relaying the message. "Your highness, you must return to the castle immediately! Something has happened to the King and Queen!"

"What?! What happened?!" Kelos asked in shock.

"We do not have details, we were dispatched to find you immediately upon the discovery," the lead guard said. "I only know that some sort of foul magic was involved."

"Rest and water your horses," Kelos ordered the three guards. He then dropped his saddlebags and as much extra weight as he could do quickly. "Lucia."

"Right," the knight said as she did the same."

"The rest of you gather out belongings and come as quickly as you can," Kelos orders. He made a clicking noise, pushed in with his heels, and flicked the reins and his horse took off at full speed. Lucia followed.

Pushing their horses hard, they quickly arrived at the castle. Sean, the royal scribe, was waiting.

"Thank you for your quick return, your highness," the scribe said. "Where are the rest of your guard?"

"I left them behind," Kelos replied as his dismounted. He patted his clearly exhausted horse. "What happened to my parents?"

"I think it best I show you," Sean said.

Kelos left his horse to the servants, and followed the scribe. Lucia also dismounted and did the same.

13532211122111.content:
Sean led Kelos and Lucia through the castle, without explaining, which irritated the prince. "Just tell me what happened!" He insisted. "Why are we heading towards the guest rooms?"

"That's where your parents are," Sean explained quietly. "We don't want word of this to get out."

"Word of what?!" Kelos demanded.

"Kel, keep it down, you don't want to start rumors," Lucia said.

"Fine," Kelos said, as it was his turn to fume.

Sean quickly led the pair up to the guest rooms, and then to the last one in the hall. He then turned to Kelos. "Please, try not to be shocked, your highness." He then knocked on the door in what seemed to be a code.

"Come in," an exasperated voice called out from inside. Kelos immediately recognized it as his sister. He also heard what sounded like children arguing with each other.

"Ori?" Kelos asked, as he flung open the door. "What happened to Mo..." he stopped mid sentence as he saw his sister sitting on the floor, her hair and clothes a mess, with two little children, a boy with flame red hair, and a girl with jet black hair, fighting over a stuffed animal.

"It's mine!" the boy yelled.

"No it's mine!" the girl retorted.

"Welcome to the nightmare, brother," Orianna said, exhaustion clear in her voice.

"Who are..." Kelos started to say, but before he could finish the sentence he put the pieces together. The boy had the same hair color as their mother, the girl as their father. "It can't be!"

"It is," Orianna replied. "It's your turn to babysit them, I need a bath and a nap." She got up. "Okay kids, Kelos and Lucia are here to watch you. Have fun!" With that she bolted out the door, not even worrying about appearing graceful in her haste.

The former king and queen continued to squabble over the stuffed animal, paying no attention to Orianna leaving.

"What happened, scribe?" Kelos demanded.

"The king and queen were in the throne room seeing petitioners. The last one presented them with a gift. When the queen opened it, they were transformed into the children you see before you. The petitioner somehow managed to escape in the chaos."

"Any idea who this person was?" Kelos asked.

"No, your highness. No one remembers what the petitioner looked like or what they were wearing. The guards can't even agree if it was a man or a woman." Sean said.

"Are you sure this person left?" Lucia asked. "They could be in the castle still, waiting for their chance to cause more problems."

"We aren't sure, but we think they left," Sean said. "At the very least there haven't been any new reports of magic. Orianna had the castle guards put on alert for anyone who doesn't seem to belong here though.

"Well that's a start," Kelos said. He looked over at the children who used to be his parents. "Did their memories get changed too?"

"We don't know," Sean said. "They haven't been very cooperative. All they've been doing is fighting."

"Well, I can see if they know me," Kelos said. He walked over to the kids. "Hello there." he said as he knelt down next to them.

135322111222.content:
"I cannot accept." Kelos replied. " As Prince..ess," she quickly corrected, "my duty is to my people and I will not see them continue to suffer while I alone am restored."

"A noble sentiment, Princess," Ariadna replied. "But how well will that sentiment hold up when faced with your new life? To be a woman forever? To lose your claim to the throne to your sister? To be married off to a fat, disgusting man for the sole purpose of securing an alliance? To bear children for that man?"

"If I were to abandon my people for my own gain, I would not be worthy of the throne in the first place," Kelos replied. "Further, my parents would not marry me off to some disgusting man. Orianna is still unmarried."

"She is engaged. is she not?" the witch asked.

"She has been engaged since she was 16, and to this day the marriage itself seems no closer," Kelos replied. "I doubt that would change for me."

"So you would not mind remaining a woman?" Ariadna asked.

"Naturally I would rather be a man, as I was born male," Kelos replied. "However, if remaining a woman is the price I must pay for the townspeople being restored, it is not the worst you could ask of me."

"Very well, Princess. I shall make you another offer. I will restore the people of this town, but you shall remain in that form."

"I accept," Kelos said. There was no reason not to. Even if the witch would not restore her, it would likely be a simple task for Xarlat.

"You should wait for me to finish," Ariadna said. " You shall remain in that form, for the rest of your life. If you even attempt to change back to a man, I will then curse all the people of your kingdom."

"You would go that far just to ensure I remain a woman?" Kelos asked incredulously.

"Did you think you could accept my offer then change back later?" the witch asked. "I'm not that accommodating."

"What would happen if someone were to use a transformation spell on me without my knowledge or consent?" Kelos asked.

"Then you must find a way to transform back into a woman by nightfall," Ariadna replied. "If not, I will declare our deal broken. That is only for someone transforming you back without your consent. If you actively try to change yourself back, the deal will be declared broken immediately."

"I understand," Kelos replied as she considered the witch's offer.

1353221112221.content:
"I accept," Kelos replied. "I do not understand why you would go to such lengths, but if that is the price for you ending your torment of this town, so be it."

"Just like that?" Ariadna asked. "You accept your fate as a woman?"

"As a Princess, it is my duty to put the needs of my people ahead of my own," Kelos explained.

"Great, a believer in noblesse oblige," Ariadna sighed, rolling her eyes. "Well this didn't lead to quite as much fun as I hoped. But very well, Princess." The witch waved her arm, and with that all the townspeople were restored to their true forms. "I did offer the deal, and I'm a witch of my word. I shall seek my fun elsewhere." With that, Ariadna vanished as quickly as she arrived, leaving a very female Kelos alone in the center of town.

"Kel, what were you thinking?!" Lucia shouted as she ran up to the new princess.

"Honestly, I was hoping she'd have said I passed a test and restored me as well," Kelos said giving a halfhearted smile. "I do hope I'm at least as pretty as a woman as I was handsome as a man."

"Oh, I'm already envious," Lucia said dryly, while narrowing her eyes.

An older man approached the two. "Excuse me, Prince? Princess?"

Kelos turned to face him. "Princess, I suppose. I will have to get used to the title eventually, after all."

"Very well then, Princess," the man replied. "I know thanks will never be enough, but you did save us all. Because of you, I am once again a man, and my daughter is once again a beautiful young woman."

"Ah so I finally get to meet the real William," Kelos said.

"Indeed, Princess," William continued. "I believe I speak for the entire town when I say we pledge ourselves to your service," He then knelt before Kelos.

"There is no need for that," Kelos said. "I appreciate your support, but I only did my duty."

"Nevertheless, because of you, we can all live a normal life again, free of that evil witch," William said. "It is a debt we must repay."

"Very well then," Kelos replied. "If you wish to repay me somehow, perhaps a new dress?" She held out the skirt of the black dress Ariadna had given her. "I find I don't share that witch's taste in clothing."

"Oh course, Princess!" William replied eagerly. "Feel free to choose from any in my shop. Though they may not suit a Princess. If you wish, I can make you a custom..."

"There's no need to go that far," Kelos said. She thought to herself that Orianna would certainly see to her wardrobe upon her return.

"Kel, we also need to figure out how to explain this to the King and Queen," Lucia said. "They might take the news of having another daughter badly."

"Perhaps," Keos replied. "But for now, I'd like to find something more comfortable to travel in."

13532211122212.content:
"So the witch offered to change everyone except me back to normal. Seeing the suffering of the villagers, I accepted," Kelos said, explaining her new feminine appearance to her parents. "I am not happy about it, but I can handle being a woman."

"I'm sure you can, dear," Latissa said. "But is that really what you want? Surely Xarlet will be able to change you back to normal."

"Oh, I'm sure he can, but part of the deal was I can never return to being a man," Kelos continued. "If I break it, she said she would curse the entire kingdom."

"Son or daughter, you've always been a shortsighted fool," Reginald spoke up.

"I've thought this through, Father," Kelos insisted. "I'm aware it would be dangerous, that enemies of Grovan might see this as an opportunity. I asked about being transformed against my will, and there's some leeway there. I shall have Xarlet make my a magical amulet that will transform any man who wears it into a woman, and then seal it so it cannot be removed. Then, even if I am transformed back, I will immediately become a woman again."

"I think my little sister has a good plan there," Orianna said. "If Kelos wants to use this as an excuse to finally live as a woman, we should accept her choice. And the little fact that I am now first in line for the throne."

"I disagree," Kelos said. "The law clearly states the heir is the firstborn son. Regardless of being a woman now, I was born a son, thus I am still first in line to be king!"

"Queen," Orianna corrected. "You're a woman now."

"Whatever," Kelos replied.

"Enough!" Reginald shouted. "This is another result of your shortsightedness, Kelos. Instead of a clear line of succession, you have muddied it. Both of you will have supporters for your bid on the throne, and the kingdom risks a war! I should simply strip you of your title, but that will not stop it. Word of your actions will inspire the people to rally to you."

"I would never allow the kingdom to be torn apart!" Kelos insisted.

"Neither would I," Orianna said.

"You say that, but are either of you willing to give up your claim? Do you think you can control all of your supporters?" Reginald said.

Kelos and Orianna responded only with silence.

"Perhaps you're being a bit harsh," Latissa suggested.

"If anything I'm not being harsh enough," Reginald fumed. "Kelos, what if you're kidnapped by Treaven, and their wizard transforms you back into a man, in order to curse all of Grovan?"

"If they manage to kidnap me, I would think we have lost the war already," Kelos said.

"Or they offered to let you try on Princess Fia's dresses," Orianna quipped.

"Fine, I have an idea to solve all this," Kelos said while glaring at her sister.

"I don't see why you're so insistent I remain a woman," Kelos replied. "But in exchange you will return everyone in this village to normal, and never torment them again, correct?"

"No, don't do it, Kel!" Lucia exclaimed "It's a trick of some kind!"

"No trick, little knight," Ariadna said. "I'm a woman of my word."

"You have an ulterior motive though!" Lucia insisted. She jumped between Kelos and the witch.

"Lucia, I told you to stay back," Kelos said.

"I'm sorry, Kel, but this witch is just trying to trick you," Lucia said. "She's holding this town hostage with her magic to try to force you to remain a woman. I don't know what her reason is, but I can't believe she's doing all this without a goal!"

"Such a nuisance," Ariadna said. She lifted her hand to cast a spell on Lucia.

"Stop!" Kelos shouted, as she quickly moved between Lucia and the witch. "I have one last offer to make!"

"This one better be good, Princess. This was amusing for a time, but I'm starting to get irritated," Ariadna replied, as she lowered her hand.

"I read a witch doesn't reproduce like a normal person. Instead, witches use magic to conceive a child with human girl," Kelos said.

If the child has a different affinity from the mother it can lead to complications. But then others of us prefer to do things the natural way and conceive a child with a man."

"Kel, you can't be offering what I think you're offering!" Lucia gasped.

"And this goes right back to being amusing," Ariadna said. "Though as soon as the child is born? Would you deny her a mother to nurse her? I'd say it will take at least another two years."

"It's better if the birth mother does," Ariadna insisted. "On the child's second birthday, I'll come and claim her, and turn you back to a man, if you so wish. If you turn this down, I'm leaving, and will continue to play with your precious subjects, beginning with that knight girl you're so fond of."

Kelos looked down, and found the witch has changed him back to a man as well. "You restored me as well?" Kelos asked, confused.

"Kel, you idiot," Lucia said. "She's going to change you back into a woman, probably at a really inconvenient time for you, and after having a baby and raising it for two years, you won't want to give it up, and you probably won't want to turn back into a man either."

"We will deal with that when the time comes," Kelos said. "For now, everyone is back to normal and the witch is gone. When we return home, I shall enlist Xarlat's aid, but this town is safe and a few years as a woman is a small price to pay for it."

Kelos then turned to face him. "Yes?"

135322111222212.content:
Kelos returned to Grovan a hero after the events in Maesurford. The handsome young prince, confronting the witch, holding firm even after being transformed into a woman, impressing the witch with a steely resolve. Word of Kelos' feat spread far and wide. Many compared him to the champions of yore, and nearly all felt Grovan would be in good hands when he finally ascended the throne. However, the tales being told left out one key detail, that the prince had agreed to once more be transformed into a woman and bare a witch child.

Yet this same detail weighed on Kelos' mind for quite some time. Time passed, days turned into weeks, weeks into months, and still no sign of Ariadna was seen. Deciding not to let promise with the witch dominate his life, Kelos moved on. He traveled to Treaven and asked for Princess Fia's hand in marriage. After months of courtship, the two consummated their relationship, somewhat before the wedding date, and Fia was now carrying the heir to both kingdoms. The date was thus moved up to maintain the illusion the child was not conceived out of wedlock. Now the day of the wedding finally arrived.

"I'm telling you Kel, that witch is going to try something today!" Lucia exclaimed. "I need to be in my armor, not this!" She gestured down to the ball gown she was wearing. It was crimson red, as chosen by Fia for the bridal party, hanging off her shoulders, with a V neck, loose flowing sleeves, and a billowy skirt. While the Princess didn't particularly like Lucia, partly out of jealousy of her friendship with Kelos, the prince insisted that she be a bridesmaid, so there would be someone trusted close at hand to his bride if there was trouble.

"It's not so bad," Kelos said, tying the sash on his dress uniform. "At least that dress lets you conceal some weapons."

"I know you've had some experience in the matter, but I have no idea what you're talking about," Lucia replied, playing innocent.

"I'm sure," Kelos said. "I appreciate your concerns, but the odds that witch will pick today of all days to collect on the promise are quite low. Both Xarlet and Marlin are here and have made sure to seal the church against magic. Now you need to join the rest of the bridal party." He placed his hand on Lucia's shoulder trying to be reassuring. "And if something does happen, I'll have you right there to help."

"That kind of smooth talk is going to get you in trouble with the princess," Lucia joked. "But fine, just don't say I didn't warn you when you're borrowing her clothes."

"If something happens you have my permission to tell me you told me so every day," Kelos replied.

"I'll make sure I do," Lucia said. "And one more thing, Kel. Congratulations." With that, she turned and left the room.

Kelos watched her leave, then went back to final adjustments of his uniform. Taking a last look in the mirror, Kelos left to head for the chapel.
