Kelos got dressed quickly, then headed to the stables. However, on the way there, he had an eerie feeling, as if someone were watching him. He looked around the hall and saw no one. "Maybe I didn't get enough sleep," he muttered to himself. He turned a corner then saw a pile of bedsheets right before smacking into someone, sending the sheets plummeting to the floor. He looked down and saw a maid who had fallen on her butt and looked dazed. "Are you alright?" Kelos asked, as held out his hand to help the maid up.

"Oh yes, of course, your highness," the maid replied as she reached up and took Kelos' hand. "It's my fault for piling the sheets too high... AH! They're all over the floor!" she exclaimed as she got up.

"Well, as long as you're not hurt," Kelos replied. He looked at the maid. She was young, probably in her teens, fairly pretty but not extremely attractive. Her hair was dark brown, tied back in a bun. Her eyes though were an unusual shade of brown that almost looked red. She was also entirely unfamiliar to Kelos. "I don't think I've seen you before. Are you new?"

"Ah, yes I am, your highness," the maid replied as blushed and gave a weak smile. "My name is Amicia, and I just started working at the castle this week."

"I see," Kelos said with a smile that came off as a bit of a smirk. "Well, I know for a fact that the head maid isn't very appreciative of girls who drop the laundry." He looked her over. While her face was pretty, she had what the prince would describe as a near perfect figure. "Though I must admit I do appreciate a woman with a bit of a clumsy streak. How about we get to know each other a little better tonight, Amicia?"

"I'd love that, your highness," the new maid replied. She then stepped towards the prince and latched on to his arm, looked up at him, and batted her eyes flirtatiously. "But why wait until tonight? We can get to know each other better right now."

Kelos could feel himself getting hard as the blood rushed to his crotch. "I would like nothing more," he said. "However, I have duties to attend to, as do you."

Amicia looked surprised for a brief moment, but shook it off. "Of course, your highness. Forgive me for being so bold. Could I just ask for a kiss to hold me over until then though?" She looked up at Kelos with pleading eyes.

13532221.content:
"Of course," Kelos said. Today was apparently going to be a good day. He just met a new maid who not only accepted but eagerly returned his advances. And tonight he would show her the time of her life. He held the maid close, and leaned down to kiss her deeply on the lips. At which point the world began to look dark and fuzzy. The last thing he saw was Amicia's face with a wicked grin on it before he lost consciousness.

"My head..." Kelos thought as he regained consciousness with a splitting headache. He tried to reach up and touch his forehead, but found he couldn't move his arm. "Damn it, how could I have been so dumb." He opened his eyes and tried to look around, but saw only darkness, with hints of light coming through a crack in what he assumed to be a wall. He tried to move again, but found it wasn't just his arm, his entire body was immobilized. "MMMPHH" Kelos tried to call for someone, but all that came out was an unrecognizable muffled noise. "So I'm tied up," Kelos thought. He tried to move his head from side to side, and could tell from the crack of light that he was turning his head. However, that was the only way, as his entire body had no feeling in it. "I can't get through the ropes if I can't even feel my fingers," he thought."But maybe..." Kelos started trying to rock from side to side. The movement relative to the feeble light source showed this was working somewhat, meaning he was in a chair, rather than something untippable. Before long Kelos toppled to the chair to the floor with a loud thud. He hoped whoever had captured him wasn't close by so he'd have time to work his way out of the ropes.

"What's going on in there?" a woman's voice called out, dashing Kelos' hopes. He heard footsteps approaching the door, which then swung open. An older woman stood there. She was thin, practically bones, her skin wrinkled, and her hair mostly white with some faint traces of black, her age not yet removing all color from it. "Ah looks like you're awake at last, deary," she said with a wicked grin. "That girl caught a real prize this time. Maybe a bit dumb, considering how you fell right into her trap, but you'll still do nicely." She walked over to Kelos and righted the chair with ease, which surprised him, given the woman's frail appearance. She then headed to the window and pulled a curtain open. Light poured into the room, revealing it to Kelos. The room had a bed with four large wooden posts, a free standing wardrobe, and a woman's dresser with a small mirror on top of it, though angled away from Kelos. The furniture looked decent, of solid construction, but lacked some of the elegant trim the prince was used to. It seemed to belong to someone who was well off, but not rich. "Since you're awake, I'll be a good hostess and let you have some light." She then left the room, locking the door behind her.

Left alone again, Kelos looked down to see how he was tied up. As he did Kelos was shocked to discover:

135322211.content:
"MMPPHHH?" Kelos exclaimed, muffled by the gag. The prince was looking down at an ample bosom, the gap between the breasts peeking out through the top of a low cut, light blue woman's blouse. It was a sight Kelos normally enjoyed seeing. However, this time the perspective was reversed, these breasts were firmly attached to his, "hopefully still his," Kelos thought, chest. That hope faded quickly as Kelos looked over the rest of what was undeniably now her body. Kelos' formerly broad shoulders were now narrow and feminine. Kelos' arms were much thinner, though still well toned. Looking further down, the blouse was part of a light blue dress. It shimmered in the light and seemed to be a high quality material, but was plain, without the fancy embroidery Kelos was used to seeing in the dresses his mother, sister, or Princess Fia wore. The dress concealed Kelos' legs, but it clung tightly to her torso, showing her new female figure. "So I've been drugged, kidnapped, and turned into a woman," Kelos thought. "When I get out of this, I must have a talk with the head of the castle guards. Clearly they aren't vetting the new maids well enough. Either that or someone let an imposter in."

Still unable to feel her body, Kelos examined the ropes holding her to the chair. They didn't seem particularly strong, but certainly enough to hold her. A rope was wrapped around her waist, holding her body fixed to the back of the chair, while other ropes held her legs to the chair's. She couldn't see her hands, as her arms were tied behind her, but most likely there was some rope holding them together as well. With her body still numb, there wasn't much she could do at the moment. She turned her head towards the window. It had thick iron bars covering it, and was fairly high on the wall. Looking out, Kelos could only see the clouds and an occasional bird. She then turned to examine the rest of the room. Nothing seemed odd about the furniture. The stone walls seemed sturdy, and the door looked to be constructed of stout wood, as did the floor. This may have looked like a bedroom, but Kelos was getting the impression of a cell.

With nothing else to do at the moment, Kelos tried to hop in the chair over to the mirror to see how she looked. Better yet, if she could knock it down, she could use a shard to cut the ropes. Before she could get even a quarter of the way, the door flew open again. "What are you doing this time?!" the old woman exclaimed as she burst into the room in a surprisingly spry move. Clearly she was not as she seemed. She smiled as she saw Kelos had moved the chair closer to the mirror. "Well, if you want to see your pretty new face that badly, I suppose I can help you with that. She walked over to the dresser, picked up the mirror, and brought it over to Kelos. "Here you are, deary."

Kelos' eyes popped wide open as she looked at her new reflection. Even with the gag covering her mouth, looking back was one of the prettiest women she had ever seen. Pretty, yet familiar. Her hair was unchanged, and Kelos could see traits of her male face, just softened, which somehow worked astonishingly well. "Well, I can tell you'd be at a loss for words even if you didn't have that gag in your pretty little mouth," the old woman said. She took the mirror away and placed it back down on the dresser, this time, so Kelos could see it. "I'll leave you to fall in love with your own reflection, Princess. If you're a good girl and don't make me come back in here for the rest of the day, maybe I'll take that gag off so you can hear your lovely new voice too." With that the old woman left, leaving Kelos to stare at her reflection.

With her body still numb, well secured ropes, and a room built more like a cell, Kelos concluded escape was not currently possible. She decided all she really could do is be a good girl and wait. So she did. Minutes passed, then hours. The transformed prince found feeling slowly returning to her, as she became aware of the silken fabric her new, feminine body was clothed in. She also began to feel the need to go to the bathroom. Fortunately, the old woman returned, "Well, you did behave yourself after all, Princess. As a reward, I'll take that gag off." Heels can be quite challenging if you aren't accustom to them."

This meant her captors were likely good at what they did. She was now free of her bonds, so incapacitating this old woman and escaping seemed possible, but something still seemed off about her. Kelos finished her business in the bathroom, and exited.

1353222112.content:
"As if I'll just sit here tied up and be a good girl," Kelos thought as the old woman left. Still, she was in a precarious situation. Her body was still numb, though she was starting to feel a slight tingling in her fingers. But even once she got feeling back, she was still tied up. Hopefully the kidnappers weren't that good at this and she'd be able to undo them. If all else failed, there was the option of breaking the mirror for a shard of glass, but that would surely attract attention. Plus, there was no way to know how many kidnappers there were. The only person she had seen here was the old woman, but there was also the fake maid with the brownish red eyes. That's at least two people. It could be just the two of them, but it would be dangerous to assume that. Plus, where was here in the first place. Kelos had no idea how long she had been out. It could have been hours, it could have been days, which means a long trip back to Grovan in this feminine body. Not a prospect she was looking forward to. She sighed, then began trying to move her fingers and toes to see if she could speed up getting feeling in her body. As she did so, she thought back to home. Surely they were at least aware of the situation.

Indeed, back in Grovan, the castle was in chaos with news of the prince's disappearance. Guards had searched every nook and cranny of the castle to find Kelos, yet hadn't succeeded. Nevertheless, the did find some clues. Lucia approached the throne with Jex, with the evidence they had collected. "Your highness," Lucia said.

"Your report," Latissa said impatiently.

"Our search was unsuccessful in finding Prince Kelos," Jex started. "However, we did find several clues to what happened."

"Only clues?" Latissa asked with an angry glare.

"We believe we have enough evidence to reconstruct the events of the kidnapping," Lucia said.

"Go on," Latissa said. "But do so with haste. Every minute we delay is a minute these abductors have to take my son farther away."

"We found the Prince's clothing in a supply closet near his room," Jex said. "Further we found a fake maid's uniform in a supply closet near the gate."

"While conducting interviews with the palace staff, many of them reported a maid they didn't recognize," Lucia said. "She's described as having an amazing figure and brown eyes that seemed almost red. Earlier today some of the staff saw this apparently fake maid helping a woman who seemed very drunk. When asked, she told them this woman had 'spent the night in the the Prince's bedchamber.' I woke Kel... Prince Kelos up personally this morning. He was alone."

"The guard at the gate reports a woman in normal clothing helping another woman who seemed intoxicated out of the castle and into a waiting carriage," Jex said. "The woman was described as having the same brownish red eyes."

"So you're saying this woman disguised my son as a woman and that was enough to fool the guards?" Latissa asked, with a cold anger behind her words.

"Not quite," Lucia said. "The theory we're working on is the fake maid used some sort of magic to transform Kelos into a woman."

"The guard at the gate took a close look, and insists the woman he saw being carried out could not be a man in disguise," Jex said.

"I see," Latissa said. Her eyes narrowed at the news.

Meanwhile, Kelos had begun to make some progress. Feeling had finally returned to her fingers, and she was able to feel out the knot in the rope. It was a standard bind, with a short lead. Had it been tied to the base of the chair, Kelos would have had less room to work, but as it was, she was able to feed it back through the knot, loosening it just enough to get her hands free. Once her hands were free, she undid the rest of the binds and was finally free. "That took long enough," she whispered to herself after removing the gag. She stretched her new body for the first time, though it still mostly felt numb. She thought about trying to stand, but thought better of it. Without being able to feel her feet yet, she'd likely just fall.

Kelos carefully lowered herself to the floor. She then crawled over to the window as quietly as she could. Once there, with the wall to support her, Kelos pulled herself to her feet. Thanks to a combination of the numbness and the heels she discovered she was wearing, she almost fell but Kelos was able to catch herself. She then peaked out the window, hoping there'd be a landmark that would tell her where she was. Unfortunately, all she saw was forest off to the horizon. Kelos sighed. She still might not know where she was, but at least she was free of the ropes. This left the next step of getting out of the room. The old woman seemed to have pretty decent hearing, so she couldn't make too much noise. Then again she could set a trap.

Kelos considered the trap, but since she couldn't be sure the old woman was alone, she concluded it was too dangerous. She leaned against the wall and removed her heels, as the last thing she needed was them clicking on the floor. After placing them on the floor carefully, she examined the window. It was just large enough for her to get through, but the iron bars seemed well secured. Even in her normal male body, Kelos thought she'd have little hope of budging them. "Well not getting out that way," she thought.

Kelos then made her way to the wardrobe. As she crept across the room, she noticed the first feeling from her legs since she was a she. The swish of her dress passing over her stockings sent a wave of pleasure through her body with each step. Not only pleasurable, but also nostalgic. Long suppressed memories from childhood flooded into her head. "How do I look, Ori?" Kelos remembered asking long ago. The then young prince stood in front of a full length mirror wearing a red dress, white stockings, red mary janes, and a long brown wig. Orianna then replied, "You look very pretty, a perfect little princess," to which Kelos smiled happily. It was a game they often played. Orianna would dress her younger brother in her old clothing, and they'd pretend Kelos was her sister, at least until a servant caught them. She took a breath and focused, then proceeded to the wardrobe.

Kelos carefully opened the door, making sure it didn't squeak. The inside was stuffed with dresses of all colors and styles. She looked through them and noticed something odd, they all seemed to be different sizes. Kelos pushed a dress clearly sized for a plump woman aside to find one clearly sized for a young girl, only for one for a thin, tall woman to be behind it. Clearly this collection couldn't be for the same person. Looking on the bottom of the wardrobe, Kelos saw a wig covering a collection of shoes also of varying sizes. Picking up the wig, the blonde strands of hair cascaded down, almost hitting the floor as she held it. Something seemed strange about it, almost as if it was speaking to her, telling her to put it on.

Kelos was in a thick daze as she was dragged through the castle halls to places yet unknown. It seemed Orianna was dead-set on having things exactly her way when it came to the wedding, and resisting wasn't much of an option on the table: the newly minted princess having been swept off quicker than a single 'eep!' could escape her lips!

But for Kelos, several little things couldn't escape her attention: emphasis on 'little!' Little, like how she had to force herself not to stumble, since her boots were too big... Or little! Like how, as the magic settled, it appeared she'd found herself shrunken to a good head shorter than Ori! Or well, little, in how much frailer... weaker she was suddenly feeling. How years of training in strength and martial prowess had so easily melted away with a sip of a potion, to now where, even if she tried, she doubted she'd be able to pull herself free from her sister's grip!

She easily could've gotten herself lost in an overwhelming whirlwind, if it wasn't for the thunderous *SLAM!* of a door!

Kelos blinked: breaking free from her head-space, and realizing she wasn't within the hustle and echo of a corridor any longer. “...Your room, Ori?” Goodness, she hadn't actually entered it in years! It'd been deemed 'improper' for a prince to regularly intrude on such a feminine space... Occasionally she wondered, blushing mad, if her secret 'Cally-time' had slipped its way on upward to someone, and that the mandate was made to prevent any 'odd habits' from developing further...

“Of course, Dear!” The older girl beamed: welcoming her in. “Mother and Father might've raised a fuss a few minutes ago, but there's nothing wrong with two sisters sharing some private time alone together, is there?”

“I... I suppose not?” Kelos replied: taking it all in. Orianna's taste had refined a fair bit compared to when they were younger- in particular a decently sized alchemy table, with beakers, and vials, lined a corner, but her eyes couldn't help but rest on the giant walk-in closet. Still giant, even as an adult. As silly as it was, her heart was starting to thud. She... She was about to have some 'Cally-time' as a real gir-

“Excellent! Now be a doll and hold still while I help you strip!”

“Wha?... EEK~!” Kelos was completely at the other girl's mercy, as she sputtered and mewled upon having every last vestige of her maleness flung through the air and left strewn across the floor.

And across a nightstand...

And a chair...
135323111.title: Kelos goes along with Orianna.

choices: Kelos is dazzled by her own beauty.
Kelos thinks this is wrong.
1353231111.content:
As Kelos stood there looking down at her now naked new body, Orianna grabbed a measuring tape and got to work. "Arms out, stand up straight!" she ordered the newly minted princess, which Kelos complied blushing slightly as her sister measured every inch of her new body.

"Is this really necessary, Ori?"

"It is if you want to have clothing that fits you, sis," Orianna replied as she jotted down Kelos' measurements. "I could get one of the maids to do this if you prefer."

"No!" Kelos squealed. "This is embarrassing enough as it is..."

"Exactly!" Orianna replied. "This is what I meant. Imagine if you were thrown to the wolves on your first day as a woman at my wedding. It would be a disaster! why, I could never do that to my sweet little sister."

"Please don't tease me," Kelos said, with a huge blush.

"Tease you? I would never! I'm doing this all to help you become accustom to being a woman," Orianna insisted. "You look the part, but you must accept it."

"I'll try," Kelos responded sheepishly.

"That's my girl," Orianna replied. "Looking at your measurements, I think I have a dress that will fit you." With that Orianna disappeared into the massive closet.

Left alone, Kelos ran her hand down the side of her body, getting a feel for her new curves. This body would take a lot of getting used to. "What have I gotten myself into?" she asked herself.

"Found it!" a voice cried out from the closet. Orianna quickly emerged, hold a scarlet red dress. "This will look darling on you."

Kelos' heart raced as she looked at the dress her sister was holding. This was extremely embarrassing, but somehow exciting. A memory then flashed in her head. She saw herself, as a little boy, trying on dresses with Orianna. She was wearing a dress, the same shade of scarlet as the one Orianna was now holding, swishing from side to side. Orianna was also dressed up, wearing their mother's old wedding dress. Kelos remembered asking a question, "Ori, can I be your bridesmaid when you get married for real?" With that Kelos' jaw dropped in realization and a tear trickled down her cheek.

"Kelos?" Orianna asked.

"Did... Did you remember all this time?"

"I wouldn't forget a word my darling little sister said to me," Orianna replied. "Now let's get you dressed and do your make up and hair. I'll help you for now, but you're going to have to learn to do this all yourself."

Kelos wiped her tear and smiled. "Of course, if you teach me, I'll be a perfect princess in no time." Orianna wasted no time. She helped dress her new sister, showing Kelos the exact order to put everything on. Before long, she was fully dressed, standing in front of Ori's mirror.
1353231111.title: Kelos is helped dress like a 'proper prince...

choices: “Completing” Princess Kelos
Orianna's perspective
Showing the King and Queen/Something else
13532311111.content:
There was an entire whirlwind of sensations in those moments where Kelos was escorted into her dress. Soft hands caressing against her soft skin: welcoming even softer fabric to makes its way home. This was the first time in well over a decade she got to be attired in something so delicate, and it rightly caused her heart thump like a pounding drum.

Seeing her reflection only led to a greater welling of emotions. Kelos saw herself. Herself. As if she'd stepped into an alternate world. A world where the roll of a die landed different. A world where 'Cally-time' wasn't deemed 'wrong.' A world where she always was Cally. Raven hair now cascaded down the arch of her back, much like when she was a child. It'd been cut short to be more 'princely' when he grew older, but Orianna's potion swiftly rejected that silly posturing, with silken tresses offering gentle tickles against the new princess' cheeks. It created a bold contrast with the fiery gown Ori had selected. It wasn't extravagant- they weren't going to a ball this evening, after all! But it accented Kelos' curves in a way that proudly informed everyone that yes, she was a woman.

Kelos' demeanor however was far from bold in that moment. Eyes were wide, and her mouth was slightly agape: twitching, as if wanting to say something, but instead, only the tiniest gasps escaped. She felt pretty. Pretty in a way where words couldn't earnestly describe. It's the type of emotion where if she threw all caution to the wind- threw all worries and inhibitions, she'd be giggling, and swishing, and tittering on about every little frill. Every little aspect of the new her.

But caution and worry were far from easy to expel, and the confidence she held mere moments ago about being 'a perfect princess,' faded- and the tears returned.

Petite sniffles and whimpers couldn't help but eek themselves out, as a trail of sobs wet her face. In that moment however, she found herself being wrapped in the arms of her taller, older sister: head guided warmly against her bosom. “Shh. Shhh~.” Was all the redhead cooed, as she rested into the crown of Kelos' locks.

“I- I'm sorry, Ori.” The transformee mewled: wiping away some of her droplets. She was thankful no cosmetics had yet been applied. “It's- it's a lot to take in.”

“I know, Little Sister. I know.” Orianna whispered sympathetically.

“How will- what will I do about Mother and Father?” The girl asked in concern.

And that was when a smile tilted its way up Ori's features.

“Why~.” With a flash, Kelos found herself twirled like a ballerina to look Ori in the eye! “You will do nothing but be a perfect princess, of course! And an even more perfect bridesmaid!” She happily exclaimed: the two sisters' noses practically touching.

Leaning back as a dancer caught in a dip, Kelos couldn't help but blink. “Um, Ori... I don't believe you can be 'more perfect' than something...”

“Tut tut tut!” Ori teased: putting a finger to Kelos' mouth in a 'shush.' “I can assure you, Little Sister, with my help, and the time we'll be spending to prepare for the wedding, you will.” The royal finished by releasing her companion in one final, almost choreographed flourish.

“But if we are to debut you to Mother and Father properly, we'll need you to be complete! And no proper princess is complete without makeup!”
13532311111.title: Kelos is dazzled by her own beauty.

choices: Skip to the mother daughter talk
Kelos and Orianna have some sisterly bonding time.
135323111113.content:
Kelos held Orianna's hand as the two stood in front of the door to their parents private chambers. Orianna squeezed Kelos' hand, gently, trying to reassure her. "Don't worry, everything is going to be fine. Mother and father will just adore their new daughter, I'm sure of it."

"I hope so," Kelos replied with a shaky voice. She looked up at Orianna with uncertainty.

"Just remember, be confident in your decision," the elder princess said.

"Mother, father," Orianna began. "When I asked you for permission for Kelos to be a bridesmaid for my wedding, you told me you would allow it if Kelos agreed to it, correct?"

"Yes," Reginald replied with a chuckle. "But we both know there's no way my son would agree to prancing around in a dress for your wedding."

"Kelos agreed," Orianna stated. "It's time, little sister."

On that queue, Kelos walked into the room, heels clacking on the tile, revealing her new form to her parents. "Mother, Father, it's true. I agreed to be a bridesmaid at Ori's wedding."

"What sort of prank is this, Orianna?" Reginald shouted angrily.

"Kelos, is that really you?" Latissa asked in shock.

"It is, mother. I have decided to accept Orianna's invitation. However, since I do not simply want to be prancing around in a dress, as father so eloquently put it, I have further agreed to be transformed into a woman so I might become accustom to this form and learn how to act properly for the wedding. To that end, please accept me as your daughter, not your son."

"Has everyone taken leave of their senses?" Reginald exclaimed.

"Not at all father," Kelos replied. "I simply could not refuse such a heartfelt request from my dear sister."

"I just wanted Kelos by my side on my special day, and she wanted to be there," Orianna added.

"Kelos, what of your engagement to Princess Fia?" Reginald asked.

"I will write Fia explaining the situation," Kelos said. "I'm sure she will be understanding. Our marriage wasn't scheduled until after Orianna's anyway."

"Your birthday is before that," Latissa said.

"Then I shall have a memorable and unique party this year," Kelos replied.

"Are you serious about this, Kelos?" Reginald asked.

"I am, father. I intend to be the perfect princess and bridesmaid."

The king sighed. "If I cannot change your mind, I must allow this. However, I cannot have you allowing your combat skills lapse. Despite your present form, I insist you continue your sword training."

"Of course, father," Kelos replied.

Reginald looked at his other daughter with a fierce gaze. "Further, Orianna, I trust you have an antidote to this spell."

"I do, father."

"Very well, you shall give it to Kelos to keep." He looked back to Kelos. "I shall treat you as a woman for now, my daughter. If for any reason you wish to change back, take the antidote."

"Thank you father, but that is unnecessary. I am a girl of her word."

Reginald winced at Kelos referring to herself as a girl. "Are you positive Orianna has not given you a mind altering potion as well?"

"Absolutely," Kelos replied.

"Very well. Though it pains me to allow this, if you are willing, you are an adult and can make your own decisions." Reginald paused for a moment and swallowed before continuing, "my daughter."

"Thank you father," Kelos and Orianna said in unison.

"Kelos, we need to have a mother... daughter talk a bit later," Latissa said.

"Of course, mother." Kelos replied.

"Your mother and I have much to talk about," Reginald said. "You two are excused for now." With that Kelos and Orianna curtsied and left the room.
135323111113.title: Showing the King and Queen/Something else

choices: Kelos interrupts, wanting to learn more about alchemy.
Specifically, mental alchemy.
Ori makes a reversal potion/Something else.
1353231111132.content:
Kelos' back was as stiff as a board, while her lips trembled up and down in a rocking wave. She'd be sweating up a storm, if a part of her didn't innately feel that'd come off 'unprincess-like.' Just a few more steps and they'd be cleared to the hall. A few more... A few more...

*CLACK*

The door behind shuttered closed.

And then, like a storm herself, Orianna swept Kelos into a possessive hug! “Oh my goodness! You were breathtaking in there, Baby Sister!” She gushed: rubbing her cheek proudly against the crown of the younger girl's head! “I knew you could do it!”

Feeling the crush of her sibling's arms wrapped around her now much more delicate figure, the raven-haired royal's features blanched. “Breathtaking... is one way... to point it... Hauuh~!” Each phrase was strained by lung-crushing clutches, which thankfully relented before she got too woozy: gently pulling her out to look eye to eye. “You might not have not've seen, but I was a nervous wreck inside!”

“Oh pshaw!” Ori shrugged in a happy dismissiveness. “No one could've come out better! Father was always going to be the toughest nut to crack, but you handled it beautifully! Like a princess! A thousand times more graceful than your former self. He called you his daughter!”

The phrasing of 'coming out,' and 'former self,' were left at the wayside, as Kelos found herself awash in the pleasant buzz of compliments. “You... really think so?” She asked with a timid blush.

“I know so!” Ori answered without missing a beat. By now they were walking through the halls again. “This was always going to be the hardest part. Dealing with the rest is only going to be a matter of formalities. Then our fun can begin!”

Their fun could begin? Kelos raised a curious brow at that. “What 'formalities' are you talking about, Big Sister?” With the turns they were taking, it seemed their heels were clacking back to Ori's room.

“Nothing of major importance~.” Again, a 'happy dismissiveness.' “It's just Father requested you have an antidote serum... So I should perhaps make one, right~?”

Kelos felt an involuntary shiver. You mean her sister hadn't already had one on hand? That she... fibbed to Father? That, in this moment, she couldn't immediately turn back? A squirminess started wriggling around in her tummy. But it wasn't the... worst squirminess? It was similar to that naughty feeling of 'misbehaving,' every time she and Orianna played together when they were younger. Quite hard to pinpoint and frame.

Figuring out her inner psychological workings would have to wait, as it seems while getting lost in thought, her sister had guided her over to her private alchemy table!

“I would've loved to have shown you all this much sooner, Little Sister, but circumstances generally prevented us!” Ori chirped. Beakers and bobs, with pouches of herbs, lined the old wooden bench, with some already filled with liquid of curious colors.

The new Princess would be lying if she said she wasn't vaguely interested. Alchemy was both frightening, and fascinating. It was here especially that she noticed a vial of some pink concoction staring right in front of her that seemed vaguely familiar. “Is that... Is that what turned me into a girl?”

“My finest elixir!” Orianna beamed from ear to ear: placing a sentimental hand on her sibling's shoulder. “Alchemy is a fabulous art, Dear. It can work wonders!”

“I imagine...” Kelos answered. There was probably enough liquid left to turn a few more men into former men.

“I'm no Xarlat or Marlin, but I do dabble! It's good fun learning transformations both physical, and mental!”

“Mental?” The shorter royal questioned, with some trepidation.

“Ah! Don't let Father's fuddy-duddiness get to you! Mental alchemy can be quite... enjoyable, depending on what you brew! Always in moderation, though. You've got to be responsible!” Now it sounded like Ori was giving a lecture. “But that's neither here nor now! How about we make you that 'cure?'”

Something inside was tugging at Kelos just then. A realization that some of her 'squirminess' might go away if she got an antidote. Did she really want that?
1353231111132.title: Kelos and Orianna have some sisterly bonding ti...

choices: Kelos doesn't feel anything.
Kelos feels Orianna's magic.
13532311111321.content:
"Ori, wait," Kelos said fidgeting somewhat. "Um... Before you do that, could you maybe teach me a bit about alchemy? You know, the basics." Kelos wasn't sure just why she was stopping her sister from making that potion. After all, she should want it as soon as possible. Right now she was trapped as Princess Kelos, which should terrify her, yet somehow it didn't seem so terrifying. If anything it seemed... exciting.

"Of course!" Orianna exclaimed, as she one again embraced her new sister. "I shall teach you everything you want to know about it! Let's start with something easy, a basic healing potion."

"That sounds like a good place to start," Kelos agreed.

"Before we do, I must warn you, crafting a potion requires imbuing the brew with a bit of magic, which I can only do once a day," Orianna cautioned while still hugging Kelos. "If we make this healing potion, I will not be able to make the reversal potion for your transformation today."

Kelos hesitated for a moment. If she agreed she would be trapped like this until tomorrow at the earliest. There would be plenty of time to learn alchemy, surely getting the antidote was the most pressing matter. Thus, she should tell Ori to just make the reversal potion after all. That would most definitely and assuredly be the logical, rational decision to make. Ori almost certainly thinks so to, or she wouldn't have even given that warning. "I don't need the reversal potion. I said I would stay like this until your wedding and I intend to keep that promise."

Orianna hugged Kelos even tighter. "I have such an amazing little sister."

"Too tight..." Kelos gasped.

"Oh, sorry," Orianna released Kelos. "But the good news is we're making a healing potion. Two if you're a quick study." She turned and headed over to the alchemy table. Kelos caught her breath and followed. "A healing potion is simple. You need three ingredients, dried sage buds, willow bark, and dried chamomile leaves." She reached up and grabbed three bottles. "I have all of them prepared, so we can skip that step for now and go straight to the potion making if you like."

"I'd like to know how to prepare them, but I suppose that can wait."

"Excellent. So we start as if we were making tea from the willow bark. However, it's important to put the bark in the water before applying heat." She put some pieces of the bark into a beaker of water, then lit a flame under a metal holder, which she placed the beaker into. Then poured a bit of the sage buds and chamomile leaves into a mortar. "While we're waiting, grind these up."

"Right" Kelos said, as she took the mortar and began to grind them. "I thought you said we were skipping the preparation."

"They must be dried in a certain way, but to make the potion it's best not to grind them until you're ready to use them," Orianna explained. "Now the important part isn't the ingredients themselves. If you just boil all these up it will not be a potion, though it still will be a nice tea to drink if you have a cold. In that case I'd recommend not using whole pieces of bark, and boiling the water before adding them. For a potion do it this way."

"I understand," Kelos said.

"Once the water starts looking tan from the bark, we pour it into another container." Orianna picked the beaker up with a pair of metal tongs."Be careful, it will be very hot." She poured the water into another beaker. "This next step I can't really tell you how, you have to feel it." She picked up a metal rod that appeared to be made of copper. "So we're going to stir in the powdered buds and leaves while adding a touch of magic. I'll hold your hand while you stir. Try to feel the magic as it flows through your hand. Then try to match that. Though you might not feel anything at first. It took me three tries before I could feel it. Now we must hurry before this cools down." Orianna gave Kelos the rod and held her hand as they stirred together while Ori added magic.
13532311111321.title: Kelos interrupts, wanting to learn more about a...

Settling in to Princesshood.
Slumber Party/Something else.
135323111113211.content:
Kelos was doing her best to concentrate. Brow furrowed. Lips formed into a thoughtful pout. To any onlooker, she'd look terribly cute. Stirring, and stirring, wondering what exactly magic was supposed to 'feel' like. Was it the warmth of her sister's hand against her own, new and dainty one? Was it the massaging of her sister's (slightly more developed...) chest into her arching back? Was it the gentle puffs and coos whispered towards her ear, as she was encouraged to not stop?

“That's right, Little Sister. Almost!” Ori seemed excited, as the beaker's contents began to shift from a muddy, earthy tone, to a brighter, vibrant red: the quintessential color of a healing potion! “Now quickly! Pour it into those vials right next to you! There should be just enough for two!”

The younger of the duo did as told: fumbling her hands and tipping the contents in: adding a capping of corks for good measure, to make sure nothing were to spill out.

“Excellent, Little Sister, excellent!” Orianna was just beaming, as she swiftly grabbed her sibling into another tight hug. She was growing quite fond of doing so. With Kelos being rather... 'compact' in terms of height, just lifting the girl up and smothering her was too easy. Too fun!

The new princess did her best to brace herself, even as she held a potion in each palm. Being so much weaker, almost in a doll-like way, was another thing which should terrify her, but getting caught in her older sister's embrace, feeling her cheek nuzzle into her crown... There was something about it which was... nice. Very rarely was she treated with so much open affection and intimacy. Even compared to when she was around Fia.

Quick as those thoughts arrived, they were whisked away when Ori twirled her around to talk. “So, Little Sister, how have you liked your first taste of alchemy, hm~?”

Eying the two elixirs she was partially responsible for creating, Kelos answered earnestly. “It's... quite fascinating, Big Sister. Though I'm not sure if I felt the magic like how you said.” A blush formed in her cheeks while saying that.

“Oh, pshaw! It takes some time to develop, that's all, Little Sister. Don't worry about it! You might even begin to feel it by as soon as tomorrow's lesson!” A silent confirmation that there would be more training to come... As well as a further delay in that gender reversal antidote.

Again, Kelos felt an excitement towards that. Like she was teetering into territory she knew she shouldn't be, but couldn't help but dare herself to step further in...

“Really, Little Sister, think of this as just your first step!” Her big sister raised up a finger rather astutely. If she didn't know any better, she'd wonder if Ori could read her thoughts. “You've made a lot of first steps today, and I am so proud of you for taking them.” A reassuring hand went to the shoulder of the recently transmogrified royal.

If Kelos thought her blush couldn't get much brighter, she certainly managed to prove herself wrong. “Thank you, Big Sister... Thank you, Ori.” She added that last bit with additional emphasis.

“Tut tut! Now don't get all sentimental yet! There's still much for us to do!” Ori gave a clap: seemingly in a constant state of giddiness. “Since you're going to be my precious little sister for quite a while to come, we must get your affairs in order! A new wardrobe! Renovating your room! I'm not sure if we'll be able to do it all by nightfall, but never fret! If need be, we'll simply have a slumber party here, and you'll share a bed here with me!”

As Orianna tittered on and on, Kelos couldn't help but feel like she should take one of these health potions. She was beginning to worry she might be developing a headache.
135323111113211.title: Kelos doesn't feel anything.

Kelos is eager to start the lesson.
1353231111132111.content:
"Ah, good morning Marie. I've been wondering, how's your younger sister doing?" Kelos asked one of the maids she met in the hall."

"A good morning to you, Princess," Marie the maid replied. "She's doing much better thanks to that potion you made for her. I can't thank you enough. She may even be healthy enough to attend classes soon."

"That's wonderful to hear," Kelos said, beaming. While healing potions were still the only thing she had successfully made despite all the instruction from Orianna, at least one of them had been put to good use.

"Are you sure you don't want payment, Princess?" Marie asked.

"Of course not, dear," Kelos replied. "A princess must look after her people."

"Oh, is it okay if I bring my sister to thank you in person?" Marie asked.

"Why that would be lovely," Kelos replied with a giggle. "But certainly don't feel obligated to, and only if she's well enough."

"Right, of course," Marie said. She then realized the time. "Oh no, if you'll excuse me, Princess, I'm late for my shift!.

"Just tell Fredrika I had asked you to get me something, and you should be fine," Kelos said.

"Thank you, princess" Marie said. She then curtsied, and left in a hurry.

"It wouldn't do if I were late either," the former prince thought, as she continued on her way to meet Orianna.

It had been nearly 4 weeks since Kelos had been transformed into a woman, and her life had settled in to a new routine. Mornings were devoted to sword practice, as she had promised her father. With her now weaker body, it had gone poorly at first, but Kelos had since adopted a new style, relying more on parries and agility, and she was beginning to look somewhat competent again. Her mid day alchemy training was, according to Orianna, going well. She had a good grasp of the basics, but still struggled with more than simple healing potions. The daily lessons also meant the reversal potion had yet to be made.

The lack of a way to turn back didn't bother Kelos as much as it probably should have. She was becoming quite comfortable as a princess. She really enjoyed wearing elegant gowns, heels, jewelry, all the fineries of a woman of her station. When she was little she had loved pretending to be "Princess Cally," but the reality of being Prince Kelos meant that had to stop. Now though, she didn't have to pretend to be Cally, she was Princess Kelos. She was also coming to appreciate and enjoy her new duties. Just last week she had hosted a luncheon to raise money to construct a new library, to be open not simply to nobles, but to everyone. Still, there was that voice in the back of her head that was telling her she shouldn't be enjoying this. Though, as time went on, it was getting pushed farther and farther back. She had even begun to wonder if she would want to turn back after the wedding.

Arriving at her sister's room, Kelos knocked on the door.

"Kelos?" Orianna called out. "Come on in, sis!"

Kelos entered, and saw Ori still brushing her hair. "Am I early? I thought I was running late."

"Not at all, a princess is always on time," Orianna replied. "We shall begin your lessons in but a moment."
1353231111132111.title: Timeskip to several weeks down the line.

choices: Orianna asks questions Kelos might regularly be too afraid to answer.
Ori gives some fun orders. Maybe even installs some triggers!
Later, Kelos 'wakes up'/Something else.
13532311111321112.content:
A part of Kelos wanted to relay these concerns to Ori. After all, in matters of gender, who better to speak to than the person who taught her how wonderful wearing a dress could be~? Repeatedly, however, she found was holding her tongue. Why do anything to risk ruining the mood? Especially not during alchemy lessons! These past few weeks had been absolutely lovely, and there wasn't a single moment in her day that she looked forward to more than the sisterly bonding time spent mixing various concoctions.

“Is something the matter, Baby Sister?” Orianna asked with curiosity in her voice: having been watching the raven-haired princess staring out aimlessly.

“Oh! Oh no, of course not, Big Sister!” Kelos eeped, snapping to attention. “I'm just... excited about today! That's all. We finished a new batch of healing potions last time, and you said that now you wanted to show me something special?”

“I did, didn't I?” Ori smiled as she placed her brush down: moving over to the alchemy table while eyeing Kelos. That girl was sitting at the edge of her bed, legs together, hands gracefully in her lap, and a pleasant face accented by some tasteful makeup.

It really was astonishing just how naturally feminine Kelos could be. Not that Ori was surprised. Not at all. For years she could tell there was something hidden, bubbling up underneath the stiff and vaguely forced bravado her brother carried. Cally-time was the happiest she'd ever seen him, and this past month was the happiest she'd ever seen her.

Which raised some questions she was hoping to answer today... While also having a bit of fun~.

“We've been mostly working on some very basic elixirs, so I thought, for this session, I could give you a taste of what intermediate, and advanced potion-crafting can do!” The bride-to-be hummed whilst shuffling out some beakers. This time, seemingly already filled.

“I believe you've already shown me some of your 'intermediate and advanced potion-crafting,' Big Sister.” Kelo gave a light giggle, as she waved a hand over her silhouette.

“And I can tell you've grown fond of the results~.” Ori quipped, walking over with a lilac tinted vial. “A bit of a sister to sister secret though,” Ori noted, voiced turning quieter. In the moment, she was wondering if this could be harder to sell than she initially thought. “A fair number of people take up alchemy not simply for the betterment of others, or to become more powerful, but instead to learn of mixtures that can be quite... enjoyable to personally experience.”

Kelos' lips became more pert upon hearing that, especially as she was handed the glass. “Like alcohol?”

“Somewhat, but not quite!” Ori quickly chimed: finger raised. “It's just us at the moment, and I know your schedule for the day is clear. If you're open to it, I'd be willing to help guide you with... experimenting.”

A redness began to percolate on the younger girl's cheeks, as she turned her gaze to the liquid. “E- experimenting?”

“I most definitely will not force you! If you like, I can put that away, and we'll instead move to try making a new brew! Maybe one that'd keep people more energized...” A pause in Orianna, as her tone turned more playful. “But this might be rather fun for you~. I promise nothing bad will happen. This room has always been safe. Just the two of us~.”

Kelos truly didn't expect anything like this when she came in today... But at the same time, a part of her was excited. The same part of her that was excited at the prospect of not having a means to immediately turn back to 'normal.' Ori was offering something abnormal. That's what she'd been offering ever since she tipped that pink potion past her lips. And, well, her sister wasn't wrong when she said she'd been growing 'fond of the results.'

Goodness! Even asking what the potion was, and what it would do, seemed somewhat unappealing. She liked the idea of the surprise. The idea of allowing Ori to do something to her.

“I... Well... It would be rude of me to decline a precious gift from my Big Sister, wouldn't it?” Turning her chin up, her voice was vaguely sardonic.

“Oh, tremendously so! Very un-princess-like!” With Ori laying it on even further: tongue firmly in cheek.

“And I promised I'd let you turn me into the perfect princess! So I should trust that I'm in your capable hands!” Staring at the drink for a beat, she opted to throwing caution to the wind before better judgment sullied matters: sipping it clean in one fell swoop.

Near instantly from that, Kelos began to feel tingly, and her mind growing foggy. “O- oh! Oh...”

Almost unprepared at the quick decision, Ori tried to mitigate. “Just relax, Little Sister. It's okay. I'm here. I'm here and you can hear my voice.” She assured: clasping her palm around the other girl's.

Internally however, it's like Kelos was being pulled from the reigns of the horse, and left to sit in the back of the carriage. A lovely purple haze was clouding... everything. Her brain. Her thoughts. Was she standing up, or sitting down? Awake, or dreaming? The only thing she could make out was a voice. Ori's voice. Ori's voice who was telling her she was here. Safe.

“That's right, Little Sister. No need to be afraid. Just let yourself drift down, and down... Down. Big Sister is telling you to do it.” Ori watched as the brightness faded in Kelos' eyes, becoming dim and blurred. A general listlessness told the older girl that her sibling was near fully under the effects of hypnosis.

Now, to some aristocrats, this might seem like a precarious scene. A political figure using mind altering substances to turn another official highly suggestible and malleable? That could be horrendous! A scandal! And while true, peering at the tiny line of drool making its way down the new princess's otherwise immaculately touched up features, Kelos was as close as putty as could be at the moment, but there was nothing outright malicious in what Orianna was aiming to do.

She was being honest when she said some people only brewed potions for kicks like these. If she was being extra honest, hearing whispered titters in the library during study sessions were partially what piqued her interest as well. And currently, this was some 'experimenting' unto her own. She'd never actually hypnotized a person before! So this was as much a learning experience for Kelos, as it was for herself.

“Little Sister, can you hear me?” She asked with mild hesitation.

Mild hesitation was what she got in return. “Yes... Big Sister...”

Oh. Oh! That drone in her Little Sister's voice was... certainly something, she noted with a blush. The first time in a long time Ori was on the receiving end of her skin turning scarlet. “Yes! Well... good! Ahem, good girl, I should say. H- how are you feeling?”

“Funnyyyy...” The tranced figure hummed.

“That- That's fine! Good, even. Good to feel funny!” A pause, as she tried to collect herself. “Little Sister... Kelos, I want today to be very special, and for you to feel very good and funny right now... But for that to happen, you have to do as Big Sister says, alright?”

“Do... as Big Sister says...” It wasn't that hard for Kelos to capitulate in that regard, she easily could be coerced into agreeing with those words, hypnosis or not.

Still, with a swirling sister, Orianna had a thousand opportunities laid out ahead.

135323111113211121.content:
Orianna couldn't help herself. It was time to find out how Kelos really felt about all of this. Sure, she seemed to be enjoying herself, but Orianna couldn't help but worry it was for show, trying to make the best of a bad situation. Could it be that deep down her sweet little sister really didn't like it, worse resented her for this? She had to find out for sure. She took a deep breath and began. "Kelos, you will tell me the truth to everything I ask."

"Yes... Tell truth..." the hypnotized former prince replied.

"Do you... Do you like being a princess?" Orianna asked nervously.

"Yes..."

The answer was a huge relief to the elder sister. She had pretty much been forcing Kelos to do this, but it seemed like she really was enjoying herself. She took another breath and asked another question. "Are you upset with me for anything I did?"

"No..."

Orianna breathed a sigh of relief. Apparently she hadn't actually pushed Kelos too far. She decided to move on to how Kelos felt about her current position. "What do you like best about being a princess?"

Kelos showed a bit of resistance, hesitating for a moment before answering. "I like... being... pretty..."

Ori giggled at the response. She was pretty sure this was something her little sister wouldn't have answered honestly without the hypnosis, instead she would likely try to come up with a more flattering answer. The elder princess decided to push a little farther. "Do like being a prince or a princess better?"

"A... princess..." Kelos said.

"I knew it!" Ori exclaimed. "You've come to see how much better being a princess is!"

"I've... felt... that... since... I was...little..." Kelos replied.

The response didn't surprise Orianna. Kelos certainly seemed to enjoy "Cally time" as a child, and while he was growing up, Ori had gotten the impression her little brother was trying just a little too hard. "Would you like to stay as my little sister then?"

"I...." Kelos hesitated before continuing, "I... don't... know..."

"Is there something you want to do that you feel you need to be a man for?"

"I... love... Fia..."

"And you can't marry her if you're a woman," Ori finished.

"Yes..."

Orianna grinned mischievously. "If I could arrange it so you can still be together with Princess Fia, would you want to stay like this?"

"Yes..."

"Leave it to your big sister!" Orianna proclaimed. "Have you told her about your transformation?"

"I wrote... letters..." Kelos said. "But... no... response..."

"I see," Orianna said. "I shall think of something. For now, I think it's time you woke up from your trance."

1353231111132111211.content:
Upon hearing Ori's command to stir, color slowly began to fade back into Kelos' eyes. When exactly she fully returned was unclear, as she maintained a goofy, tranced smile for a long, long time after. For her, it was like being brought out from the pleasantest of pleasant dreams. A sweet, gentle voice, washing over her, and causing her to melt in submission. It didn't matter what exactly was being asked. Or who exactly was asking it. All that mattered were those few, fleeting moments, where it was like her very soul was being wrapped, and cradled, and made to feel good.

That was, until she realized everything she said, and felt her face slowly redden up, like a teakettle rising to a boil.

“O- Ori!” She swiftly belted: head darting left, right, up and down. “W- what I just told you... I didn't... I was... I was...” Her figure was comically trembling: stuck in her seat, mortified, as if she just muttered the most embarrassing secret in the world. Truthfully, it might've been.

“Shh, shh! It's okay, Little Sister, really!” The older royal reassured: leaning in closer, and placing a hand on the other's shoulder. Silently, she was cursing how she didn't do anything to soften the the awakening. “We were just having a nice heart to heart chat, weren't we~?” She asked, playing dumb.

The raven-haired girl pursed her lips. Was that right? The further away from the magic of the potion, the harder it seemingly was to comprehend she was under the magic of the potion, and well, her very important and lovely Big Sister wouldn't lie, would she? “I- I guess?” She hesitantly stuttered. Maybe... Maybe she just let some things slip... accidentally. Being in this room... Being around Ori... It always made her drop so much of her guard...

Before very suddenly, her eyes shot fully opening, and she began to stiffly speak. “You had me under hypnosis, and made me confess that I prefer being a princess.” And then relaxed.

...And then swiftly tensed up. “WHAT?!” She barked in complete confusion: jumping to her feet.

Ori's mouth hung open, and then she remembered something from merely a few minutes ago: 'Kelos, you will tell me the truth to everything I ask.' Oh dear... it seemed she accidentally placed a trigger in her Little Sister! She was feeling almost as embarrassed as Kelos was at her confession! “Well. Um. I guess that... did... sort of happen...” Her finger scratched at the side of her cheek, as she held back a cringe.

“Ori, you're unbelievable!” Kelos belted: shooting forward, and looking as incensed as her cutely feminine frame allowed her to look.

“Please, Little Sister, calm down!” The redhead was doing her best to damage control: waving her arms back in a defensive manner, while having to stumble back. “I just thought you needed an opportunity to let it all out... Can you blame me?”

“Yes!” Her 'Little Sister' shouted: inching herself up closer in a frazzled aggression. It appeared she had no problem telling the truth to this question.

“Ah. Okay. Perhaps.” Her sibling stuttered: literally and figuratively being pushed up against the wall. “But was it really that bad?”

Which caused Kelos to then promptly freeze up again: arms dropping to her side. “No, actually. I quite enjoyed the loss of control, and the thrill of you having power over me. The risk and perceived danger is what drove me to drink the potion in the first place. Having no particular knowledge of what it would do was exciting.”

…

The silence occupied that moment was deafening.

...Until Ori broke it. “Well, that's a bit on the nose, Little Sister, but if you like, we can maybe try some more hypnosis! Or possibly some magic artifacts I so happen to have! We can make a day of it with you experimenting!” She half-cheekily smiled: trying her hardest to lighten the mood.

Kelos, however, didn't take it so well: promptly turning on her heels, and stomping as loudly as the delicate footwear allowed.

*SLAM*

Came the sound of Ori's door, as the younger princess promptly exited the room.

This caused Orianna to wilt somewhat. “Oh dear... Well that could've gone a tad better.”

Surely there must be a way to repair their new sisterly relationship! Ori poured herself a cup of tea, then walked over to her writing desk and sat down. She took a sip and placed the cup down. "Perhaps I could drink the same potion?" she thought. "Though I don't suppose Kelos would be willing to do to me what she objects to me doing to her." She took another sip of tea and continued to think. Something Kelos had said during their last session jumped to the front of her mind. "Princess Fia! Kelos hasn't heard from her since the transformation!" She pulled out some paper and a quill. "Now who in Treaven owes me a little favor..." She dipped the tip of the quill in some ink. "Ah yes, the finance minister's wife." She then began to compose her letter.

Your dear friend,

Each time they'd cross one another in the halls, Kelos would simply swish on by, and offer nothing but a perturbed 'hmph!' Orianna stared at the letter in disbelief. Surely she had misread it. She again read the letter from Princess Fia. She had most definitely not misread it, nor misinterpreted it. Her husband to be was in truth a revolutionary! One who fully intended to usurp the throne of Traevan for his own gain. If there was any usurping to do it would be her who did it! She raced out of her room with the letter. It was still morning, so her sister would likely be taking part in sword training, which their father had so boorishly insisted she still participate in. The elder princess rushed down to the training arena.

Kelos stepped to the side, deftly avoiding the lunge from Jax. She then whipped her foil around and delivered a quick strike to his chest.

She had her hair back in a pony tail, and was wearing what looked to be a feminine take on the standard padded training armor. While it offered protection, the way it hung on Kelos' hips left no doubt she was currently female.

“Visit Fia?...” Kelos parroted: assuredness of what she needed to do beginning to wane.

Orianna's lips turned upward. “That's right.” She said: slithering closer to her cute little sister, and snaking her arms around her. “Truth be told, I was going to need to make an excursion to Traeven to finalize the arrangements anyway, so it should be perfect! You'll attend as my very special Maid of Honor!” Eyeing the younger girl's current attire with minor annoyance, she made a mental note that Kelos would not be traveling with any clothing that resembled pants. Skirts and dresses only!

The raven-haired princess's brow furrowed after a moment: moving to point a finger at her sibling. “Even if I were to have forgiven you for...” A pause, as a blush filtered onto her features: possibly betraying some of her more overt feelings. “Hypnotizing me, do you understand the potential danger you'd be putting ourselves into? We'd be entering right into the middle of a political coup!”

The other girl was swift to counter. “A political coup where your favored Fia is at risk! Is it not the duty of a dashing prince to come to her rescue~?”

Kelos took the tease with an indignant pout. “Right now, I'm a princess.”

Ori couldn't help but feel a fluttering in her heart. “Oh, yes. Of course dear. The prettiest princess in the land, might I add! Next to me, anyway. But well, one princess coming to the aid of another makes for a fine tale in its own right, does it not?”

Her counterpart sighed.”Ugh, fine. You win, Ori. I'll hold my tongue to Mother and Father, and come with you.” This was probably a terrible mistake.

We shan't want to put Fia in danger!” Though if she were being honest, the idea of getting to spend a few days together again with her wonderful and precious 'Cally' seemed equally as important. She'd make sure to bring a portable alchemy set with her, too! Kelos was a week behind on practice, and it wouldn't do to allow her to keep slacking!

More and more thoughts of this caliber brewed, and as strange as it may sound, worries over the man she was supposed to marry weren't holding as much sway in her head. Maybe that was a form of denial in its own right, but for the moment, she was just glad Kelos wasn't giving her the cold shoulder.

"We can't just go alone," Kelos insisted. She turned to Jax. "Gather your best men to escort us to Traeven."

"At once, Princess!" Jax said. He rushed off to gather his men.

"I'm not sure showing up unannounced at Traeven with an army is the best idea at these delicate times," Orianna commented.

"I'd hardly call a reasonable number of guards an army," Kelos replied. "I can handle myself, but Ori, you aren't a trained swordswoman like I am. If we get separated, I can't protect you."

"Oh I quite agree some protection is reasonable, but I don't want it to seem we've come to take a side and set off this coup we're trying to stop," the elder princess explained. "Perhaps if there were some way to hide the fact they're guards. Some sort of disguise."

"We could replace the driver with a guard," Kelos suggested.

I'm sure Jax and his soldiers will make excellent bridesmaids. I've even thought of the perfect excuse, I will ask your dear Fia to be a bridesmaid too. Wouldn't that be just lovely?"

A sweatdrop formed on the back on 'Jess's' head. “Ah. Nothing, your majesties. My apologies for the interruption.” Evidently, she was currently going under a new, temporary code-name.

At least, she hoped it would be temporary...

“We're all so pretty~!” A voice to the side giggled. A blonde girl, dressed in a cream-colored outfit, with a look on her space that spoke of there likely being more air between her ears than brains: swishing, and turning, and seemingly having a grand time throughout all this.

Orianna offered a small smile. “I very much agree, Lieutenant-”

“Melody!” 'Melody' interrupted. “Though can it just be 'Melody'?...” She asked, while twirling a tress of her hair. “Lieutenant sounds really uncute!” Melody had the (mis)fortune(?) of believing the dose to transform was supposed to be two bottles, and as such, she ended up the most developed out of the group... For our current mission, it's our duty to stay undercover, and act as my sister's band of supportive and endearing bridesmaids.”

"Not only has she turned your son into a woman, and somehow convinced him to stay like that, but she has turned three of our finest defenders of the throne into women as well! She must be stopped! King Reginald sighed. "I do not believe my daughter has plans to..." He paused for a moment. The thought of her putting the potion in the wine at her wedding seemed almost plausible. "It's unlikely she'd go that far, and if she did, Xarlet is more than capable of fixing the situation. But if it will ease your concerns, Minister, I will talk to her."

"Thank you, your Majesty," Minister Benoit replied. "If we know the Princess' plans, it will greatly ease the concerns of the court." He excused himself, leaving the king to confront his daughter.

His popularity with the lower nobility and the clergy meant he was difficult to simply dismiss, a status he used to speak his mind freely. He knocked on the door as he arrived.

Reginald stepped into the room and looked at the new bridesmaids. "I need to speak to your sister."

Jess and Sandra tried to keep a blank expression as they watched the elder princess effortlessly lie to her father.

"I don't think I want to change back," Melody blurted out. "Being a girl is great!" She happily twisted her hips from side to side, causing her dress to swish back and forth. "You should try it too, your Majesty!"

After all, Kelos has not once objected, and look how happy Melody is. I think spending some time as 'Queen Regina' will help you experience a new perspective that will help you become an even greater king than you already are."

135323111113211121131122132.content:
It took a moment for the gears in the king's head to register what was being suggested to him, but when they did, it caused a red bluster to appear on his face that hadn't shown since all those years back when he first heard about Kelos' 'Cally-time.' “R- ridiculous!” Reginald blustered in a stuttering, airy-gasp, as he pushed away the drink the princess offered. “How could it make me a better king, when it'd make me- when it would make me a queen?!”

His highness scanned the room, eyeing the ensemble of absolutely beautiful young women- each of which could have been plucked straight from a fairy-tale. That's when the reality hit however of how four-fifths of them used to be men! “Orianna.” He used her full name. “I can see now that this little game of yours has gone far enough! It's utterly childish! I order you to hand over all these potions, and turn everyone- turn everything back to normal at once!”

“Aww, but I don't wanna be a boy...” Melody whined this, before Sandra jabbed her in the shoulder. “Don't talk back to the king, you bimbo.” She hissed in a quiet scolding. “Besides, you wouldn't be a 'boy,' you'd be a 'man.'”

Back to being boy or man, Kelos' heart couldn't help but skip a beat at the insinuation. “Ah, but Father...” She didn't know what to say: only raising up a small, gentle hand in protest. “I'm not sure if I want to go back.” A beat. “Yet.”

Knowing how just the phrasing of that could prove a problem, Ori took that opportunity to hip-bump Kelos aside. “Aha, what my precious little sister means is she can't go back yet! None of these girls can. They've all signed up to be bridesmaids at my wedding!”

Reginald just scowled at that: crossing his arms. “And when is that happening, exactly? You certainly seem to be taking your time with it.”

The redhead gave a strained grin. “Ah! Father, I'm glad you asked! I, and these lovely young ladies here.” She gestured with a wave. “Are planning a trip to Traevan right now! To sort out the final plans with the Duke. If you delay things by making them take on... 'alternate forms,' I'd need to assemble a whole new party! The wait could harm our relationship with the other kingdom! You see...”

Already the king was fingering his brow. His daughter- his daughter who wasn't ever previously a son (to his knowledge!), just kept prattling, and prattling after this, to the point it was giving him a headache. “Enough!” He bellowed: approaching the royal with a stern finger pointed. “You and your 'sister' are both on thin ice, you hear me? I don't want anymore dilly-dallying! Sort out whatever it is in Traevan, but I want you in a white wedding gown post-haste!” At this, he swiveled to exit the room. “And I'm serious about that blasted feminizing potion! I'll the guards in here by the end of the hour to collect every last vial of it up!”

Slam!

There was a deafening silence, as the door was shuttered. A good beat held, with no one saying anything, until Jess let out a long held breath. “I don't even think he noticed who I am...” A pause. “I'm somewhat glad.”

“Aww, I wanted to meet Queen Regina. I bet she'd be real pretty!” Melody pouted.

“Well... we might still be able to pull that off...” Orianna's lips pursed, as she fingered her chin. “Though would she look better more as 'cute,' rather than 'pretty?'”

“Big sister?” Kelos piped in with a curious look on her face.

“Little sister! It's come to my attention that you've become quite lax in your alchemy lessons! Before we head off to Traevan, I'm going to need to enlist your help in brewing a very, very special potion!”

"Xarlot will have him back to normal in a matter of minutes."

It was incredible how quickly Ori could work when she was focused on something she was passionate about. Kelos too was becoming a surprisingly quick learner, as she kept up with most of her sister's beats. A dab of Cottontail Fluff here, an ounce of Youthful Peeps there, and soon enough the duo had themselves a downright electrifying potion that'd take 'years' of burden off any man's shoulders! ...Even if they might not be a man afterwards.

And it came at a perfectly poignant time, too, as a small cavalcade of half a dozen guards soon marched themselves into Orianna's room without asking permission.

“Our apologies for the intrusion princesses, but we're here on His Highness's orders to...” This was apparently the leader of the troop, who was pulling out a scroll. “'Do away with those blasted pink drinks.'” He shuttered the paper, and glanced around, noticing the slightly disarray state of the area. “Have a bit of a party, M'ladies?”

Castle Grovan was a rather large estate, and those assigned to royalty like the king weren't necessarily totally involved of the goings on of others. Of course, Prince Kelos' transformation into a princess had spread quite rapidly through the rumor mill, but the exact specifics of how, why, and all of that hadn't simply become second-hand knowledge. Let along the desire to turn a gaggle of willing soldiers into bridesmaids for an upcoming scheme.

Because of this, already gears were spinning in motion within the redhead's mind. “Something like that! My apologies men- I do hope my father didn't overreact by sending you all here! Kelos and I had a get together with a few girls, and were trying a few specialty drinks! Our lovely king decided to spare a moment of his time and join us, but it seems the brew wasn't to his taste!”

“Is it alcoholic?” One of the men asked.

“That would figure. His Highness is a bit of a lightweight.” Another chimed in.

“Shh.” Came a third.

“Either way, our party is well over at this point. Feel free to do with the drinks however you wish.” Ori motioned for the corner with which they were kept. Several dozen of them in vials, all lined up and pristine.

“Looks like they're made for shots.” One of the soldiers commented, as each of them took several of the corked bottles by hand.

“Apologies for any rowdiness, Princesses. My men are apparently very ready to retire for the night.” The lieutenant of the squad eyed them with a serious glare. “We'll take these, and be on our way.”

“Feel free to drink them!” Kelos practically shouted: eyes widening at how quick and eager the words came out. She utterly surprised herself, to the point of where it made very confused inside.

The men were already heading out however, but rabble of 'beer is beer,' and 'the guys in the barracks should get a kick from these,' could be heard.

As the room cleared, there was a brief silence, as a fiery blush eeked its way up, and consumed Kelos' faces.

It took all the royal decorum in Ori to not find herself rolling on the floor and laughing in that moment: instead just settling for a chirping giggle, as she placed a hand on Kelos' shoulder. “Points for eagerness, Little Sister! Though I might suggest something more subtle when we go for Father.”

Kelos' heart was thumping, as she put a hand to her chest. “I'm... not sure what came over me, Big Sister.”

“You and I both like pretty things, Little Sister, and we want to put more prettiness into the world. I think it's quite self-explanatory!” Ori assured, as she reached over to the potion they concocted: electric blue, and practically charged with energy. “Though our next target is going to be both pretty, and cute!”

"As well as pretty irate at what will soon happen to those guards," Kelos observed.

"In this case, it's his own fault for issuing vague orders," Orianna replied.

"Yes, but if father is angry with us, it will certainly make it more difficult to convince him to drink the potion," Kelos said as she looked at the blue liquid her sister was holding.

"Then we must not waste any time, little sister. We must come up with a plan." In truth, Orianna already had several ideas, but thought including Kelos in planning would strengthen their sisterly bond, making it all the less likely she would even consider becoming a man again.

"We need Father to trust us," Kelos said. "It's likely the guards have yet to drink the potions they took. Perhaps we should inform father that they seem intent on drinking them?" She then lowered her voice to a near whisper. "Also, it will give us an excuse to see the results of their party."

"What a wonderful idea," Orianna replied. "I will also tell father I made this potion as an apology for my actions, that it will restore his youthful energy."

Kelos giggled at this. "It will indeed do so." She then paused. "Although, would it not be best if we left the potion for father to drink after we have already left? Though I would like to see the results right away."

"I believe you may be disappointed if you want to see immediate results."

"What do you mean?" the younger princess asked.

"Well, I did say this was a very, very special potion," Orianna replied, with a soft, confident smile. "The first night it will indeed grant him more energy. Why, I'm sure father will spend the night exploring all sorts of pleasures with mother. The second night, however..."

"It has a delayed effect?" Disappointment was visible on Kelos' face. This didn't last, as it was soon replaced my a mischievous grin. "Ori, I just had an idea! You give father the potion, and ask him to come with us to Traeven. He'll transform along the way, and we can say she's our cousin who will be the flower girl!"

"How absolutely devious," Orianna said approvingly. "Though we must hurry if we are to convince father we are attempting to stop the guards from drinking the potions."

With that the two princesses hurried to their father's chambers. "Father, it's me, I believe we have an urgent matter!" Kelos called out as she pounded on the door as they arrived.

"What do you want now, Kelos?" Reginald asked as he opened the door. He was clearly annoyed at this intrusion.

"We believe your instructions to the guards you sent to confiscate my potions were unclear," Orianna added.

"Unclear? I was quite specific when I ordered them to dispose..." Reginald's face turned white as he realized his mistake in wording.

"They seemed to believe they were alcohol," Kelos added. "Father, I do believe they intend to drink them."

"Blasted fools!" Reginald shouted as he rushed past his daughters in the direction of the guard barracks. Kelos raced after him, able to keep up despite her heels. Orianna sighed, knowing she couldn't keep pace, before turning to follow at a walk.
