1353231111132111211311221321112.content:
A lot was buzzing through Kelos' mind as all these events occurred. She'd been dealing with new feelings, new sensations, and new ideas that were difficult for her to understand in such a short time frame. However, it was as if the universe itself aligned, as she and her father rushed into the barracks that early evening.

Some had already transformed. Wide-eyed, innocent looks of confusion on their features, as they found themselves draped in the over-sized clothes and attire that were ill fitting for their new, soft curves. Others were mid-way into the process, with Kelos getting to see first-hand the rough muscle, and chiseled strength, morph into figures much daintier. Much softer. Much prettier.

There were shrieks. There were cries. There were even a few coos. But by the good graces of whatever higher power looked over Grovan, every bottle of that wonderful pink elixir had found itself passing through the lips of the now former men occupying this station. Reginald of course had groans, and curses of exasperation, as he, like a ruler, tried to bring order to the bevy of new female subjects that were under his charge.

Kelos though stood back watching all of this. Playing the role of a more passive observer, as her heart couldn't help but thud. Thud. And thud. As a blush couldn't help but burn. Burn. And burn across her cheeks. Every moment of this... girlifying seared itself into her vision. Into her mind. Into her very being.

It was somewhere between her father yelling at a very flustered brunette to 'put a shirt on,' and the Lieutenant of the keep doing her best to stutter out a status report, that the raven-haired princess felt a hand gently land on her shoulder.

“A marked improvement, wouldn't you say, Little Sister~?” Ori rhetorically asked, with a wink, and a hushed whisper.

Her tone might've been playful, but something in Kelos very much 'clicked' deep down, as she watched her sister strut forward: carrying a supply of blouses, and various feminine linens, that she acquired on her slower meander over. Kelos was the one responsible for suggesting the soldiers drink the potion. Kelos was the one responsible for all this... girlifying.

And rather than feel shame, or be disturbed, the only thing crossing her thoughts was wondering just how each of these new lovely ladies were going to look in dresses and skirts!

-_-_-_-_-_-_-

“By the Maker...” Reginald sat slumped in his throne, with the past few hours having been utterly exhausting for the king.

“It's... quite unfortunate Xarlat has already left for his Wizard's Conference.” Kelos said through slightly stuttered words, and a shifty eye.

“Thankfully the maid quarters has plenty of room to house the new girls until he comes back!” Ori clapped her hands, as she attempted to look on the 'bright' side of things.

“I need a vacation...” Reginald barely even registered his two daughters by his side, as he leaned his head back to quell the migraine that was surely brewing.

That's when a Cheshire grin couldn't help but form on Orianna's face. “Father, I was actually wondering about that! Since you seem so adamant about me sorting out my engagement, how about you attend our trip to Traeven? It'd get you out of the castle for a few days!”

The king's hand went to his beard, as he fingered through it in thought. “That... might just do. If nothing else I could see that pompous oaf Arthras, and gloat over the sorry state of his land compared to Grovan.” His shoulders however gave a tired slump. “To be honest though, I'm not quite sure if I'm in the state to travel, since I assume you're heading out tomorrow?” His words were pointed, as if to say 'no dillydallying.'

Kelos looked to Orianna just then, who proceeded to pull an electric blue vial from behind her back. “Then perhaps I could interest you in this, Father?”

“...And what is that?” The king asked, dubiously.

“It'll help bring back your youthful energy!” Kelos parroted: intervening.

“I and my Little Sister conjured it up as an apology for any minor... trouble that we might've caused.” A pause, as she slunk up close to his highness. “It'll do you wonders, I assure!”

A dower look appeared on the older man's face. “Do you really expect me to drink a potion, after all the trouble they've caused today?”

“What if I told you Mother especially would love it~?” Orianna teased with an upturned brow.

That's all it took for the ruler to chug it down in a single swig.

"Ori, are all these dresses really necessary?" Kelos asked. "It seems nearly every dress I own is being loaded in that carriage."

"Oh, dear sister, you still have much to learn to become a proper princess. Why, what ever would you do if some buffoon spilled a drink on your dress?" the elder princess replied, feigning shock.

"It would need a lot of buffoons spilling drinks on me for that many dresses to be necessary."

"Or simply a prolific one," Orianna replied.

At that Kelos' eyes subconsciously turned towards Melody, who had just dropped one of her own trunks full of dresses after insisting she load her luggage personally. The former prince turned princess watched as Sandra quickly raced over to help her friend. "I suppose you do have a point. Still, we will need an entire extra carriage just to carry our clothes!"

"Then you shall have it!" a man's voice bellowed from behind.

Kelos and Orianna turned to see their father walking up to the carriages. "Good morning father," they said in uniform.

"Good? No, it is a glorious morning!" Reginald took a deep breath. "After spending the night with my wife, the most beautiful woman in all the lands, I will be taking a trip with my two lovely daughters!" He approached them. "Orianna, I owe you an apology. The potion you crafted was simply marvelous, no, miraculous! I doubted the intentions of my own daughter because of a minister with delusions of grandeur. I will never doubt your words again, and you may make all the potions you see fit." He then turned to Kelos. "I owe you an apology as well. I have spent my life imposing my vision of what you should be upon you, rather than letting you become your own person. Whether you wish to remain a woman, or change back into a man, you will have my full support from now on."

The two princesses glanced at each other nervously. "My, father, you certainly sound much happier this morning," Orianna said.

"Of course," Reginald replied. "Last night was amazing and even though your mother and I did not sleep for even an instant, I feel like I'm a young man who had a full night's sleep!. Tell me, how long will this potion of yours last?"

"It should leave you feeling youthful for some time," Orianna replied. "How long is up to the quality of the ingredients I used."

"We used top quality," Kelos added. Seeing her father's sudden change in heart left her feeling somewhat guilty about the changes she knew awaited him later today.

"As I would expect from my lovely and brilliant daughters." He then looked to the carriages which still had much to load. "Now then, I shall show these lollygagging workers how to load a carriage." With that, he bounded forward, grabbed a massive create, lifting it effortlessly "The big ones go on the bottom, not those little ones!"

"Ori?"

"You don't need to say more, father's sudden acceptance is not what I expected. I fear we may have made a mistake."

"Can it be stopped?" Kelos asked.

"Not without removing the youthful vigor which had father so energized," Orianna said. "Plus, I do not think I could make it in time."

"Perhaps we should just tell father now?"

"I suppose we could, but after all he said, I wouldn't want to crush his new view of us. We may find something we could blame for his upcoming transformation on the trip and deny any connection. I will leave it to you to decide."

135323111113211121131122132111211.content:
The trip up to Traeven was supposed to be fun! Key words being, supposed to be. Ori and Kelos tittering among themselves, as they watched their 'father' transform into something so much cuter, and so much prettier than the rude brute he was acting like.

Instead, however, it all got turned on its head: hours spent sitting in a carriage, brooding, and fidgeting, with questions of what to do about the situation. Right now, the two siblings' currently (still) older father was sitting amicably with the group, as they broke for an early evening camp.

“My goodness! So you've known Melody for how long, Sandra?”

He was rapt with attention, as the blonde, Melody, wrapped her arms around Sandra, and smothered the brunette in a suffocating, 'boobs to the face' hug. “Like, Sandy is my bestest, best friend since forever!”

“Mmph! Mmph! You are not calling me Sandy!” 'Sandy' protested in a deep bluster.

Meanwhile, Jess, who technically wasn't currently a 'Captain,' still took the reigns at handling the logistics of travel. “We should reach Traeven within the next day or so, Princess.” She assured, marching (as best as she could in heels and a skirt) to the adjacent tree stump where Kelos stayed. In her hands, she carried with her a piping hot cup of tea: perfect for a chilly night.

This snapped Kelos out of her thoughts, as she turned to her fellow bridesmaid, and offered a smile. “Ah, thank you Jess!” But these facts, and the chill, were the furthest concern on her mind.

“Careful. Melody brewed that. She insisted. Something about how she wanted to 'get good in the kitchen' now that she's a girl.” Jess gave a playful warning at that. The blonde stumbled into a tea shop during their shopping trip earlier, and had just been wowed.

Kelos offered a chipper smile at that. A smile that was soon drowned out by worry. “Jess... May I ask you something?”

The former captain didn't seem surprised. Her princess had been distant all day, and as a knight, it was her duty to offer her assurance. “Of course, your highness. Is something bothering you?”

“If, perhaps, hypothetically... Ori and I had transformed you into your current state without asking... How bothered would you be?” Even just asking that was making the young royal grimace: speaking her way through a strained voice.

That made the raven-haired guard take pause to think. “Well... It is my task as a knight to serve, Milady. While it would be... surprising, my time so far as 'Jess' hasn't been particularly bad.” Her thoughts turned to earlier. To being with Melody and Sandra. It was oddly... relaxing. No need to put on a tough bravado in front of the others in the castle. They were just girls out on the town... Plus, Melody's optimism was strangely infectious. The whole affair was certainly more memorable than an average night out on the tavern.

Kelos gave a small sigh of relief at this, as her words turned more hopeful. “And what if also, instead of just turning you into a a girl, we turned you into an eight year old as well?”

...

“...Princess?” Jess deadpanned.

“Aiiieeeeee~!”

Their words were interrupted by a high-pitched scream into the night. The scream not of a man. Not of an adult, but of a child. A child who suddenly, in practically a poof, materialized in a pile of loose clothing, where once Reginald fit so snugly.

“Oh dear...” Kelos palmed her face.

“W- wha- what happened?” Came the cry of a new little girl: surprisingly, she had red hair, just like Orianna. It was always assumed to be a trait from her mother's side, but apparently maybe something was in Reginald's blood, too. Though unlike Ori, the king's face was absolutely dotted with freckles. As if she had a permanent blush marring her features.

“I suppose it's now or never.” Kelos sighed, standing up. If anything, this was a bit late. Confessing after her father got transformed would probably not be too endearing.

But then a twist of fate came into play.

“Oh nooooo! Like, did I screw up the tea?” Gasped the vapid and innocent voice of Melody, as a potential out came into play. “Like, nobody drink it, and stuff!”

Kelos' mouth hung slightly agape. Should she roll with it?

1353231111132111211311221321112111.content:
"No, it wasn't you Melody!" Kelos insisted. She then turned to the little girl who was formerly the king. "Father, I did this! I'm sorry, Ori was upset because you ordered her potions confiscated and you wouldn't accept me as a woman, so I thought if we transformed you into a little girl it would get even!" Tears were forming as she confessed to her scheme.

"Kelos..." Reginald said, seemingly angry. However, as a few moments passed without a word between them, a smile formed on her face. "I see what you're trying to do here. Really, back when you were a man, you would have thrown your subordinates to the wolves to get ahead. Now though, you're trying to take the blame for them. Becoming a princess has made you a better leader, my daughter."

Kelos looked shocked. The idea of her father not even believing she was responsible had never even crossed her mind. "B-But father, I'm not trying to take the blame, I'm really responsible! I mean how could even Melody mess up tea so badly that it could transform you? That would require a magic potion..."

Reginald simply shook her head and cut Kelos off. "Tell me, if you don't put any magic into a potion what do you end up with?"

"Tea," Kelos replied.

"Exactly. So if you can make tea while trying to craft a potion, you can also make a potion while crafting tea." Reginald explained.

"Princess, I totally appreciate it and all, but this was so my mistake," Melody insisted.

"But I really..."

"Do not worry, Kelos," Reginald interrupted. "I'm well aware that Melody did not do this deliberately, and she was an idiot even before being transformed. Her punishment will be fair." the little girl who was once king looked at Melody. "As punishment, I forbid you from changing back into a man!"

"Y-You mean I can stay like this forever?!" the former knight asked, eyes wide in surprise.

"Yes."

"Sandy! The king said I can stay like this!" Melody shouted in joy as she ran up to her friend and practically tackled her.

"Father, I..." Kelos began.

Reginald held up a hand. "Let's leave this as it is. I choose to believe this version of events. Besides, even the other version, what I said about you remains true. Any anger I might have pales before the pride I have of my daughter trying to protect her sister." She then held out her arms, the oversized royal robes hung off loosely. "In any event, I'll need some new clothes. Oh and a name. I can't have you calling me father and revealing who I am. Regina is too obvious and rejected."

"Oh my, Father?! Is that you? Whatever happened?" Orianna asked as she walked up on the scene.

"Melody accidentally brewed a potion," Reginald said.

"My how terrible!" Orianna said with feigned shock.

"Ori," Kelos said sternly.

"I need some new clothes. I'm sure you'll just so happen to have something suitable for a girl my age, correct?" Reginald said.

"Err, why yes, I just might. After all, once must be prepared for any eventuality," Orianna replied. She hurried off and retrieved a dress.

"What do you think of the name Linette?" Reginald asked.

"I like it," Kelos replied.

Orianna soon returned holding two dresses. "Father, I found these two, but I'm not sure which one is better." She held up a white dress with decorated with pink lace trim, and a pink ribbon around the waist which then formed a large bow on the back. In her other hand was a purple dress, lacking the frilled trim, it made up for it by how billowy the skirt was.

"Not father, call me Linette until we return to Grovan and fix this. Also I prefer..." Linette stopped. "I need to speak more like someone my apparent age. I like the one with the pink bow, it's so cute!" The former king smiled smugly, satisfied with that performance.

"Excellent choice, sweetie," Orianna said. She handed the dress to the former king. "Let Auntie Kelos know if you need help putting it on."

"I'll be okay, Aunt Ori," Linette replied. She then shuffled over to the carriage to get dressed.

"She seems to be taking this better than I expected," Orianna said.

Through this though, Kelos managed to break away from the chaos. “Have you happened to see Princess Fia, Sir Duke? Is she well?”

The high tower containing Marlin's lab, was largely isolated from the rest of the palace. Both by design, and by coincidence. The magician's reputation was fiery, and fearsome, and nobody wanted to be risk offending him, nor risking his influence with the king.

The times where an explosion would rock that tower to it's roots, or when billowing clouds of unnatural colours and odours would escape meant, that few visited the him, and fewer wanted to visit him. Even when he wandered the corridors and passages of the rest of the palace, he had a distant look to his eyes, and frequently spoke to himself. The chambermaids and cooks recognised the herbs he collected from the forest when they were poisonous. The guards heard the deafening roar of his magic, and upon investigation, would find mass destruction, or worse left behind.

Despite his reputation, and abilities, the King considered him kindly and wise. Both men were fiercely loyal to each other. The gossip around the court told one particular story frequently, especially as it was so well witnessed.

The day one of the sculllery boys, whose normal work left them buried in the kitchen scrubbing pots and pans. Little Jack was waiting to surprise his love, one of the palace maids. In his exuberance, he leapt out from behind one of the suits of armours, and groped his true love. His hands roaming her body, squeezing her breasts, and sliding between her legs.

The shriek of outrage drew the guards, and as his true love turned around.... Well, it turned out to be Princess Fia, who landed a resounding slap on his startled face, and stuttering apology. When Fia drew a knife to defend herself, her honour, Jack twisted the knife from her hand and fled.

However, within a week, Fia had found a new Lady in Waiting, a youngish girl, though well-developed for her age. Initially she had a reputation for endless sobbing, and mournful looks. Even her clothes seemed to set her on edge, some dismissed it as the fickle emotions of youth. Jasmine however, positively flinched and cowered at the shuffling sound of the wizard's feet on the uneven stone floor of the castle. Not that rare a reaction, but there was a hint in her eyes, and from a certain angle, and in some lights, the vaguest hint of a scullery boy could be made out.

- - - - -

In Marlin's lab the glassware was clinking and chiming, as the wizard worked on a new infusion. It was a joyous opportunity, a chance to celebrate the upcoming meeting of Princess Fia and her suitor, Prince Kelos. The hope was this would secure the alliance between the two powers, and bring peace and prosperity.

Putting down the beaker, he went over to the cauldron, the contents brewed and stewed with a heavy slow bubbling certainty. Cautiously sniffing the brew, he nodded approvingly. Soon the perfection potion would be ready, a chance to further cement their love, and bring an abiding peace.

With a toast, both Fia and Kelos would take the potion, and their imperfections and past wounds be wiped away. Skin refreshed, features tweaked and improved. Not so much as to destroy their original proportions, but just to improve their pleasing symmetry.

Raising one hand in an imaginary toast to the happy couple, he failed to spot when the sleeve caught one of the test-tubes on the nearby table. Only when it shattered on the floor did he notice. A swirling cloud of emerald green rising, as the contents evaporated. It danced in the air, at moments moving against the air. Sparkles lighting it from within. Even Marlin wasn't quick enough, before it darted, like an insect and rose towards his face, his nostrils before sinking deep into his lungs.

Marlin fell to his knees, coughs racking his body. Each one scratchy, each one rising in pitch. Marlin's whole body rattled and rocked with each cough, as if trying to break his spine. He tried to talk, to mouth an incantation. He knew the potion he'd knocked over, knew it's consequences. Dread filled his heart, as he felt his clothes becoming baggier on his body, his hands retreating up his sleeves. He felt what few muscles he had winnowed away to softer, rounder flesh.

Kneeling on hands and knees, he coughed as if he were throwing up his lungs, and then stopped. The changes complete, finally able to breathe easily once more, he rocked back onto his heels. He felt his bum press against his feet, both wider and plusher than before. Marlin knew what this extra padding meant, he felt also the shifting weight on his chest. His spine was tickled by a long mane of hair, from his previously rather sparsely covered head. Dreading the discovery and the uncertainty, he explored his face. His hands discovering the extra plush lips, fixed in a permanent pout, not wide, but inviting, a mouth made for one thing, made for teasing and relieving men's aches and needs. Even the hand doing the exploring was slender and fine, long enough to encircle a man... where it matters most.
